description:
I got in line at 450pm and doors open at 5pm. I was the 16th person on the waitlist after everyone was seated. At roughly 6pm I was seated on a shared table with another party of two.

Overall I would love to doc a star for the wait but it's not their fault they are so popular.

I ordered the Hakata DX, Chicken Paitan DX, Fried peppers, and Marukuku Bites. Honestly I could have done without the fried peppers not a star item on the menu.
author: Jenny N.

description:
!!!! Probably the BEST ramen place in SF (I guess l haven't tried all of it but I've tried most of the really popular places and hands down marufuku is the winner) 

The line is always long but that's why the yelp waitlist exists (you're on yelp rn! Get on it after this review!) and there's a bunch of cute stores nearby to check out while you wait. 

The service is prompt and attentive. Sometimes they combine your party with other parties if both groups are small so you might even make new friends. Or sit in close proximity and ignore each other as you get fully absorbed in the greatness that is marufuku.

The Hakata deluxe is great; meat was tender, broth was creamy, and egg was cooked to that perfect golden (not light yellow but GOLD). Your stomach will be full, your heart will be happy, and you will be about $20 short (tax and tip included) of your money-- but you'll remember the taste and that's priceless.
author: Carmel M.

description:
Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

Or something like that. All I know is this place's ramen is top class and was well worth the waitlist.

Where do I begin? You're not looking for a dining experience here. You're not looking for excellent service. What are you looking for? Possibly one of the best dang Japanese ramen spots that you can go to. But there's a reason for the ridiculously long wait time. Heads up San Francisco, join the waitlist so you don't have to wait forever to actually grab a table. 

I waited about 1-1 1/2 hrs on the waitlist on a Friday night. You need to be within a 3 mile radius to be on it. After waiting, I ended up sharing a table with another couple. If your party is 2 or lower, you're going to be doing this so don't freak out or anything. 

This places atmosphere was pretty nice- dim lights, Japanese decor, etc. The service was good enough for how busy it was. I was quickly provided their cucumber/mint water and was asked what I wanted to order.

What did I get? The Hakata Tonkotsu medium. The couple next to me kept on saying that the mild broth wasn't nearly as good as the medium. So take that with a bowl of noodles, I mean grain of sand. I would recommend going this route because having too spicy of a broth is going to kill the experience.

Just wow. The broth was rich, had a beautiful pork flavor, was perfectly seasoned, and was well balanced. The noodles were cooked to perfection- they still had a nice bite to them and were a perfect vessel for carrying more of that broth onto my tastebuds. The toppings accompanied the bowl perfectly. The chashu was fantastic and the soft-boiled egg was nice and runny- this is one of the few times where not having a typical soy-sauce, soft-boiled egg was okay. 

With this in mind, I ended up devouring my bowl. I rarely drink most of my broth, but I finished over half of it this time. For anyone reading, I would highly recommend getting extra noodles if you tend to eat a lot! That's pretty much my only gripe, but then again the portion size is perfect for most people that don't enjoy eating themselves into a food coma.... *looks in the mirror*

So in summary, this is probably the best ramen place I've ever been to, and I don't use the word "best" lightly. I'll be back at this place Terminator 2 style. Until then, everyone should check this place out!
author: Nick Y.

description:
I was visiting SF 2 weeks ago and came here for dinner with my gf and her daughter; we had a great experience. Prior to this, I did not understand why my gf had developed an obsession with ramen after her trip to Japan. Now I completely get it, and I'm sold on it!

We began with some bao pork buns, which were fresh and tasty. My gf and her daughter both had hakata tonkosu pork ramens, spicy and mild, respectively. Their ramens were delicious. Fresh, flavorful, and not greasy. I had spicy chicken paitan ramen, which was equally excellent, the combination of flavor and textures was just wonderful. 

I'm not an expert on Japanese cuisine, but my gf is, and we both agree that this was a food highlight of our trip.

If you are not from SF like me, I recommend that you bring your patience. We had to wait nearly 2 hours to get a table. Fortunately, the place is located in a plaza with lots of other stores to see and they have an organized waitlist system. Besides, I found that pretty much everything worth having here in SF, you'll have to wait for. 

Other than that, the ambiance and service were nice, and the prices reasonable. I recommend it here and look forward to returning one day.
author: Renzo I.

description:
From the website: 
Marufuku proudly serves the authentic hakata-style tonkotsu ramen featuring a rich and milky, premium tonkotsu broth cooked for over 20 hours to extract umami flavor, an ultrathin artisanal noodles that match perfect. with the broth, and cha-shu made from specially selected pork. 

Lots of hype for this one...I wonder why? 

PRO TIP - come here during the weekday during lunch before opening to avoid the wait. 

Located inside the Japan town strip mall. Parking is street or structure. Most likely you will have to pay for parking so there is no avoiding it unfortunately (this is SF after all). We arrived about 30 minutes before opening and were second in line. By the time the restaurant was about to open, there was already a long line that formed behind us. Also, your party is only 2, be prepared to share your table with another group if that table is large enough to fit more people.

If you are not lucky enough to make it in with the first wave, the restaurant uses Yelp as a waiting list. Last time my gf wanted to try this place out but the wait list was over 100 people? INSANE! 

Here is what we ordered: 

MARUFUKU BITES 6.50 - Japanese Steamed Buns Filled with Homemade Pork Chasu 
CHICKEN KARAAGE 6.50 - Japanese Style Fried Chicken
HAKATA DELUXE 16.99 - Hakata Style Ramen with Rich Pork Broth Buta Kakuni (Braised Thick Pork Belly), Chashu Pork (Simmered Pork Belly), Seasoned Soft Boiled Egg, Green Onions, Kikurage Mushrooms, Bean Sprouts, Sweet Corn, and Nori Seaweed.

The ramen was the highlight here obviously especially the broth. The richness of the pork broth was very apparent with the first sip. You soon enter pork heaven and with each taste of the broth you realize that your bowl is almost empty. 

Overall it was what I expected in ramen. It was quite delicious but the real question is if I would wait potentially 2+ hours for it, well due to the fact that you can just sign up on the waitlist and shop around the area without actually waiting at the restaurant then I would say that this spot is a place not to miss next time you are in the SF area and craving some ramen!
author: Charlton C.

description:
I really liked the ambiance of this popular ramen spot inside Japan Center. It was dark and serene, almost intimate. 

We'd made reservations via the Yelp app and the wait on Sunday early afternoon was almost 90 minutes (and the Yelp reservation estimate was accurate). 

Service was friendly and efficient and our order came out within minutes.

Chicken karaage ($6.75) was moist and delicious and my little boy's chashu bowl and my tonkatsu deluxe quickly followed.

The tonkatsu deluxe XT had a complex broth and its medium spice level was just right. 

For $18.75 (including extra egg) it was a good value with a generous amount of sliced chashu and a thick slice of pork belly. The pickled ginger added an interesting depth and the molten egg was perfect. I'm glad I ordered an extra egg! 

The chashu rice bowl ($6.50 that included sweet corn and a molten egg) was less impressive: I had a small taste and the ground pork tasted mealy. My little boy said he liked it but his tone lacked enthusiasm.

The unpleasant surprise was the bottle of Hitachino White beer that cost $11.50 for a single bottle (gulp). 

Note to self: Don't order from a splashy photo on the menu.

Another less-than-pleasing note was the staff began sweeping up the dining room floor as we were in the midst of our meal. 

While we were dining past their 3pm close, it was an unsanitary step, especially since the restaurant was still about 40% full. 

Given the overall experience, I'm a little mystified why Marufuku Ramen generates 2 hour waits given the plethora of good ramen spots all around the city and in Japantown. 

Marufuku is good and I'd probably return but between the wait and the other small issues, they're on the list but not yet at the top.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I sincerely do miss the ramen found in Japan, and this place nailed it. 

The Hakata Style Ramen with Rich Pork Broth was sooooo darn good. The porks was so flavorful and thick with all the fatty goodness...just the way they do it in Japan. YUM!!!

I'm glad the bae and my daughter got they own bowl...because a sister did not want to share after tasting that broth. 

This place was packed when we arrived, and there was a long line to get on the waiting list. So that was annoying. 

Was it worth the 2 hour wait??? YES!!! I recommend going on the waiting list on yelp and then driving there on the suggested time frame.
author: Sheila P.

description:
Delicious ramen in Japan Town. This complex is a store house of yummy Japanese treats. I'm glad they have a yelp wait-list now so I was able to go without standing in line for 2 hours.  My friends got the special ramen - they had only a few bowls left and they liked it. They have a vegetarian ramen which is not listed on the menu but it's pretty good. Their Soft boiled egg is nice. 

Pretty good ramen overall - I recommend.
author: Eshita S.

description:
Holy S**T! This is probably the best ramen in the WORLD. 

there is a reason why Marufuku always has long lines EVERYDAY. IT IS WORTH WAITING 30+ minute on each visit. I usually get pork broth ramen or chicken broth with a chicken leg and other side orders. 

I've had takoyaki, karaage, all rice dishes, and haven't had any bad dish yet. (Trust me, I've been here numerous times already...) 

One down side would be the service and the wait, but if you are patient and a true foodie.... you gotta try it.
author: Jina C.

description:
One of the best ramen restaurants I've tried in the U.S.! We ordered pork delux and regular chicken ramen which were both cooked to perfection. I particularly enjoyed the broth that came with the pork ramen - so savory, rich but not greasy at all! Both ramen came with a whole poached eggs where were also cooked perfectly. 

The pork ramen delux also came with a big chunk of pork belly on top of braised pork meat. It was very tasty but I thought it was a little on the leaner side. We also ordered hot sake which only costs $5. Can't wait to return already!!
author: Winnie C.

description:
Tip: Go there early! This place gets really busy and has long lines.

We got on the the waitlist around 5:15pm and didn't get seated (for 4 people) until 6:30 ish. I got the Tonkatsu Ramen. The broth is very tasty and reminds me of the ramen I've had in Japan. 

I've always had good service here. This is one of our favorite places to eat ramen. I just wished the place was bigger to accommodate more customers. Sometimes the wait time is just too long. That is the only reason why I'm giving this place 4 stars.

If you love ramen, you should give this place a try!
author: Suki K.

description:
I love it!  Rich, flavorful and not-too-salty broth hits the spot anytime any day.

There is a good reason why there's a line all the time here and Marufuku deserves the high ratings!

Hakata ramen is the way to go, at $16.99 - it's not exactly your cheap eats.  BUT, it does include as standard a WHOLE soft boiled egg, corn, bamboo, and ginger... where other ramen places would charge extra for.  The tonkotsu broth was milky and light, and not as fatty as other places, which I appreciated greatly.  It is packed with flavor and not-too-salty... my number pet peeve for ramen places.., where they often overcompensate flavor with salt. 

We also opted for some side dishes and they are just as impressive:  the shishito peppers are lightly salted, fresh and simply yum! and The karaage chicken is fried perfectly and lightly breaded.  Again, not too salty which I appreciate so much!  

4 bowls of ramen, 2 appetizers + 1 Japanese beer = $130 put the door.  

At 6pm, I placed my name on the waitlist via Yelp! and my party of 4 was seated at 7:40!  

While the food is really good - I felt that it didn't warrant the hefty price tag for ramen bowls and the 100-mins wait.  Good to try once to feel the hype... can't say i'll be back soon.
author: Winnie W.

description:
The broth is just wow. Both the Chicken Paitan and the Hakata were so flavorful, but not overly heavy and oily. We absolutely loved everything about about the ramen dishes (although I still prefer Mensho's noodles because they're thicker and chewier), and the side of braised pork belly was melt-in-your-mouth heaven.

We came to put our name down 10 minutes after they opened but there were already 26 parties waiting so we had to wait about an hour. It was definitely worth it though!
author: Alice C.

description:
BEST RAMEN I HAVE HAD SO FAR! I've tasted my fair share of ramen in the Bay Area, but Marufuku Ramen takes the title of best ramen I've had by far.

Marufuku Ramen is located in the heart of Japantown inside Japan Center on the 2nd level. Japantown is a pretty touristy area altogether so this place is always packed! Make sure to sign your name and phone number on their computer located by the entrance, so you can be placed on the waitlist. The queue is always very full so be patient. We came here pretty early just before lunch time and the wait was already 1 hour. Though it does help that it's located inside Japan Center so you can go into the shops to pass the time. 

Once we were seated the first thing you notice is how amazing the ambiance and atmosphere of this place is. The design is somewhat vintage Japanese with a modern twist. Just right by the back of the wall, you'll notice the kitchen staff hard at work on the meal that you're about to eat. The place is lightly dimmed, which gives it more of a cozy feel. The decor was pretty stylish as well. Once we got inside the wait staff were quick to acknowledge us and get us going with our meal.

Now onto the food. We ordered the Fried Calamari for appetizer which cost us $8. We thought it was ok. Pretty basic and portion was pretty tiny. Not for the main course and what we came for, the ramen! My friend and I ordered the opposing ramens. Hers, the ever so popular pork belly ramen. As for me, since I've always gone to ramen shops and ordered pork, I decided to give the chicken ramen a try. I've always been very skeptical of chicken in any soup form since they're very quick to dry out the chicken. Each order of the chicken ramen comes with a side of sizzling grilled chicken, all for $18. It was a bargain for the amount of chicken you get! You also get a quarter chicken in the ramen itself.  The grilled chicken was the most finger licking, softest juicest chicken there ever was in my belly! The flavor was amazing and each bite blesses your palette with greatness. The ramen was amazing as well. The chicken broth was out of this world flavorful, and rich. I usually have trouble slurping down all the broth, but this was one was so good, I just couldn't think of leaving any behind! The boiled egg on the other hand, was a little too solid for my liking, but it good enough. 

Marufuku Ramen is a place I will definitely keep coming back to. The prices are great for the quality you are getting. The portions are generous, the taste of the food is absolutely top notch, the ambiance/atmosphere beautiful, and the to top it all off, they have great customer service. If you're ever in town in search of a great ramen place, or simply craving to taste a great bowl of tasty food, stop by and you will not be disappointed. Oh, and also let me know so I can come along!
author: Oliver B.

description:
Wow! The best ramen I've had in a long time and compared to ramen in other cities (San Diego, Denver, Boston). I just had a simple bowl of the tonkatsu and was so impressed! The soup/broth was delicious, I drank it all! The ramen noodles were perfectly soft and the egg was cooked just right. Loved all these flavors together and I added the sweet corn. My friends enjoyed their bowls too.

I was visiting SF and they wanted to try Marafuku! We put our name on the Yelp wait list and we were seated as soon as we arrived. There was a line during our entire dinner (on a Thursday night). It's a very quaint space. Glad we came here!
author: Annie G.

description:
This is my second time back after trying it for the first time about two months ago. Marafuku Ramen is known for the spot to always have a waitlist inside Japantown. Make sure to join the waitlist on YELP before heading there, it saves so much time for your hungry self. I've tried almost all their ramen from the 
*Hakata Paitan Deluxe
*chicken paitan 
* chicken paitan deluxe(includes the chicken leg)
My favorite would definitely be the chicken paitan deluxe because of how tender and flavorful the chicken leg is. The broth is super rich without it being too thick or oily. The service here is great, constantly checking up the customers due to the wait haha. This is my go to spot for ramen in SF.
author: Lisa W.

description:
This place is amazing! First of all the yelp waitlist was super useful (or else you'd have to wait like 2 hours). 

I got the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen. The broth was amazing - not super salty or oily. Personally I like thin noodles in my ramen, and the noodles were cooked just right. 

For appetizer, I highly recommend the fried squid because it's good portion and good price for the quantity. The marufuku bites is also very good.
author: Alice H.

description:
Nothing but love! Wait times are long and it's understandable, this place is legit. Service is fast, friendly, and they handle the crowds well. 

Menu is limited but that's because they specialize in two types of ramen, and excel at it. My boyfriend and I ordered the Chicken Paitan and Hakata Tonkotsu and loved both. His chicken thigh came on a sizzling plate on top of bean sprouts and it was cooked to perfection. I ordered my tonkotsu in spicy and it was AMAZING! Something about their spice is so smooth and mixes well in the ramen. At other places they sort of just dollop the spice on top and it's usually the kind of spicy that hits the back of your throat. Marufuku also uses thin noodles which I'm actually not fond of, but theirs have converted me. Definitely going to be craving this ramen again in the near future.
author: Nicolette E.

description:
Here's the breakdown:

1. The wait is super long. But you have the option to get on the wait-list on yelp mobile. Definitely do that. 

2. The service is meh. It doesn't feel genuine since they are trying to get as many people in and out as possible. They asked us if we would be okay sharing a table with another party of 2. We agreed until we were taken to a booth with a couple sitting on the opposite sides on it. Sharing a table meant sitting at the same booth as a different party. It seemed odd and awkward they would place two different parties together on one booth. It showed they weren't really interested in good customer experience but rather getting people in and out as fast as possible. I wasn't really in the mood to sit side by side with a stranger or have my side uncomfortably touch the other's bag on the booth seat... We said no and waited for a table that wasn't shared. 

3. The food is... overhyped. The ramen was okay. We got the pork ramen but it wasn't as good as I thought it would be. I did have high expectations since the wait was so long though. BUT - The pork buns are delicious though. Definitely get these. If anything, get multiple pork buns and no ramen.

4. The price is reasonable. $12.99 for the basic and $15.99 for the deluxe ramen.

5. The interior is nice. The typically Japanese restaurant feel.

I would only recommend this place for the pork buns. It's only worth it if you get on the wait-list via Yelp mobile. But those pork buns. So good.
author: Shin L.

description:
OMG one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had! 
**Pro-tip: Put your name on the waitlist using Yelp. I put my name in before leaving the house, and it said I'd have a 45 min wait (around 6pm on a Wednesday). So I drove to Japantown, shopped at Daiso, and they called me 10 min before my name came up. I walked right up and checked in, and they sat me within 1 minute!!**

Now onto the food - the 20 hour tonkotsu broth - I am a ramen lover and cannot believe I had not discovered this place sooner!! That rich, delicious, full-flavored broth! And the thin noodles were AMAZING. I ordered the deluxe version which came with TWO soft boiled eggs and kakuni...wow, the kakuni!! Moist, flavorful, perfect balance of fat and lean meat. Delicious! 

The service - incredibly fast and efficient. I ordered as soon as I sat down, and I had the ramen within 5 minutes. When I finished my meal, I asked if they had a dessert menu, which they don't, so I asked where I could get fresh mochi/manju. The server told me Nijiya Market carried fresh mochi daily, so I was able to head over there to get some dessert to-go. Brilliant!

I can't wait to share this place with everyone I know. Love the food, love the Yelp waitlist, love the service! A well-deserved 5 stars!
author: Jaching H.

description:
I'm slowly becoming a ramen noodle slurper.  The primary reason is due to a recent trip to Japan earlier this year.  As such I've been keeping an eye on best places in the City for a bowl of ramen.

Marufuku must be under the radar.  We happened to be in JTown a couple of weeks ago when we noticed a huge line.  My first question was what happened to Sapporo-Ya Ramen that was here?  It's been that long since I've been to this side of the mall.  

No need to wait in a 2-3 hour line.  Decided to come back for lunch last Friday.  We waited around 11:05am for the doors to open at 11:30a.m.  Already an queue but we were part of the first wave.

Hubby & both ordered the Hakata Deluxe for $16.00. I requested mild & hubby requested spicy.  Our ramen bowls came quickly.  The pork tonkatsu soup was delish.  Very thick & flavorful.  We slurped up our noodles and was finished and out the door by 12 noon.

#1 on my very short list of 3 places so far is Mensho, #2 Marufuku and #3 Ippudo.  More ramen to follow down the road.

Yelp tip:  add your name to the wait list via the Yelp app.  Then you can time it.
author: Shirley N.

description:
You gotta this place out! There might be a long wait but when it's located inside the mall and you can get a text telling you to come back and check in when you are about to get a table soon is definitely worth the wait. Go wander around or grab a drink at the bar upstairs. Just make sure to check your position. I went with my group and they removed us from the list without any notice on accident. Woulda really sucked to start that line all over... 

Anyways, I had the tonkotsu medium spicy. The broth was very flavorful but the spicy level was not there. Had to add in more so next time I'll go one or more levels up. There are pretty standard toppings (wood ear, green onion, bean sprouts, and red ginger). You can order the deluxe option to get the egg but I am perfectly happy without an egg.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
A very good experience and well worth the wait (if you get there early enough!) 

Marafuku Ramen SF provides a good dining experience, attentive servers, comfortable seats, and mint lemon water.

My party both ordered Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen, while I tried the Chicken Paitan Ramen. I recommend getting the Hakata. Both are flavorful, but the Haktata is more flavorful and spicy. Chicken is more plain. Plus, the Hakata meat tastes better. 

Be sure to get there early before opening to line up and wait less. If you come on weekend around lunch time, you'll be on the list for at least two hours. Yelp Waitlist is also a good option too but be prepared to wait as well.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Update after 1.5 year...

I didn't need to line up for this place and the price was affordable.

I'm just sad, the ramen is still good and all. But I don't want to wait 2 hours for a decent bowl of ramen for $16. I also don't appreciate how they gave me the check 5 minutes after they put down our ramen... What if I needed to add noodles...

Anyways, I don't think I will be coming back.
author: Wing C.

description:
My favorite ramen place in the city. The broth is slightly sweet, but still very tasty. The noodles are hand down what makes me like Marufuku better than the other ramen places I've been to. I had thought that ramen  noodles were always hard and chewy until coming here.

Service is all about getting you in and out as quickly as possible. Definitely recommend coming during the week, and even then you still will have a long wait. But I don't mind the wait for Marufuku because I don't have to sit in a line outside of the place. The flexibility of the Yelp Wait List definitely makes Marufuku my forever favorite (and the fact that their ramen is top notch).

Pro tip: first thing you do is get on the waitlist then walk around Japan Center. I wouldn't bother coming back by the restaurant until there's 5 parties ahead of you. And even that is a generous amount of time.
author: Arezou A.

description:
Marufuku is officially the best ramen I've had yet in San Francisco. 

Our group started with the Chicken Karaage which was perfectly cooked and came with a delicious aioli-type sauce. A few got the Marufuku bites which were a pork bun type dish. Each order comes with two. They were a big hit!

As for the ramen, all of us got the Hakata Deluxe, except one who go the Hakata Tonkotsu. The ramen was just SO tasty. I could drink the broth all day. The noodles were tender and the perfect thickness. The pork belly was also delicious and perfectly cooked. And to top it off, they give you an entire soft boiled egg, whereas a lot of other places will just give you half. I wish I could have this ramen everyday!!

As for spiciness, they let you choose from 5 levels: no spicy to ultra spicy. I got the spicy which had a nice little kick but wasn't overwhelming at all. Our friends who go the ultra spicy said it was hot but bearable. 

Tip: The restaurant is small so there is ALWAYS a long wait. Get on the Yelp waitlist as soon as it opens. We noticed that for dinner, it doesn't open right when the restaurant opens at 5, but we kept checking and it opened around 5:45. At that point we got on the waitlist and it was about an hour wait. However, since you can get on the waitlist from home, you don't have to be waiting at the restaurant for that long and can just show up at the designated arrival time.
author: Jessie K.

description:
To start, the ramen was good, but in comparison to other places in the area (including South Bay), I honestly can't say it was worth the wait.

I joined the waitlist via Yelp for Saturday lunch and it gave me an 70-100 minute wait time and told us to arrive in about an hour.  We got there at the scheduled time, but it was about 45 more minutes until we were seated.  The restaurant isn't very big, so I understand why the wait time is so long, but I wish the waitlist system was more accurate.  

Our party of two ended up sharing a two-top with another couple, which they asked us about and we were fine with, but I was slightly annoyed that we were sat about 5 minutes before the other party, yet the staff took their orders and brought out their food first, even though we were ready pretty quickly.

We ordered the chicken karaage and Hakata deluxe, which has the thick pork belly and chasu pork.  The karaage was not worth ordering.  Being fried chicken, it tasted good, but the batter was oily and overall not as good as other places.  The ramen itself was delicious, but my main critique is that the soft-boiled egg wasn't extremely plain.  Most ramen restaurants marinate their eggs in a sauce to give it flavor, but Marafuku's egg was very bland and didn't impart much to the dish.

Overall, the ramen was good, although if you want the deluxe ramen, it'll set you back $17 a bowl, I wouldn't consider Marafuku worth the hype and the extremely long wait during popular times.  If there wasn't such a long wait, I'd consider coming back here, but there are other ramen restaurants that I'd go to first.
author: Kelsey P.

description: Excellent, excellent, excellent chicken ramen with iced matcha. Worth the wait or use Yelp to put your name down in advance!
author: Kristina W.

description: Got to say, this place is probably the best ramen in SF. The hype is indeed real! Their regular pork ramen dish is absolutely delicious, with a thick hearty broth, well cooked chashu and noodles. Highly recommended! I also got their takoyaki, which was incredibly flavorful! I got there on a Saturday morning 15 minutes before they opened and there was already a huge line, so plan to wait. Well worth it though! I did feel a little rushed but what do you expect, they have a lot of people waiting!
author: Andrew T.

description:
If I went back in time to my younger self and said that I waited 2 hours for a bowl of ramen, my younger self would probably say "WTF is WRONG WITH YOU!"

I still have a hard time reconciling that fact of how long I am willing to wait for ramen. At Marufuku I guess 120 minutes isn't quite too long of a wait....partially b/c of their wonderful e-check-in and queue alert system and of course, their ramen!

When arriving there is a little kiosk stand at the entrance which allows for electronic sign-in onto their list. You are then alerted via smartphone text how many others are ahead of you. You are now free to leave and roam un-tethered. When your place in the invisible e-line nears, you will be alerted to return back. Wonderful concept. Without this system in place, I would never have waited this long. I am sure that I wouldn't be alone either with that fact.

The wait time is obvi the longest during weekends. That's when I had no choice in going b/c of out of town guests in tow. Holiday weekend to boot. Ugh! Oh well. Been there before so I knew what I was getting myself into. My guests weren't so sure....only until after they had finished their meal here too.

When our turn arrived we were promptly seated and ordered. Two pitchers of ice cold adult beverages later, the pain of the 2-hour wait had subsided. Our table all ordered their Hakata DX with medium spice. The service and delivery of goods to our table was fast and efficient. 

The bowl of ramen is the best I have had. Ever. No doubt about it. It's not even close.

The broth in any ramen is the key. The 1985 film Tampopo definitely comes to mind when savoring the other-worldly broth of Marufuku. Flavors so deep with multiple layers of subtle deliciousness. Very, very difficult to put into words. Really! Kinda like trying to describe what you saw if you ever 'Saw God'. 

No, I don't purport to seeing any deity while imbibing in Marufuku's broth, but it was close. 

Definitely willing to go thru their wait time gauntlet in order to experience their ramen again in the future. Best to go during the week before or after the lunch time crush. Maybe 15 minutes before they open even.

Definitely!
author: william s.

description:
As a ramen obsessor, I've tried a lot of ramen places in both LA & SF. Marufuku seems to be a solid ramen place in SF with its rich broth and chewy noodles! 

Every time I come here, I try to arrive at least 15-20 minutes before they open on weekdays in order to secure a spot! There ALWAYS is a long line so be prepared to wait or come early!

Whenever I come here, I always get hakata ramen ultra spicy with chicken leg as a side. Although you cannot choose the richness of the broth nor the chewiness of your noodles, they seem to be just perfect for me as I prefer rich broth with chewy noodles! 

This is my personal preference, but I wish the noodles were a little thicker and hope the broth had more garlic flavor into it! Other than that, it seems to be a great spot to grab ramen on a cold day!
author: Justyn P.

description:
Where's the hottest table in Japantown?  

Just look at the line or amount of people waiting, sitting, or standing around this building end restaurant.  But, guess what?  It ain't as bad as it looks if you do your homework.

I actually tried to come about a month before dining here but the line was long and I had a medical appointment.  As a result, I was more organized and able to enjoy my lunch within minutes of arriving on my next attempt.

After a short wait, I was seated at a two seat table near the entrance and promptly given a menu.  It isn't particularly large and, after doing an internal debate, I decided to try their Hakata deluxe ramen (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=1ndoOYZIJDvDtcSIJ35wtA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  The ingredients were all there and the flavors were good and meshed very well together.  It is deceiving as you need to flip the noodles and mix the ingredients to fully appreciate your bowl of ramen.  The meat was tender and soft and the other ingredients (egg, corn, seaweed, etc) brought a variety of textures and flavors as a nice change.

Wanting to try more things, I ordered a Kakuni bowl (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=JfS5FBCNzDUnM6cBsGCh3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) for home.  Not wanting to change the texture of the ingredients by reheating, I ate this for dinner that evening.  It did not disappoint as, cold or hot, the integrity of the rice and flavors kept well.

Some friends complained about the MSG level in the broth but I had no such problem.  Service was prompt and efficient as they clearly want to flip the tables for the waiting patrons.  It kind of reminded me of Japan in the order, eat, pay, and go concept.  Now, the trick in cutting that waiting time.  Use your Yelp app and lock in on a time estimate and time your check in on your phone as you are coming.  Trust me, this will save you a lot of anxiety as well as time.
author: Mike C.

description:
A chilly day calls for a heartwarming bowl of ramen! After exploring town all day, my then-fiancé and I found ourselves in Japan town during dinner time. With high ratings and with almost 1,500 reviews, we had to see what's up. This place was true a 4.5 Stars for me like what the Yelp average rating is. The best time to come here is right when they open as there is no wait time. Otherwise, you can use the Yelp app to put yourself on the Waitlist, which I highly recommend. I put myself on the list as we were about an hour away and we got there just on time to check in. Now, that's winning big on time for us, impatient New Yorkers! 

My now-hubby and I got the Karaage Fried Chicken to start with and the two deluxe ramen bowls: Hataka and Chicken Paitan. Karaage Fried Chicken was nicely fried and crispy and the squeeze of lemon juice was just perfect. Hataka is the braised pork belly ramen bowl. It was super hearty and the broth was so flavorful. Ramen noodles' texture was perfect as well. Poached egg was perfectly gooey! The garnish green onions added a nice aroma to it. This bowl was porky delicious! Chicken Paitan was also really good! The menu says that there are only limited 15 servings each day. To my surprise, we made it! Grilled Chicken Leg was grilled with soy sauce flavor and it was really good! Chicken Paitan is much cleaner in taste. Either bowl, you're making the right choice! 

Awesome ramen bowl!!!
author: Cynthia D.

description:
There is always a line out the door for Marukufu in the Japantown center, but people move through relatively fast! 
I got the Tonkotsu ramen. The broth is absolutely amazing! It's very light but full of flavor. 
The noodles are much thinner than typical ramen noodles, which actually worked quite well with the lighter broth. 
The yelp waitlist opens up about 15 minutes after opening, and fills up really quickly. I came before the waitlist opened and was able to be seated in the second wave about 20 minutes later.
author: Miranda N.

description:
Heard the buzz about this place and finally had to check it out. My friend and I arrived right at 5:30 when it opened to see that there was already a decent line before doors even opened. Luckily we did get seated because we ended up sharing tables with another party. 

When the hakata deluxe came out, my first thought was that the bowl was small. But trust me when I say the rich fatty broth will definitely fill you up. I got it medium spicy although that wasn't spicy at all. The broth did have a really good rich flavor and the meat was so delicious! However, I think that if I came back, I would order the regular hakata and just order more of the sliced meat instead of the thick pork belly that came with the deluxe. The thicker piece was tougher and dry so it wasn't as tender as the thinly sliced pork belly. This place is worth a try, but for $17 bucks for a bowl of ramen, I don't think I'd be coming often.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Oh my god. The lines are worth the wait to sit down and eat some of the best ramen in the city. However I just walked in and ordered something to go. It was ready in 5 minutes. 

I actually don't know what i ordered. I just showed the lady a picture of something that looked good on yelp and it tasted even better than it looked. The broth was amazing and full of flavor. The noodles were the perfect thickness and the veggies and meat were tender and cooked to perfection. 

This is my new go to ramen spot. It's right upstairs immediately above the bonsai tree store in the JapanTown mall.
author: Michael P.

description:
Don't let the fact it is in a mall scare you away. Top rate ramen. They will rush you so order an app and chill. There is great attention paid to the egg noodles, pork and broth of both options. And yes- That is a side of pork belly in the attached pic. Couldn't resist. 

They have a good waitlist tech so you don't have to wait too long outside entrance.
author: Ken R.

description:
This was outstanding no frills ramen.  Worth the wait, or cordinating with the yep app.  If you do arrive early there is a sake bar next door that has karaoke... While you sit at the bar.  Stationary store down stairs is a good spot too. 
The Ramen was delicious. Savory flavors abound.  It really was incredible.  Best Ramen I've had in the United States.
author: David P.

description:
WOWEE!!! This is a place for the patient minded and I am not one of those. I have "tried" to dine here three times and failed because each time the wait was over 70 mins!! what's crazy is there's a line to get in the line! For the first 30 mins or so Marufuku disables remote join the waitlist so you have to physically get in line via the kiosk stand. I've tried to wait but my hanger gets the best of me and my poor poor husband having to tolerate my darkest hanger moments. The first three times we tried to dine in Marufuku we ended up going to neighboring restaurants in the japan center.

The fourth time I got smarter! I went during lunch on a weekday with some coworkers! YATA! the wait was only 30-40mins, what a score!  practically all of my coworkers ordered the Hakata deluxe and wow it was amazing. For the price per bowl (~$17) there were a lot of meat in the ramen. With that said the meat was really well cooked. It was so tender that it would almost fall apart when I pick it up with the chopstick. It was so well seasoned that I can taste the distinct flavor of the pork versus the broth. The noodle was very will cooked, it wasn't soft nor was it under cooked. Note: at first I thought I didn't get an egg, but it at the bottom of the bowl. Since I didn't discover the egg when the ramen was first served it was a little bit more cooked than I liked. 

Overall I definitely would like to dine here again for the food but.... the wait.... I don't know if its worth it since it affects my personal emotions.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Definitely a unique experience. The decor is an Asian style with shared tables. Sitting is definitely limited which explains the wait. We got on the waitlist at 6:00pm and got seated around 7:15pm with 39 parties ahead of us. My husband got the deluxe chicken ramen which came with the chicken leg quarter on the side served on a sizzling platter. I went simple for the chazu bowl. 

Food rating - adequate but not the best ramen we have ever experienced before. The broth lacked depth in flavor and had a muddled boiled chicken fat flavor. The chicken came out way before the ramen nearly 10 minutes before. My rice bowl was a bit excessively sweet and could have used depth of flavor and some spice to give it complexity. Over food was as I stated adequate.

Service was very rapid to a point were we felt rushed out of the place as soon as we looked remotely done with our meal. If your looking for a relaxed atmosphere this isn't the place. Quite loud and fast.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Located in the Japan Town Plaza, Marufuku is definitely not for the faint of heart, as the line here can easily get over 30 minutes just moments after the dinner doors open. However, if you can brave the line then what awaits is a mouthwatering bowl of ramen.

Marufuku offers mainly two different types of ramen; one based on pork broth and one based on chicken. I've only had their pork broth so the review will be based on those. Marufuku has two different options, deluxe and regular. The only difference between the two is that the deluxe option comes with a fat slice of pork with a good sear on one side leaving it soft and melty on the other and in the middle and a $4 increase (maybe $5 I don't remember). Either way the real star of their ramen is their mouthwatering tonkatsu broth. I've had a good amount of tasty ramen (mostly from LA) and this stuff bests most of them. Something about the creaminess and the fact that their spicy is the perfect amount for my taste buds make this ramen so freaking good. The ramen is priced much more reasonably than Ippudo IMO so I'll definitely choose Marufuku anyday.

Parking around here is fairly easy, just park in the parking structure close by and it's less than a 5 minute walk to the restaurant. The only issue is their wait, but you can join the virtual waitlist if it's open so keep your eyes out for that to minimize your actual wait time at the store. 

P.S. their bowls are aesthetic af so there's that if you're a person really looking for a good IG photo.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I came here 5 times and this place was my best ramen spot in SF. But every time I visited I can tell their quality keeps going down slightly.

To begin with, soup was not as flavorful as my first time visiting. And my last time visiting even noodle become very soggy. Also meat become very tiny. Only half size compare my first time visiting.

I started question myself did they change ramen noodle to pasta? Otherwise it can't be this bad. I used to rate them 95/100, now I will only give them 60.

Probably they become famous and start being lazy, I won't come here again.
author: Hana H.

description:
Yumm. 

Cept the wait.

2.5 hours to be exact.

Got dropped off at 7:00pm by my cousin to put our names down while she looked for parking. Was super thrilled cause I thought, hey. Can't be too bad if we put our name down at 7 right ?! 

WRONGGZ 

Got in there and put my name down for 3 at 7:10 and we didn't get called until 9:30.... like when they closed. Didn't think it could be this bad but it was. 

Regardless, we just waited. Mainly cause my cousin raved about this place and cause everywhere else had a darn wait. So why not. 2.5 hours went by ok. We walked around and loitered in the bookstore until the lady kicked us out at 8 cause they were closing. Then we just sat our bums down outside the restaurant and watched as everyone got called. We became the second to last party to get seated... at least we're not last, right. LOL 

Ordered quick cause they were doing last call already. I got the chicken paitan, my cousin got the hakata delux, and my sister got their chicken karage mini rice bowl. My ramen was delicious but I actually like the hakata delux more. I initially chose the chicken cause I don't like fatty pork belly. But the pork belly was alright as long as you take out the fat part and eat the lean. The ramen was made al dente and was super addicting to bite into. I ordered mines in SPICYY and it was perfect. Service was soso. Quick order, drop off, and check.

Didn't expect much but it was definitely worth the hype.

And the wait, I guess :D
author: Anissa D.

description:
While this ramen was really good, I have to state an unpopular opinion that I've tried better. I did enjoy this ramen, but IT IS NOT WORTH THE 3 1/2 HOUR WAIT. I understand that's it's popular and was on tv and has good reviews and all that, but we're in the Bay Area for god sakes! There's amazing food all around us and soooo many hole in the wall restaurants that are truly authentic. 

First of all, the price is ridiculous. I understand it's good food but they're totally taking advantage of their hype. I can buy 2 ramens for the price of this one anywhere else.

Second of all, the broth was my favorite part! It was very unique, different than any other broth I've tried before. It was savory and had some unique flavors. The noodles, on the other hand, I liked but didn't prefer. It was still cooked REALLY GOOD and chewy just how I like them, not soft at all. My personal opinion is that I prefer the traditional ramen noodles with a kink in them as opposed to the straight spaghetti style noodles, that's all.

Thirdly, not sure if this is just me but I thought the bowl was kind of small compared to other ramens that I've had! It wasn't tiny, but I found it to be average sized while other ramens I've had before are quite large. 

My other favorite locations add roasted garlic cloves and black garlic oil for a more affordable cost and larger portion, was still tasting FREAKING DELICIOUS! So while this place was good, I will probably not returned.

Sincerely,
An honest review from a true foodie.
author: Alejandra A.

description:
My first visit here and to be honest, I'm a huge fan. Obviously, you can't dock stars for a long wait. A long line half an hour before the restaurant even opens is a good sign of business! With all the reviews, I had to give Marufuku a shot. 

As a party of 2, we came at 4:55 pm on a Sunday afternoon. Not surprised by he long line wrapping around the lower floor staircase, we waited our turn up till around 5:20 or so to put our name down on the waiting list. Yelp has a great feature called Waitlist which allows you to see how many people are in front of you, all with the convenience of an app. 

First impression: the restaurant is very small. The place probably seats 45-50 customers. The lighting isn't great. There are big booths for the larger party which seemed more comfortable than the two person table we were seated at- wooden seats with a firm cushion. The menu is simple with offerings of appetizers, 3 types of ramen, and some sake locally sourced out of San Francisco. 

Takoyaki: 4/5 Just your basic takoyaki-tastes like the frozen takoyaki thrown into a fryer. Crisp exterior with soft gooey dough on the inside and some pieces of octopus and ginger. 
Ramen: 5/5 Ouch, $17 for a bowl of ramen? I'm not gonna lie. I felt a bit cheated but the serving size was really big. But man, take one sip of that broth and you're won over. The broth is creamy and rich- perfect balance of savory flavors from the pork bones. The noodles are cooked perfectly. I didn't care for the pork belly, it was dry and nothing special about it. However, the chasu pork was extremely tender, fatty, and flavorful. Hands down, the best chasu pork I've tasted in my life. It had a rich smoky flavor to it. I highly appreciate that a full soft boiled egg was included in our ramen- unlike other ramen places that only serve half an egg. 

The prices here are a little discouraging. $17 for a bowl of ramen seems steep. I would get the basic $12 ramen since nothing was too special about the pork belly. The wait looks intimidating, but luckily, theres quite a bit to do around Japantown while you wait. I definitely recommend coming early before they open.
author: Sandra N.

description:
My first time using Yelp's No Wait system with Marufuku and it is wonderful!  When you get to Marufuku there is usually a line outbreak door.  The trick is before you leave the house you put your party on the list through yelp and it tells you how many parties are in front of you and the approximate waiting time! 

The ramen here is awesome here, there are the thinner noodles and the pork broth is super delicious.  Worth the wait especially with the yelp no wait waiting list!
author: Edmond T.

description:
Best ramen I've ever tasted.   Ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu which was pork belly.   The broth was perfect, the meat was perfectly cooked and the "spicy" wasn't overwhelming.    The egg was cooked to perfection and the noodles were spot on.   I can't imagine why they don't get a bigger venue.  There a constant stream of people here so waiting for 30+ minutes is normal.    Perhaps they want to always have a crowd to make them look busy, but this place has so many reviews and has become such a staple that they're just hurting themselves at this point.   

The water was an added bonus, since most of the Asian restaurants have been giving hot tea, and this spicy ramen definitely needed water as a compliment.   The mint lemon was a nice extra touch.   

I'd eat here once a week if I didn't live on the other side of the country.   This was one of the more cost effective bang-for-your-buck places I've been to during  an otherwise costly food experience in San Fran.
author: Philip G.

description:
I'm such a noob when it comes to ramen, but my friend recommended this place, and there was already a line outside for when this place opened, I guess it has to be good right?

We put our names down fairly early, and you give them your number so that they can call you when you're table is ready. Makes it really easy to wander around the area to other stores while you wait. So it makes the waiting part not bad. We got there before it opened, and only waited maybe 20 minutes. 

Their menu is pretty simple, not too many options and not too complicated. I got the Hakata Deluxe, while my boyfriend got the Chicken Paitan Deluxe, which apparently they only serve 15 each for lunch and dinner. Either this is really exclusive or it was really good marketing, cuz it definitely lured us in to order it. 

Hakata Deluxe: you can see pictures on Yelp of the menu for what it contains lol so have a look. This was definitely super flavorful and the egg was cooked almost perfectly. Compared to some of the other ramen places I've had, this is definitely one of the better ones. 

Chicken Paitan Deluxe: the cool part of this is that the chicken comes separately on a sizzling platter with onions. It's actually really well seasoned and cooked as well, I really thought that it would be too dry. But it was pretty tender. The ramen was also really delicious as well, not much different from the hakata deluxe, so just order this if you really want the chicken. 

Overall, really good experience here. Come here early though to avoid the wait, but remember you can always put your name down and then wander around the shops.
author: Katherine H.

description:
My goodness, this is hands down the best ramen in SFS. Went with a couple friends, not a word spoken at the table once the food came out. We were busy slurping on the classic Hakata Tonkatsu and munching on pork buns. Definitely worth the long wait. Nuff Said!

Recommendation: Be in line at least 10 min before opening. If not, you'll be occupied with shopping at the bookstore.
author: Michael D.

description:
Came on a Saturday night and waited about an hour. The good thing is that the nice bookstore is next to the restaurant so you can go there and burn time while you wait. Next time, I'll probably join the wait-list on Yelp and wait from home before heading to the restaurant (there's only so many books that I'll check out!)

Once we were seated and we ordered, it took about 5 minutes for the food to come out so that was great. I got the tonkotsu ramen.

Pros:
- super rich delicious broth. Was the highlight of the bowl, and honestly probably the most important part. Very well done. I think mensho is still the best in the city but this is 2nd.
- good amount of portions. Good ratio between the sides (cha shu, etc) to noodles.
- cha shu had good taste

Some things to improve:
- cha shu was somewhat dry. The taste was nice but it was just too dry and wasn't too pleasant to chew on.
- the ramen comes with very thin noodles. Personally i like them a bit thicker and the option to customize the thickness would be appreciated.
- i got mold spiciness but it seemed like they accidentally added more spiciness for me. I thought it was much more than mild and after having my GFs soup (who also got mild) it seems that was the case.
author: Desmond C.

description:
I was worried we wouldn't be able to snag a table, but Yelp helped us out by letting us wait for a table without actually having to wait in line. I love this! We put our name down approximately an hour before we got to Japantown, and we walked in approximately 10 minutes before we were called. It was perfect timing!

We ordered a bowl of their hakata style tonkotsu ramen. It was delicious! I loved the noodles, and the broth was so good. I haven't had very many bowls of ramen in SF, but I'd say this place ranks high on my list. 

We also ordered the chicken karaage bowl, and I was initially worried about the sogginess of the rice based on some people's review. Thankfully, it came out perfect, and I loved the chicken. It was pretty crispy and juicy inside. I'd order it again.
author: Jennie T.

description:
Just a note. I am not a fan of ramen or fresh noodles/pasta because I'm very picky about how I like my noodles. The Taste such as whether the noodles grabs the soup/sauce. The texture should have a bite and good snap to it. But here is my honest review of the place

There is a waitlist you can leave your number where they will call you when your table is about ready . Your wait maybe from 30mins- 1 to 2hrs. But after you order your food. It comes in 5-10minutes . At least that's what I noticed 

The waitress was very friendly with a great smile. Apparently she was thai because I heard her spoke it to table next to me ! Anyways

Hakata pork belly deluxe - broth is excellent. Clean and tasty . The pork belly fell apart but was dry 

Chicken paitan deluxe - limited to 15 a day. The roasted chicken leg is tasty, falls apart but more on the dry side. Tasted close to soy sauce chicken. The chicken breast meat wasn't anything special. Almost a bit tough to eat. The broth tho was very good. 

Ramen - looked like wonton noodles/angel hair noodles. It's different and interesting but a bit soft to getting soggy easy 

Soft boiled egg - it's a soft boiled egg

Ultra spicy - my waitress told me if I can eat spicy  then it's more of a medium spicy level. I got the ultra spicy and for me it wasn't that spicy. So your call to try! Just remember food should taste good ! Not spicy where you can't even eat it anymore!

Takoyaki - it's good . The octopus inside wasn't tough like most other places 

Chicken Karaage - my friend said it's too salty . I thought it was fine. It seems like the meat was marinated so there's a nice flavor. It wasn't juicy or soft . Cooked a bit too long maybe 

Never know or believe till you try it yourself .  #jessteatit
author: Myron L.

description:
This is my favorite ramen spot!!! I love ramen and I tried about a million ramen spots but this place makes my heart and belly happy, It is my truly favorite ramen place! Their ramen is so flavorful!  The broth is delicious, and I love how they make their noodles - THIN! I always get the Deluxe! So so so good! 

Whenever I am at Japantown, I make sure I eat here. If you hate getting in line, a trick would be to come here 30 mins before they open, on a weekday. I always get seated right away. 

Also, they have a wait list here at yelp!
author: Khristine H.

description:
The ramen is AMAZING here.

I'm hardly a connoisseur of good, genuine ramen, but the broth for the tonkotsu is juicy and filled with flavor, and you get an excellent amount of ingredients included.  Everything tastes fresh and is cooked to the perfect amount of doneness.

I've also eaten at Marufuku's sister location in Oakland and it was the same quality of food. The decor also gets a plus from me - understated and simple, but it's a good atmosphere and the place doesn't feel too crowded.

I didn't get a chance to try the Chicken Paitan, but I did have some of the appetizers (edamame and the chicken karaage) and they were excellent additions to my meal.

The servers and waitstaff were very attentive and I had a great experience - we never felt like we were being rushed out of our seats and they came by frequently to fill our water and check if there was anything they could do to improve our dining experience and meal.

I'm taking a star because of two things: the wait, and the parking. Parking in Japantown can be challenging, and this is especially true if you are coming here on a weekend or during an event.  It is possible to find street parking, but it's a bit of a nightmare, you have to get lucky, you have to be good at parallel parking, and otherwise it is paid parking that to my knowledge cannot be validated.

The wait is a whole other story. They do have an automated system with Yelp, but my friend and I arrived on a Sunday before opening and not including the wait before the restaurant opened, we still ended up waiting about 45-60 minutes before we got a table. I've heard the wait can be 2-3 hours if you're unlucky or if you don't plan around the meal. That said, there is a lot to do around Japan Center SF and in the surrounding areas, so if you plan to eat here, just time things correctly so you don't end up wasting a couple hours of your time.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
Pros:  fast and good service
           Good food
           

Cons:  water cups were a little stinky
author: Bayarea K.

description:
Super tasty ramen, not sure if it's worth the wait, we didn't feel super great after. 

I arrived at 5pm (their opening time) on Sunday, and there were prob 60 people who had been waiting already. However, their waitlist system is efficient: your party signs in on an iPad, and it tells you your order in line and asks for your phone number so it'll text you when ready. After the first rush of people, we were 15th in line at 5:10. 

Our table was ready at 6pm - so about hour long wait for party of 2. At that time, there were like 50 parties waiting according to the iPad with a 75 minute wait. Nuts! 

We both ordered the deluxe ramen in spicy with Sapporo beers. The Sapporo was pretty flat. 

The ramen was a good size. The broth and meat were excellent. I enjoyed the ginger in it, my boyfriend thought it was weird. We both agreed we should've gotten the Extra Spicy. The noodles and egg were alright. 

Service is fast and no-frills. 

Definitely one of the better bowls of ramen in the city. However, our meal didn't sit right with us later; just a lot of bloat and discomfort. Maybe it was the beer?
author: Thu P.

description:
Recommend: Can't go wrong with either Pork or Chicken Ramen!

I'm not exaggerating when I say that I may have found my favorite ramen place in the Bay Area.  I've been on the hunt for a good ramen place in SF, and I can finally say mission accomplished.    

I normally prefer my ramen noodles thicker, especially if it's in a thick Tonkatsu broth, but this place serves delicate, thin ramen noodles, so I went in with very low expectations.  However, I can say that I am now completely converted and I'm on that thin ramen noodle train (who said thicker was better??).   What converted me was the combination of the bouncy, springy noodles with the flavorful broth.  The broth left me speechless; it was rich, mouthwatering, savory, distinctive, spicy....the list goes on.  It was a religious experience. 

We ordered both the chicken and pork broth options, and I'm conflicted as to which one is better. They were both singular and delicious in their own ways, and equally jam-packed with flavor.  The best surprise was the soft-boiled egg hidden beneath all that glorious ramen noodles.  Normally at ramen restaurants, you have to order your own soft-boiled egg at an additional cost, but this place was complimentary.  We also ordered the Takoyaki as an appetizer, but to be honest, it was overshadowed by the amazing ramen.

We arrived at 12pm on a Friday, and put ourselves on the waitlist in front of the restaurant.  There were about 30 parties ahead of us, but we only waited about an hour.  This is because service is very very quick.  We ordered our food and received our ramen within 5 minutes. The good thing is that you can put yourself on the waitlist on Yelp and receive notifications as to where you are in line. The wait is worth it.  Trust.
author: Charissa S.

description:
It was just OK. $100 lunch for 4 people for average ramen in SF...times are tough.

Lined up at 10:45am on a Sunday and was the third party to be seated. 

Interior - Cute, clean, dark, cozy. 

Service - Good. Attentive.

Takoyaki - Warm, comforting, plenty of bonito flakes. 

Chicken Paitan Deluxe - The chicken was over-salted and tasted like it was soaked in soy sauce. Soft, savory, juicy, but a little too salty. 

Vegetarian Ramen - Richer than it looks, heavy, and with egg noodles. Not vegan (tried asking for other noodles but no alternative). Asked for more nori, bean sprouts, and green onions, but it didn't really add anything, and my ramen bowl felt small and incomplete. 

A little frustrating that the chicken pieces came out 10 minutes before the main entree. We were so hungry and it took so long for our ramen to come out!
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: The ramen here was beyond amazing! It reminded me of my worldwide fave ramen shop, a short rib ramen in Osaka. The deluxe ramen is probably my favorite in the US and I have eaten at all the major shops in NYC. The wait is long but you can join the waitlist on yelp which I think is a great touch. We also had the karage and buns which were ok. Save room for dessert from matcha cafe maiko that's downstairs!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Marufuku Ramen is an extremely popular Hakata-style ramen shop located in a plaza called the Japan Center (San Francisco Japantown). This ramen shop is known for two items -  Hakata-style tonkotsu ramen (broth cooked for over 20 hours) and chicken paitan ramen (both ramen are always available). One of items on the menu (Chicken Paitan Deluxe - basically chicken paitan ramen with an extra grilled chicken leg side dish) is limited to 15 servings (the menu did not specify whether the limitation is per day or per lunch / dinner meal). When our group got here at 4:30 PM, the line had already started and it eventually went all the way back to Izumiya 15 minutes later (about 25+ people waiting). The door opened at 5 PM on Sunday and my friend was able to order Chicken Paitan Deluxe without any issues. You can choose spicy level for your ramen.

***

Hakata Tonkotsu (Chashu Pork [Simmered Pork Belly], Seasoned Soft Boiled Egg, Green Onions, Kikurage Mushrooms, and Bean Sprouts - medium spicy, $12.99): Since I was still full from my previous lunch (tacos and a half burrito from La Taqueria), I didn't get chicken paitan deluxe and only ordered a bowl of ramen. Pork belly was well marinated and it was really flavorful with melt-in-your-mouth texture. Broth was also extremely flavorful with medium spicy level gave a nice tingling sensation (personally spicy level was just right). I really liked their thin noodle and noodle texture was great. Overall this bowl of ramen was well-balanced and rich flavors.

***

I tried a lot of ramen places in Southern California and I am really impressed with Marufuku. In fact this was one of the best Hakata-style tonkotsu ramen I have ever had - even better than Shin-Sen-Gumi Hakata Ramen in Los Angeles.

P.S. - There's another location in Oakland.
author: Luke L.

description:
Love their Ramen,If you can endure the long waiting time,between 20min to 45+,then  this is your place!you can use Yelp app to put your name online on their waiting list! 
the good thing about waiting on line is,I love checking art books at kinokuniya bookstore which is located on the other side of this store! so you have plenty of time to kill while waiting!
author: Mohammad M.

description:
My number one recommendation for this place is to come as early as possible, and to come before the restaurant even opens! This ramen spot is notorious for having super long waits, and after trying it out for myself, the lines are definitely very long. We came at around 5:10pm on a Sunday night, and there was already a long line formed outside the door to check in on the waitlist at the front. Luckily, there's a lot of stores around the restaurant, so walking around Japantown really helps kill some time. In total, we waited around 1.5 hours to get a seat, and we ended up being seated at a combined table where we shared a bench table with another two people party. This ramen spot is definitely not conducive for large parties, and I would recommend coming with either one or two other people, or else the wait could be even longer.
 
Their menu is very simple, with choices of either a tonkatsu or chicken based ramen. I went for the Hakata tonkatsu ramen, and it was the perfect amount of food for me. To my surprise, the ramen was very good! I am usually not a fan of hakata style, thin-noodle ramen, but the one at Marufuku was perfectly cooked and rich in flavor. The broth was the perfect, milky-creamy flavor, and the added kick from the spicy oil made it even more delicious. The pork belly was very tender and the soft boiled egg was perfectly cooked, with a runny yolk on the inside.
author: Sandra S.

description: Great flavours and thin noodle ramen! The bites was very flavourful and the broth of the ramen was creamy. I came from Toronto to try this place for dinner and it was great! The lineup was long especially if you do not come early, but it's worth the wait !
author: Vanessa W.

description: Okay, I know what everyone is thinking... 1-2hr+ wait is ridiculous... and I am not disagreeing, but if you can get on Yelp and put yourself on the wait list and arrive near your expected seating time... DO IT. This ramen is spectacular. I have had ramen in so many places, but this one is probably top 3. The flavor is like no other. The service is meh, but it is quick. Your ramen comes out within 10 minutes. They also have some good beers there too! If you are in this area and want good ramen, get to Marufuku asap.
author: Denise C.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in SF. Tbh I didn't really like ramen until I tried this! Each and every element of this dish contributed immensely to the power packed flavors of this ramen. In a lot of ramen places I've found the noodles to be too thick but here they are thin and absorb the broth very well.

Marufuku serves tons of people so make sure you put yourself on the yelp waitlist in order to avoid reaching the restaurant and not getting a spot after waiting for 2 hrs :)

This place is definitely one of the gems of SF that truly lives up to the hype.
author: Akshat G.

description: Got on the yelp waiting list.  2 hours.  Showed up at 8:12 but didn't get seated till 8:42. Tried the mild spicy chicken deluxe since i was so hungry.  Baked chicken was super tender comes in a bed of bean sprouts. Chicken ramen came with 2 slices of white meat chicken.  The broth was slightly too salty.  Is it because it came from the bottom of the pot? The cucumber water was super refreshing.  My friend took my leftover broth home.
author: Helen L.

description: One of my favorite ramen places!  I went the first month they had opened and remember the ramen being excellent and wait pretty short for a Saturday.  Then I went more recently and was glad to see that the quality is still top notch maybe even better; downside is the much longer wait time.  But there are plenty of stores in the complex to amuse while you wait.  And the wait is so worth it!  Hakata tonkatsu ramen-I always want to go for this bowl, broth so rich and comforting and noodles have the perfect chew.  Soft boiled egg has that perfect warm runny yolk.  I definitely need to try the other bowls, too!
author: Helen H.

description:
Arrived 10 mins before opening time for Friday lunch and just made it to first seating Yay!
Upon entering, nice decor, simple and clean.
Just had to order the chicken Paitan, especially when only 15 are made daily plus the Tonkatsu ramen. Lovely presentation and I loved the ceramic bowl too.  Ramen is smaller than the regular ramen I've tried but really good and slightly chewy .  Both broths were rich, milky and tasty.
Overall, great food, nice ambience and reasonable prices.  Definitely will be back to try other dishes.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Tried the Hakata DX ramen, takoyaki, fried squid legs (geso), and fried shishito.

Appetizers were good but not great. Broth from the Hakata ramen was rich and decadent. They use thin ramen noodles but I personally prefer thick curly ones. The meat was tasty and tender but a little dry. Tried the wasabi beer and definitely would pass on that.

Would come back again if I don't have to do the one hour wait. Can't wait to try the chicken next time!
author: Tina S.

description:
I've come here twice and really liked this place. The wait can be long but if you're craving ramen, I'd come here.

I've found this to be the only place I like as much as Izakaya Sozai. But then again, I love ramen in SoCal and SF just doesn't compare.
author: Sophia L.

description:
So, this is definitely good ramen, but I don't quite get the hype. While it was tasty, I didn't feel it was worth a 2-hour wait. We put our names on the list at 5:30 and were seated around 7:30. We watched the hostess put a sign on the tablet that they weren't taking anyone else for the night around 7:30, at which point there were about 100 parties on the list.

There are two ramen options: chicken and pork. Didn't see a vegetarian option. Also be aware that these are eggs noodles, so I would probably not come here if I were vegan. I ordered a chicken ramen with medium spice and found the spice levels to be true to what I ordered (not too hot or too mild). The flavors were good and the soft boiled egg was well-prepared.

We figured that after waiting two hours we may as well go all out and get some sake. Didn't really enjoy it tbh. But this was my first time with sake so maybe I'm just not a sake person. We ordered a large, which ended up being too much for two people. The small would have been a perfect amount.

If I were to be in Japatown on a night with a miraculously short wait, I would totally come back here. I enjoyed the ramen and the ambiance is good. Don't think I would wait two hours again though.
author: Audrey S.

description:
Omg the wait is crazy!!! WHYYYY IS THERE SUCH A LONG WAITLIST!?!  Came here at 6pm on a Saturday, got on the waitlist and was in the #80s!!!! 

Since we were going to be waiting for over an hour, I got an ice cream cone at matcha cafe.  Dessert before dinner, why not?! 

I've been to the one in Oakland and the wait is not even close to the wait in SF!  Parking in Oakland is also easier to find than in SF.    

Okay on to the actually food.  Same as Oakland! Nothing different other than the ambience.  We ordered pretty quickly. Our waitress was quick and our food came out right away.  Very HOT (temperture-wise)!!! Almost burned my mouth a couple of times  I got the tonkatsu ramen.  Flavor was great.  Very filling!  

Four stars for the food, but I want to take a star off for the long line.  I'm not cause that's not the restaurant's fault.  I don't think it's worth waiting over an hour!  I'll just stick to going to the one in Oakland (easy parking and shorter lines!).
author: Jennifer T.

description: The ramen here is clutch. No doubt about it. But there is a but coming.......but; I have had better. Gawd sorry to say that. I guess someone has to. The spicy here isn't spicy at all .....at least if you are a spicy food eater. The broth is phenomenal just not the best. Would I go back.....yes... on the list is the location in Oakland.
author: Stacie J.

description:
I'm a HUGE ramen fan and I've had ramen all around the world and this is the best in Sam Francisco for sure. Maybe even California. We got to the restaurant around 5:05 and there was a small line already. By 5:30 there was a long line. So if you don't wanna wait be there early and if they're full put your name on the yelp waitlist. 

The place is really nice but small. The staff are really efficient and get people in and out quickly. They get your order quick and are really attentive. Water is always refilled and everything is taken care of. Our waitress was really friendly and helpful. 

Now the ramen, we got the tonkotsu ramen and it was amazing. The size was good for the price and all the components were great. The broth was really flavorful and had a lot of depth. It was rich and very complex. Not just some thin broth. The meat was great but a little salty. Egg was excellent and all the toppings were great. I would suggest getting spicy or even the hottest one if you like spice because it's just cayenne and makes a really great flavor.

Overall, great ramen, great prices, excellent service. Definitely would recommend trying this place out!
author: Mickey C.

description:
Expect to wait. An hour minimum is likely, but thankfully you can check in on the Yelp app or tablet they have up front. I don't think this is the fault of the restaurant though, as it's actually quite spacious... which means the reason it takes so long is because people take forever to finish their ramen.

Let me just say that ramen is supposed to be THE antisocial food. You get it, you eat it in ten minutes or less, and you leave. Unfortunately, it seems that everyone has friends and they all like to "socialize" while eating... heathens. The line would move quicker if barriers were put up between seats.

I'm kidding, but for real, eat your ramen fast otherwise it stops tasting good.

Onto the food...

I ordered the Hakata-style tonkotsu, and the first thing I did was taste the broth. Such a bold, clean flavour without being too salty. The noodles had a firm, al dente bite to them, and they did a really great job holding onto the flavour of that pork broth. I started tearing up a little bit as I was eating; I'm not too sure if it was because of the steam from the hot broth, or because I was so happy I finally managed to find a good bowl of ramen in SF, but I'll accept both answers. It's just a really nice and balanced tasting bowl of ramen, and you feel like you can keep on eating forever because it's not heavy at all, despite being a tonkotsu broth.

Bonus points to the shape of the bowl too. As a user experience designer, I was pretty delighted by the spout on the side of the bowl that made it easy to drink the broth when you were done with the noodles.

I also ordered the mentaiko rice bowl, which... was lacking in comparison to the ramen. The rice was a bit mushy and it didn't really taste like much. I'll forgive this one though because it's a ramen restaurant, not a rice bowl restaurant.

Service was fast and attentive, as I never had to ask for water refills, or wait too long for my bill when I was finished. I was really surprised at the speed they brought my food; it was something like two minutes from the time I ordered, which is insane considering how busy they were. 

After weeks of trying different ramen around the city and being disappointed every time, it was Marufuku that ended up delivering. The ramen whispered to me, "you're always welcome back... as long as you're okay with waiting in line".
author: Calvin Z.

description:
Had to write this review while the taste of the Tonkatsu was still fresh in my taste buds!

I arrived to Marufuku about 25 minutes before the doors opened, and got into a line that had already formed of about 20-25 people. We put our name down on the waitlist iPad that they had, and waited about 20 minutes or so. 

The Tonkatsu ramen was out of this world, and was flavorful with every bite. I got the Hakata Tonkatsu, mild spice, ($12.99) and a side of chicken Karaage ($6.50) and both were delicious. I got a side of extra noodles for $2.50, which came on a side plate. 

The mild spice rating was not very spicy at all, so if you have a bit of a tolerance I say you could go for a medium or a bit higher and probably be fine. I added some spice to mine with the spice shaker they had on the table. If you're unsure on how much spice you can take, go with that rout and ask for mild, and just add spice as you go.

The service was great and prompt, probably more so because they have so many people and are trying to get people in and out as soon as possible, but not once did I feel rushed or like the servers were being rude. Everyone was kind, and the waiters checked up on us, and refilled our water cups very often. 

Marufuku lived up to the hype in every way, and I will be back. This was my first time here and it already has cracked my top 3 favorite ramen spots to go to. 

5/5 burritos!
author: John James M.

description: Their chicken paitan ramen is off the hook! It's got the right balance of creaminess from the tonkotsu and chicken broth mixed in. If you get the DX version, it comes with a sizzling plate of chicken drumstick/thigh. They are generous with their noodle servings here. The braised pork belly on top of their tonkotsu ramen is reminiscent of santa ramen. Cool ambience inside. Super long line so get here early or use the Waitlist on Yelp.
author: Ellin C.

description:
Long lines, crowds, believe the hype! 

Visited Japantown back in March and wanted to try this place out, but was discouraged to wait in the 54 person queue. Decided to stick it out with only about 15 people before us and got on the waitlist using the Yelp app, which made it so much easier. Decided not to stand around the front entrance and just waited on a nearby bench. Before we knew it, got a text that it was time to be seated.

Ordered the Karaage and the Tonkotsu Ramen to share, since there was a day of eating still. Karaage brought out first and the Ramen came out shortly after, was served with a small (children's) bowl, but was quickly swapped out for a normal bowl.
