I thought this small attention to detail was commendable. I was in no way offended and liked the kid's bowl, but love that kind of consideration on their part.

Karaage - Really impressed by the karaage here, perfectly crisp batter, but not heavy or greasy at all. The chicken was cooked perfectly, was juicy and the appetizer came out piping hot served with a lime wedge. Definitely, one of the best karaage's I've had in a long, long time. Great texture, simply delicious. It's incredible to think people can get fried chicken wrong, but they do ... Marufuku knows how to do it right!

Tonkotsu Ramen - Super creamy Tonkotsu broth, lovely and fatty. Tbh, I was skeptical because of the straight noodles, but I must say ... I may have been converted. With an aversion to straight ramen noodles in the past due to it reminding me of angel hair pasta or not being cooked well I feel that Marafuku has changed my ways. The ramen noodles were cooked well, they had a good chew and bite to them, the broth coated the noodles well and the toppings to the ramen were great compliments to the bowl. Served with tender, fatty charshu pork, pickled ginger, scallions, wood ear mushroom and a boiled egg.

The service here is spot on, attentive, showed attention to detail, waters refilled and we didn't feel rushed despite the long line of people outside. The actual interior of the shop is big and open. It's worth the wait people!
author: Janet N.

description: I don't eat pork so it's hard to find good chicken ramen. I came to this place and ordered chicken ramen. Soooooo good. I usually write a pretty big and detailed review but today I'm speechless. Its THAT good , no words can describe how much I loved this place. I almost cried having it.
author: Sumbal A.

description:
This could quite possibly be my favorite ramen place! The broth is so flavorful I drank every last sip. The charsu and soft boiled egg are cooked to perfection. The noodles had just the right amount of softness. I ordered the Hakata Deluxe and it was quite the culinary experience. It was a little expensive however, $16.99 a bowl. I would say the next time I would order the Hakata Tonkotsu, which is exactly the same as the deluxe except without one type of pork (I forget what it is called). The Tonkotsu is $12.99. 

The service was quick and friendly. There's also an option to put your name down via the yelp app which is super handy! It'll also tell you the recommended time to be there by, so you can walk around Japantown doing other things while waiting. I can't wait to come back here!
author: Katherine N.

description:
I'm about to go against the grain...Marafuku did not live up to the hype. Here's why:

1. The wait is actually the most convenient part of the experience. You can sign-in via Yelp, either remotely or at the front. They text you a link with your current place on the waitlist and you get a text when you're next up. I went around 5pm on a Sunday and I was number 43 on the waitlist to start, which took about 1.5 hours. But, I didn't have to wait there, which was great.

2. The ambiance was not typical of a ramen shop. No one said "Irrashaimase" when anyone walked in or left. My "arigatou gozaimasu" was not returned. Stuff was handed to me with one hand. I know I'm not in Japan, but c'mon at least try to make it seem like a Japanese restaurant -__-

3. Up to this point, I was still excited because the food is what makes the restaurant. I started with an order of takoyaki, which was priced at $6.50 for 5 pieces. The consistency was good, but where was the tako?? More tako and less yaki please! (ok that was a corny joke). But seriously, I was not impressed.

4. But who cares, right? I didn't come to Marafuku for the takoyaki, I came for the ramen!! At this point, I was still wiling to give this place 5-stars, even 6-stars, if the ramen was sugoiiiii. However, this was no so :(. Lemme break it down:

- Noodles: perhaps the most important component of the ramen. Thin noodles, not too soft, not too firm, good flavor, but didn't taste super fresh. When I asked them where they get the noodles from, the waitress responded that they were "home-made". I immediately, follow-up with "do you make them here?" To which she replied, "No, we make them in a factory." Not sure how that's homemade, but maybe the space is just small and they don't have the room. When I asked how often they transport the noodles from the factory to the restaurant, she did not know. Another waiter was listening to our convo and budged in and said "every day." I'll let you, the reader, decided this for yourself, but I was unconvinced.

- Broth: by far, the best part of the ramen. The broth is rich with flavor, however it does tend to be relatively thin. I prefer thicker broth, but that is just a preference, no harm done here. If you get the spicy broth, make sure you mix it well, since all the spices tend to fall towards the bottom.

- Pork: I was unimpressed with the pork. Too salty, too thin in my opinion. I does have good flavor though.. I haven't tried other options, but there's a reason most people order Hakata Tonkatsu. 

Overall, I can only give 5 stars to ramen shops I've been to in Japan, and I can only give 4 stars to two ramen shops in the Bay Area: Iza and Mensho. To everyone out there that showed up at Marafuku at 9pm only to find out the waitlist was 50 people they had no room to serve you... don't be so sad, being a Marafuku reject isn't the worst thing in the world ;)
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Marufuku Ramen, you have made me a hopeless ramen-tic for you.

I don't think I've ever eaten a bowl of ramen faster. Honestly so good and comes out super fast. The Hakata DX is definitely the way to go. The broth is the right amount of spicy, the noodles is the right amount of firm, and the meat and other toppings were tender and delicious.

Don't worry about the wait - just join the waitlist on Yelp and they'll text you when your table's ready. ENJOY!!
author: Claire W.

description:
Location: Right in Japan town! Couldn't have ask for a better location. 
Food: I got the typical ramen without adding any additional toppings. It was a big bowl. Super filling and delicious! I think it was a little bit on the saltier side but... people got different palette! Overall it was very good. 
Service: The food came out relatively fast!
Tips: Make reservation through Yelp because it can takes a very long time. It was just the two of us on a Tuesday evening and we waited for about 1.5 hours.
author: Yuan Z.

description:
Without a doubt, Marufuku is one of the better ramen spots in the city!  I heart ramen and noodles in general but when rich, creamy broth is paired w/ thin ramen noodles, how can I not be a fan?!?  Even the Mr. who usually only likes thick noodles loves coming to Marufuku.

There is usually always a wait here but use your Yelp app to put your name down.  Super convenient!  The turnaround time is usually pretty quick here too, people are in and out pretty fast.  Service is always friendly and they really try their best to seat everyone in a timely manner.  I once even came with a big party of 15 and they were very accommodating.  While there was still a bit of a wait, they sat us altogether in a long table without having to split us up in their small restaurant.  That was super nice of them!

Whenever it is available, give their Paitan DX a try!  The extra few $ is worth it for a nice juicy chicken leg hot off of the sizzling platter.  Everything is very reasonably priced and tasty, we have never had any bad food/experience here.  Cheers!
author: Janetto L.

description:
This is our 1st time eating at this location 
The ramen dishes were very tasty an have very flavorful broth the pork belly definitely was delicious with the ramen and it extenuated the dish itself. The appetizers were also exceptional. I know that they have another restaurant like this in Oakland and I am definitely going to go to this one and make a comparison. I was very pleased with the attentive staff that welcomed us!
I shall return !
author: Gil P.

description:
I realllly love this place. We came right before they opened and there was already a pretty big line. They sat us down right away when they opened and served us water and gave us a few minutes to order before they asked what we wanted. I got the chicken ramen and my friend got the tonkatsu ramen. They were soooo good. I didn't expect a chicken broth to be so creamy. The chicken my ramen came with was also moist and crispy. I never had ramen like this before. Even the tonkatsu ramen was better than anything I had.

The waitresses were super efficient and knew exactly what to give their customers. The chefs were also just as impressive, if not more. We sat next to them and saw how quick they were in preparing the food. I wish this place had a bigger location to accommodate more people.
author: Jessa L.

description:
This is the best ramen in SF! So good that we go every weekend and all the workers know us by now :D We've tried the Marufuku in Oakland to compare (slightly less wait, prices are slightly lower which makes up for the bridge fare) which is similar but somehow the broth is just better at the original SF location.

The wait is a beast on the weekends. We recommend either getting to Marufuku 20-25 minutes before opening to wait in line (with about a 75% chance of getting first seating on the weekends with this method) or waiting until about 12PM when they open up the yelp waitlist and putting your name down and planning to arrive 1-2 hours after. Street parking is free on Sundays and plentiful in the late morning/early afternoon unless there is a festival or special event nearby. 

Hakata Tonkatsu HANDS DOWN! The broth is where the $$$ is at! It is really the best broth I have ever had, and as a ramen fan who has lived in Tokyo, New York, LA, and SF, I can safely tell you this is the BEST. The noodles are thin and vermicelli like which can be a disappointment for those who like thick al dente ramen noodles, but I think the thinness of the noodles soaks up the flavor of the amazing broth. The egg was initially inconsistent but for the last 4-5 visits has been consistently soft boiled with a runny yolk :) The pork is usually melt-in-your-mouth good, although once in a while it can be a bit chewy (I would say the consistency of the meat is about 50%). Since they opened over a year ago the consistency has gotten much better and recently we have had consistently perfect bowls of ramen (good broth, good meat, good egg).

The buta kakuni bowl and chicken katsu are also delish. The chicken paitan dx comes with a glazed grilled chicken quarter that is extremely moist and tasty - I don't know how they do that! I am sometimes tempted to order this again but I usually revert back to the tried and true Hatakta Tonkatsu ramen because the broth! The BROTH!
author: Michele L.

description:
Wanted to check out what the hype was about! My friend and I waited for about 30-40 minutes on a Friday noon time which was fine I'd expect it. Once we got our ramen, it smelled nice and looked aesthetically pleasing. The noodles were okay and the broth was good but definitely could have more flavor.

The takoyaki on the other hand was bomb! They were fresh out and I loved every single bite.
author: Yenni H.

description:
The broth is really good.  I got the tonkotsu ramen and really enjoyed it.

I came on a Tuesday for lunch as the place was PACKED.  I used yelp to get on the waiting list and the wait was a little over a half hour.  So put your name down, wonder around Japan town, and come back when you get a text.  

I did share a small table with another party because I was a solo diner.  Be prepared to do so if you're a smaller party.  I appreciate this because it cuts back on wait time.  

The food came super fast.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Okay, after a two hours wait and being the second last to be seated 22 minutes AFTER they closed....the wait is definitely worth it. Word to the wise, put yourself on their wait list ASAP on the Yelp App BEFORE you come....
Their broth is rich in taste but not salty, the Ramen is just "al dante" and very fresh. Their meat is cooked to perfection after perfectly marinated it. Their chicken CRUNCHY karage, perfectly seasoned and still very moist. Definitely a must try.
author: Christopher L.

description: Went 10 minutes before they opened on Saturday during lunch. Still had to wait about 20 minutes. Tonkotsu ramen was really good with really tasty and rich broth. Would definitely come back again
author: Nathan H.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here at 11:05, and there were already people waiting in line! Luckily, when this place opened up at 11:30, we were able to be a part of the first seating. 

I had the edamame and the tonkotsu ramen. The edamame was nice and warm. And the ramen was so good! The broth was so creamy and flavorful. And the noodles were cooked perfectly! The egg was a little over cooked, though. 

I would definitely come back, but I'm not sure if I'm willing to wait in line.
author: Rachel H.

description:
While my girlfriend and I were wandering and exploring Japantown, we came across one of the busiest ramen shops in SF. During the time we had the opportunity to put our names down and be one of the first to dine in for dinner, but we had no idea. Once we realized how popular this place was, it was a little too late and we had to wait around an hour-ish, but we had just eaten so it wasn't so bad to wait. The line gets backed up here FAST.

Anyway, fast forward to the important stuff: the food.

I was absolutely blown away by the bold and deep flavors immediately. The broth was packed with goodness and while normally I dislike thin ramen, it worked so well with everything that was going on in the bowl. The braised pork belly was so damn tender, the meat and fat would just melt the moment you bit into it. Altogether the bowl was just slammed with intense flavors.

We also ordered a rice bowl with braised pork belly. We really enjoy pork belly if you didn't notice by now. The rice bowl was great, the pork was a little dry, but still amazing nonetheless.

We also ordered karaage and takoyaki, both of which I only took a bite of. It was good and absolutely a safe appetizer option to go for if you're unsure of what to order.

Service was great, especially with how often the waitress had to refill my water (thanks). They should just do pint sized glasses so they wouldn't have to run around refilling so often.

While LA has some great ramen places to go to, the pork belly here is on a whole different level and unfortunately I won't be back to get any, probably for a VERY long time. Until then, I will always think of you. Every day. Love, Kurtis.
author: Kurtis C.

description:
Definitely the BEST Ramen noodle restaurant I have dined at and wish there was one close to my home.

The cool part was you can reserve a sport via the Yelp app, but need to be within 3 miles of the restaurant and this was a HUGE benefit as this place really does get crowded. Just login and reserve your spot and take your time getting there and bingo, you are on the list. They will call your name when ready.

I had the Hakata DX ramen with rich pork broth, braised pork belly, soft
boiled egg, corn, and deleted the green onions, kikurage mushroom and bean sprouts. I should have ordered extra pork as it was that good.

What a wonderful treat this place is....highly recommended.
author: Bill S.

description:
PRO-TIP: Join the waitlist via Yelp app before you come here. You'll thank me later :) Came at 6:30pm and the waitlist was already at 60+. You've been warned!

Had the Hakata Tonkotsu (12.99). Broth was silky and flavorful. If you like thin noodles, then this is your spot! Egg was half juicy just the way you'd want it to be and the slices of pork got the job done. 

Don't miss out if you're hanging out in Japantown!
author: Raymond W.

description:
FINALLY GOT TO TRY THIS PLACE & IT'S MY NEW FAVE RAMEN PLACE!

Be prepared to wait! There's usually a long wait, but we had a group of 5 on a Saturday. Got there 30 minutes before they opened for dinner at 4:30pm, and there was already a line. We still made it into the first round. Pro tip: there's a Yelp waitlist so you can add your name to that before you get there. It just won't be available until a bit after they open. I think they prioritize everyone already there waiting.

For the order- I got the Hakata Tonkatsu (spicy). The Hakata DX is just with a bigger chunk of meat & corn. They also have an ultra spicy, and I would totally be down to opt in for that next time. It kinda reminds me of the spicy in the ramen in Japan. SO GOOD. The noodles were thin, a little more firm that I usually like, but still good. The egg was beautiful and cooked to perfection. The pork was a bit salty, soy based. The pickled ginger is ehhh. Lastly, the broth was made with perfection - pork based. I enjoyed this meal A LOT.

The water we got was fruit infused, yum. 

Anyways, if there wasn't always a wait, I'd come here all the time!!! It's literally my new fave place for ramen and I'm not even a huge ramen fan, so I think this says a lot! It's comparable to Ichiran in Japan I would say!
author: Melody W.

description:
I had this place on my list of places to eat at when in SF. Since my boyfriend is not really a ramen person, I was not intending to go here but we were wandering around Japan town and saw the line before it was open and decided to hop in. We were probably close to the 20th person in line and managed to be the last people sat down for the first round. We had to share the big table with another couple who had been seated right before us but that was no big deal.

Since I was not planning on eating here, I had to do my research pretty quickly on what people liked most and what to order. I think it was because I had not eaten before this that I decided to order the Chicken Karrage on top of the ramen. The Chicken Karrage was juicy and flavorful. If you are a fan of this dish normally, it is something I would consider ordering but probably not something I would order again unless craving fried chicken.

For the main dishes, we ordered the HAKATA DX and the CHICKEN PAITAN DX. I feel like when something on the menu says limited servings, obviously your eyes wander there. The grilled chicken on the side came out first and it smelled and looked super good. It was on a sizzling plate so that made it look even more delicious. The meat just fell off the bone, was super flavorful and had so much flavor. I would recommend ordering that dish just for the chicken on the side.

The broth from the CHICKEN PAITAN DX was our favorite out of the two ramen dishes. It was exactly like described on the menu, rich and full of flavor. It was creamy and smooth and I literally could go back for this probably every week. The HAKATA DX had the pork broth which was also good but it was definitely more rich and more salty. The noodles were a mix between firm and soft, more on the soft side. If you like firmer noodles, you may want to see if they can cook them a little less.

This place is worth the hype; especially if you are a ramen lover. Get there early before it opens if you want a seat at first round. Otherwise go there whenever and put your name on the list and wander around Japan town.
author: Emily J.

description: Absolutely terrible service. Never leave your Friday date night plans in the hands of unacceptably rude and clueless servers
author: Rosstin A.

description: This place is awesome.. great food, great service. Ramen is excellent. The best ramen for sure.
author: Carlos H.

description: Best ramen. Really good ramen. Love this place for ramen. If you're looking for ramen in San Francisco, look no further!
author: E T.

description:
This is just based off of one experience. I'm not from the area, so I haven't tried other ramen places for comparison. Some people say this is the best ramen in the area and that may be true, but for me, it definitely wasn't worth the 2 hr wait. I definitely had better ramen (I'm from Dallas, TX) and at a more reasonable price too. This place just seems overrated - waiting 2-3 hrs for a bowl of noodles. 
We ordered a chicken based ramen and a tonkatsu ramen. The tonkatsu was delicious - broth was rich and meaty (but not in a oily, gross way). The chicken one was a little too salty for my taste and doesn't offer the same richness compared to the pork one. We got a beer as well and all together the bill came to a hefty ~$45. 
Of course, give this place a try if you never had gourmet ramen. Remember that you don't actually have to be at the restaurant to get on the waitlist - put your name down through yelp!!
author: Lily Z.

description: The Haiata Tonkotsu was one of the best ramens I've had, broth was very tasteful without being over powering, and noodles had the right chew to them.
author: Kelly C.

description: WOW. SO GOOD. I got in line on Yelp at like 5:30 on a weeknight, was given an arrival time of 7, got there at 7, and then had to wait about an additional hour before being seated. But - the ramen was actually great enough to be worth that hassle.
author: Catherine S.

description:
A two and half hour long wait? Yeah, I'll do it. I've done crazier things. Like watching a Future concert -- totally, undeniably crazy, because he sucked. 

It was worth the wait. I've tried both the Chicken Paitan and Tontkotsu, at the behest of my best friend, who swears that the Paitan gave her food poisoning. Both splendid, but I have to give it to the Tonkotsu. Thicc like there's no tomorrow, like every day is squat day. And she goes to the gym more than I do. 

I know the big selling point that everyone talks about is the pork belly. I would say that I've had better pork bellies -- it fell apart in kind of a strange way and seemed slightly stringy/dry. However, the corn -- the kikurage mushrooms -- even the ginger on top (and I despise ginger) -- swirling in this broth gave me more delight than a kid on a merry-go round. The broth is pretty salty, but not absurdly so. The flavors are hard to pinch out at times when you're absolutely destroying everything at once. Not as flavorful as Ichiran's, but then again, nothing holds a candle to Ichiran.
author: Celena C.

description:
1st time trying Japanesse Ramen.... sooooo good!!! Wait was appx 1.5hrs.... 42 guest before me... we shopped around the mall meantime. 

Food is served appx 5m after ordering. Customer service is quick and efficient.
author: Vero M.

description:
SHORT VERSION:
I am serious about good Ramen and among all the new authentic ramen shops popping up in the Bay Area, I think Marufuku serves the best bowl.  Everything about the ramen (Hakata Tonkotsu) is perfect - from the broth to the noodles (thinner than most shops) to the charsiu, the ramen egg and the extra Buta Kakuni I ordered. Pack your patience but the food is definitely worth the wait.  I also ordered their takoyaki and geso fry (squid legs) as appetizers and their rice bowls to go.  Everything tasted great and authentic. Prices are very reasonable and service was good once you are seated. Highly recommended!!!

LONG VERSION:
I've been wanting to go to Marufuku Ramen for a long time but have always been discouraged by the scores of people waiting in line (and they don't take reservations). I decided to suck it up and line up around 10 minutes before they opened for Sunday lunch.  

When I arrived, the line was already very long but it's shorter than most nights so I stuck it out. I did not make the first seating (11:30 am) but ended up number 8 on the waitlist.  There is an iPad out front where people can sign up and the service (via yelp) texted and called you when your table is about 5 minutes away.  You can actually join the waitlist via the yelp app as well (noted for next time).  I was seated around 12:20 pm (an hour after I initially lined up). 

I ordered a couple of the small bites (takoyaki and geso fry) and the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen with extra Buta Kakuni.  Food came out relatively quickly (within 10 minutes) and it was just perfect. All of the aggravation of lining up and waiting evaporated as soon as I had a sip of that broth. Every element of it was just perfect - broth, charsiu, kakuni, noodles and ramen egg. The geso fry and takoyaki were great too.  I also ordered four of their rice bowls to go (they are small but the prices are really affordable and I want to go on a diet).  

Prices are really affordable and the service was good once I was seated (my water glass was always full).  Highly recommended!!!
author: Andrew S.

description:
There is usually a line of people waiting for the doors to open so they can enjoy a bowl of Hakata ramen. You won't be disappointed when you sit down to a meal here. It's a nice get away when you don't have the time to jet off to Japan for a bowl of ramen.

Hakata Tonkatsu - Hakata Style Ramen with Rich Pork Broth. Chashu Pork (Simmered Pork Belly), Seasoned Soft Boiled Egg, Green Onions, Kikurage Mushrooms, and Bean Sprouts. ($12.99)

Hakata Deluxe - Buta Kakuni (Braised Thick Pork Belly), Chashu Pork (Simmered Pork Belly), Seasoned Soft Boiled Egg, Green Onions, Kikurage Mushrooms, Bean Sprouts, Sweet Corn, and Nori Seaweed. ($16.

Takoyaki - octopus balls - 5 pieces ($7)

One of the best places for ramen in SF. Check it out!
author: Kristina S.

description:
I've had my eye on this spot located inside of the mall in San Francisco's Japan Town and finally got a chance to try it! We had the karage chicken bowl and tokotsu ramen. The chicken was cooked perfectly: very juicy and flavorful on the inside with a crisp outer layer. Only thing is I wish the bowl had a more proportionate chicken-to-rice ratio (with more chicken, of course). The ramen was pretty much what we expected: savory and delicious  thin noodles, boiled egg, char Su, and whatever add-ons you like. 

Once you get past the massive line (we got there about 35 mind before it opened and there were already people lining up), the restaurant is small and modern. 

I thought this place lived up to the hype. Just make sure you get there before it opens and/or plan to do something else while you wait. Would love to come back and try something else here.
author: Kelli N.

description:
A place that doesn't really need an introduction, touted by some as the best ramen in the city, I showed up 30 minutes before opening for dinner on a Wednesday and wasn't even the first in line. The hype is real.

FOOD:
Tonkatsu ramen. Almost exactly what you would expect. Bouncy, chewy ramen. Heavy, but more milky than anything broth, with big pork flavor. Mildly spicy if you order it that way. The pork pieces, fatty, soft, and flavorful. Very good, but not great.

As for the chicken, I felt like I got sucked into the hype when I saw other people ordering it and it came out on this sizzling hot plate. While it was good, it really wasn't anything special or that novel. You could compare it to a viet five spice chicken, but it is slightly different. It's a bit sweeter. Either way, it's a crispy on the outside and moist and flavorful on the inside. Still very good.

Service was good and food came out at a decent pace. I'm not sure how long I would wait in the line for, as I'm sure the wait is often upwards of an hour if you don't get there for the first seating. It is good ramen, and more and more, waiting more than an hour looks like the price you must pay for ramen of this quality. At least you don't have to physically wait in line here (just sign up on their tablet).
author: Bryant C.

description:
FIVE FREAKIN STARS!

Here's the quick read: Get there early (and you may still have to wait), read the menu while waiting in line, get extra of your favorite toppings, eat and enjoy the best ramen in SF.

I like the Hakata Tonkotsu, but from what I've seen and heard, you can't really go wrong. Haters will say that it's overhyped, but finding good ramen in SF is like finding a needle in a haystack, so I think this is worth taking a trip for.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Marafuku had some reeeally tasty ramen. I wouldn't call myself a ramen snob, but i'm definitely a little picky when it comes to a good bowl of noodles!

My friends and I all ordered the Hakata DX ramen, which seems to be the same as the normal Hakata ramen with the addition of corn and a FAT piece of pork belly. I'm not sure if that's worth the extra $4, but go big or go home I guess! The hakata-style ramen is made with thin, straight noodles instead of chewy, curly noodles like you may be used to at other ramen shops. I like hakata stlye because of the milkiness of the broth, without getting too rich where it's hard to finish. The pork belly was very tender and had an average amount of fat.

We also ordered the chicken karaage on the side, and although it wasn't the crunchiest chicken karaage i've had, it was definitely the juiciest! It seemed like the chicken was dark meat so I appreciated the tenderness.

I was pretty impressed with Marafuku! Unfortunately I heard the line gets really long, but I definitely want to come back and try the Chicken paitan DX ramen. We lined up at around 4:30 pm (opens at 5) and we were seated with the first parties.
author: Tara A.

description:
Why is the line so long?

I much prefer Hinodeya down the street, their bowls are a lot more exciting (flavor-wise) and the wait is 1/10th of the time.  The ramen here is decent, and I guess worth getting if you only have to wait a couple minutes.  Otherwise, I don't think I would eat here again.  The paitan and tonkotsu are pretty standard.  The toppings are kind of plain (especially if you get the paitan), unless you order the DX which will be about $4 extra.  

Tips and Tricks:
-If you're one of those San Franciscans who need to wait in line to know something is good, go to Mensho instead.  To skip the wait, head to Hinodeya
-You can put your name on the waiting list online 
-Chicken karaage is skipable
-"Spicy" isn't really all that spicy
author: Jessica L.

description:
Coming from Los Angeles I thought there would be tons of really good ramen places in SF, but that hasn't been the case. However, Marufuku is hands down my favorite ramen spot in SF, so far. I prefer tonkotsu style ramen and this place has some seriously creamy and flavorful pork broth without being overly fatty. The noodles are the thin straight kind, which I also prefer over the kinky thick noodle, mainly because I feel that the thinner straight noodles deliver more flavorful broth to your mouth. The pork itself is tender and melts in your mouth. The egg is perfectly cooked, lightly seasoned, and sits at the bottom of the bowl like a treasure waiting to be uncovered. If tonkotsu ramen is not your thing, they also serve chicken paitan. 

The only downside to Marufuku is the wait. You can join the waitlist on the Yelp app ahead of time, but still be prepared to wait. I will also note that when you're on the wait list you'll get a call telling you to check in and that your table is ready and the Yelp app will indicate that there is nobody else ahead of you, but be prepared to wait another 15-30 min.
author: Sara P.

description:
BUSY!  Put on a waitlist and worth it.  1/2 later I as seated at a community table since as it was just me for lunch.  No problem!  Ordered the chicken patay ramen.  Really, really rich broth and yummy ingredients s. Only two pieces of chicken though.

Still good!
author: Susan C.

description:
My favorite ramen in SF. Their ramen broth is always piping hot!

The first time we came we made the mistake of getting the paitan dx because it looked cool. Well let me tell you it is just a big piece of (delicious) grilled chicken.

Tonkotsu all the way!!! Broth is delicious and the noodles are the perfect texture.
author: Michelle R.

description: Are you kidding me?? The BEST RAMEN  I've ever had in my life!! This is a MUST VISIT when in SFO...come visit Japantown! It is so quaint & the food is astounding. How can ramen be so good? It has FRESH broth, almost miso but tasty like chicken broth. They add scallions & these deliciously thin mushrooms. And you let them know how spicy. Finally, they top it off with FRESHLY GRILLED chicken breast cut into trips. The flavor combinations are perfect!! Well worth the 30 minute walk from Union Sq.  Hint: Their online waiting system on Yelp is weird. It almost always takes longer than posted. Be there on time though, or you lose your spot! And be ready to sit next to another group!!!
author: Shawn W.

description:
The food is wonderful. It is 5 stars. 
We tried the Takoyaki, chicken paitan and hakata deluxe. Everything is delicious. 

But the service is bad. The waitress is very rude to me. When we ordered the food, the waitress is serious and nasty. LIn addition, there is no water for me even after ordering food until I request it from another waitress. I just gave around 10% tip Then I found out the restaurant charged me several dollars more to match 15%. It is not a big amount. I am not sure they did it on purchase or by accident. Anyway, if I visit here again, I will pay attention to the receipts.

Besides the personal negative experience above, welcome to come and try the food if you are a ramen lover! u u
author: Xuan Z.

description: The best ramen in San Francisco. I am here for the week and I are here three times for lunch. Get here early, right when they open. The Hakata Tonkatsu is worth every penny.
author: Beth P.

description:
4.5/5

After two attempts at conquering the long line extending from Marufuku, my friend finally decided that [today] was the day. Our party arrived 30 minutes before opening for dinner and fortunately were the first ones in line on that weekend! :D We waited just a quick (honestly... 30 is short compared to what other ppl have to go through) wait, we were promptly seated and handed the menu. Then came the second hardest part of the Marufuku experience... deciding what to get.

Marufuku really offers you just two choices for ramen (+ a XL version of each). I don't know what it is about small menus like these, but decisions are just SO hard to make because you don't want to regret having one over the other... but you also know for sure that BOTH are going to be good. Of the pork belly or chicken ramen, I got the chicken ramen.. XL version of course.

My foodcame with the standard chicken ramen as well as a chicken leg on a sizzling plate. 

First off, the egg was ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE. It was seasoned SOSOSO well and was the PERFECT runniness. Not a hint of "hard-boiled"ness which was actually crazy, considering the egg was served whole (therefore making it prone to being uncontrollably cooked in the ramen too). I would come back and just order a bunch of extra eggs in my ramen if cholesterol wasn't a problem... honest!

The broth was also very nice. Not too salty and very flavourful. The noodles were a nice level of firmness and size. My only complaint would be the chicken leg. I didn't think the XL was really worth because I found the chicken leg to be noticeable overcooked and lacking flavour. The subtle hints of barbecue flavour that was coating the chicken didn't really compliment the savoriness of the broth.

Overall, very happy with my experience here! No wonder it's so popular :) Can't imagine what it would be like to wait longer than we did though.
author: Monica X.

description:
I highly recommend the Hakata DX pork ramen. I chose Medium spicy which is more like mild, so will probably get Spicy next time. The thin noodles are perfectly firm and had a great texture. When eaten with a spoonful of the bean sprouts, kikurage mushroom, braised pork belly and pork broth, you get a mouthful of flavors and textures that will leave you satisfied. The pork belly was great and they did not skimp out on the size of it. I do wish there were more noodles than bean sprouts. Overall the bowl is large and very filling. Don't forget there is a soft boiled egg in there which is on the bottom of the bowl. The egg was good as expected. I dare say their ramen is up to par to the likes of Ippudo if not a little better.

The structure in the center of the restaurant is strange and doesn't seem to make good use of space. Can probably fit more tables without the structure in the way. I was quite uncomfortable sitting there as there is no back rest and I had to climb over the seating in order to sit down. I can imagine if someone was wearing a dress/skirt it'd be an issue. 

There is a deceiving waitlist option on their yelp page however you actually can't place yourself on the waitlist through the app. You have to physically go to the restaurant to put your name and phone number down via their yelp kiosk that is located in front. The nice thing is you can walk away and shop while monitoring your place in line from the yelp app so you know when you should start heading back. Once you receive a text that you're next make sure to check in with the host within 5 mins or you'll lose your place in line. I waited about an hour with 24 parties ahead of me after joining the waitlist a few mins after 11:30am on Saturday.
author: Donna M.

description:
It almost hurts writing this because I REALLY wanted to love this place. 

Tried both the tonkotsu and paitan ramen. The broths were excellent. Rich without feeling too heavy; complex and flavorful without being too salty. The noodles are thin but were still perfectly cooked with just the right amount of chewiness.

The problem is that there's just too much going on in the way of additions. It's a perfect example of how the Americanization of other cultures can turn a beautiful thing into a chaotic mess. Somehow we've gotten to think that you can always make something better just by adding more things to it. It's really my own fault for ordering the "deluxe" versions of each dish. The pure ramen itself is great, but in the menu's current form, you end up instead with a cacophony of corn, multiple flavors of meat, way too many vegetables, and nothing to really focus on. If I ever come back, I'll order the plain ramen. Hopefully I'll be able to update this review then too.
author: N. L.

description: Best ramen I've had in my entire life.  We have ramen places in the 'burbs, and they're decent, but this place is in another league.  I was worried because my husband usually gets pissed at me for wanting to try out highly rated yelp restaurants.  We had a 1.5 hour wait, and we showed up on a Friday right at opening.  This restaurant was on point because my husband acknowledged this place was worth the wait and the broth and the noodles were excellent.  I also appreciated that this place had a chicken option and I would recommend the chicken karaage.
author: L. M.

description:
The entire wait - order - serve - bill process was also impressively quick and efficient. From sitting down to leaving (we didn't even eat that fast), it was about 30 min. The table next to us were the same speed. 

Get your spot on Yelp or at the door and get updated on your place in line. As soon as you sit down, you get a menu. A minute after your order, your food is served. As you finish your food, the check is sent over. 

We got one spicy ramen and one mild spicy ramen. The mild didn't taste spicy at all! Haha next time I'm trying the medium spicy. 

1. I loved the amount of kikurage mushroom and bean sprouts! It was so much! I like to get some bean sprouts and some mushroom to go with very bite of my noodles, but most places never give me enough to last till the end of the noodles. Marufuku gives the perfect amount! 

2. The broth was rich in flavor - the broth looked very very milky - but not texturally thick and amazingly not too salty or oily like at many other ramen places. I almost drank all of it. 

3. The simmered pork belly was pretty unique. It was cut pretty thin and a bit chewy. I wished there was more! 

4. The noodles were pretty thin - big reason why they were cooked and served so quickly. 

5. The red pickled ginger root is actually a unique topping of Hakata style ramen - the spiciness really added some zing to the mild-tasting soup.
author: Iris H.

description: Wow. One of better ramen places out there. Broth is super rich and deep. Flavors meshed very well together. And everything cooked super well. Although I felt a little rushed by wait staff, it was understandable since there was a line of 60+ people outside. We lucked out and got there before they opened and only waited 12 mins. The places is not large but they do have a couple tables that seat parties of 6 or 8. Anything larger you should go elsewhere. Highly recommend!
author: George W.

description: Very yummy although probably not worth the wait! They use thinner noodles which I liked, but my boyfriend didn't. It didn't super impress me over other ramen places with less wait time. Fun vibe though!
author: Valerie F.

description:
Well well! I had a ramen craving and I wanted to try this place! Be sure to put your name on wait list on Yelp! That can save time! It may be an hour or so wait but you can walk around and explore.

I got the hakata Tonkatsu ramen (ultra spicy). I'll be honest, it wasn't spicy lol but it was good! The broth was so so rich! The noodles were perfect and the pork...that was so delicious! I loved every aspect of it! It had a delicious flavor  and it was so tender. The egg was also perfectly cooked! It had a slightly runny center but it was perfect!

Inside it had some mushrooms and pickled ginger. Overall, super satisfied! I'd definitely check this place out again.
author: Natalie M.

description:
I visited Marufuku Ramen last weekend, there was a long line outside the restaurant and at first me and another friend had decided to try other places instead but soon after one of their staff told us there were two seats available so we got in and had water while we were still checking the menu (Their great and efficient customer services were the first thing that I noticed ).
                We ordered the first and the second Ramens from the menu and it took about 10 mins we finally had our Ramens，Thin flour noodle which is the real tradition noodle (拉面) that I am looking for and the their thick broth which is good but for me I was a little bit salty, but overall it tasted really really good. 
                 I am very appreciated their staffs they are very great! Definitely will come back next time and I highly recommend this place.
author: Weng C.

description:
There's always a line/waitlist, but it is worth it! Time goes by pretty quickly when you walk around Japantown. It is by far the best ramen I have ever tasted! The noodles are different from the ramen I usually get, but to super good! I came here twice and each time the ramen was perfect! My boyfriend wants to eat here everyday. The service was also quick! 
When people ask me what I would recommend them to try in San Francisco, I would tell them to come here.
author: Elaine G.

description:
The wait is definitely a thing at Marufuku -- we arrived around 4:50 on a Sunday, and there was already a line! It took maybe 20 minutes for us to get a table, but they have a yelp waitlist you can enter your information in so you are free to walk around and explore the mall! 

Once we were sat, I knew pork belly was on my mind . I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen with medium spice and ate it so fast. Holy crap, it was good. The pork belly melts in your mouth and the flavors out of the broth were incredible. 

I'm already drooling just thinking about this ramen, and am so excited to go back! 

The restaurant is nicely decorated, with a modern Japanese aesthetic. The lighting is dim, food is good, making it a great date night spot. Their beer can be a little pricey, however, so if you're looking for a good brew, be prepared to spend over $10 for a beer!
author: Cecilia C.

description:
After exploring some of the shops in Japantown Peace Plaza, we made our way upstairs to the bookstore.  Nearby we couldn't help but notice the growing line at Marafuku Ramen... this was 15 minutes before the place actually opened up!  Our curiosity led to a quick Yelp check resulting in us our decision to get in line as well.

Soon Marafuku opened and as we neared the front, suddenly the line stopped.  The restaurant was at capacity and we ended up using their electronic device (with the Yelp reservation app) to get on the wait list.  The device synched us with Yelp and it continually updated us with our position in the queue.  With the app we were able to enter the bookstore to kill a little time.  We eventually made our way back to the restaurant when we were #2 in the queue.

The overall wait time was probably 30 minutes.  We were seated, handed menus and served water.  The menu is small, so it took very little time for us to decide what we were going to order.  After seeing that there was a limited serving of (15) Chicken Paitan DX with grilled chicken on the side, we knew that was our choice!  The wifey was content sharing the ramen with me and we ended up getting 2 orders of takoyaki to complete our order.  We had visited B  patisserie that morning, so we weren't super hungry.

The Chicken Paitan DX had a rich white "paitan" broth, chicken chashu, corn, green onions, kikurage mushroom, bean sprouts, a boiled egg and they serve a delicious side of grilled chicken on top of that.  The broth had a milky white color (I believe that's what "paitan" means) and really nice depth of flavor... rich, creamy, meaty, very satsifying!

It was my first time having paitan broth and it was extremely good!  The chicken chashu melted in my mouth and had very nice flavor.  The ramen tasted fresh and was perfectly cooked.  Each bite was a heavenly mixture of textures and flavors and every ingredient complimented the others.  And just when you thought it couldn't get any better, you take a bite of that grilled chicken that's super tender, has that nice charred grilled flavor and boom, you're on another level!  Hands down the best ramen I've ever had.

The takoyaki while good wasn't as good as what we've had here in San Diego.  The restaurant was nice and clean with a nice modern design.  Service was very great (very friendly), our waitress and another checked on us several times.  So the price was high compared to San Diego (I think it was $15.99 or $16.99 for that bowl)... but it seems the price of food in general is a little higher here in San Francisco.

The ramen was worth the wait!  Definitely a must go if you are a ramen lover!

4 / 5 - Takoyaki
5 / 5 - Ramen
5 / 5 - Cleanliness
5 / 5 - Service

5 / 5 - Overall
author: Calvin N. H.

description: Hands down one of my favorite ramen spots. Very flavorful and the service is great! Only thing I recommend is getting there 30 minutes early because a big line starts forming since it's so popular.
author: Joe B.

description:
Probably the best ramen I've had in the U.S.

The Yelp online waitlist is brilliant. I bet it saves the host/hostess plenty of manual work and headache. Also gives folks a chance to join the waitlist distance away and ahead of time. The progress of how many parties ahead of me is also nice to see. This is a win-win for the restaurant and customers. 

Ordered the Hakata DX (Deluxe) with a premium Sapporo draft. The broth was flavorful, but a bit on the rich/sweet side. The noodle itself reminded me of ramen I had in Japan, particularly Ichiran, but the broth was different. The pork belly was fat and tasty. I was very satisfied with my ramen. Although this still cannot beat ramen in Japan, it at least reminded me of Japan ramen. Also, I was actually full after the meal (well, with a big glass of beer). Shoot, after spending $24 on ramen and beer, I'd better be full! Lol

If I'm ever in Japantown and I have time, I'd definitely visit again. Wish we had more ramen places like this.
author: Lon H.

description:
My husband wants to know if there is a 6-star rating? We checked in on Yelp wait list then spent lots of time in the stationary store and went to check-in at Marmaduke when Yelp said we should (or lose our place in line!) BUT it turns out that you only go when they text/call. It took 90-minutes and we were so happy to get in at all! 

Now for the food: the broth was perfectly well-balanced and had a depth of flavor I had not experienced before. The octopus balls were exactly as I remembered them from street carts in Kyoto! 

I loved Japantown and look forward to our next to trip!
author: Adrienne S.

description:
By chance, we decided to walk around Japantown in the afternoon having eaten an early breakfast, and a 5pm dinner didn't seem ridiculous. By 4:10 on a Saturday afternoon, there was already about five people lined up outside the restaurant. Since I happened to have a magazine, I decided it wouldn't be too ridiculous to get in line, so at 4:25, I lined up and was sixth in line. In my mind, I seriously doubted the wait could be that long.

Around 4:45, I finally lifted my head and turned around and was shocked to find out that a HUGE line had formed, at least 50 deep, behind me. Doors opened at 5:00, we were all seated quickly, and my girlfriend and I each got a tonkatsu ramen and shared a kaarage.

Broth is saltier than I like, but decent. Pork was really good, extremely flavorful. Service was great, constant refills of chilled cucumber ice water. Naturally the tables were super tight, practically eating on top of one another. Beautiful decor inside. The only thing is we left the plaza feeling really bad for the other much emptier ramen spots that had been filled with people years ago.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Best Ramen in SF.

Best Karaage in SF.

Use the Yelp app waitlist at least 1 hour before you wish to eat; it is magic!

Incredible!
author: Leslie G.

description: I made sure to get in line early before they opened and by the time the doors opened the line was pretty long, so plan to wait. We enjoyed the broth and their pork belly was outstanding and well as the chicken that comes with the big chicken ramen. The downside for me is that their noodles are nothing special.
author: Andrea Y.

description: Medium Spicy ramen with pork and hard boiled egg really very good tasting the broth was delicious and noodles perfect pork tender I like ramen & this place is a must try also had Hitachino nest beer go's well With ramen , might have a short wait but it's well worth it .
author: Aaron B.

description:
Probably the best ramen in SF, and I live above one of the most popular ones in lower Nob Hill.  My friend actually recommended this place or I would never have known about it.  The wait was fairly long, approximately 40-45 minutes for us.  We were also almost last on the list if not dead last on the list even though there were other parties who came after us.  It may have to do with seating space as we were a party of 4 and the others were a party of 2 so it would have been easier to seat.

I got the regular tonkatsu ramen and customized it with corn and a few other toppings that I wanted.  It's going to vary by taste but that's what makes this pretty awesome.

Tonkatsu Rame (amplified):
PROS:
- great broth: not overly salty, not overly thick either so you don't get ridiculously full off the liquid, not super oily
- good selection of additional toppings but as with most ramen places, this can usually up your bill
- cha siu pork was not dry, nice thick cut
- ramen was not soggy or overcooked.  
- generous with ingredients: I can't stand large bowls, too much soup and noodle but the toppings have clearly been skimped out on.
CONS:
none --- I will have to say, for those of you who are large eaters, one bowl will keep you comfortable but probably not full.  I don't see this as a con because well, health.  ALSO, for eating purposes, it allows you to share the appetizers amongst the rest of the table (or get your own if you really wanted to try any one particular one).

Definitely worth it and definitely coming back again.
author: Vera L.

description:
OVERALL: Very good ramen, pretty heavy broth if you have the room for it, and the noodles are great texture. However, the wait is crazy! You gotta plan ahead, come before the open, or it seems you're pretty much screwed.

THE WAIT: I got there at 10:45am (they open at 11:30am) on a Sunday and was the first in line. I was by myself for 5-10 minutes, when a huge crowd suddenly appeared behind me. Probably if you get there by 11:10am or so, you'll still make it in the first seating wave. They also have very quick service; we had ordered, gotten our food, eaten, and were out within 30 minutes of them opening. 

THE FOOD:
* Hakata Tonkotsu ($11.99) - 4.5 stars
Fantastic fatty meat. Great heavy broth.

* Chicken Paitan ($11.99) - 4 stars
Broth honestly tasted the same as the Hakata to me! The chicken is tender, less fatty than the Hakata, so a good option if you want something slightly lighter.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I passed by Marufuku on a Sunday afternoon before they were opened and one of the employees told me to come back no later than 4:30pm if we wanted to get seated immediately upon opening. 

I did just that and there was already a good line forming down the plaza.
We waited 30 minutes for them to open and got seated immediately. The restaurant itself is pretty small but very trendy. I ordered the HAKATA TONKOTSU and made it spicy. Not even 5 minutes later our order came out. 

The broth is good, not too salty and oily like some ramen places. Spiciness was not really there, so go for Ultra spicy if you want more spice. 

The pork was really good, nice and tender... very flavorful. I was not the biggest fan of the noodles they used, but that's alright. 

All and in all, good ramen spot, but definitely come early if you dont want to wait.
author: Milton F.

description:
Tried this on a Saturday Morning after hiking in the city and it hit the spot!

Wait: Queued in line at 11am, which seemed like about 15 or so people in front of us. Restaurant opened at 11:30am and our party of 3 was seated within 5 minutes. Seemed like 30 guests could be seated at once. After tables were all seated, host directed guests to tablet and instructed to stay idle once they were paged/notified.

Service: Once we were sat, the host placed menus down. A server greeted us and took down our drink order immediately and offered us a few minutes to look over the menu. Server came back and took down our orders. I asked for stiff noodles and the server didn't understand so she came back to clarify what stiff meant: hard or soft. After responding, "hard Noodles, please," server thanked me and rushed back to the kitchen. We received our appetizer, chicken karaage within about 5-10 mins. After we devoured the chicken, server cleared our small plates and we got our ramen shortly after (5-10 mins). Loved the water refill!

Food:
*Chicken Karaage (5/5)- Perfect ratio of batter to meat with the right condiments to match. Lemon wedge added an explosion of flavor when squeezed on to the chicken; also, the mayo mellowed out the zest--together with the chicken, a very special combination.
*Hakata Tonkatsu (4/5)- Great amount of Ingredients (pork belly, mushrooms, bean sprouts, radish topping) that really make the ramen stand out. My only concern is the amount of saturation/richness of the soup. It felt like halfway into eating the bowl, my stomach felt heavy because of the amount of sodium or oils in the broth. The thin (hakata style) noodles made up for it in a way.

Overall, a downright undeniable experience for your mouth and stomach! Highly recommend to try for ramen fans!

Beware: Only Chicken Paitan has a low serving count daily (15?) but do arrive early as soon as the restaurant opens. Lines are fairly long similar to queuing for ramen shops in Japan.
author: May A.

description:
This place is just the best in San Francisco! It is worth the wait!The Chicken Paitan DX - you need to ask for this, but it is so delicious.The broth is delicate and bright.The chicken is served in a sizzling pan on the side and has a rich glaze.

The Hakata DX with extra braised pork is unbeatable.The broth is rich and flavorful and the meat is so tender but perfectly marbled. 

Ramen is what they do well and the appetizers are all very good but the ramen is the main star!
author: melissa l.

description:
Come here hungry, but not too hungry. You'll have to wait for a spot (likely an hour during peak lunch/dinner hours) in this highly rated and conveniently placed ramen shop, but it was definitely worth the wait -- especially if you've browsed around for an hour in Japantown waiting and growing hungrier by the second.

The PRO:
- Clean, modern ambiance. The matching wooden tables/benches create the coziest of atmospheres! It's a place I'd consider bringing my mom if I wanna impress her for lunch haha.
- You're gonna have to wait for a seat here... there's no getting around that, but atleast you're in Japantown with all the cool bookstores, daiso, and cutesy shops/arcades to visit! They will also give you a heads up text when you're close to the front of the line.
- Such pretty presentation of the ramen and the sides @__@.
- Ramen broth - both the chicken and pork XDs were flavorful and had a nice umami/depth. Also loved how perfectly chewy and slippery their noodles were ... ugh *drools

The MEH:
- Nothing I can think of atm. Maybe just the wait, but it hasn't been that bad.
author: Vy T.

description:
OMG! Hands down the best ramen I've ever had! No ands. Ifs, or buts about it!! 

Awesome! We waited on the waitlist w 35 parties ahead of us!  Well worth the wait. 

You can get on the waitlist before you arrive to save on time!!
author: David M.

description:
tldr; BEST RAMEN EVER OMG

As I stood in Marufuku's 2 hour line on a Saturday night, my expectations weren't *that* high. I've already tried Ippudo + Ichiran, how good can this ramen be?

Answer: IT CAN BE VERY GOOD.

My friend ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu and I ordered the Hakata DX. The Hakata DX had a deeper, more complex broth, and had braised pork belly instead of simmered pork belly.

First off, the Hakata DX broth was a beautiful golden color. It was so thick, rich, complex, full of porky flavors and complex spices that you can literally not see through the broth. Definitely the most complex ramen broth I've ever had. They also give you a lot of al-dente, thin ramen noodles that grabbed the broth perfectly.

Next off, the braised pork belly. THIS WAS THE BEST PIECE OF PORK BELLY THAT I'VE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE. Literally falling apart as I was trying to pick it up with my chopsticks, there were so many flavors packed into the many layers of fat and lean meat. The extra $5 for the braised pork belly vs simmered pork belly is definitely worth it.

Next time you're in Japantown, you have to give this place a shot! It'll blow your socks off!
author: Cassie Z.

description:
There is always a very long wait, however it's great that you can put your name down...go meander around the mall, and even if you miss your name, they can still seat your party when you get back!

DINNER
Hakata dx, mild- I decided to splurge for the fancy pork.  I really enjoyed the quality of the broth and meat, however I found the noodles to be weird because they were very thin.  I am a fan of fat noodles, so these threw me off.

4.5 stars for Marufuku...it just may be my favorite ramen place in the city?  Still undecided because of the noodles, but it is a strong contender.
author: Lyn C.

description:
A cozy spot in Japantown that serves some of the best ramen in the city. There's often a long wait during lunch time. There's a reason why this place is hyped. 

When you arrive, you can sign up on an electronic wait list. You will be served pretty quickly once you are seated and have ordered. The restaurant inside feels clean and has pretty simple decor. The restaurant is not large, so you will be sitting at arm's length (a comfortable arm's length) to the people next to you. The Tonkotsu ramen is the signature dish - you can't go wrong with it. Prices are very reasonable for high quality ramen. 

I've only been to Marufuku during lunchtime, although I'm sure they're just as busy in the evenings. Use the Yelp app 30-45 minutes before you arrive to cut down on your wait time. This is critical. 30 seconds of forethought can save you 30-45 minutes of wait time within that same hour.
author: Chris W.

description: Some of the best Ramen I've ever had. I would've never found this place if it wasn't for Yelp! It's tucked away on the top floor of a small mall in Japantown. Thank god for Nowait because you can just put your name on the list and there's always a wait. They give you enough Ramen for like 2 people. I also had the fried squid legs which were amazing. If you love Ramen and haven't been here then you have not lived!
author: jason k.

description:
The HAKATA deluxe is definitely my favorite ramen on the menu.  The braised pork belly is so rich in flavor that enhances the bland noddle (perfect combination).  Their broth is rich without being too fatty and greasy.

Luckily for us, we got in without the long wait simply by queuing 30-40 minutes before opening.  If you missed the cut-off time, the wait can be painfully long.
author: Phg T.

description:
Good but definitely not as good as what consensus says.

Would've gotten 5 stars if not for:
- wait times (but at least you can wander around until they call you)
- small portion
- noodles didn't have any strength to carry the delicious broth
- egg was not cut in half and was therefore difficult to eat and sank to the bottom of the bowl

What was really good and hard to match/beat is the broth. That's some good tonkotsu broth.
author: Sherry L.

description:
My friend works around here, and he's a big ramen fan.  I had high expectations, and judging by the line, my expectations were even more elevated.

The food is good, however I've had better.  They do have one leg up on the competition...their appetizers.  Order the sishito peppers to compliment your paitan.

I don't know if it's worth the wait, but if I'm in the area again and there is a shorter line, I'll drop in.
author: Ron L.

description: Marufuku is the bomb! What an awesome place for Ramen, nestled inside a non descriptive building inside of Japan. What a gem of a place, that we are glad to have stumbled into. Well done Ramen, cooked just to the right amount with a sumptuous  broth and the best veggie/poem assortment. Good service and the right portion.
author: Harish D.

description:
First time here with my wife.

I was pretty amazed that you could check-in on the waitlist prior and save sometime waiting. Keep in mind, you do have to be a mile or less away from the restaurant.

We had to wait, this is a busy restaurant, but there was some confusion on actually checking in and it appears that you do have to physically check-in with a waitress. We were seated in the middle section, which is pretty unique, but not uncomfortable either. The restaurant is clean and really nice overall, small, but roomy.

Since we had already browsed Yelp, we knew what to order, and we got the Hakata DX as well as a small chicken/rice bowl Karaage Bowl. I was interested in the octopus balls, but a previous customer told us it wasn't good. The Hakata DX is amazing and they had it prepared immediately! It has a great mixture of pork, egg, corn, and delicious broth. The Karaage Bowl was decent, nothing spectacular, but I saw a couple get the Chicken Karaage and that looked like something I'll try next time around.

I would definitely recommend this place to everyone and will be coming back when I return.
author: Kareem G.

description: First time here and approved! The broth is amazing. The ramen is good.  I especially love the pork and soft-boiled egg. The line is a bit long even though it's on a weekday, but it's worth the wait. Staff are nice and efficient. You won't be disappointed. I will eat here again when I am in the area.
author: Twee W.

description:
Very very good ramen! Get the hakata deluxe for a smallish size of ramen but with two different kinds of pork (belly and char siu), a whole delicious egg, corn, seaweed, mushroom... It's small but you can always get extra noodles. The broth was very good! Rich, flavorful, fatty. You can ask for different spice levels too. The pork was good but on the sweeter side. 

The chicken karage was a little salty for me. 

The wait was not bad if you show up soon after 5:30 when they open. They have an iPad to greet you--sign in and check for updates on your phone of where you are on the waitlist.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
There's always a monstrous line for this place. You'll have better luck getting a table if you go before it opens. And even then, there was a line. I got in line a little after 11am and was seated a little after noon. Most everyone in front of me was seated and I was second to put my name down. The restaurant is pretty tiny with very few tables. The waiters ran around, rushed. 

I ordered the chicken paitan. It came pretty quickly, but I couldn't see the noodles under the pool of oil. I kid you not, it's like they poured oil directly on top of the ramen. Everyone at my table had the same oily problem. I actually couldn't eat my ramen without separating the oil. When I was done, I had a bowl half filled with oil. It was pretty disgusting. The ramen itself was fine, perhaps even good, but I was too disturbed by the excess oil to fully enjoy it.
author: Mallory L.

description:
The check in was kinda clunky.  I was asked to share a table with another party of two.  No problem, great way to meet other people, but then we are seated together in a booth.  Not very comfortable seating with two others you don't know, a table would have been appropriate. The menu is very simple and easy to order, Chicken or Pork, four levels of spiciness.  
I orders the spicy Braised Port Ramen,  nice presentation, good size portions, not oversized but not small.  The noodles are great, the broth has a nice bite, spicy with a lot of flavor. The pork was fantastic, well cooked great flavor, just wish there was a little more in the Rame.  The deluxe combo comes with 1/2 a chicken, only limited number of chickens served per day so come early if you want the combo.  The chicken was moist, with good flavors and tasty.  
Over all a good experience, great food and fairly priced.
author: David E.

description:
When this ramen place opened, I was eager to try it. I went there on a Saturday, around 11 or so, and I put my name on the list. After waiting for 50 minutes, I was finally acknowledged and was brought to a table. It had a casual vibe, with dimly lit lights. I looked at the menu and ordered the ramen that seemed appealing. After waiting another 15 minutes, a waitress took my order in a rude manner, grabbing the menu from my hand. Later, when my food arrived, it was luke warm. I tasted the broth and found it not flavorful at all, the noodles were rubbery, and the meat was over cooked. I don't know if they were just bombarded with orders, but I was not content with this bowl of ramen. I also felt that the whole time I was rushed. The ramen is also rather expensive. 

If you want bad ramen and subpar service, then this place is perfect for you.
author: Jello O.

description:
I read all the high praise for this place and decided to eat here for dinner on a Friday night. I arrived about 10 minutes before opening with already about 20+ people in line. I ended up having to use the Yelp wait list. It was an easy process and I only ended up waiting about 25 minutes to get my seat. 

I ordered a beer and the hakata tonkotsu ramen. My favorite part was definitely the broth. It was just the right amount of savory and richness, without being too salty. The rest of the ingredients were just good, but not great. They use straight noodles, which was weird at first but fine. Pork belly was a little well-done and not very fatty. Egg was soft-boiled and placed whole, making it hard to pick up with my chopsticks. The ramen was pretty good, and I'm really curious about their chicken paiten ramen. But I've had better ramen elsewhere.
author: Alfie B.

description:
This is a decent bowl of Hakata ramen. The broth is full of flavor and I enjoy having the option of choosing a spice level. 

It's cool that they have the option of getting another order of noodles (kaedama). 
However the price of $2.5 for the extra noods makes me a little sad when I remember getting multiple orders of extra noodles for $1 while living in Japan. 

I think this definitely does the job of satisfying a legit ramen craving. On the other hand, I do not think it's worth waiting over an hour in line for!
author: Christine L.

description:
Finally got to check out this place and thanks to yelp waitlist we didn't have to wait that long. It was my first time using it so it was fun to see where I was waiting in line. I got the Hakata Tonkotsu and it was amazing. The broth was super creamy and flavorful and the egg was perfect. The ramen is on the thin side and I was able to finish my bowl. I felt like I could've ate more, so if you have a big appetite you should order extra ramen or appetizers. 

The service is pretty quick here too. We only ordered ramen, but it came out within 5 minutes of placing our order. They also provided our check after bringing out our ramen so we could pay whenever we were done. 

Parking was easy on a Thursday night. I was able to find street parking right across. I'm not familIar with Japantown so it took us awhile to find this place, but if you know where Sophie's crepe is located, it's right across. If not, it's located upstairs in the West mall. 

Overall, this is now one of my top ramen places. I will definitely come back!
author: Renee Y.

description:
I'd give this place 4 stars for the food and service - the 5th star is for the execution on the waiting game. If you're a ramen aficionado; you probably suffered long waits for the popular joints in the bay. Well, here is no exception - but the upside is they are using the Yelp reservation system that puts you in an automated waited list. What does this mean? You don't have to be physically waiting in line. You can go walk around J-town, grab a drink nearby, and keep up on your spot in line. This makes the whole experience 2x better. 

And oh, the ramen here is pretty good. Get the chicken karage too - one of the best I've had: soft and tender; full of flavor.
author: Gary Y.

description:
I went to Marufuku 2 months ago on a trip to SF with my boyfriend and let me tell you, I am still dreaming of it. We make it a point to try ramen in every city that we go to as its one of our favorite foods but the selections are thin where we live and this one is by far, one of the greatest. I had the Hakata DX and it was SO flavorful I had every last bit of it. I normally try to only eat lean meats but I made an exception for the pork belly and it was delicious! Seared to perfection. The only thing about this place is that the wait can be a minute but it is well worth it. It was one of the best ramen experiences that I have ever had. 

BRB: Currently, scheming of ways to get back to SF and have as much Marfuku as I can.
author: Vivian P.

description:
All it took was my penning of a fair to middling review of a supremely popular Hayes Valley ramen joint for someone I trust to steer me in a direction that was far more to my liking.  

The ramen at Marufuku is a fraction of what it costs at that other place which, right there would've garnered an extra star from me, even had I been served the exact same bowlful.  Even better though, it wasn't the exact same bowlful.  The ramen at Marufuku is simply delicious with none of that one-note taste I got at the other place.  

Located across from Japantown's Kinokuniya, Marufuku has an efficient check-in policy and a menu that's both simple and direct:  2 types of ramen, each with a deluxe version costing a few dollars more.  Two of us opted for the non-deluxe versions of Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen ($11.99) and Chicken Paitan Ramen ($11.99) and shared an order of Takoyaki ($6.50), my favorite Japanese junk food.  

Marufuku's web site says that customers are welcome to customize their ramen orders by choosing broth thickness, noodle firmness, and even the option of extra noodles.  I found none of this necessary.  In fact, the only thing we specified for each bowlful was "spicy" as the server asks specifically about this.  

That broth.  

Although I opted for the Chicken Paitan Ramen I must admit that I favored the Hakata Tonkotsu.  The rich, milky broth cooks for over 20 hours and you pretty much understand that with each spoonful.  

My son had never before tried Takoyaki and bit into his first ball nodding his head, "I get what you mean by 'the best junk food ever'" he said.  Dancing with bonita flakes, this is a perfect shareable treat if you absolutely can't wait until your ramen arrives.  

I understand that a wait here is standard practice but on a weekday not long before their lunchtime service was ending, my wait was a reasonable 20 minutes.  I'd waited at least that long at that other place for a pricier, far less satisfying meal.  

Marufuku and I will meet again very soon, I am certain.  If you're seeking excellent ramen, perhaps I'll see you there.
author: Tracey A.

description:
I really like the food here. The broth of the ramen is rich and delicious. You can't go wrong with any of the ramen here. The pork bun appetizer is also nice. Been here about 4-5 times and the food has consistently been good.

But, the wait can be horrendous. And when it's super busy, it's not organized super well. People who put their names after you, may get seated first. People who order after you, may get their food first. It just gets too crazy and sometimes they appear short-staffed.
author: Linda W.

description:
We ordered the takoyaki appetizer, Hakata DX ramen and Hakada Tonkotsu ramen.

I requested a medium spice level for my Hakata DX ramen which has thicker cuts of pork belly and thicker broth than the Tonkotsu.

The broth here is rich and has a depthful flavor. The noodles are perfectly bouncy and not overcooked. I enjoyed the broth and the perfectly cooked egg.

What my SO and I didn't like in both our ramens is the pork. It was overly salty and just wasn't pleasant for our broths. For that reason, I think this place gets a 4.
author: Cindy N.

description:
The Coe Roe Rice is beyond my expectation & I would say it even taste better than the Ramen.

The line is long but worth the wait ..
author: Julie L.

description:
This is my favorite ramen place in the city and I've tried most of them. The wait is helllla long though, but well worth it. Their ramen is very reasonably priced and, in my opinion, the best in the city. I love everything about it. The broth, the eggs, the pork, the noodles - it's all worth it. You could randomly pick a ramen off the menu and you can't go wrong. The chicken karrage is also amazing and a great choice for appetizer.

The wait isn't even that bad because you can explore all the fun stores nearby in the mall in that time.
author: Eric L.

description: Absolutely amazing Ramen. The Tonkotsu Deluxe Ramen should be one of the Seven Wonders of the world. The pork fell apart as if the fibers of the meat were never connected at all and the soup was so rich and thick that it's like drinking a solid. The extra fatty piece of pork was truly something to be admired but make sure you come early or you might not get seated right away.
author: Antonio T.

description:
Coming to SF I was really looking forward to some good ramen because of the famous Japan town they have here.

After looking on Yelp, I decided to try Marafuku Ramen because of its good reviews. It is located at the Japan Center on the 2nd floor across the bookstore. (We almost made the mistake of trying a different place because we couldn't find it from the street and on the first floor). Because of its popularity they pretty much always have a line outside. To make it easier, they have a touch pad at the entrance to add your name and phone number to hold your spot in line. The restaurant will text you a link to follow your place in line and will notify you when your table is ready. While waiting to be seated we were able to explore the 1st and 2nd floors of the center.

Looking into the restaurant itself, it only occupies a small area and there are only about 14 separate tables parties can be seated at (probably why it gets so crowded). The atmosphere is nice with relaxing music and some more modern Japanese seating. 

After being seated, we were nicely greeted by the friendly wait staff and given menus with some refreshing cucumber and lemon water. One thing to note is the extremely small menu with only 4 different choices of ramen. Of course there are other starter appetizers like chicken karaage, edamame, takoyaki, etc. but we decided to just get ramen. My girlfriend and I both ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen, mine with extra noodles. We were given the option to choose our spiciness from 1-5 (1-No Spicy, 2-Mild, 3-Medium, 4-Spicy, 5-Ultra Spicy). I chose the 3 and she chose the 1. 

Unfortunately I think they forgot about our table, but quickly noticed and recovered by providing a free chicken karaage bowl (which was so good!) and our ramen. Although upset at first, everything was made extremely fast, fresh and delicious! Like classic Tonkotsu broth, it was creamy, flavorful and delicious. The noodles were thin but complemented the broth nicely, and the toppings were to die for. The pork was a surprise because it was sweet, but still good. They definitely went above and beyond and made it more than worthwhile to stop by here. I am definitely coming again!
author: Ben T.

description:
My friend and I both thought Marufuku was okay! It's located upstairs in that Japan town plaza. We came for lunch on a weekday and was surprised that there was still such a wait! It's nice though because you can leave your number and they'll text you when they're about ready for your party. You can walk around and visit all the cute little stores in the plaza. It made time go by pretty quickly, even though our wait was ~30-45 min. 

We got the takoyaki appetizer and I got the hakata tonkatsu ramen and added corn. You can pick spicy level. 
The takoyaki was AMAZING! It came out super fresh and hot. Tasted amazing, and all the flavors with the sauce was perfect together. 
I wasn't super amazed with the ramen. At first it was delicious but did get a little too salty for me as I kept eating it. I wish the meat was softer, it was a little hard/chewy for me. The bowl looks pretty small but it was actually very filling and I couldn't finish it, because I was full but also was getting salty so I didn't want to finish it. I do like the cool ceramic bowls it comes in though!
author: Christine Y.

description:
Came in around 8:30pm there were 4 parties waiting but went pretty fast. They use a self check in method to reserve your spot and call your name when it's time. The interior is very modern with wood paneling throughout the restaurant and cool light bulbs hanging above each table. 

We ordered geso fry to start and it tasted very fresh. The legs were soft and the batter on the exterior was perfectly crisp. Only issue was the size. I looked at other people's order of it and we received a much smaller portion:( sad because it was so good!
