We both ordered the Hakada Tonkatsu with side of braised pork(better value than ordering Hakada XD if you want more meat). Braised pork was very tender. Broth was rich and creamy. Noodles were perfect texture. 

My dad's not the biggest ramen fan. But to my surprise, he LOVED it! (He's seriously so picky with his food) He was really considering just getting starters only n no ramen but I convinced him and he didn't regret it!

Overall, my favorite ramen spot in Japantown. Will definitely be back! 

Side note: they don't take discover card!
author: Mary R.

description:
This is comparable to Ramen from Japan!!! 

I visited Japan for 2 weeks in January and since my return to the states, Ramen have been mediocre compared to my travel memories. When I went to visit SF, I heard of the crazy wait and delicious, hand made ramen here and I was quick to hop on it! I wait listed at 7pm through yelp and there were 101 parties ahead of me. After I took a nap, I woke up at 9pm to see 25 parties ahead of me. I took an uber to this very cute plaza, which resembled LA's Lil Tokyo in a very uncanny way. The restaurant closes at 9:30PM but that's when we were finally seated.

Noodles- hand made and super fine. This resembled the noodles from our Japan trip. It just made eating so much more enjoyable since you don't get overwhelmed by fat, wide noodles

Pork soup base- delicious and my favorite part. It was rich, but not too heavy and complemented all the toppings and fine noodles perfectly. It was soo good that we ordered extra noodles so we can enjoy the soup longer

Price- pretty damn affordable compared to the other places I yelped!! This place adds to my list of "eats" whenever I visit SF :)
author: Jaddis H.

description:
Super super long qeue.. luckily my friend checked in first. Even though  we checked in at 6 ish we didn't get seated until 7:40. A lot of people have up and left. The place small but nice.

I ordered the hakata tonkotsu with ultra spicy. But when the bowl came out it was not a bit spicy. I had to add a lot of the chili powder that was sitting on the side of the table. I maybe added 10+ shakes to get the soup red. The noodle is different from you typical ramen. It's thinner, it reminds me of the chinese shrimp flavor noodle that you can find at the asian markets. But I can say the soup is nice and smooth. You can tell  that the chefs took time simmer the broth.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Back in Japan, I found those really good ramen places share one common ground - they only serve one or two types of ramen in the entire restaurant. This place does the same, and it is either the creamy chicken broth or the tonkotsu broth. I believe high quality needs concentrating and letting go. Marufuku did it! Get the premium ramen that comes with grilled chicken thigh. They know how to marinate for the tenderness and flavor.
author: Ivy H.

description:
I've always wanted to check this place out but never had the time to wait hours for ramen... but I discovered the yelp line and my life changed... teehee... I highly recommend that you check the wait on yelp and add your name onto the list through here... def saves you a lot of time!

I tried the tonkotsu while my husband tried the chicken deluxe. We were super excited to try the chicken! But we were actually not that impressed. It was rather salty and a bit sweeter than we anticipated. The saltiness and sweetness overpowered the flavor. The ramen was great tho. The broth is super flavorful. I'm not sure if we'll get the deluxe again, but we will definitely come back for the ramen. But keep in mind, the ramen was perfect for us, but I've heard friends who said that it was too salty. So I think it rly depends on the day. It was perfect when we went :)

At first, I thought the bowls looked small but there's actually a LOT in those bowls. So don't worry if you're hungry!! It'll definitely fill you up :).
author: Janice H.

description:
Marufuku Ramen is the best place to get ramen in San Francisco without a doubt. Unfortunately, word has gotten out about this place so either be ready to wait at least an hour for a table, or get here no less than 20 minutes before it opens (30 minutes on weekends). 

The service here is almost TOO good. The waiters are insanely attentive and my food has always come out within a few minutes of me ordering every time. Although there is routinely a massive line out the door, they like to ensure efficiency to get as many people served as possible.

I order the Hakata Deluxe when I dine here and appreciate how rich the broth is, but also how expertly made the noodles are. Overall a delicious experience that will not disappoint even the snobbiest of ramen enthusiasts.

Amazing service, great ambiance, and splendid food. Just get here well before opening or be ready to wait with everyone else!
author: Phillip V.

description:
Check in inside the store and you can put in your informations/ parties. When I was here it was pretty crowded. We were behind like 7 groups, so we waited by walking around the mall. In less than 15 minutes we were texted that our table is ready(you put your number in the computer for text update).

We were seated and our servers are all friendly. All full of smiles. They checked us every few minutes, but they all asked us if we are ok. The services is definitely a 5 Star. Lastly for the food, at first I wasn't satisfied and I was like this is alright, but the ramen meat was so good. After that everything just clicked and made this ramen place one of my favorite ramen place. Definitely will fly to San Francisco for this.
author: Mardine M.

description: Came here on a Tuesday and waited about 30 minutes. I had their ramen with pork broth. Their egg was cooked exactly the way I like it - slightly runny. It was cold though, which I found odd. Broth was delicious, but noodles were a bit too firm for me. Their chicken karaage was good.
author: Sophia B.

description: This place is so good. The service is awesome even though the house always full. The pork ramen is so good. We always come here and order the deluxe whenever in Japantown.
author: Becky N.

description:
TIME: Friday @11:30am

I didn't know what to expect. There was already a long line when my sis and I arrived right at opening trine: 11:30am.  We were the last to get seated right away without needing to be on the waitlist!

STAFF:
Nice and efficient--no complaints in service here!

ATMOSPHERE:
This small restaurant is quite nice and felt kinda fancy.  We were asked if we can share our booth seating with the 2 strangers behind, and we said sure! The booth seating was quite deep!

ATE:

HAKATA TONKOTSU - $11.99
Hakata style ramen w/rich pork broth, simmered pork belly, soft boiled egg, green onions, kikurage, mushroom and bean sprouts. 
Don't let the tiny bowl fool you because it's actually quite deep. Not a fan of that because I will make a mess, and I don't see much of my food! I had to really dig in there to find the egg. The egg was okay--it was more hard than soft.  The pork was very tender--thinly sliced. I didn't care for the picketer ginger but that's more of a personal taste.  The broth was quite rich and delicious I must say.

HAKATA DX - $15.99
It's pretty much the same as the HAKATA TONKOTSU, but with a thick slab of braised pork belly.  So for $4 more, you get that, and it was not impressive.  My sis ordered this and I had some. The braised pork belly was chewy and dry.  Unfortunately her slices of simmered pork belly wasn't as good as mine--it was dry. So yeah I don't recommend getting this.

Overall I had I liked it here and had a good time!
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
We stumbled on this restaurant ~5:15pm on a Thursday while visiting Japan Center. We were planning to visit the nearby udon restaurant but decided this restaurant must be better if there were already people forming a line outside prior to its 5:30pm opening.

By the time the restaurant opened at 5:30, we were probably number 15 in the queue for a party of 2 and were able to enter. We both ordered the Hakata Deluxe and iced green tea. They brought the ramen out fast (5 minutes?) but left out some ingredients that they brought out later once we pointed it out.

Overall, it was worth the wait, although not the best ramen I've had (Ippudo in Tokyo is probably my favorite)
author: Minh N.

description: Excellent service and super fast serving. Chicken Karage is perfect cook. Broth is so good and ramen noodle is cook perfect. Definitely I will be back again to try other menu
author: Ray K.

description: Having lunch with a colleague, we ordered salads and the chicken karaage for aps, and we got so full we couldn't order ramen too. The chicken satay Ed super crunchy while we chomped our way through the generous fresh salads. It's yummy! I'll get to the ramen next time.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
Dang this is good. Had the limited chicken special - amazing bbq chicken along with a great bowl of chicken based ramen. Great interior, great service. 

Can't wait to try more. Which is actually problematic because the line is soooooo dang long. There reservation system is an absolute mess. They need to go to just a line like Mensho or a proper reservation system. 

Very glad to have another amazing ramen place in town.
author: Ryan B.

description:
I was finally able to sample this restaurant. Was it good, would I go back...? Definitely!! The restaurant went with the modern look with the wood panelling on the walls, matching beams of seem thru wood paneling, stylish but still relaxed feel when you sit down, inviting and bit homey.

The ramen options we sampled were the chicken paitan and the pork belly paitan dx, we also sampled the edamame, kaarage, and pork buns here is the breakdown of each and how they all faired

The chicken paitan was delicious, the noodles are super thin almost vercemillin thin, the option for the dx was sold out so we went with the regular chicken paitan, not saddened by this, order the spicy and it was not spicy, kick it up a notch and ask for the very spicy you will not be sorry, I would order this again

The pork belly paitan dx was similar in taste regular spicy, the bowl was larger the noodles the same super thin, I want to say there was 3/4 slices of pork belly full flavored not spicy, yes order this dish if the chicken is out

Edamame was standard no frills, made steamed, seasoned with salt

The kaarage was piping hot little different your standard kaarage due to all the seasoning and diced artwork they added to the dish, of course there is piping white rice underneath all this goodness, as a secondary filler sure order this

The pork buns - 2 open faced type chairman bao pork buns, heavily seasoned with that sweet sauce, try eating in one bite lol

If you go late you have less of a wait but you do run into the options of ramen being minimal but from what we sampled, I would definitely go back

Ramen *****
Sides dishes ****
Price $$
Service ****
Ambiance ***** modern chic
author: Clarence A.

description: After being unable to endure the crazy line twice, I finally made it. I've drooled over the thought of you, I dreamt of your taste, I've wondered about your 20 hour broth and you did not disappoint... not one bit!!  I had the hakata deluxe..broth was rich and fatty, the al dente-ness of the noodles was perfect, the pork melted in my mouth, all of it was well-balanced and so freaking good. I can't wait for our second date.
author: J T.

description: This place is next level good. For a chicken ramen lover like myself, there's nothing better. The broth is fatty and creamy which you usually don't get unless it's pork broth. Cooked to perfection with all the goods. Most definitely worth the wait
author: Lee L.

description:
Weekend dinner time this place gets VERY Crazy but it's worth the wait! its located upstairs (2nd floor) in the Japan town plaza building in the corner! 

Waited about 1.5 hours but it did not disappoint at all! 

Karaage was delicious! The broth was creamy but not too salty and the noodles were perfect. I was hoping my egg would be a little less cooked but still yummy! The pork is the most amazing part!! great balance between fatty and non fatty parts and marinated very well! 

Also really enjoyed that they give you a good amount of corn in the soup!
author: Ivy L.

description:
We got in line just 5 minutes after they opened, it ended up being a 75 minute wait. Given, it was a Saturday, so a wait time was expected. What's nice is, it's in a little shopping center so there are plenty of things to do to kill time. Try to get in line early if you plan on going during a high traffic time, or plan a visit on a weekday. 

Since we had to wait so long, you know we had to over-indulge to make sure our visit was worth it! We ordered the chicken karaage and takoyaki to start. Our dishes came out SUPER fast! I bet they already had these already prepared, considering how busy they were. The karaage was just ok, nothing spectacular. I really liked the takoyaki, it was flavorful and wasn't fishy at all. Probably one of the best takoyaki I've had. 

I ordered the hakata tonkotsu with medium spice. If you enjoy spicy, I think it would be safe to opt for spicy or ultra spicy as I didn't find medium to be hot at all. I ended up sprinkling a lotttt extra spice into the broth. The broth was very rich and pretty addicting, I found myself still drinking it even after being super full. It made us super thirsty and put us both into an unbelievable food coma, so be aware of that!

All in all, a pretty solid experience, though I don't think I would wait over an hour to eat here again.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Ramen is one of my favourite foods, I looked up highest rated ramen in SF and this place came up. It did not disappoint! It took us over 2 hours to get a table but using the Yelp app was really efficient, saved us time and I always love not having to talk to real humans ;)

The menu is very small, which I think is always a good sign for quality and speed of service. Don't expect to sit down for a two hour meal here! Both my husband and I loved our dishes, doesn't matter what you order. I will miss this place when we leave SF!
author: Roxanna K.

description:
Absolutely amazing ramen. 

One of the best inventions ever is how this place has an online wait list. You can use yelp and put yourself on this online wait list, which estimates the time you should arrive. This was wonderful, efficient, and we didn't have to wait at all.

We showed up at our estimated time and checked in, and were seated quickly. This online wait list really made the experience much better, as we didn't have to wait.

I came with two friends and two of us ordered the chicken paitan, and the other one ordered the vegetarian ramen. My vegetarian friend was very happy to hear that they had this option for her. She really enjoyed her ramen and was only sad that she didn't have enough room to finish her entire bowl. I tried this broth and it was very flavorful as well.

The chicken paitan was amazing. Such flavorful broth, I can't even explain it, you just need to try it yourself.

In case people are confused, this place is tucked inside the shopping complex in Japantown. It is on the second floor.

We were all super full and satisfied. Definitely one of the best ramen spots in the city, and it's even better that they have an online wait list.
author: Julie L.

description: Absolutely marvelous. We had the Marufuku Bites, the deluxe pork and the standard chicken. Wow! The ramen egg was cooked to a stunning "magma" consistency! Absolutely loved the pork belly, which was like butter. Lots of food so I'd say it was a good value!
author: Brendan N.

description:
yes, this is one of the best.
the very best!

on my Birthday I wanted to eat noodles from the best noodle shop in the city. wether it's (Japanese Ramen / Udon / Soba) or (Chinese Lo Mein / Chow Fun) or (Italian Pastas).
noodles symbolizes long life, health, loyalty, prosperity and perseverance in Asian Culture.
and nothing better to eat on my Birthday than having a bowl of Japanese Ramen from the best Ramen shop in San Francisco that also happen to be located in Japantown.
the shop open at 5.30 PM, I came at 4.00 PM, I saw 3 people waited already.
at 5.00 PM I came back to stand in line, I was already number 7 and behind me the line was already formed in double digits.
I got the first seating.

I ordered Takoyaki, Hakata Tonkotsu with extra noodles on the side, and extra bamboo shoots.
takoyaki were average.
nothing to write about and you don't miss anything if you skip it.
however ..
the Ramen was incredible!
the noodles were springy, fresh, and perfect.
the broth was creamy, porky, and smokey.
mouthful.
the pork belly was kinda obscured, not prominent at all in the bowl.
just focus on the broth and the noodles.
eating a bowl of good ramen should give you a feeling of being hugged by the people that you love.
and I was.
author: Rudy H.

description: I came here while I was visiting SF. It's in this Japanese mall. There was a long wait but thank god for yelp we were able to reserve a spot and walk around. It's community seating if you come with a small group of ppl. I got the chicken ramen. The menu is pretty small so it makes the choices very easy. My friend got the pork. Both were really good. I definitely recommend this place if your craving ramen.
author: Anina M.

description:
Showed up for dinner tonight and arrived at 7:26pm to find out they are not taking anymore customers for the rest of the evening.   Never been to a restaurant that can't fit in a customer who arrives before 7:30pm.  

Will be the last time I come here.  Waiting the 1.5 hrs was bad enough, but now it's no longer an option even.
author: David T.

description:
After coming to Japantown my whole life I had never seen a line that long just for the wait list, so I knew I had to try this place out. 

The four of us came in right at opening at 11:30 on a Saturday and put our names on the waitlist. The place is a bit small but it is pretty updated and modern. There were about 15 parties ahead of us so we just decided to walk around the center a bit. The wait was about 45 minutes. 

Three of us ordered the Hakata DX and one of us ordered the Chicken Paitan DX. We also ordered a large Hot Sake, the Geso Fry, and the Takoyaki.   

The broth was a bit salty for my taste but the braised pork belly was soft and flavorful. The noodles were a bit thinner than I was used to but a good texture nevertheless. The portion was also a pretty decent size. The grilled chicken that came with the Chicken Paitan DX was literally fall-off-the-bone good. The Geso Fry was the perfect amount of crunch without the squid being too chewy, although the portion was super small, and the large sake was enough for us all to have 3 shots each. The total for our meal was about $105. 

All in all it was definitely a good bowl of ramen, but I definitely would not drive all the way to SF for it or wait more than an hour for it either. If you are interested in trying it out, definitely try to come early and get on that waitlist as fast as you can so you don't have to wait too long. After we finished our meal and were on our way out, the line was even longer than before!
author: Ashley W.

description:
The restaurant is located inside Japan Center. When you get there, add your name and phone number onto the electronic list. You'll receive a text and will be able to go on Yelp to check your place in line. We were #55! 2 hour wait... sigh. My friends are not used to waiting this long and I felt bad. But at the same time, I wanted my ramen!

When it was finally our turn to be seated, we were ready to order. I had the Hakata DX (mild). The pork broth was rich and flavorful. I tried my friend's ultra spicy broth and wished I ordered that instead though. The braised pork belly was tender and fatty. I loved my soft boiled egg. The only thing I didn't care for too much were the thin noodles. If you decide to come, go early!
author: Helen H.

description:
Great Ramen. There were waiting list on Lunch. It was electronic waiting list. If u leave your name and phone numbers, they will call. 

Ordered Karage, Tonkusu Ramen and Chicken Ramen. You can choose your spicy level. Karage was really good. Both were also great. It cames in small bowl. Soup was not really rich and it was good. Noddle was thin. Toppings were great!
author: Da Won L.

description:
Swung by here for lunch right before it closed. For newbies, make sure you put your name down on the iPad!! We didn't realize this and had been waiting in line and almost missed the cutoff time! 

The atmosphere is so perfect -- I love how well and creatively they utilized the small space, and the decor is traditional with a modern twist. Staff is super nice, attentive, and fast. Even though they were closing up soon, they still told us to take our time, and we never felt rushed. 

For two, we decided to split several items:

-Hakata tonkotsu ($11.99): broth was super flavorful, egg was cooked to soft yolk perfection, thin noodles were the perfect texture, great bang for your buck!
-Mentaiko bowl (spicy seasoned cod roe over rice) ($4): delicious mixed with the rice and seaweed, but definitely spicier than we expected. 
-Fried squid legs ($6): delicately crispy, mayo was well seasoned and not overpowering. 

We were so stuffed and super pleased at the end. Will definitely come back.
author: Annie K.

description:
Hands down the best ramen in town. I've had friends wait three hours for this place. I came here two consecutive days: one with my brother and the other with my entire family. Both times required a wait of two hours or so. 

Once we came in, we noticed the cozy, yet distinctly Japanese tea room vibe. Since we were famished at this point after the wait, we ordered the fried chicken and squid as appetizers. We also ordered the tonkotsu and chicken paitan with extra noodle. The star of the show is the broth so having extra noodles prolonged our enjoyment of the restaurant. 

I ordered the tonkotsu deluxe and it didn't seem too different from the regular tonkotsu besides extra pork. Also don't order spicy because it overwhelms the salty brother.
author: Nathan C.

description:
I wish I could give Marufuku Ramen a lower rating for their long ass wait (I had an hour and a half wait at 7PM Tuesday).  That being said, their ramen is so damn good.  

The broth is neither too light or too heavy.  The noodles is cooked to a perfect firmness / chewiness ratio.  The deluxe comes with a generous portion of food.  

The neighborhood itself has a lot of things to do so you can grab a drink while you wait somewhere else.
author: Justin L.

description:
Came here on a Sunday and waited for just over an hour for a table of 3. They have a good system in that you can put your name down on the waitlist and you can check using the yelp app when your turn is coming up and they will also text you.

I ordered the tonkatsu ramen, which was delicious! The soup is quite rich, so do keep that in mind. They also don't have a wavy noodle option, which I wish they did! But the chashu in the ramen was really good and high quality! Overall very filling, great system for the line, and good service!
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
As of writing this review on January 2nd, 2018, I still believe that Marufuku Ramen is the most hype place for ramen right now (rightfully so). There will be a line, there will be a wait, there will be lots of people on their phones, there will be dudes standing in line while their girls are at the bookstore, there will be lots of Asian people who like to trade cryptocurrency, but more importantly, there will be yummy ramen served in a well-decorated and furnished soup establishment!

I went with the Chicken Paitan Dx which was a lot of food since it literally comes with a big piece of chicken (uber tender and tasty) on the side. The soup and noodles were good, but not sure if I'd be so interested to order it again. Next time I definitely want to get the Hakata Tonkotsu for a more "classic" ramen experience.

If you don't like waiting and/or you have a big party, I recommend coming about 30 minutes before opening.
author: Marlon T.

description:
MUST COME EARLY. On Saturday, they open at 11:30, but a line already starts forming at 11! Waiting 30 minutes was definitely better than 1+hour.

I ordered the Hakada DX ($15.99) AND my mind is blown. The broth is so clear and flavorful. The pork pieces are tender and practically melts in your mouth. At the bottom of the ramen, there is a soft boiled egg. I would recommend fishing that to the top unless you want a slightly less soft-boiled yolk. The service is great, they are attentive, but have the tendency to give customers their check before they are done (pet peeve). 

An overall solid bowl of ramen, and would definitely come back again!
author: Teresa C.

description:
Originally I wanted to go to another ramen restaurant, however, I don't regret coming to this one. I'm actually glad we came to this one.

The moment we arrived, we had to punch into the tablet to get on the waiting list. There were 6 parties ahead of us, so we had to wait about 30 minutes before getting seated. It's a small restaurant that only has about 12-15 tables. The line was lonnngggg, so I'm glad we went a little earlier. 

We get seated and we were quickly served water with lemon, mint, and cucumber in it. We ordered our ramen and it took no more than 10 minutes to receive, talk about fast service. The ramen was flavorful and fulfilling! There's only 4 different (main) ramen and we got to taste all 4. They also have a different spice level, which (Ultra) spicy wasn't even spicy. 

I would definitely come back!
author: Abbie S.

description:
Limited menu so you'll be in and out quickly. You have to make a reservation thru Yelp. Do so before band so you don't have to wait forever. I ordered the chicken ramen xd. It as amazing!!!! I got the last one but it was like 7:30 pm. They don't take Amex. I gave it 4 stars because I got an upset stomach and I'm assuming it was from there. 

Also, go for spicy!
author: Adriana L.

description:
Good ramen. Friendly people.
Large crowd. Their name speaks
for itself. Try the tonkatsu ramen.
author: Adrian R.

description:
Pretty awesome. The lines get a little ridiculous if you show up after 4:20pm for a 5pm opening. We happened to be the first to step in line one day, but there were already people waiting around to step in line as well. Initially there's no waiting list and everyone gets seated by waiting in line. I don't know what the process is after the first seating.

Got the Chicken Paitan DX ($15.95) and it was awesome. There are only 15 from when they first open, so keep that in mind The braised chicken was super tender. The broth from the ramen was perfect. It wasn't overly salty and packed a lot of flavor. I split this dish with the boyfriend, but also saw another couple get this dish and a regular ramen.

Would love to try their tonkotsu next time.
author: Christina L.

description:
My roommate and I went on a ramen binge during a few rainy days in San Francisco. The first time we went to Marufuku, we learned that the ramen shop is only open for a few hours. You have to put down your name and party size on an iPad, which sends you a text and links to your Yelp account. Pretty neat, in my opinion.

When we went, it was unfortunately closer to 1:00 PM. There was a line out the door, and the staff members had removed the iPad because the remaining patrons would take them to closing time. Darn. We went to another ramen restaurant nearby instead.

A few days later, we took our lesson learned and took another crack at eating at Marufuku. We successfully put our name on the list and waited for about 20 minutes. Even though there's not a place to wait and sit, there's the Kinokuniya Bookstore nearby. Super convenient.

When we were seated, we stared in awe at the beautiful decor and interior design of the restaurant. It was small, but they were able to accommodate a good number of seats. We ordered shishito peppers and the Hakata Tonkatsu.

The shishito peppers were disappointing. Flavorless, even with the sauce. The Hakata Tonkatsu, on the other hand, was amazing. The broth was the best part, and my roommate claimed it's the best ramen he's ever had. It was definitely up there. 

The biggest downside was my roommate and I getting food poisoning from the ramen when we went home. In terms of quality, the ramen was excellent, and I don't want to detract from the Yelp rating based on that... but seriously, food poisoning sucks. Hopefully that doesn't happen again, but maybe we'll see in the future.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Legit! Legit! Legit Ramen! We arrived around 5:15 p.m. and had to wait for a table. Were 6th in line. The check-in system is neat and helpful! You get a text when your table is ready which is awesome. We shopped while we waited for our table. It took about 30 minutes to get a table which was not bad at all.

We started with some appetizers:

The pork belly: don't get this because it will come with your ramen, only if​ you want extra.
Pop Corn Chicken: not bad but more on the dry side

The prices of the ramen are awesome! $12 for the basic bowl and $15 for a special! For quality, this is a steal! I went with their famous bowl of $15 ramen. It was worth the price point! The pork belly was flavorful and well braised. The fat melted in my mouse and the texture was tender. The broth was milky and not too fatty like most ramen broths that I have had in the past. The only thing that I did not like was the fact that my egg was not cut in half. It was a whole egg that floated to the bottom. I did not even know that it came with an egg until I almost finished my noodles. I was full by the time the egg came around.

I can not wait to return.
author: Kong L.

description:
To be honest, this place was just okay, and definitely not worth the normal wait time you would have to have to eat here. The food is good, especially given the choices in the area, but it's really nothing that special or amazing.

I had the Tonkotsu Ramen with Extra Chashu, mild, and it was okay. Outside of the oiliness of it, there wasn't much more to the ramen. The broth wasn't particularly special or hearty, the noodles were just okay, the toppings were whatever, and the chashu wasn't mind blowing.

That being said, it was still good enough, just not to the level you'd expect for the wait you had to do to eat here. I also had the takoyaki and the bao, and both of those were just whatever, nothing too noteworthy besides being decent snacks.
author: Tyler T.

description: Expect a wait! I was on the waitlist for 1.5 hours before getting seated but definitely worth it. The broth is packed with flavor and noodles the perfectly cooked (thin ramen noodles should always be slightly hard). For sure one of the best ramen place is SF. I would also recommend their buns.
author: Rene C.

description: So this place is located in Japantown. Once you go inside the mall you must go upstairs. Restaurant is located on the second floor next to elevators (took us a while to find it). My suggestion is to get on the waitlist through yelp. Due to the popularity of this place, wait times are about 1-2 hours. However, the food is totally worth it. The porks are sooooo tender. The ramen soup base is light and not salty. Even there water is good as they have mints and cucumbers in their water pitcher. Servers are very friendly and attentive. Definitely recommend this place if you ate visiting SF.
author: Esther L.

description: Marafuku? More like marafuuuuuuck this is so good. We waited 90 minutes to be seated but just toured all the little artisan shops in Japantown Center and the 90 minute wait time flew by!! This was one of the best ramen I've ever had, the broth was done to perfection in my opinion!!
author: Steven Z.

description:
Worth the wait and definitely lives up to the hype! 

It's located inside a mall within Japantown, surrounded by other awesome food establishments. I joined the waitlist using the feature on Yelp and I waited about 10 minutes when I got there. 

The restaurant is fairly small but can hold a good amount of people since the tables are small as they would be in Japan. 

I sat in the middle portion and it felt like I was back in Japan since it resembles the horigotatsu style seating. 

I ordered the Hakata DX and really liked it. The broth tasted the most authentic I've ever had outside of Japan. Also, the spiciness was in the form of powder rather than paste which was very authentic. The bowl itself was gorgeous and the perfect size. The broth was light but had a lot of body. I also got their hot tea (I believe it was a rice tea) and it was tasty. 

The service was amazing. Every waiter and waitress was checking on me. I was in and out of there within 30 minutes. My bowl of ramen was $15 and they didn't even charge me for the tea. Not sure if that's the norm? 

I would definitely recommend Marafuku and will be back for more the next time I'm in town.
author: Sisian G.

description:
Out of all the reasons why I love my girlfriend, there is one that I'll always cherish more than most: She got me HELLA OBSESSED with ramen. And by ramen I don't mean cup noodles; I'm talking about a steaming bowl of pork broth that's been cooking for 10+ hours.

Ever since we started dating, we've been traveling around the Bay Area in hopes of discovering the best ramen shop. She's been faithfully loyal to Santouka (https://www.yelp.com/biz/hokkaido-ramen-santouka-san-jose), whereas I am hooked on Izakaya Sozai (https://www.yelp.com/biz/izakaya-sozai-san-francisco). Recently, we checked out a new place that EASILY slipped into our top five: Marufuku Ramen!

As a ramen shop, Marufuku can't get any simpler. This restaurant has only 4 ramen bowls: 1. Hakata Tonkotsu (simmered pork belly with mushroom, egg, scallions, and bean sprouts), 2. Hakata DX (like the normal one but with braised pork belly and corn), 3. Paitan Ramen (chicken-based broth with chicken chasu instead of pork), and 4. Paitan DX (they give you corn and grilled chicken on the side too). They say they only serve 15 bowls of their Paitan DX a day but I saw a lot of people getting it - so not sure how much of a restriction there is. If you're looking to complement your meal, this place also has a few appetizers as well as small rice bowls. In terms of pricing, normal bowls cost $11.99 and the DX is $15.99. As for small bites, they go for ~$4-$8. We ended up getting two Hakata Tonkotsu bowls and one order of Karaage. Here's what we thought of our experience:

-- KICKA$$ KARAAGE --
Excuse me for my language, but the Karaage here was SPECTACULAR. When I had Karaage at Oakland's Geta (https://www.yelp.com/biz/geta-oakland), I thought I would never experience such amazing fried chicken at another restaurant. Besides the smaller portion size, Marufuku's Karaage was every bit as comparable as Geta's. The breading was crispy, meat was tender yet SO JUICY, and the sauce + lemon combo = bomb.com. Please do yourself a favor and check out their Karaage.

-- CREAMY AND ORGASMIC TONKOTSU RAMEN --
Marufuku definitely had one of the best pork ramen I have ever had in my short life. The broth was close to perfection: It was super rich (like you couldn't see through it at all kind of rich) and tasted very flavorful. As for the ingredients, they cooked the egg well and the veggies came out fresh. Also, having thin noodles was a very nice change. But the pork slices truly took the cake, as every piece MELTED in our mouths! The only con about the Hakata Tonkotsu was that they could have given us less ginger, although it didn't overpower the broth. 

-- VIBRANT ATMOSPHERE --
Though the restaurant was small, it compensated by having a bright and intimate ambiance. The modern decor, dim lighting, as well as the comfortable seating - they all made Marufuku a welcoming place to dine at. When coming here, try to get placed in the middle area, where the seats are actually lit up! SO COOL.

-- POLITE, BUT SERVICE TOO EFFICIENT??? -- 
Overall, we found the employees to be friendly and responsive. They made sure we had everything we needed and they also asked us whether we were enjoying our meal. Plus, since we were kind of in a rush, I appreciated that they brought out our food less than 5 minutes after ordering. Efficiency = amazing, but this might turn off a lot of people because I honestly thought that they were just trying to get customers in and out as fast as possible. So consider that if you are coming here for a long dinner.

-- HORRENDOUS WAIT --
Despite what their hours might say, you NEED to come early - especially during dinnertime. For example, since they open at 5pm on Saturday/Sunday for the evening, arrive by 430pm or else you'll have to wait an hour+. We got there at 5:05pm (JUST OPENED!) and there were already 18 people ahead of us on the waiting list! Now that's a testament to how good Marufuku is. Fortunately, there are plenty of shops to keep you busy and they will text you when your table is "ready." I say "ready" because I think they notify you when a table has gotten a check - NOT when someone actually leaves. 

-- DECENT LOCATION WITH AFFORDABLE PARKING --
Marufuku is found inside the Japan Center, at the heart of San Francisco's Japantown. This isn't a bad spot for a restaurant since there's a lot of culture and life around you. Finding free parking on the street might be a disaster, and so I strongly encourage you to find a spot inside the Annex Garage. It was only $2.5/hour for us! 

I debated back and forth about whether Marufuku Ramen was worth waiting more than an hour for, and I think I've finally decided. Despite the traffic this place gets, Marufuku truly lives up to all of the hype. The food here is ungodly and the environment is as rich as the ramen. Furthermore, price point is fairly inexpensive too! For those reasons, I have to give Marufuku Ramen an "Omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this" rating! Arigatogozaimasu!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Long waits even during weekday nights! Make sure you enter your info as soon as you can on the iPad to get on the waitlist, it asks for your full name and phone number so they can text/call you when your table is ready for you.

The menu is simple. If you are here for ramen, they have Hakata Tonkotsu and Hakata DX for pork chashu lovers and Chicken Paitan and Paitan DX for those who prefer chicken. 

HAKATA TONKOTSU (4 STARS) // The chashu was SO flavorful (a little salty). The whole soft boiled egg was also very yummy, sweet and gooey. The pink ginger slices was a first that I've seen in ramen. The medium spicy was not spicy at all. Ramen Hachi has noodles just like Marufuku: thin noodles that reminds me of Chinese shrimp roe noodles. The soup was oily but pretty good, but the umami is not as strong as Ramen Dojo's.

TAKOYAKI (4 STARS) // This was a tasty appetizer that comes in 5 pieces. Fluffy breading and savory sauce with lots of bonito flakes on the plating.

Definitely worth trying once!
author: Amy T.

description:
Marufuku Ramen was worth the wait.  After two hours and 50 people seated in front of us, I was able to enjoy one of the best ramen places in the city (Mensho is another super trendy one).  What I liked most about the ramen was that the chashu was prepared extremely well in a way that tasted better than most ramen places.  The broth and the noodles were tasty as well but the standout to me was the meat.

Marufuku is located in the Kinokuniya building in Japantown.  I found the decor of the restaurant to be very visually appealing and was surprised that unlike most other ramen restaurants that there was no bar seating area.  The check is expensive but is about the same as many other ramen restaurants in the city that are less tasty.
author: Mark C.

description:
Tasty ramen but LONG wait on the weekends. Party of 4 came around 6pm on a Saturday night. Seated at 8:15pm. We all ordered their Tonkatsu ramen (non deluxe). Ramen came quickly.

+ noodles and broth were both very good
+ reasonable price of $12 a bowl, which is definitely on the cheaper side in the Bay
- hard to find by following Google Maps (located on the second floor of the mall)
- small shop so LONG wait. server told us to expect 60-75 minute wait but we ended up waiting 2 hrs and 15 min.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
Went on a Friday night for dinner.

The thing with the yelp reservation is that you have to be within 3 miles of range of Marufuku to be on the waitlist. I think I signed up for seats for 2 around 6-6:30pm and didn't get to eat until almost 9pm.

Ordered:
Chicken Karaage
Geso Fry
Marufuku bites
Hakata Deluxe  (No Spicy and Spicy)

The Geso Fry and Marufuku bites were pretty bomb. The chicken karaage was a bit greasy and fat. The ramen has a really nice thick and rich tonokotsu broth. There were not that many sides to go with the ramen considering I probably had a total of 10 corn bits in my bowl and barely any sprouts. The ramen in general was just really rich and heavy with the broth so if you are into good tonkotsu ramen this is not a bad choice, if not, go with the chicken paitan. The noodles were chewy and worked perfectly with the broth, it was like magic in your mouth.

Was the wait worth it though? Debatable. 
They also do not validate parking so...
author: Sunny C.

description:
tl;dr great ramen with delicious grilled chicken if you're early enough to snag one. Noodles on the thin side though.

Had the chance to try this spot a couple of Saturdays ago for lunch. My friends and I all wanted to try the limited chicken paitan DX (only 15 servings a day), so we met up at 11, 30 minutes before the restaurant opens for lunch. When we arrived, I was surprised that there were already a couple groups in front of us waiting. 

Just in case you don't know where it is, Marufuku is in the same area as the Kinokuniya and the cute crepe spot, on the second floor.

As we were waiting, I saw the line get progressively longer behind us, so this is definitely still a very popular spot even though it's been open for a while. We got seated pretty soon right after they opened at 11:30, and since we knew exactly what we wanted, we were anxious to flag down a server and be one of the first groups to place our order. However, it was surprisingly hard to grab someone, as they were all running around the place and taking other table's orders.

We all ordered the Chicken Paitan XD ($15.99), which is chicken ramen with paitan broth, chicken chashu, a soft boiled egg, and various veggies. It also comes with a piece of grilled chicken on the side. Once we placed our orders, our food came out fairly quickly. The grilled chicken arrived first, and we all started digging in.

The grilled chicken was juicy and tender with a sweet teriyaki marinade. It's a joint leg and thigh piece, so paired with a bowl of ramen, it's quite filling. All of my friends were able to finish both items, but I ended up taking half my chicken home.

The ramen came a couple minutes after the chicken. I enjoyed everything about the ramen except for the chicken chashu and the noodles, which are Hakata style i.e. the noodles are extra thin. I don't think I've ever had such thin ramen noodles before, and I realized from this meal that I'm not exactly a fan. The chicken chashu tasted like dry-ish breast meat and wasn't the melt-in-your-mouth chashu experience I look for. The soft boiled egg was amazing though. I wish I had added another one to my ramen.

Service was pretty fast; everyone works quickly here as they're cognizant of the long line of people waiting outside.

I don't think I'd come back again, but that's because I'm not a huge fan of the hakata style thin ramen noodles. I'm glad I tried it once though.

There's usually residential parking to be found within a couple blocks of Japantown. I parked a couple blocks away on Webster and walked to the restaurant.
author: Dianna H.

description: Went here last night and had the Takata Tonkotsu. Very rich broth complimented by a perfectly soft boiled egg and tender chasu. Ordered a pitcher of Sapporo with a friend and we felt that it was definitely heavier than most Sapporo beers which was odd. However, I'll definitely be back for the deluxe with the pork belly.
author: James B.

description: Ramen freak here. The pork belly was awesome and the broth is to die for. Best ramen I have ever had. A must go-to if you love ramen.
author: Judith M.

description:
Was walking around JP-town on a lonesome Sunday night around 9pm when I serendipitously encountered Marufuku ramen. 

We were browsing the menu outside for s*its and giggles and noticed that their offerings were not too overwhelming and had just the right amount of ramen offerings scattered with a few appetizer and rice dishes. I hate it when there's too much to choose from! Oh the power of choice right....

The lady came to the front and I asked what time they were closing. They said 9pm but if we wanted to eat they would accommodate us. My +1 and I said f*ck yes! Let's do it! Since there was almost 5 stars on Yelp I figured this place would usually have a line so I better be strategic and eat while there's no line. 

I'm all about serendipity folks. I'm not a huge ramen connoisseur and rarely go searching for this stuff on Yelp but boy am I glad for randomly experiencing this joy of a place. 

The decor was quite nice inside with the wooden accents and the restaurant appeared clean and well maintained. I ordered the hakata tonkotsu mild and my +1 ordered the same but without any level of spice for comparison. To be honest, the broths both tasted very similar and you can hardly taste any of the spice in the mild version. It's not really a toss up between the two in my opinion because they both taste the same.

The ramen itself was bangin'!! Everything was cooked to perfection. The ramen noodles were like no other I've ever had. They were thin, whiter in color, and chewy with a nice bite to them. The broth (which had apparently been simmered for 20 hours) was rich and flavorful with the right amount of fat content and wasn't overly seasoned or salty. The simmered pork itself was perfectly seasoned and just melts in your mouth. The garnishes were also perfect. I love me some crunchy mushroom and bean sprouts!

Would definitely give this place another visit to try their other ramen flavors and offerings as I know the ramen selection around town is quite overwhelming and just as competitive.
author: Connie M.

description: Delicious and worth the wait. Better than Ippudo or Mensho in my opinion. Mensho's broth is too thick and creamy. Ippudo lacks flavor. Marufuku is just right! You get lots of meat, and the broth is so delicious! The noodles are the thin kind. Prices are on the cheaper side in terms of SF ramen, esp for the quality you're getting. Even on waitlist, the wait is about an hour. It's not too bad though because Marufuku Ramen is in Japantown. While you're waiting, you can walk around and check out all the cool shops! My boyfriend and I ate dessert before dinner during a quick pre-ramen stop to Maiko Matcha Cafe, which is on the first floor in the same building. I will definitely be back!
author: Kaitlynn L.

description:
I tried Marafuku Ramen for the first time a few months ago. Great ramen and great customer service. My friend and I decided we wanted ramen for dinner and decided to go here on a whim.  And when I say whim, I mean an hour before closing. There was still a wait list going when we got there. After a 20 minute wait, we were seated and the server promptly took our order. He was really nice even though we were those people who were still ordering just half an hour before closing. 

I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu. The broth was rich and flavorful...it really hit the spot. My friend ordered the Hakata DX and she really enjoyed it too. The restaurant is simple and traditional, with a short and straightforward menu. I really liked it and would come back the next time I'm in the area.
author: Rosalie N.

description: This is probably one of the best ramen placed I have ever been too!! I was just visiting from LA with my family and was craving a good hardy ramen. Ramen is my favorite food so seeing the reviews I was hoping this place would be delicious - AND IT WAS. There was a line waiting before it opened at 5:30, so make sure you're there early to get seated right away!! What can I say, service was the best service I've ever gotten in a ramen place EVER. They are fast, get you everything right away, waited less than 15 minutes for my food even though it was super busy. Ordered the fried chicken and the steamed pork filled buns and they were delicious (though they only give you two buns, it was a good starter)!! I'll make sure I stop by this place every single time I'm in town.
author: Chloe R.

description: Delicious Ramen！The soup base is rich and yummy. The pork belly is on the sweeter side but nothing is wrong with that. You can use yelp to book a reservation which is so convenience
author: Jael C.

description:
Hmm...

Pros:
-Fresh/high-quality ingredients (noodles, broth, veggies, meats, egg)
-Classy environment
-Efficient and accurate service
-Texting/Calling notification for available seating (after you sign-in)

Cons:
-Kinda on the pricy side
-LONG WAIT (we also had to wait another 10ish minutes AFTER being texted that our tables were ready)


To be quite frank, I did not particularly like the ramen at Marafuku because it was not my style. The noodles (which are Hakata-style, aka super thin, were perfectly cooked but not ideal for me). If you like Hakata-style noodles, this is the place for you! The simmered pork belly was a little too flavorful (meaning really heavy on soy-sauce or something). Lastly, the broth had this taste that reminded me of gravy (kind of odd). But, the broth was very clean.

Props to them for getting the egg cooked perfectly. Sadly, my friend's was more on the hard boiled side.

The Chicken Karrage was pretty good ( with tasty white meat). BUT we only got five pieces for $5.50. Kinda a bummer. 

Other than that, my experience at Marafuku was alright!
author: Christine H.

description: The best ramen I've ever had in the United States (haven't been to Japan yet). Would recommend this delicious ramen to anyone, but definitely wouldn't get the red bean beer or whatever it was again because it was like $11 for a small beer... :/ Ramen was delicious though!
author: Cory P.

description:
The wait was insane. 35 plus minutes. Luckily, I got on the waitlist early via Yelp. An absolute must! And it took me a while to even find the place. Second floor back corner. 
The Tonkotsu ramen is excellent and worth the wait (if you are not in a rush). We added some yummy shishito peppers.
My return is definite.
author: Manfred S.

description:
Solid ramen joint, for the type of ramen they have. I really like thicker noodles, so it wasn't going to get full stars from me from the get-go. I had their tonkatsu. Based on my traditional ramen ranking:

Broth: It was not bad. Pretty light, so definitely not extremely rich. There was still a strong pork flavor. I asked for spicy and it was okay. I should probably go to the spiciest level. 

Noodles: Was okay, but again, I like the thicker ramen. No fault of the restaurant though.

Toppings: There's not a ton of toppings, just a bit of the black mushrooms, sliced pickled ginger, and an egg on the bottom. Yeah, the bottom of the bowl. I assume they have eggs pre-cooked, and they put the egg on the bottom to warm it through. It was a little odd, but that means when you seek your egg, use your spoon to fish it out. Otherwise, you'll break the egg and yolk everywhere. The egg is the great runny one though. If it was warmed through it would be better (and it took me a good 10 minutes to even find the thing, so it should have warmed through).

Environment was cool. My friend and I were seated in the center, which is really awkward to get into. Ladies take note - don't wear a dress or skirt here, in case they stick you in the middle. I'm just weirdly tall, so it took a little planning for me to get my legs into the space. 

Service was quick, and very efficient. We arrived about 15 minutes after opening on a weekday and had to wait 30 minutes, so there's also that.
author: Lily W.

description:
The best place for ramen in San Francisco which explains why there is always a long line when coming here.  Be prepared to wait at least an hour or more but I can tell you it's worth it!  There's something about the way they make it that makes it so ono! 
Ordered: hakata tonkotsu ($11.99), hakata dx ($15.99), chicken paitan dx ($15.99)
author: Mikayla M.

description: Pretty good, but I've had better. Not worth the ridiculous wait, in my opinion. My personal preference is for noodles that are a bit thicker and chewier; I felt like these noodles had the consistency of somen more than ramen. Also, the "ultra spicy" broth is not spicy at all.
author: Jung Ha L.

description:
If you know me, then you know I am a ramen snob. 

We've been here twice in the last month. Which is saying a lot considering it's a trek from the East Bay into Japantown...and then to battle finding parking. 

I've had both the DX and the regular ramen. The DX's meat portion is overwhelmingly huge. What is unique about Marafuku is the ramen noodles they use. It's much thinner than regular ramen noodles. Surprisingly, I really like it. 

Be warned though, there is ALWAYS a very long wait here. Be prepared to wait for at least 45 minutes to an hour. 

The karaage is delicious! MUST GET THIS. 

You bet we'll be coming back again soon for our ramen fix!
author: Katy W.

description: Went right when the opened and only had to wait for the 1st round of customers. This was on of the best, but not the best ramen I've had in the Bay. The cha siu was really good and the broiled pork was decent, but the chicken deluxe was pretty bad. How do you mess up a chicken leg? The broth was pretty flavorful and the ramen noodles were really cooked nicely al dente. Probably rate it slightly under Ramen Parlor and Ramen Dojo.
author: calvin y.

description:
After spending four years in LA and exploring the ramen scene there (everything from Shin Sen Gumi to Daikokuya), this  was probably one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had. 

The wait itself was incredibly long and quite trying (we waited around an hour at 2 pm on a Sunday), but the saving grace was that the wait-list that was powered through Yelp. That way, I got a text notification letting me know when my table was going to be ready. I could also see where I was in line the entire time. This freed me up to go explore all the Korean beauty and stationary stores in the mall while waiting.

Once we finally got seated inside the restaurant (sharing a table with another couple), we were served really quickly. We ordered the Chicken Karrage (Japanese style fried chicken) to start, and both got mild Hakata Tonkotsu. 

The chicken was delicious and really well-balanced in terms of breading and meat. Each piece was really juicy, and I savored all the pieces we were served. The ramen was so incredibly flavorful. The broth was extremely rich and the pork beautifully savory. All the other parts were also good, but those were the two highlights for me. There was even extra spice flavor on the table if you wanted to take things up a notch in the heat department. I loved everything about this food.

I'll definitely be back here as soon as I can!
author: Jenny D.

description:
Per recommendation from a good friend, I dined here with 3 others during a day trip to the city. We had pretty high expectations, since my friend who recommended it has tried damn near every affordable ramen joint in the city. There was a wait list, and we were afraid we weren't going to get it by the time they closed (2 pm for lunch I think). This added to our hunger and expectation.

I had the chicken ramen, and I have to say it really hit the spot. The broth is incredible, and the chicken was pretty good as well. I wish there were a bit more toppings, but I guess I'll have to come in early next time to get the limited quality special. My friends all got the chashu ramen, and I have to mention that we ate in a comfortable silence, concentrating on the flavor of the dish. I can definitely say I'll be back to try each flavor :D
author: Melanie F.

description: I'm gonna go ahead and say this was one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had. The tonkotsu broth is absolute perfection, the chashu was tender and delicious and the flavoring + ingredient quality was absolutely top notch. Was a bit of a wait but you can pop your name on the list through Yelp before you head over. If you like good ramen, don't skip this spot.
author: Gregg L.

description:
I like that they have virtual waitlist that you can sign up through yelp. But I didn't like that the wait time estimate was pretty inaccurate. We don't live too far away from here so we signed up online while we were home and then walked over to be there by the lower end of the estimate they provided us. In our case it was 50 minutes after we signed up. They tell you to do that - to check in by a certain time. But there was still 18 parties ahead of us. I wish it was more of a real time update. They do ping you on yelp, I think and let you know you have 5 minutes to check in or you lose your spot. We weren't seated till about half an hour later. This was about 20 minutes later than the expected time stated on the waitlist. 
Since we had time outside, we had pre-perused the menu and decided what we wanted. I got a non-spicy hakata tonkotsu ramen and the hunnie had a mild hakata DX. Noodles came out really quickly, as ramen should. They have all the stuff prepared in the back - it should just be putting the bowl all together. Anyways we both liked the rich, creamy broth - it wasn't overly salty, which has been the case of a lot of ramen places. And so we were both able to finish the broth at the end. Haha. Mine had the pork chashu, soft boiled egg, wood ear mushrooms, bean sprouts, green onions, and a little bit of the red ginger. The DX had braised pork belly instead of the chashu, corn and a piece of seaweed. I also tried some of the mild broth and you can definitely taste the spiciness. I'll stick with my non-spicy broth - still had plenty of flavor. Noodles were just ok, maybe slightly overcooked. I like when it has more of a snap or al dente-ness to them. Portions or the bowls looked really small. But I was actually pretty satisfied by the end of it. The price is a bit on the pricier side for such a small bowl though. The pork and soft boiled egg were the standouts. Pork had good amount of fat, flavor and was fall apart tender. The egg was cooked perfectly - yolk still runny. Slurped it down in 20 minutes and was out of there quickly. The meal set us back about $40. I saw a bunch of people getting takeout. So I might do that if I was tired of the wait.
author: Alison W.

description: My favorite Ramen place in SF.  The quality of food is still same since opened, I ordered the deluxe.
author: JoJo Y.

description: I went here back in March only to show up and take an L. There were 54 people in front of us and I was way too hungry to wait that long. But I came back again and 15 people ahead wasn't bad. I think I waited for 20 minutes and I didn't mind it at all. Once we were seated we ordered the karaage and the tonkotsu ramen. Karaage was really good. But the ramen was absolutely amazing. They served straight noodles and I usually prefer the yellow curly noodles but here, they tasted really good. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Alex L.

description: Saw the line waiting out the door and was curious.  (Only place in Japan Center with a line).  A very pleasant surprise.  The ramen was great!  Noodles and eggs were cooked to perfection and the pork broth was delicious.
author: Carmen N.

description: Love this place, I like the no nonsense approach, the menu is super easy to navigate and the food is delicious. In my opinion, that's how dining should be (unless it's some special occasion). There's really not much else that needs to be said; the ingredients are great, and it achieved what I want my ramen to achieve "Hug-in-a-bowl" status. Also, I love the no-wait app that allows you to roam while you wait for your party to be called.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Possibly the best ramen we've found in the USA! USA! Marufuku! USA! Marufuku! USA! Marufuku! 

The broth is exactly how tonkatsu broth should taste, bones, porky, thick, and fatty. Even without pieces of fat floating in the broth. Sounds gross? Well, then you've never had real ramen! Trust me, pieces of fat = authentic ramen. 

The only un-Japanese about this place is that they have different level of spiciness. Something that is uncommon in a ramen bar in Japan. Oh, and the egg. It's cheap, not organic, and not seasoned. 

Marufuku's long queue and wait time is justified. Thank you Yelp for allowing us to add ourselves to the waitlist via the Yelp app!
author: Debbie T.

description:
Yum yum. After spotting this place two days ago, and seeing how long the line was, I had to return. At lunchtime on a (holiday) weekday, the wait was 45 minutes (with 35 parties ahead of us). Pretty awesome to be able to monitor where we were in line based on the Yelp app.

The decor is has a modern Japanese feel, with a lot of wood accents. The service was friendly, but clearly somewhat sparing. They only came when they had to.

Food: 
- Chicken Karaage: The texture was really good - crispy on the outer layer, but the flavor of the chicken overall wasn't particularly notable. The aioli that came with it really tied the flavor together. 

- Hakata Tonkotsu: The broth was SO creamy. It almost tasted like it had cream in it. It also wasn't super salty the way some other ramens are. The pork belly was SO good. It had a garlicky and sweet tasted and was so tender. The noodles were cooked really well. Came with a full egg (!), but mine was slightly overcooked. The portion didn't seem large, but I already started feeling full part way through, maybe because of how rich the soup was. 

Overall good experience and maybe the best ramen I have had in SF.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Marufuku Ramen 
With 4.5 stars and more than 1300 reviews on Yelp, Marafuku Ramen really don't need any more positive reviews to prove to you how good they are.

Located in the Japan Center Mall in San Francisco, Marufuku Ramen is a restaurant that specialize in authentic Hakata-style Tonkotsu ramen
We came on Saturday afternoon and we got lucky with a parking spot in the front.  Street parking wasn't terrible, there is a mall parking as well but it will cost you $2- $3.5 per hour depending on the time of the day. 
We went into mall through the Post St and Filmore St entrance and it is just up the stairs in the corner.  There was no line when we got there and we were like OH it's our lucky day... but it's not.

TIP: Marufuku Ramen use the Yelp Waitlist system so make sure you get on the waitlist before heading over to the restaurant to avoid the long wait.  Since we didn't get on the waitlist beforehand, we waited for an hour- but it's okay since there's plenty to see in the mall.

The interior felt modern and clean with wooden tables and décor.  It's pretty standard and what you expect from a Japanese restaurant.

We ordered the Chicken Karaage appetizer, one Hakata Tonkotsu and one Hakata Tonkotsu Deluxe. 

The Hakata Tonkotsu Deluxe was truly amazing- coming from someone who's been to Japan and loves a good bowl of ramen.  Once the bowl arrived, I quickly took one sip of the broth, burnt my tongue and then took another sip. It's just so flavorful and creamy that makes you question how long has the broth been cooking? It looked very rich milky and immediately made me question if I'll need to take a lactaid pill before I continue.  The noodle came al-dente with some chewiness (guess that's their default, you can also customize the richness of the broth and firmness of noodle), here they use the thin straight noodles, I was hoping they would use the wavy or thicker noodles so it could soak up the broth a little better but either way it was excellent!  The chashu pork was sliced thinly but had good flavor and balance of fat and meat. With that said, I am not a fan of the braised thick pork belly, although it had good flavor, it was not tender and quite hard to chew. The soft boiled egg deserves a major compliment, not only did it have good flavor but it was cooked perfectly- when the yolk looks liquidy (is this a word?) but was just cooked enough to be held together, just perfect! 
The portion was good and filling but since I had extra broth left over, I ordered extra noodle. The main different between the deluxe and the regular was the addition of the braised thick pork belly, sweet corn and nori seaweed.  Personally if I could order again, I would have went for the regular bowl and add extra chashu.

Service- Good! Our waitress was attentive and came to check on us and refill our water regularly even though the restaurant was quite busy.

Price- Good! The Hakata Tonkotsu Deluxe will run you around $17 (at time of writing), with drinks and appetizer, you are look at around $25 per person.  

Overall- 4.5 stars (I'll round it up to 5).  Definitely one of the best bowl of ramen that I've ever eaten in the States, it is worth the wait and price.  A fair warning-  It's a rich bowl of ramen so if you are not used to heavy/rich food, prepare yourself or be ready to take some Tums.
author: Felix S.

description:
Long wait and competitive wait-ers. Why? Because it's worth it. 

I get the Hakata Tonkotsu at the Spicy level, and it's perfect. The broth is the best I've ever had. The pork is pretty good, and I think the noodles are perfect for carrying the soup. 

It's fast-paced service. Definitely not the place to take your time, but I mean, why would you? You wanna get this ramen in you as quickly as possible. It's awesome. 

Give this place a try when you have time to walk around Japantown while you wait! You waitlist and they text you when it's time to get to your table. 

Amazing flavors and ambiance! Kind of a busy location but if you're serious, then the wait should be easy peasy.
author: Dom B.

description:
Good creamy broth
Tasty pork belly
takoyaki
good friendly service


It's really good ramen on a cold rainy san francisco night,.. tonkotsu dx was really creamy and tasty,..
Pork was soft and tender,.. and their service is really good,.. our server was attentive and was friendly to the kids... overall nice good bowl of ramen with a side of friendly service,..
author: Chester V.

description:
On a Friday night, our wait was an hour and a half for a table. The list of people waiting was insane. Luckily, we were able to walk around the Japan Town Center so we weren't so bored.

We shared a takoyaki and it was delicious. I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen. The broth was full of flavor, noodles were fresh, chashu was tender, and egg was soft boiled to perfection. Everything in the bowl was extremely tasty.

Came in starved from the long wait, but left with a happy stomach.
author: Julian Y.

description:
Tried: Hakata DX (5/5)

My friend and I both got the Hakata DX, me in ultra spicy and her in mild. Really, there were only 2 (slight) imperfections for this dish. 1) Both of us thought the broth wasn't spicy enough and had to add the pepper which was provided on each table, and 2) we both thought that the braised pork belly made the dish a little overboard - the Hakata Tonkotsu is probably what we're getting next time. Besides that, the broth was delicious, the noodles were perfectly chewy, and the egg was just the right amount of yolky (it's at the bottom of each bowl)! This is definitely my favorite bowl I've tried in SF, and I'd come here over Mensho Tokyo any day.

The wait times were also less than what we thought they would be. It took around an hour for us to get seated and there were 30 groups ahead of us. Besides, there's a nice book store right across to spend your time. Just ask for some extra garlic paste with your ramen and enjoy :)
author: Hannah H.

description:
Located on the second floor of japantown near pika pika.

Seating: about 50 people

Dropped by here around 1pm and there was a long line. About 10 people ahead of us. Got seated around 1:45pm. They still took people in even after 2pm (the time they close)

Customer service: Lacking. The only good thing is they have fast service but not friendly at all. They serve you and leave you alone unless you call for them. One star down because they didn't bring my bill even though I was finished and they walked past me several times. Had to get up to the register and ask for the bill. Like I know you guys are very busy but it would be an improvement if the staff interacted better.

Other than that the food was AMAZING
Hype is worth it, ramen was as good as the one I had in japan.

Ordered the pork ramen $11.99, broth was rich and tasty (medium was not spicy at all, it was just flavorful), noodles were very thin, about 3 types of veggies, 2 pieces of pork that were very flavorful and tasty. Boiled egg was perfection. Overall the ramen was worth the wait. 5/5
author: Michele G.

description: It was a bit biter.Me and Ike just ate it and we just said so so.
author: Myles S.

description:
Marufuku is one of the best ramen joints in the entire city. As a consequence, lines here can get ridiculously long and the online Yelp wait listing feature has made estimated wait times to be around 2-3 hours in the evenings. If you want to eat dinner here, make sure to reserve a spot on the app/website an hour or two in advance.

Wait times aside, the food here is on the upper end of ramen in SF. It is reasonably priced, being a few dollars cheaper than the other ramen spots in Japantown (Yamadaya, Hinodeya, Waraku, etc.) The ramen is broth is light and delicious, and I especially love the noodles here, although they don't let you customize firmness like Ippudo. 

I've been here countless times and can recommend:
- Hakata Tonkotsu ramen (I like the Tonkotsu broth better than the Chicken one)
- Chicken Paitan DX ramen (Get extra corn!)
- Karaage (Huge portions)
- Marufuku bites (Steamed buns with shredded pork) (Love this!)
- Calpico (try this Japanese soda if you've never had one)

One downside of eating here is that the wait staff will subtly rush you to order and eat quickly since there are such long lines. They come to your table asking you to order the second you sit down and place the check on your table almost instantly after you've been served your food. This is mildly annoying.
author: Neivin M.

description: The ramen was delicious, I could have done without the ginger though. I ordered the Hakuta Deluxe Spicy Ramen and my husband ordered it mild. We both enjoyed the experience. We got there around 1129 and there was already a line formed.
author: Heather H.

description: The best ramen in the city. Just go there. Major downside is it closes by 9:30 pm. The one in Oakland is open till later.
author: Saad Z.

description:
Why do people wait for almost an hour to get a seat? Because it's that good!
Yes, we actually waited for 45 minutes but prepared to have an awesome Ramen meal at Marufuku!
The Tonkatsu Ramen was delicious! The pork broth was rich, the chashu (pork) was well seasoned with a sweet salty taste to it. They actually include a whole soft boiled egg which adds to the quality of the flavors of the broth, chashu and thin and tender homemade ramen noodles.

Yes, they will give you two containers to separate the soup from the noodles for if you have leftovers.

Definitely worth waiting in line.
author: Calvin N.

description:
If I can give an extra half star, I really would. This place was almost perfect for me. 

To start, my boyfriend and I stumbled upon this place by accident. We were walking around Japan town and saw that there was this huge crowd outside of their doors. We looked up the name on Yelp to see what the fuss was all about and saw the impressive reviews this restaurant was getting. Unfortunately at that moment, my boyfriend and I had an event to attend to, so we said if it was still opened when we came back, we would try it out...thankfully, it was opened!

We ended up getting to the restaurant about half an hour before it was closing. Thankfully, there was a short line and they ended seating us. When you enter the restaurant, it gives this mixture of modern/traditional Japanese vibe. Service was great, giving us water right away and was able to give us suggestions on what to order. Both my boyfriend and i ordered their Hakata Tonkotsu since thats what Yelp was raving all about and that was what this restaurant was known for, and boy, were we not disappointed.

The broth was jammed packed with flavor. The pork slices were so good! I remember when I bit in it for the first time, i literally dropped my chopsticks. I have never tasted something so delicious! Every time after that, I had to pause and slowly chew the pork because I was just enjoying it that much. 

Now, the reason why this place was near perfect was because I was not a huge fan of the noodles. I felt like the texture wasn't where I would have liked it, but this is me comparing to another ramen place I have been to. Also, even though the service was great when we entered, when we were trying to receive our check, they were a little slower than we would have liked.

Overall, I really liked this experience. I cannot wait to come back and eat at this location again.
author: Tramanh D.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for the best ramen. I've heard that Marufuku has amazing ramen, but I didn't expect it to be my favorite ramen place of all time.

We waited 45 minutes to be seated, but it was totally worth the wait. I order the chicken paitan dx which included grilled chicken on the side. The chicken was so juicy that I just had to add it to my bowl of ramen along with the chicken chasu that was already in the bowl. The ramen itself was so refreshing and the broth is mouth watering. 

My fiancé ordered the hakata dx and I have to say that I prefer the tonkotsu over the chicken paitan, but they're both super delicious. You can't go wrong with choosing either or. I prefer the hakata because the broth is much richer and creamier.

If you're in the Bay Area and happen to visit Japantown, please go and visit Marufuku Ramen. You will not regret it!
author: Mallory L.

description: This is the BEST ramen place in SF! This time I got hakata ramen ultra spicy and it was so good! I came here around 1:20ish and waited about 30 minutes to be seated! Definitely worth the wait! All my friends LOVED it :)
author: Clare L.

description:
I think this is my favorite ramen in SF.  Good price/quality ratio and LOVE the waitlist option you can do on Yelp.  I can join the waitlist an hour before and arrived just about when the table is ready.  I wish all restaurants do this!  There's also plenty of store in this mall that you can browse while waiting.
The $12 Hakata ramen is my go-to order. If I'm feeling a bit more ambitious, the Hakata deluxe includes both types of meat (chashu and kakuni) and a couple more toppings.  The soft boiled egg is just right - slightly runny on the inside.  The meat is tender and flavorful, although not the very best I've had (hence the 4 stars).  The broth is the rich tonkotsu which is the kind I like and the noodles are just right.
Definitely worth the wait in line!
author: Dian K.

description: The best ramen in SF no doubt. Get there 30 minutes before opening otherwise expect to wait.
author: Brent C.

description:
Hit the spot after a day out on town and we were craving for something hot.  Piping hot broth, fully of flavor and perfect spice level at medium. We got the signature tonkotsu ramen w extra bamboo, chicken karage which was very juicy and well flavored and fried shishito peppers.  The ramen looked deceivingly small.  The ramen bowls were small but deep.  We were all full by the end of the night.

Downside is you guessed it! The wait. We got there at 8:15 on Saturday and the yelp waitlist was already closed at 7:30. We got seated after an hour. Luckily there was daiso and other stores to keep us occupied and entertained.
author: Mikii S.

description:
To me, this is about as good as it gets outside of Japan. To make it clear, I much prefer the hakata style ramens (which is what they serve here). It's from Fukuoka, and has a thinner noodle that isn't curly and just really rich flavorful broth. I prefer these noodles because you get a better noodle-to-soup ratio (in my opinion). 

I think the chicken leg is really good, but don't despair if you don't get it (they have limited pieces each day). The chicken leg is similar to the one you can get at nojo ramen tavern, but the star of the show here is definitely the ramen (though at nojo i'd say the star is the chicken... clearly not as big a fan of nojo). 

Overall, the noodles are cooked well, but the broth is truly amazing. Flavorful, creamy, and yet somehow not too heavy. Some ramen broths straight up make me feel ill because they're so greasy, but despite being creamy, somehow marufuku manages to keep it light. I recommend coming on the weekdays at lunch and still coming 15 min early to guarantee getting in when they open. Weekend lines are pretty crazy, but go before they open if you want to get a chance to be in the first batch to enter. Oh and karaage here is good too! (Fried chicken as a side).
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
Yes the wait is worth it!!! Advise place your name on the list.  Average 30 minute wait.  This place ranks one of the better ramen places that I've been to in NYC, Seattle, Chicago and Vegas.  

The braised pork belly is awesome- tasteful- must get.  Ramen is very good, egg is cooked great. Tayotaki is one of the best I had. Service is fast as soon as you sit down.  Highly recommend.
author: Rolly T.

description:
My friend kept talking about this place and how she saw so many reviews on it and suggested we tried this after we experience the Cherry Blossom festival. We made a reservation via yelp and was told it was about a 45 minute wait. We came over and double checked to make sure we were on the list. Our party was 5 people, and it was pretty nice waiting outside. The wait wasn't bad but the best part was after we ordered it came pretty fast. We ordered 3 different things between the table, one chicken karaage, a chicken ramen and a regular tonkatsu ramen. They don't give too many options like most ramen places but you can also add additional ingredients. Broth was great, you can pick how spicy you wanted it. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen along with medium spicy. LOVED IT!! Soup was definitely 9.5/10 but the noodles weren't really ramen noodles, they were a bit different. I prefer ramen noodles, so to me, the noodles were like a 6.5/10. The egg was different between dishes. For mine, it was a bit overcooked whereas my boyfriends was still softboiled. 

Service was ok, we had to ask them 2 times to fill our waters, rather than them coming by to fill it. Loved the flowers in the water. 

Parking is definitely harder to find in general and during cherry blossom, it's definitely even worse. Parking lots were full that day, however my bf found parking about 3 blocks away.
author: Amy Y.

description:
