One of the best ramen I have ever had! I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu and the broth was rich and flavorful! Trust me, not one drop was wasted! 

The Buta Kakuni was soft, tender, and melt in your mouth good! The chicken karaage and edamame were just decent, but I came here for the ramen. Lol

I washed everything down with some hot sake and it ended up being one of the best meals I've ever had!

Come early because lines tend to form! But it's definitely worth the wait!!!
author: Ryan N.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place since I always see a wait! I was finally able to try on a weekday for lunch. Arrived a little before they opened and wow there was a line already! Luckily, I was able to get seated on the first round.
Inside is actually pretty spacious but a little dark. There are tables and booths and a center section where you have to climb in. Cute but kind of a hassle.

I tried the Hakata DX and it was quite good! The braised pork belly was soooo yummy and they give you a generous helping. The ramen was a little weird for me because it was so thin. I've only been to like 1-2 places that have ramen like this. I do prefer the thicker ramen noodles but these were fine! 
My friend had the Hakata Tonkatsu and the simmered pork belly was good too! 

Not a place I would wait long to eat at but definitely worth a try!!
author: Kristie L.

description:
Fantastic ramen. Ordered the marufuku bites and hataka tonkotsu. Ramen noodles were cooked al dente and cooked just right with a chewy consistency. Noodle to soup ratio is perfect (there's a surprising amount of noodles for the size of the bowl). Broth not too oily and flavorful. Only thing that was odd was the cucumber and lime infused water that made for an odd pairing with the savory ramen. 

Service was fast (~15 minutes) but the wait was long (~2 hours). Can definitely explore the rest of Japan Center while you're waiting and there's a lot to do in Japan Center; there's a stationary store, a crepe restaurant, matcha ice cream shop, Asian beauty store, etc. The wait didn't feel like a problem. I recommend using Yelp to put your name on the waitlist (you can check your order on the waitlist using Yelp) and setting aside time to do something else while you wait because they'll text you when they have a table ready.
author: Jennifer L.

description: There's a reason why people wait an hour+ to get a meal here. Even though we got there 30 minutes before it opened, we were cut off after the first group went in. It's nearly as good as the ramen you'll be getting in Tokyo and a very reasonable price. They have the two broths, one that's pork based (tonkotsu) and one that's chicken based. My family and I shared both and were very impressed with the flavor of the broth and how perfectly the noodles were cooked. My personal preference is that I love a thicker chasu pork, but the one in this ramen was decent. We also ordered the takoyaki, which was very good. Overall, if you are in the mood for ramen, I would wait the extra time to get the best in the area.
author: Alice K.

description:
We went, we slurped, we paid good money. 

This place has a decent spot in the Japantown mall, not too cramped but definitely not spacious.

Service was prompt, naturally hurried, and efficient.

The food was good, but nothing really stood out for me as particularly good.

Just your standard high quality ramen. It tasted good, but I mean, other places still have the edge on this one.

Both places outside the mall in the plaza have a bigger menu and better ramen, but I won't poop all over this one for that.

Step the game up!
author: John W.

description:
I was so happy to discover Marufuku Ramen uses Yelp's remote waitlist! I put myself in line an hour ahead of time, and took my sweet time getting down to the restaurant.

The restaurant is fairly small, and the tables barely have any space between them. I could hear every word in the conversations of the adjacent tables. Overall, it was pretty loud and hectic inside.

Service was almost too fast, which I'm sure is necessary to turn tables over to accommodate the perpetually long waiting list. Our waitress took our order momentarily after the hostess had seated us; good thing we had time to read the menu while waiting for an hour. Within another five minutes of ordering, all our food had come out:

Geso fry (fried squid legs): These were perfectly hot and crispy, served with a small dollop of Japanese mayo. Highly recommend if you like squid.

Hakata DX (deluxe) ramen: This seemed to be the most highly recommended ramen. It's pretty loaded with different veggie toppings, and of course comes with generous slabs of pork belly. The noodles were very firm and chewy, which is to my liking. However, it's not for everyone, and they don't seem to offer different levels of firmness for the noodles.

What rubbed me the wrong way was that our waitress seemed eager for us to leave. She gave us our check maybe fifteen minutes into our meal, even though our table was still full of food and drink. As we dined over the course of just ~30 minutes, she regularly peered over to see if we were ready to pay. Again, I get that they want to seat as many people as possible, but I hate feeling unwelcome like I'm being rushed out of a restaurant.
author: Yuki P.

description:
GREAT RAMEN. Wow! This place's flagship ramen, the Hakata Tonkotsu, did not disappoint in the least.

HACK - GET this dish, the Hakata Tonkotsu, with the braised pork belly as an additional topping for only $3.50, and you basically get the the Hakata DX (which is $14.99) for only $14.49, WITH the simmered pork belly that comes with the regular Hakata Tonkotsu. I'm not sure why the Hakata DX is a full $4 more in cost with respect to the Hakata Tonkotsu. Either they aren't good at math (unlikely as all Asians are remarkably good at math) or they WANT you to do this.

Hakata Tonkotsu with Braised Pork Belly - SO good. The braised pork belly is a MUST here. GET THIS AT ALL COSTS. The pork belly was so tender and each bite quite simply just melts and falls apart in your mouth. Your teeth basically sink into the flesh like it was nothing more than some butter on a warm day. ALL the other toppings fit quite well with the rest of the ramen to form an incredibly cohesive ensemble of flavors. I found myself enjoying all the toppings in each and every bite. HOLY CRAP this is so good!! The broth is amazing as well - rich and robust with flavor, it is so soothing and unbelievably welcoming. I don't know how they were able to infuse so much flavor into it and they must have simmered those pork marrow bones for an eternity. I basically felt like I was drinking essence of marrow. 

Mentaiko Bowl - I enjoyed this very much but this dish definitely played second fiddle to the incredible bowl of ramen and I wasn't able to finish it all. I've never had this dish before  and my friend mentioned to me that usually the dish is served with intact cod roes, instead of the macerated ones that came with this one. He didn't seem to like that, but I enjoyed it a lot! I can imagine though that having those little unharmed pearls pop in your mouth would be a refreshing feeling. Good appetizer regardless!

Overall I am SO happy that I waited in line for probably about an hour to try this place out. My friends and I were definitely contemplating ditching the line here and trying some other nearby ramen place, as there are plenty nearby. That bowl of ramen may have been the best I've ever had (I'm having trouble racking my brain for a better one at the moment), and if not, it was most certainly in the top 5. TRY THIS PLACE OUT AND GET THAT BRAISED PORK BELLY!!!!
author: Michael P.

description:
This place is the reason that made me write my first Yelp review you are reading right now. Ramen is my favorite food and I have tried a lot of places in the city. I heard a lot about that place, so my expectations were quite high.

We put our name on the list and we had to wait about an hour to get seated. But, we didn't have to wait in line, they send you a message some minutes before your table is ready.

Our order came really fast. We ordered Chicken Karrage (Japanese style fried chicken) and Takouaki (Octopus balls) for appetizers which both were really good! We had hot sake as well and 2 x Hakata DX Ramen. This ramen is honestly the best I've tried in the city and one of the best I had in my life! The broth is so milky and savorous that gives you the authentic umami flavor you expect to find in a Tonkotsu ramen plate. Literally, this plate went me back 6 years ago when I was in Fukuoka, Japan tasting a local Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen dish! It was like Deja Vu, like living the same moments again. All of a sudden all those flavors residing in my memory for all those years began to come alive again! The katsu (pork) was also very similar to the one I had at that time, in big bite-size chunks as it should be. Also, the egg as jammy as I would expect to be.

There are no other words to describe this plate. I will visit this place again and again and I will let other people know about this gem!

The only pros I could find is that the bowls could be a bit wider so that the noodles would be more sparsed letting you enjoy the ramen better, since there is a big portion of noodles there.
author: Thanos P.

description: One of my favorites for a quick weeknight meal.  Tasty, quick service and friendly staff.
author: Joe S.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner and was reasonably impressed. I got the Hakata Tonkotsu with braised pork belly in the side. I would definitely recommend getting this instead of the Hakata DX, since it's basically the same but with more meat. The braised pork is huge and delicious, and the noodles are plentiful and perfectly cooked.

I think I do prefer Ippudo in Berkeley. Marufuku's broth is saltier (especially if you get any spice), and the simmered pork belly is somewhat tough. However, Marufuku is still very solid. The wait isn't even that bad, since you can browse the nearby stores in Japantown.
author: Serena J.

description:
Meh.  I hate to say it, but I think this place is overhyped.  

My party of 8 was able to get to the restaurant 20 minutes before opening and was 3rd in line.  We made it into the first seating and the food came out quickly.

I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu DX.  While the pork belly was high quality and tasty, I wasn't impressed by the broth at all.  The broth was fatty and creamy like Tonkotsu should be, but it was lacking the depth of flavor that I typically expect with a Tonkotsu broth.  I much prefer when Tonkotsu is at least a little bit garlilcky- without the garlic, the broth felt overly heavy on my palette.  The noodles were also thinner than I prefer, but had a nice consistency.  The soft boiled egg was my favorite part of the dish.  It was perfectly cooked with a soft, yolky middle (make sure you dig it out of the bottom of your bowl before it gets overcooked).

Overall, my party enjoyed their meals, but I would definitely not wait in line for this place in the future.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I was running errands nearby and decided to try Marufuku.  It was 1 pm on a weekday and I was hoping that the wait would not be too long.  I signed in and was told 22 people were ahead of me.  Let's not panic, I told myself.  Within 5 minutes, the line was shortened by 6 parties.  In another 5 minutes, another 5 spots opened up.  In total, I waited approximately 30 minutes before my table was ready.  

After a quick review of the limited menu I chose the Hakata DX, which is the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen with additional braised pork belly and corn.  Note that the portions are not huge and remind me more of the portion sizes in Japan. I inquired about the spice levels and was encouraged to go with the Medium spicy option with the recommendation to add additional hot pepper seasoning if it wasn't spicy enough.  I'm glad I went with this option because Medium spicy wasn't that spicy (just a hint of spiciness) but the additional pepper seasoning that they provide to you had a kick!

The ramen arrive hot and steaming approximately 5 minutes after ordering.  The broth was thick, rich and creamy from the many hours of cooking bones to make the pork stock.  The noodles were slightly chewy and the generous portion of pork belly was fatty, meaty and very tender.   The egg was soft boiled and had a creamy, runny yolk.  This bowl of ramen was perfection and so very delicious.  While appearing to be small, the portion was the perfect amount of noodles, broth, meat and vegetables.  I was satisfied, but not stuffed.

Tables turn over fairly quickly as most people seemed to leave soon after they finished eating.  While the staff did not urge anyone to leave, they don't do anything to encourage folks to hang around either.  Checks arrive soon after you are finished eating but not in such a way that you feel you are being rushed.  They are friendly and kind while also being very efficient at preparing new tables for the next customer.  They know how to handle long lines and crowds here.  Some single parties were asked if they minded sharing their table with other solo diners.

One of the best features is using Yelp to handle their waiting list.  It's so easy to see where you are on the list and to better anticipate how much longer you have before returning to the restaurant entrance.  I received a phone call and a message when I made it to the top of the list.
author: Melissa L.

description:
I've been dying to come back here but the ultra long wait times during the weekends is always a bit discouraging. I decided to visit again on a Monday evening at 7:30 PM and there was still surprisingly a long line! Luckily the wait wasn't too bad and we were able to get seated in 30 minutes. Note to self, eat a snack before waiting in line. 

We ordered the Chicken Karaage, Hakata DX Ramen, and Chicken Paitan DX Ramen, and of course some Sapporo beer. The food was spectacular and I was impressed by how quickly the food came out! The Chicken Karaage is a must try, especially if you're a fried chicken fanatic. The chicken was juicy and tasted delicious dipped in the aioli. 

I also really enjoyed my Chicken Paitan DX Ramen Bowl! The broth was light and flavorful and the egg was also perfectly runny. I also love that it comes with a sizzling plate of chicken on the size. It definitely is worth the $15 and you'll definitely leave feeling full!

I'm looking forward to coming back again during those chilly SF nights. I'm sure the wait times will still be crazy though...
author: MyTien P.

description:
We ran into this gem in Japantown. I remember  hearing that this is the best ramen place in town, and it is!!!

We ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu and the Hakata DX (braised pork belly, rich noodles, kikurage mushrooms, egg, and bean sprouts).The Tonkotsu builds on the DX and comes with corn and simmered pork belly. 

This was my first time trying ramen with a pork based broth, as opposed to the soy sauce based broth. It wasn't salty at all and was very tasty! The best item we had was the Marufuku Bits (steamed pork buns), they were not soggy in the least bit and the pork was so tender and flavorful! I do wish the eggs were soy sauce eggs, though.
author: Samantha A.

description:
This is the best ramen I've ever had.  Yes it's always busy, but they are super efficient, and have great waitstaff.  

In the last 4 days I went 3 times with my wife for lunch, because we couldn't get enough!!!
author: Aaron P.

description: Finally I got to try their chicken ramen with the grill chicken. Grill chicken isn't anything wow but the chicken ramen is good.  Service is good too and fast. Note to self, make reservation on yelp .. we didn't have to wait at all and we reserve on the same day. It even tells us how many ahead of you. Pretty cool to use Yelp for this location. No wait unless you come before they open.
author: Christy V.

description:
A bit of a Yelp surprise with the waiting list feature.  Wow, 30 minutes wait but wait, I am 15 minutes by Uber away. Puurrrfecttt!  Drop my name, call the car, zip in with 10 minutes to spare, name already on the iPad wait list, oohhh we be next! Now that is convenience.  Love this feature.  
Hip but small.  Cool modern take on zaishki tatami seating is the centerpiece of the room.  Love the solid hardwood tables.  Small window into a happening kitchen on one side.  Simple menu, busy servers all working the space 
Hakata tonkotsu ramen is the only reason to be seated.  A few very reasonable priced apps and sides.  Beer and sake offerings available.  Wish they had a Japanese draft but Asahi from Canada will have to do.  Order and then...
Less than 5 minutes later the apps start coming.  Wow!   Ok, pork kakuni is a dish up and the takoyaki is a premade deep fry but still... that's fast.  And the noodle dish is only 3 minutes behind.  No wonder we cleared the waitlist quick.  This kitchen rocks!  Presentation is clean, kakuni portion was huge @ 6oz of cooked pork belly for $7!!! That and a bowl of rice would have been a meal in itself.  Ramen broth was deep tasty, wish it was smoking hot but still more than warm enough.  Thin chewy noodles with the soft boiled tamago lurking underneath like a baby chicken submarine!  Food is on point!
Pay the check as the line is still 15 parties deep and we out of there in 30 minutes flat.  This place has their act together.  No wonder they are #1.   Go and put your name on the waitlist NOW!
author: David W.

description:
Marufuku is among the best ramen places I've tried. Get there early! It opens at 5:30 PM for dinner, my party lined up at 5 PM, and we just made it in before the folks behind us had to sign up on the waiting list. That being said, the turnover is pretty fast and the food comes out lightning quick.

The incentive for getting there early is getting the chicken paitan deluxe. There are only 15 servings! The chicken leg that comes with the set has some sort of soy sauce based marinade. Yes, think of it like soy sauce chicken on flavor steroids. It was well worth getting there early and paying the extra price. The chicken ramen itself was surprisingly delicious. It comes with thin, lean, juicy slices of chicken. The broth was flavorful and it carried throughout the rest of the components. Heck, even the corn niblets were packed with flavor!

The ramen is not too oily or heavy, and in comparison to other ramen places I've eaten at, I felt GREAT after slurping up the bowl.
author: Matt H.

description:
If you enjoy making strangers feel awkward by showing your Snapchat buds how long the line is, this is the place for you. When I first arrived at 5 there wasn't a line. Come back 10 minutes later and there's already 5 parties waiting. At opening, the line was already stretched to the crepe shop on the other side. Absolutely dumbfounding. 

When you first sit down, you're immediately given a grand high end impression. The aesthetic was pleasing and the music and atmosphere made it feel classy. As soon as guest are let in, you can see the kitchen ready to go and servers with no hesitation. 

Now here is why Marufuku to me, is 4 star and not a 5. For dinner I ordered Chicken Karaage ($6.50) and Hakata Deluxe ($16.99). In total at the end with tip and tax, I was spending almost $30 on one dinner for just myself. I'm not criticizing the pricing model. I'm criticizing how dull it was to pay $7 for 5 small pieces of Karaage. How for $17, the portion size for a deluxe bowl was comparable to standard bowls at other shops. If the pricing was in the taste that would be fine. And that's not to say that my meal wasn't delicious, it definitely was. But there wasn't an X factor that justified the pricing and the hype. There wasn't a reason why if you wanted soul lifting ramen, you would come here over other nearby stores. It made me really consider what it would of been like to have ordered one of their standard bowls. 

Overall, Marufuku is a fancy joint with delicious ramen. It's expensive and you could get the same tasting experience at any other store with no line. My main point for Marufukus is that there's nothing to justify the pricing and long line. I didn't find it in the service, the waitresses were pressured to get people in and out. And the "deluxe" broth and noodles were unbiasedly comparable to other shops. But all this is just due to high standards. Don't let my critiques downplay how much their ramen will hit the spot.
author: Tony N.

description:
This place is easily 4.5 stars & worth the wait. Let's start with the appetizers. 

Chicken Karaage is flavorful & not greasy. I say better than average. The Geso fry (squid legs) is really nice, crunchy & again not greasy.

We ordered the Hakata DX Ramen which did not disappoint. The broth was rich, deep, & very flavorful. The ramen is the thinner type which is usually not my favorite. However, this ramen seems really special. It has great texture & mouth feel. I describe it as "bouncy"! Every ingredient in the Hakata DX complemented it, except for the braised pork belly. It was kind of dry on the non-fatty parts.

We tried some special beer called DaiDai & Red Rice, unfortunately both disappointed. The DaiDai was bitter & medicinal while the Red Rice was just nothing special.

One suggestion to the business, please have your servers wash their hands prior to handling any food after touching their cell phones, which we observed happened often. Did you know that cell phones are reservoirs for all things germy? Yuck!

Fortunately your ramen is well above average, so we'll be back! We do hope to see more hand washing next time.
author: Amen C.

description: Best ramen in the Bay. The wait can be quite long, so I highly suggest checking in on the Yelp waitlist an hour before you intend on arriving so that you can save some time. The queue goes pretty quickly as service is immediate. You get your food within 5-10 minutes of sitting down and the servers are very diligent with checking in on you, refilling your water, and getting you in and out. The Hakata DX is the best since it's got all the toppings.
author: Patty B.

description:
Very bland, got all excited from all the hype and went after watching a show in SF.
I prefer Nojo ramen.
author: tabitha l.

description: Had the chicken deluxe ramen and the tako balls. The chicken drumstick was good but slightly salty. The broth is white and concentrated, but salty as well. I loved the tako balls though!
author: Vivian L.

description:
I am just now walking out of this establishment completely changed. Granted, I have only had restaurant ramen a few times (broke college kids like me add an egg to their Top Ramen when they're feeling fancy) so I am definitely not a connoisseur, but this was beyond incredible especially given the price (12.99 plus tax and tip for a simple bowl, which I have learned is modest in this city). The one drawback is the wait time, but I took that opportunity to explore Fillmore Street and Japantown by checking in through my phone. It was a two hour wait, but well worth it. In fact, once you get inside, the service is whiplash fast--since I ate here alone, they sat me with a stranger who had a flight at 10:25. We were seated at 8:55, and he was out the door by 9:15. The service is phenomenal given how speedy it is.

The simple chicken bowl with medium spice made me reconsider my dinner plans for tomorrow because of how delicious it was. If you have the sense to plan ahead and get on the waitlist, I cannot recommend this place enough!
author: Juliesa C.

description:
I made the mistake coming on a Saturday, even though I got here roughly at 5pm.  There was 39 parties in front of us, and it took about an hour ten minutes.  While we waited, we really went window shopping all around Japan town, and other customers went to get ice cream.  I'm all for that!  
I didn't regret it because the turnaround was really fast.  The ramen came in about 7 minutes and we ate for about 15 because we scarfed it down.  Both of us went down to the last bit of broth.  Best ramen I've had, hands down.  When I commend ramen, I'm really pointing out the broth and the proportions that come with it.  The broth marrying the sufficient amount of pork belly, corn, seaweed, and the broth are so perfect in the Hakata DX (medium spicy).  Get the medium spicy.  It makes a difference in taste compared to the mild.  It's a little more change to spend for ramen but it's worth it!  The dark meat of the pork is my favorite.  We ordered the karaage as well.  Karaage is karaage, but the creamy sauce sums it up. 
I also didn't regret coming here because they had a good timekeeping system for customers they use through Yelp.  You can track to see how many parties are before you and watch the number quickly go down.  You get a call 5 minutes to about your turn, so just wait on the right side in front of the entrance in line.  Wait for the host to call your name.
The restaurant is actually on the second level inside the mall right behind the stairs.
Restrooms are in the right corner of Japan town upon exiting Marufuku.
I absolutely loved the classic/real jazz playing and the cute bench that formed a square in the center for patrons dubed as really cute decor!
author: Janet T.

description: If you are in search of an upscale, best of the best ramen place, look no further.  Came here with a friend and got the large Hakata ramen, Marufuku balls, and fried chicken over rice.  The pork in the Marufuku balks was sweeter than honey, and the fried chicken over rice was the perfect appetizer.  As for the ramen, the soup was as thick as the pork itself, and the pork was as soft as butter.  The interior was comforting and had a modern but authentic feel.  We arrived 5 minutes before the restaurant opened for dinner and were met by a long line, but luckily were seated right away.  Wow.
author: John S.

description: First time here, and I love this place! The atmosphere is very nice: warm, ambient lighting and jazzy music is played in the background. The staff here is very attentive and made sure our water glasses were always full. The ramen came very quickly- all six of our orders were filled in about 10 minutes. I ordered a Hakata DX(deluxe) and the meat practically melted in my mouth. I also love the soft boiled egg. The difference between Hakata Tonkotsu and DX seems minimal though- so for the extra $4 I'd order the normal Hakata Tonkotsu instead of the DX.
author: Tammy W.

description:
A long wait but it was all
Worthy, the food is amazing best ramen in town in my opinion.
author: Carlos B.

description: The ramen is so good get the pork deluxe and the chicken karage. The spicy isnt so spicy. The squid is like calamari. Get to the place early and plan to wait for a long time however it is worth it!
author: Nan T.

description: This is a decent ramen place but not the best . Go here when in the hood. Service is okay but nothing to rave about. I'll be back here and there
author: Eileen G.

description:
Venue: Located kitty corner from Kinokuniya on the 2nd floor of Kintetsu mall in Japantown. 

Time: 4.55 pm on a Wednesday and we were the first in line; Crowd grew steadily to 15 by 5.15pm and it swelled to at least 30 by 5.30 pm when Marufuku opened. Crowd was mostly millennials in their early 30s and everyone was promptly seated. Another line started to form.

Ramen along with curry rice are treasured in Japan far more than sushi and miso. I'm not talking about instant ramen, the sustenance of a poor college student but the Marufuku kind, which is the culmination of hours of labor of love and soulful rituals. That's what Marafuku mean by 'real artisan flavor' where everything in Marafuku is painstakingly hand made and made from scratch.  This is indeed a breath of fresh air for Japantown as ramen in the Mall has hitherto been mostly underwhelming.
 
The long and short of Marufuku's menu boils down to either Chicken Paitan ramen or Hakata style tonkotsu ramen. In either case, the key is their full-bodied broth and firm ramen texture. The creamy white broth was made from long hours of cooking chicken or pork bones, the holy grail of ramen bases. The broth in some other ramen-ya can be overly chicken-y or porky but not here. Long hours of slow boiling in Marufuku paid off with good balance of flavors, good depths without being overly fatty or salty. Hakata style implied thin noodles were used and they were definitely al dente and slurpable.

The toppings in each were pretty standard like corn, kikurage (cloud ear mushroom), nori, beni shoga (pickled ginger) etc but deserving special mention was the hanjuku tamago (soft boiled egg) buried under the noodles. The ramen egg is soft boiled where the white is cooked through but the yolk remains runny so you can twirl the yolk around and mix with the broth. The egg I had was a tad too well done and the yolk not as runny as I had hoped. The simmered pork belly had a little fat, which I ignored coz it was so tender that it just melted in my mouth.

So it was a no brainer that we picked one from each style, Hakata Tonkotsu  ($11.99) and Chicken Paitan DX ($15.99) to share.  The Chicken Paitan came with an added bonus..... A sizzling plate of a good-sized soy braised chicken leg nestled on top of a bed of bean sprouts. It was delicious and tender but quickly lost its scrumptiousness when the chicken started to cool off.

The interior was elegantly appointed in contemporary style with generous usage of natural wood carpentry throughout the smallish dining room.  Service was non-existent albeit lightning fast. It took only 10 minutes tops for food to be served.  In this sense, ramen eating may be regarded as fast food as the proper etiquette is to slurp both the broth (sans spoon) and noodles as fast as you can from the bowl and create as much racket as you wish in the process! 

Gochisosama deshita (Thanks for the meal)
author: Geoff G.

description:
Got a recommendation from a friend about the delicious ramen at Marufuku.  We finally made it for dinner on a Thursday. The restaurant can be a little challenging to find as it is located on the second floor across from the Kinokuniya Books in the mall building on Post and Webster, not in the main mall complex. 

Read about the waiting lines here on Yelp, so we got there at 5pm for their 5:30pm opening. Still we were about 20th in line. When the restaurant opened, the hostess sat the patrons and whew! we did get seated.  The restaurant is modern with seating for about 50 patrons with mainly tables, but there are three large booths. 

After reading fellow Yelper reviews, we had our minds set as to what we were going to order.  When the waiter brought our water, we were ready and placed our orders.  You can order broth with no spice, mild, medium, spicy or ultra spicy.

Hakata DX - It's similar to Hakata Tonkatsu with its Hakata style ramen with rich pork broth, soft boiled egg, corn, green onions, kikurage mushrooms and bean sprouts.  The difference? It has braised pork belly instead of simmered pork belly.  The pork was tender.  Now I have to try the simmered pork belly on the Hakata Tonkatsu. 

Chicken Paitan DX - a chicken ramen with rich white Paitan broth, chicken chashu, soft boiled egg, corn, green onions, kikurage mushrooms and bean sprouts.  A grilled chicken thigh and leg comes on the side. The menu states that this dish is limited to 15 servings.  So it's pretty much a dish that will be available for the first two sittings. The chicken come out in a sizzling hot plate. While we were there, at least 10 patrons ordered it.  The broth was delicious and full of flavor. The chicken was moist and flavorful. 

The bowls might look small, but they are deceiving deep.  So the portion is a good size. The broths on both were the highlights, so rich and tasty.  Egg was perfectly cooked. 

One of the best tasting ramens I've had.  Now I can see why there's a waiting line here.
author: Al L.

description:
Cute little ramen place in Japantown. We had heard that they don't take reservations and lines/wait times can get very long, so we came here around 11:20am on a Wednesday (they open at 11:30am). Getting here early was a good idea, as a line was already starting to form. We were able to be seated when they opened, and service thereafter was quite fast. 

There were 4 different types of ramen, two pork and two chicken-based, and each could be ordered with a number of different spice levels. I opted for the Hakata tonkatsu ($11.99), a ramen with pork broth, simmered pork belly, soft boiled egg, green onions, mushrooms and bean sprouts. The broth was flavorful and delicious without being too fatty. I love that they included an entire soft-boiled egg, and 3 pieces of tender pork belly. The noodles were a bit thinner and smaller than the chewy flat ramen noodles I have had at other places, but they were quite good as well. It was a ton of food and I left in a pleasant food coma after finishing all of the bowl and the broth.
author: Amy C.

description:
I wanted to try Marufuku Ramen from all the great reviews, and it did not disappoint. I put my name down and we ended up waiting 30 minutes which isn't too bad because we were able to walk around and look at the various shops around the restaurant.

We ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen.  The ramen came in less then 5 minutes and I took a sip of the soup and immediately knew that this was good ramen. The soup had the depth and complexity of it being cooked for many hours.  The noodles were chewy and on the thin side but that is expected of Hakata style ramen.

I'd recommend going there when it first opens to get the first seating. But if not, waiting 30 minutes or more at a mall that has lots of shops to pass the time isn't so bad.
author: Nette T.

description:
I enjoyed both the Hakata Tonkotsu $10.99 and the Tonkotsu Deluxe with an extra egg $16.74. I actually don't care much for the fatty pork belly in most ramen soups so I ordered an extra egg  in mine. I don't like the corn in ramen either so I just eat all of the corn first haha. The broths are excellent. They are pretty salty so I might be ordering a cup of hot water to add to the broth next time. 

I tried Ippudo in New York and I think Marufuku's seems just as good. The Paitan Deluxe with the chicken on the side was tasty although more labor intensive. The chicken had nice char on it.

It's located on the second floor of the Japan Center.

Service was good. The wait wasn't long because we arrived about 5 minutes before they opened for dinner on a weekday. There was already a crowd waiting.
author: Thien H.

description:
Alright, this place has got to be one of my favorite ramen places of all time including ones in Japan. I swear the broth is just so good and the noodles had the perfect texture. 

We came here on a Saturday late morning just about they're about to open and there was already a crazy long line. They started seating people right away once they open but unfortunately we just missed the first wave so we had to put our name on the waiting list. If you don't get here about 30 minutes before they open you can probably expect to wait about an hour depending on the size of your party. 

Since we were the 5 name on the waiting list we waited about 30 minutes after they opened (we got there about 20 minutes before opening so in total it was about a 50 minute wait). Good thing it's located inside the Japan center so there's an abundance of stores to browse in the meantime. 

Anyway, as for the ramen, I got the tonkotsu DX. The pork was super tender and the soft boiled egg was just about perfection. 

My boyfriend got the chicken paitan DX which is their signature ramen and they supposedly only have 15 servings a day. What's interesting about the chicken ramen was the giant piece of chicken leg on the side. I liked it but not as much as the tonkotsu. My boyfriend said it's like a more flavorful chicken noodle soup lol. 

For appetizers we got the geso fry and they were also really good. 

To top it off, the service was super efficient. They were really attentive and got our checks to us before we asked for it!!

Amazing.
author: Mi N.

description:
Very long wait,  this Ramen is in high demand.  We waited  nearly 3 hours for a table.  Got in right after closing hours at 9pm.  

Quick service,  in and out,  order food,  no up selling or putting you through a dining experience with sever personalities.

Raman is too die for,  4 of 5 stars is for food,  the last star would be for service as it was good but wasn't personal for our table.  

Bill was about $78.00 for 4x people.  2x apps, 4 Raman's, 2x Coke's, and 1 Japanese beer.  

They could use a bigger space with more servers and could do some serious damage with revenue and raving reviews.
author: Will S.

description:
4.5 Stars! Marufuku Ramen is a Hakata style ramen shop, serving excellent quality ramen with super thin noodles and rich pork broth cooked over 20 hours. They are located inside the Japantown Mall, on the second floor, diagonally across from the popular Kinokuniya bookstore. My first tip is to get here early because even before the doors open at 11:30am, there is a line forming. We came early on a Saturday before opening, but not early enough, as we didn't make it into the first round of seating. We had to wait about 30 minutes for the next seating. The restaurant is clean and modern, but if you need to use the restroom, you have to go out to the mall. 

The Hakata DX ($15.99) is the way to go! Delicious braised pork belly, rich pork broth, thin noodles, soft boiled egg, corn, green onions. kikurage mushrooms, and bean spouts...the best on the menu! There is a good amount of pork belly (thank God!) and the broth was very tasty. If you don't see the egg at first, don't worry. It is usually hiding at the bottom of the bowl.

Takoyaki ($6.50) for 5 pieces. These were not bad. There were just small pieces of chewy octopus inside of the soft fried ball. There isn't a lot of octopus, but it still tasted ok. 

Marufuku is one of the better "artisan" ramen shops in San Francisco. All of their dishes are handmade with quality. It's definitely a very worthwhile destination if you are looking for great ramen.
author: Jean S.

description:
Some of the best Paitan Ramen I have ever had!!

Sure people complain about the line ( aint no line at Al's house of food poisoning!).

Their bone broth is thick, rich, unctuous, and bursting with flavor It is not white like the stuff I had in Tokyo before but more orange...probably from the spice level I picked.

Marufuku Ramen is a lovely little restaurant on the second floor of Japan town. The decor is simple but elegant. Service is pleasant and efficient. Prices are pretty reasonable. The Chicken Paitan Deluxe is a large meal consisting of a sizzling iron platter of a quarter chicken served on a bed of bean sprouts and a very large bowl of Ramen.

The ramen is served with the typical garnishes: fresh corn, nori, noodles ( yes they are thin and not thick), chashu,  scallions, kikurage and the best part ( and you must hunt for it) the soft poached egg at the bottom of the bowl....explode that sucker and release the yolk.

This broth will really make you happy btw!!!

You have the option of choosing 5 levels of spice. The medium was perfect.

Tips: Get there 15 minutes before opening on weekends or if it fills up sign the waiting list on the door.

Pass on the appetizers their Takoyaki was pretty blah at best.

They only make 15 of the Chicken Paitan deluxe a night so do not hesitate.

Lastly get a tall boy of Asahi or Saporo to wash it all down.


Kampai!!!!
author: David G.

description:
BEST RAMEN I'VE HAD IN THE BAY AREA.

Where do I even begin, this place has my favorite ramen and honestly after trying this place, every other ramen I've tried has been so unsatisfying. I've had Mensho, Orenchi, Ippudo, etc., BUT NONE OF THEM CAN EVEN COMPARE TO MARUFUKU. Their broth is so good, its so rich without an overpower fattiness, the noodles are the thin kind and are nice and firm, and the pork is delicious. Their takoyaki and chicken karage are really good too. The chicken is seasoned nicely and is super moist, and the takoyaki comes out piping hot and tastes so much fresher than other restaurants. Definitely give this place a try and I can almost guarantee you that ramen at any other restaurant (outside Japan) cannot even compare to the bowls of ramen at Marufuku.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
SO GOOD.  I went on a whim and when I saw on Yelp it's really popular, I hopped into line despite not being very hungry.  Oh well, I'm on vacation.

I get in and i'm swiftly seated at opening.  They're used to this busyness because they're at my table in a minute asking if I'm ready. Thankfully I am!

I started out with the karaage.  Yummy!  Not mega hot so I'm able to scarf it down.  Next I got the Hakata DX with medium spice.  Glad I didn't bump it up because that was spicy enough!  The server was patient enough to answer my silly question of 'how spicy is medium' so I think I chose well.  She told me that I should start a level down and go up with the spice on the table.  

Now, I've eaten a lot of ramen, instant and restaurant.  This is easily top 5 I've had even in Japan!  The broth is so rich and flavorful.  Not only that but they were so fast.  Again, not playing around in making people wait around when you have a successful ramen shop. 

They also have a great waiting system.  Love when restaurants will text you when your table is ready as opposed to waiting around close by.
author: Brandon B.

description: Great broth and chashu was amazing. Was it worth 90min wait? Perhaps not... But worth a try for sure. There are just too many good ramen in Bay Area - if you are close by definitely give it a go.
author: Yiran P.

description:
Great Yelp reviews, long lines as you walk by... It's gotta be good!

What's the chances of a small wait if you show up 30 minutes before 5pm on a Saturday?... Hahahaha I was kidding myself. Long line so we said might as well wait. Well doors opened and we snagged the very last table for the first seating. Phew that was lucky! 

Now onto the food! I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen for $11.99 and my bf ordered the Hakata DX for $15.99. Bowls are the same size, only difference is the DX comes with corn and braised pork belly while the cheaper option comes with simmered pork belly and no corn. 

We agreed that it's a good deal for the Hakata Tonkotsu but not for the DX. 

Staff were friendly though and coming around regularly to refill waters and clear the table... They also want to turn the tables so haha yeah. But good service.

I'll go back.
author: Mandi W.

description:
I had really high expectations of this place after seeing Yelp reviews and having a friend tell me about it. Fell just a tad short of my expectations.

Pros:
- Their homemade chashu is aMAZing. Definitely trying out the chashu buns. The meat is fall apart tender and packed with flavor.
- The ramen broth is rich and flavorful.

Cons:
- Their marinated egg in the ramen was not marinated. It was just a regular boiled egg which I was disappointed about since this is one of my favorite parts of a bow of ramen.
- Their noodles are super thin, like angel hair pasta. Not your standard ramen noodle. I'm not a fan but maybe some folks prefer that?
author: Rachel U.

description:
Service here was quick! We got our orders taken only a few minutes after being seated and our food was also served within a matter of minutes!

The ramen was great! The portion sizes here are a bit smaller than what I'm normally used to from other ramen places, but the quality definitely makes up for it!

(Make sure to come at least 30 minutes early before opening, since a line typically starts to form right around then. If you're unable to make it early, you can add yourself to the waiting list on yelp!)
author: Katelynn A.

description: I absolutely LOVE this place for their ramen dish. The staff didn't speak the best english but that helps immerse one within the organic vibes! Great place
author: Marlow S.

description:
I got to Marufuku about 20 minutes before Sunday dinner, and was surprised to see no line. After positioning myself in front of the door, many  people who I thought were just hanging out on the floor gradually made their way behind me, and in less than ten minutes the line stretched across the floor. It was a rather interesting sight to behold!

We got the Chicken Paitan DX and Hakata DX to share among three people; we weren't too hungry at the time, and the portion was just right. The grilled chicken leg was nothing short of amazing - piping hot, fall off the bone, right amount of flavor, tender, ... the list goes on! The ramen broth was excellent as well, and brought the other wonderfully cooked components together. The ramen itself is a solid 4, but the chicken leg brings my rating up to a 5. 

Amid the craziness of the place, the team and place still gave off a warm and friendly vibe; the servers checked on us regularly, and the environment was overall very inviting. Hope to be back again for the chicken!
author: Yen Ting L.

description:
Expect long lines, 1hr or more.  But also expect awesome food.  4.5stars.  Even if you have a large party, you may be able to be seated before smaller parties.  It just depends on which tables open up.  There are a lot of stores around, so it does help pass the time. 

I went around 8pm and waited about 45min to have a delicious bowl of hakata tonkatsu DX. I loved the thin noodles, which is different than some of the other ramen places.  They give you so much meat.  The chashu is amazing.  It's so tender, juicy, and flavorful.  They give you a thick piece along with a few thinner pieces.  The broth is amazing as well.  They ooze of the fat from the meat, which gives it so much flavor.  All the different topping add to the bowl as well.  They don't clash at all.  I love the soft boiled egg that's cooked with the right texture.  

Marufuku offers 5 levels of spiciness.  I ordered #3 (medium), but I should've gone with a #4 (spicy).  Medium adds a little bit of kick, but it's not that spicy.  It was $15.99, a bit higher priced that other bowls of ramen, but considering how much meat and toppings they give, it's worth it.

I also tried tried their small salad.  It was ok.  Didn't care for the dressing.  It was sweet and sour, but a bit too sweet for my taste.  

I'll definitely come back to try some of the other stuff.  I'll come before I get hungry and just spend my time waiting at the small shops around.
author: Shirley C.

description: The wait was really long. But, luckily we could check the updated waiting time on our phone. I like the texture of ramen, but I wish I asked for a little bit firm noodle. Chashu is good, not a big fan of pork belly. I do like their broth.
author: Grace L.

description:
One of the best ramen spots in San Francisco! I ordered the "chicken paitan" and loves the broth It was so creamy and yummy! We also got the takoyaki and the geso fry. The takoyaki was awesome!

The only downside about this spot is the long wait! We had to wait for 1.5 hrs in line!
author: Haya D.

description:
This is my second visit to Marafuku. I thought about the ramen for months after visiting 2 months prior. My boyfriend and I weren't fond of the type of noodles that they serve, but the ramen at Marafuku was the only place that seemed to compare to Hawaii's ramen joints we frequented.

This time, instead of going with a party of 2, we had 3. This heavily affected our wait time. Last time, when it was just my boyfriend and I we waited about 20 minutes. You will see a similar trend that parities with 2 move faster in the list. The establishment is very small so parties larger than 2 take more time since people are sitting longer. We waited about 1hour~1hour 15 minutes. I was contemplating if the wait was worth it but I wasn't willing to try anything around the area.

When we entered, we were given water. The water seemed to taste and smell weird.. I thought that it was just my cup, but my boyfriend and his mom's cup also smelled fishy. We decided to not drink the water. It wasn't a deal breaker tho! My boyfriend and I got the Hakata DX while his mom got the Tonkatsu ramen. It was exactly what I remembered except.. It wasn't spicy at all! I love to have my ramen spicy so that was just one part that disappointed me. I was going to ask for them to make it spicier but I remembered I didn't have any water to aid me with the spiciness.. 

The bowl looks very deceiving! It looks tiny but when you dig in.. you'll find a bunch of things like a boiled egg, corn, beans sprouts, etc. It'll fill your stomach so don't let your eyes be bigger than your stomach!

TIP: If you like your egg soft boiled, take out the egg as soon as you can.. Mines was fully cooked when I remembered I had an egg :'(
author: Thuyen P.

description:
Very popular grub in Japantown, so be prepared for a wait, especially during peak hours. We came for Sunday lunch, and waited ~45 min for a table for 5. 

Food: The ramen comes in good portions, and the broth is flavorful without being overly salty. We got the Tonkatsu Pork Ramen and cod rice. The Ramen was pretty good, with a creamy broth and chewy consistency. The Cod rice was decent, but a bit too spicy for my liking. 

Service: polite and fast. Would definitely recommend this place if you can stand the wait on an empty belly.
author: Chenchen S.

description:
If you plan to come eat here you gotta come early before the restaurant opens. If not prepare to wait in line. This place is worth waiting 30 mins for.

Get the chicken paitan DX! It comes with a quarter chicken and the ramen broth was light that gave me the some comfort as chicken noodle soup. Omg the egg was hands down one of the best soft boiled egg I've ever had. The noodles didn't remind me of ramen noodles. They were thin and honestly I could have ordered extra noodles.
author: Jackie N.

description: Best ramen you'll ever eat. The chicken flavor comes with a drumstick; the most delicious and most savory flavored chicken you will ever eat. There's only 2 choices of ramen on the menu which tells you they only need 2 choices to impress you. The broth and meat in the ramen is so delicious. It doesn't get any better than this. It's crowded in there and the wait time is crazy, so only thing I wish for this restaurant is to move to a bigger location.
author: Kristina C.

description:
We came on a Wednesday. Hubby arrived around 6pm and put our names on the list. I arrived later and we went up to some shops on Fillmore to look around. By 7pm we were seated.

Tip: Although the waitlist is handy don't go too far as they give you only 5min to get back and claim your table (so they say, I didn't push it)

Once you order the food comes out super fast. Like within 5-10min. We got the chicken karaage, hakata tonkotsu, and chicken paitan. 

Chicken karaage was really good. Hot tender juicy chicken. Crispy batter. We could barely eat it because it was hot from the fryer and as we finished - and we weren't dallying - both bowls of ramen came out. 

Both broths were pretty good. I'm not usually a chicken person when eating out but the chicken broth was very soothing. Though if I had to pick just one, I would get the tonkotsu. But chicken fans would not be disappointed by the paitan. The noodles are on the thinner side, not my preference. The pork belly was amazing. Thin slices of melt in your mouth belly fat. If you like a lot of meat get extra. I think there were only 2 thin slices in the regular but I didn't mind. The chicken was good but nothing special - not like the pork belly. Both bowls came with an egg as well.

Overall very good solid ramen place. Wish it wasn't so crazy busy.
author: Jean K.

description:
Really really really delicious - I got the Hakata Deluxe spicy. I've only had ramen a couple times before and this made me reconsider that decision.

The wait's not bad if you check in on yelp beforehand! Only have to show up ~20 min before you're seated that way.
author: Thomas S.

description:
YUUUUM! I've been taking a break from ramen for quite some time now, maybe 2 or 3 years. I just never craved it anymore, and all the ramen places just started tasting the same to me with slight differences. However, Marufuku has resurrected that love for me! Wow, it feels like ramen done right. 

We each got the Hakata DX ($16), and the only difference from the regular Hakata is that the DX is with braised pork belly vs simmered pork belly. The website menu is a dollar less, but I'm almost sure that it's a dollar more in the restaurant, because I remember thinking "whoaaa this is pricey!"It was our first time, and I deeply appreciate a delicious pork belly, so I thought I would go for it. 

I'm glad I did, because I really did enjoy my meal. The broth was creamy and not overwhelming, and went really well with the thin noodles. I've never had thin noodles in my ramen like this but I enjoy quite a lot, because you get more of the soup's flavor with the thin noodles. As for the meat, the braised pork belly was an excellent choice! You get plenty of slices, and the meat itself is juicy and tender. Thick cuts with layers of yumminess. I got the medium spicy, and it wasn't as spicy as I expected, but it was still good. There's the spicy seasoning that you can add to your ramen for that extra spiciness. 

They have a huge selection of appetizers. Some like those of your typical ramen places; takoyaki, chicken karaage, gyoza, edamame, etc. What caught my eye was the "Marufuku bits." It seemed like a specialty here since the name of the restaurant was in here. I thought it would be bite-size due to the name, but I was wrong. It's kind of like the peking duck and the bao bun, but without the duck. They used beef instead. There's a drizzle of mayo and you get a lot of it if you just bite into it, but according to the bf, you should eat this like a taco to get a even amount of all the flavors. It's pretty flavorful as all the juices from the meat is soaked into the bao. We also got the mentaiko rice bowl, and I thought it was just typical. It's good, but it's not out of the ordinary. 

This place also has a bunch imported beers from Japan. There's two that caught our attention that we decided to try. Both were not to our liking. We tried the Wasabi one, and the flavor is very light. We also tried the strawberry one (like how could I say no to strawberry?), and I must say, I was very disappointed. It tasted just like cough syrup, and I couldn't even finish it. 

Overall, skip the imported beers. The ramen here is very delicious, and I would say it's a nice treat yourself meal. Probs my new favorite ramen place atm. Good job, Marufuku! I'll be back for you.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I came here for the first time after seeing on Yelp that they served amazing vegan ramen. I learned this wasn't exactly the case. A couple tips for newcomers: 

1.) Be prepared to occupy yourself if you come here on a Saturday night! There were over 50 parties ahead of mine when we checked in around 6PM. No exaggeration! Luckily they keep you posted through an app and call you when your table is ready, so you can shop around to pass some time. 

2.) Vegetarian ramen is off-menu. While they can prepare vegan broth, they only have egg noodles available. Kind of a bummer, but they can still accommodate vegan folks with a side of white rice. 

Overall, the broth was excellent, and the restaurant has awesome decor. That said, in the future if I'm in the area and craving ramen this place won't be my first choice. I sincerely appreciate the flexibility given my dietary preferences, but there are other options nearby that suit me better. It's still worth scoping out if you are vegetarian or a vegan with a light appetite. Enjoy!
author: Carly R.

description:
I arrived just in time before the cut off for lunch. I attempted the yelp waitlist and it was not working. So don't depend on it to get you a spot in line. 

I got the Hakata Tonkotsu, medium spicy. I could have gone another level up since there wasn't much heat to the medium. The potion is a bit smaller than most ramen places around SF. The egg was a whole egg unsliced, soft boiled but not marinated like traditional eggs in Japan. Noodles was thin with good bouncy texture. Broth was creamy. Overall it was a decent bowl of ramen.
author: Diana N.

description:
Heard about this place for awhile and always wanted to visit. So I finally did; really enjoyed it. 

Location: locate on 2nd floor of Japanese Center; 30 Min walk from Parc 55 all the way north via Gerry then post street.

Wait time: I started 6pm, the wait time is 55 min; good thing is you can "add to wish list" so I timed and did not have stand line.

Broth- First of all, this Rame broth is no like any other Rame I ever had - it will make it very difficult to go back to other Rame. The broth is very thick, taste more "fat" like bone broth, in a good way; it is smooth and super satisfying. 

I ordered chicken Patain DX; the chicken leg is very tasty; the chicken in the Rame is so so; I asked use less salt, more broth and less noodle; the waiter are very flexible with it; it is a lot of food for me; end up asked for a container to pack half back hotel. (I could use even less salt though) 

Cost: affordable place, With tips $20. ($15 shall be good as I ordered too much food)
author: Marine Z.

description:
Super long wait and no reservations. Small restaurant too. But the ramen is pretty tasty. They have a waitlist so you can check out other places when there. 
Don't bother with the chicken delux it wasn't great. 
Spicy option wasn't that spicy so just go for the ultra spicy. 

I waiting 1hr 35 min on a weekend. Should definitely avoid peak times.
author: Arjan N.

description:
Good but definitely not worth a hour+ wait. I really love the noodle type they use here as it reminds me of shinsengumi in SoCal.

We ordered the chicken ramen dx and pork ramen dx. If you're trying to optimize for meat, the sizzling chicken leg that comes with the chicken ramen is huge and very filling. I think the value is better there, but the braised pork belly is much yummier. The only problem is they only give you one piece and the rest are the thin slices that comes in normal ramen, so I felt the $15.99 price was not worth it. The chicken leg was ok, flavor pretty much tasted like soy sauce.

Broth wise I liked both and the thin noodles are great for soaking up flavor. The egg was also cooked perfectly and very good.

Service was friendly and food came pretty fast. Overall I'd come back but definitely not during peak hours as the wait is pretty crazy.
author: Sophia H.

description: I went here last wednesday with my cousin and had the tonkatsu ramen. The broth was very flavorful. I will definitely come back
author: Magicc C.

description:
Best ramen I've had so far in SF! The broth is tasty and the meat is well cooked. There's also a good selection of appetizers. 
Tip: get on the waitlist on yelp before heading there.
author: Adé F.

description: 4.5 stars to be exact. There's always a long waiting line, but the folks there run things efficiently. It's the best ramen place in town in term of the noodles they serve there, amazing texture. Excellent service, quick and friendly. Half a star taken off for the inconsistent broth flavor ( slightly bit more salty and rich some days than others). All and all, worth the wait if you are in the area, but not worth to drive across town just for the meal.
author: Mai H.

description:
This is some of the best ramen I've had. It was a little pricey I thought but I also had it a second time the very next day because I just couldn't stay away.

Call and make reservations but please try it.
author: Mallory A.

description:
I was in the Japan Center buying mochi and afterwards decided to walk around the rest of the plaza... As I got to the end past the book store, I saw a giant line of people forming and compulsively got in line before I even knew what I got in line for. (My friend says it's the Asian in me that's just drawn to lines...) I looked up and realized it was Marufuku - the ramen place I've heard so much about but never been because I'm generally never in this area.

I thought the line was moving surprisingly fast so I thought it was extremely big inside. Nope, just kidding, people were just waiting to put their names on the list. (Which, you can totally just skip if you use the Yelp app on the phone, I realized later)

There were 15 parties ahead of me for a party of 2. I was still waiting for the bestie to show up as I was expecting an hour - hour and a half wait. Surprisingly, I was called and texted within 45 minutes. They seated me at a huge table fit for 6 even though my friend was not here... however they made me felt uncomfortable by constantly hovering over me and asking whether she was going to be here soon. I understand their anxiousness because they do have a long wait so I went ahead and put in my order.

Chicken karaage, takoyaki, and 2 Hakata Deluxe. Food came fairly fast. My friend loves the takoyaki. I wasn't as much of a fan. The chicken karaage was... okay. I don't know what I was expecting but it wasn't as juicy as I hoped it would be, it was a bit on the dry side. When the star of the restaurant finally arrived, it was beautifully presented. The broth was extremely flavorful. The egg was at the bottom of the bowl hidden by everything else but it was soft boiled to perfection. The noodles were a thin egg noodle that was pretty good but a lot different than most of the ramen restaurants I go to. The pork was dry and I didn't really like it much.

Before we even finished our meal, our servers were more of less rushing us out of our table. Again, I understand that they have a huge line but dang, we still had a full bowl of ramen and half a glass of beer left...
author: Judy H.

description:
This ramen is insaaaaaannne! So good! The broth is delicious and has an almost creamy quality to it. It's the best ramen I've ever had (though I wouldn't consider myself a ramen expert by any means). It's the only bowl of ramen where I slurped down every last drop.

On a Sunday at 2pm, we waited over an hour for a table. However, it's totally worth the wait. The only knock against this place was that the service was a bit slow, and our water glasses sat empty for most of the meal before being refilled.

My advice: Definitely go, but strike at an odd time or right at opening to get seated quickly.
author: Fiona F.

description:
Really badly managed waiting system. Also hosts are extremely inconsiderate and close to rude. They don't even let you put the names down and walk away. Folks are just standing in line for more than an hour even when they reach by 5. Seems more like a gimmick to create hype than actually provide good service. 

Food is decent but there are places with similar quality in SF like Yamadaya and Nojo.
author: Rashi S.

description:
Ramen was pretty good. We waited for a well 10 minutes to be seated but it was well worth it. My friend and I ordered:

- Hakata Tonkotsu
&
- Chicken Paitan

Both were delicious and probably the best I've had in a while. If I were to choose, I'd choose the Chicken Paitan over the Hakata Tonkotsu. Both were good but one tastes more genuine. 

Overall, I'd come back.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
My favorite ramen in San Francisco is, hands down. The wait is long but it's worth it and being able to add to the waiting list from the app makes it way more convenient. The service is fast, friendly, and you can easily get the attention of wait staff when needed.

Both the Tonkotsu and Chicken Paitan are great. If it's your first time, definitely go with the Hakata Deluxe. It comes with the most tender pork belly I've ever had in ramen. All the meet is good quality and is delicious.
author: Edwin R.

description:
LONG WAIT BUT DEF WORTH IT.
9.2/10

- Thin noodles (typically prefer thick) but maintained shape. Did not get soggy.
- The broth was flavorful (spicy is the way to go!!) and had a creamy texture
- Chicken was okay
- Definitely hard to finish for me... come with a large appetite

Other than that, just remember to put your name on the wait list. We put our names down at 7:20 and our check in time was 8:47. We got seated at 9:20.
author: Nabiha J.

description:
First time visiting this space as Marufuku, which replaced the former Sapporo-ya. 

First off, major kudos on the waitlist. Waiting for food in SF is often a very painful experience: flagging a staffer to jot down your name, standing around for an hour outside, and having to keep an ear out for your name. Marufuku uses the Yelp Reservation system. You just go up to the tablet and write down your contact phone number and number of people in your party. You'll get a text confirming your place in the waitlist and another when your reservation is ready. Given the location in a fun shopping mall in Japantown, you can shop around or grab a drink/snack.

The actual ramen was warm and hearty. I think the broth wasn't as intensely flavorful as some other places I've been, but it was still good. What I really liked was that the basic ramen was $11, which is just a much more reasonable price than many other places in SF.

With the not-too-difficult parking in Japantown, not-too-painful wait experience, fun location in Japantown that I would like to shop in anyways, and yummy and affordable ramen, I'll definitely be back!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I love it!

Classy ramen!

Soup is delicious, noodles are chewing and pork is soft and not oily.

Rice is so soft that I love it!

It is worth trying!
author: Zhijian J.

description:
As many reviews mention, the wait can be reaaalllly long here. However, I like how you put your name and number down so you can see where you are on the wait list. I find it quite easy to kill time during the wait, because you can explore the mall :) 

I'm a creature of habit, so I always get the Hakata Tonkotsu. They allow you to adjust the spiciness of the ramen, which is cool. I've slowly inched my way up to spicy, and I don't think it's that spicy. 

If you're looking for a new ramen place to try, I would recommend this place.
author: Leslie L.

description:
The broth was sooooo good! Deep flavor. The soft boiled egg and the noodle were delicious as well. 
Long wait. But worth it. Also, if you put your name on the wait list, you get a text when your table is almost ready. Which took us about 30 mins. I recommend putting your name on the list first, then stroll around the center.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Finally braved the long lines at Marafuku. If you don't mind waiting and feeling rushed throughout your meal, the ramen is worth it.

It was a bit intimidating to see a huge line 20 minutes before the restaurant opened for lunch on Saturday, but it wasn't too bad. Total wait was around 45 minutes. At least you can walk around Japan Center, go to the bookstore or grab a crepe while you wait.

We didn't make it to into the first seating, but the system is set up so that you can make a Yelp reservation as soon as the restaurant opens. (Pro tip: Put yourself on the virtual waiting list as soon as it opens, regardless of where you're standing in line!)

OK but the Hakata Tonkatsu ramen was good...that pork broth was rich and the soft-boiled egg was perfectly done. I wouldn't get the DX versions unless you're super hungry. In case you're wondering, it's pretty different from the nearby Hinodeya Ramen, where the broth is cleaner and lighter. Slight preference for Marufuku, but both places are good!

You'll be in and out in under 45 minutes -- the servers will make sure of that. ;)
author: Valerie L.

description: Hands down the best ramen I've had. My boyfriend and I were visiting from NYC, and we wish we could bring this place back with us. The wait was lengthy but there's cool shops nearby where you can browse through cute and interesting trinkets. Definitely worth the wait!!
author: Grace D.

description:
This place always has a 1-3 hr wait and before I tried it, my question was is it worth it for a bowl of ramen that is normally consumed within 15 mins? Here's what I think after I tried.
1. To skip the line, you either join the waitlist long before you show up and meanwhile just find something else to do or go there before they open for lunch/dinner and line up so you can be the first group of customers for seating. This is what I did after waiting for 2.5 hrs the first time and went to Ramen Ramadaya across the street because I got too hungry.
2. If you have not tried this place, you gotta try at least once. There is a lot that goes into that broth and the ramen is great. 
3. They have a limit of 15 on that sizzling plate chicken leg dish with ramen. I think the chicken leg is okay so if you can't get it, a bowl of ramen is good too.
4. If this place did not have such a long wait every time, I'd go more often. But is it worth the wait for every ramen craving I have. No. I think the nearby Ramen Hinodeya and Ramadaya and the Ippudo in the financial district are all very good! The Ippudo also has a wait and is pricier and smaller portion, but their tonkotsu broth is more flavorful. This place has just ramen and if you want takoyaki, curry, etc you get more selections at Ramen Ramadaya across the street and their ramen is also amazing.
author: Sharon H.

description:
Online waitlist is genius. You can track how many parties are ahead of you, which came in helpful when we were browsing stores in the Japan Center. Yes, the wait can be long, but it seemed like most patrons were mindful and didn't lounge around after their meals. Besides, the wait is worth it!

For appetizers, we had the edamame, chicken karaage (4 pieces) and chashu and buns (2 buns). Everything was good, on the smaller side portion wise. For drinks they have calpico and ramune if you have a sweet tooth, sake and beer. Water was infused with cucumber. Yum. Service was on point. It was busy, but our server still managed to keep our waters filled and see if we needed anything. 

If you really must deny the ramen, they also have rice bowls. We all ordered the hakata dx lol, but only because the paitan dx was sold out. Everything is handmade and the soup is cooked for over 20 hours. The braised pork belly was so good! The broth was rich and creamy. Even biting into that egg you could taste the broth. Mild spice level was perfect. You can also add extras. 

My favorite ramen to date!
author: Giselle B.

description: I have to say this Marufuku is one of the best ramen places I have ever had in North America (comparing to Toronto and NYC).  Me and my friend randomly came across Marufuku when we were wondering in the area and after reading the Yelp reviews, we decided to give it a try!  The broth was really rich and the noodles were cooked perfectly.  Having the experience to taste authentic ramen in Japan, I do feel that Marufuku is definitely a gem!
author: Kiki F.

description:
I waited an hour to get into this place and it was well worth it! They get people in and out quick and for good reason - line is out the door and waiting list is an hour long 

This place is at the top of the mall in Japan town and is a tiny hub with a handful of tables. Service was quick and clean, not much time for talking since food is coming out literally every minute 

Ramen broth made the dish - however they slow cook this is made to perfection. The pork in the ramen is thick and flavorful, it's easy to get carried away and finish the entire bowl even after you're full.
author: Angella G.

description:
Damn, have y'all ever had good ramen? This was at best ok!

I came around 1:30 as a party of one and still waited an hour. You'll sign in on the waitlist and be notified you're on the Yelp waiting list. It'll tell you how many parties are ahead of you and will notify you when you're about to be seated! Once you're called you'll wait another 5-10 minutes before being seated. I was seated at 2:30.

I ordered the chicken karaage and the Hakada Tonkotsu. Chicken karaage was okay! It came out piping hot, but it was plain! Without the Japanese mayonnaise on the side then it wasn't something to rave about. I still have my favorite place for karaage (Shalala in Mountain View) at the top spot. Now for the main event, the Hakada Tonkotsu! The ramen was served about 8 minutes from when I ordered. Pretty fast and steaming hot! The broth was rich and thick, but I didn't love the thin noodles served with it. If you love thin noodles then this is your spot. The chashu wasn't as flavorful as I thought but good overall. 

The servers were fast and nice! The restaurant itself has about 14 table tops which is why you're waiting so long! However, the turnover is fast. Not sure if this place is worth the wait. I would say this place is all H Y P E! Yeah
author: Tianna N.

description:
Ate at this awesome ramen place in Japan Town.  First time there, but heard about it from our son who raves about it.  

Friday night this weekend was very busy, but Marufuku's check-in system is excellent.  Enter your name, number of people, and cell #, and get texted a link to track the number of tables until your table is ready for you.  Even with 14 tables ahead of us, knowing where you were in the process allowed us to browse thru J-Town stores while keeping our place in line and not feeling lost on the list.

We had the roast pork ramen for about $12.00, and a house salad.  We got the mild spicy broth and it was amazing.  Light, but rich with a deep flavor.  The noodles were perfect, firm and flavorful, and the whole cooked egg hiding at the bottom of the bowl was excellent and added richness to the broth.  

Service was friendly and efficient and at no time did we feel rushed.

Marufuku is now our go-to ramen house!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I thought this place was oooooooook... but I admit that I'm no ramen fanatic/expert. I wouldn't be able to tell the difference between AMAZING ramen and good ramen.
This place uses yelp for its waitlist which I loveeeee. You walk up to or stand in line to use a tablet to add yourself to the waitlist. You'll have to leave your phone number so that you can get notified (via call/text/Yelp app) and check your status (you can see how many parties are ahead of you if you open the Yelp app). After about ~1.5hr of exploring Japantown and even driving to another ramen spot, we noticed that we were almost about to get called... and we came back...... ahhaa
I thought the Hakada DX was okay. It was good but not worth waiting 1.5hr (I came Sunday ~12:30-1pm). I'm down to come back when the wait isn't as crazy anymore!
author: Annie S.

description:
This place was packed on Saturday evening. They use the yelp reservation service. It was easy to reserve a spot on the waitlist just before closing time. Once you secure your place, they send you a text and call you closer to your time. It's first come first serve for this service so if you plan to eat here, get on the waitlist via Yelp.
Oh boy was the wait worth it. Waited over an hour before getting seated. We ordered the chicken karaage for starters with a large hot sake. I mean why not?! We knew what we wanted as our main course so we placed the order for Hakata Tonkotsu: Made with rich Pork broth, the simmered pork, boiled egg, green onions, kikurage mushrooms, and bean sprouts. Spicy levels are your choice; I chose medium just to add some kick to their rich, creamy, pork broth. My boyfriend ordered the Hakata DX. Pretty much the same ingredients with the addition of corn & braised pork belly - mild. The noodles were thin. Which are pretty tasty since it soaks up that oh so good pork broth. By far tastiest ramen I've tasted. A must try place for ramen lovers.
author: Martine D.

description:
First, the noodles: the noodles are thin and al dente-- they take to the broth very well and absorb the soup's flavor well. Kind of look like thin spaghetti noodles, which initially threw me off, but hey, this is the way Marufuku does it. 

Onto the accompaniments: the bean sprouts, thinly cut wood ear mushroom, and pink ginger ribbons give the soup a good crunch. The chicken pieces themselves were a bit rougher than I would have liked, but they do soak in the broth and pick up the broth's flavor. The egg (they give you a whole egg!) was basically perfection-- a mostly gelatinous but slightly runny middle. Salty sweet perfection. The medium spicy was a true Asian medium spicy. The ceramic bowls the ramen came in were very pretty-- I want these someday!

Finally, let's get to the broth: the broth is just the right amount of saltiness as you're eating your food from it. The chicken broth really captured the essence of chicken (and the tonkotsu one captured the pork essence). It wasn't the taste you get on your tastebuds as much as the smell you get upon inhaling the broth. Both were creamy and perfect for a cool day. The tonkotsu one even had little bits of congealed pork fat that made it extra tasty. 

We came on Saturday around 8 and there were ~80 people ahead of us on the waiting list. I did some market sizing math and estimated a 2 hour wait given the seating capacity and turnover. My dining companion factored in attrition and we decided to come back in an hour after eating animal crepes downstairs-- and he was right, so don't be intimidated by the line!
author: Nicole H.

description:
A resturant that ellicts the revitalization of reviewing in Yelp means a lot. This is the case for Marufuku in SF Japantown. My wife have been hearing raves about this ramen resturant. An opportunity knocked when we visited the city. 

First off, the long wait and anticipation. You list your name in front of the entrance and anxiously wait as they call your name. I felt like I was in the scene on Seinfeld with the soup nazi: the lady faintly calls your name and if doesn't see an affirmation, she scratches your name out and on to the next customer.

After catching my name, we were promplty seated. After our expedition in Fukuoka, it is natural that I chose thier Halata Tonkotsu Ramen. Big plus is that you are able to choose how spicy your ramen is. I chose medium as I still wanted to savor the pork bone soup. My wife ordered Hakata DX, and we ordered Chasu Bowl for Jacob and Chicken Karage and Takoyaki for the table.

The soup is amaizing! It (almost) brought me back to Fukuoka with is flavorful broth, accompanied with very good noodles and proper heat to boot. I must admit that the pork was just alright. However, the boiled egg was perfect and the rest of the ingredients in the soup blended harmoniously.

The Karage Chicken was delicious as well and the Takoyaki was good. Marufuku (almost) brought me back to Fukuoka. That itself deserves 5 stars.
author: Paul V.

description: Chicken paitan ...broth is hella bomb and the soft boiled egg is on point! Be there early tho cuz the line is long
author: Emily H.

description: The queue rivals, dare I say surpasses, that of Ippudo NYC during peak times so that was a bit of a shock for a party of one. The bowl looked amazing however the noodles were slightly overcooked and the broth was too salty. The chashu and kakuni were tender but salty as well. The service was very rushed. Not wholly unexpected but they brought the check without asking if I wanted anything else and I did want kaedama. Overall, it was better than average ramen, nowhere near justifies the wait.
author: Ama K.
