description: It's busy, so you should go on yelp and join the waitlist before you go.  Good ramen and good side dishes.  I recommend if you want your ramen "kicked up"
author: St Giles I.

description: Excellent ramen! This place is an absolute favorite from my Girlfriend and I. We come from Napa, CA. So it's definitely worth it. Although we recommend thAt you check in using the Yelp App, because the wait time is absolutely Lengthy! Customer service has always been on Par and a really nice feel to the restaurant as well. Thanks!
author: Jose Luis L.

description:
This place is has earned the title of best ramen joint in San Francisco. In fact, I came here twice within a month (mostly because I was with two different friends who wanted to try this place) but it was good that I recommended it to them.

Located inside the Japantown plaza, the wait for this place can get pretty long. Once inside, it is very spacious and it is quite surprising how fast the line goes (about ~30mins for half a page on the waiting list, per the waiter). For a party of two on the weekend, I only waited about ~30mins each time...which is a really short wait compared to the ramen joints in San Mateo or San Jose.

I got the Hakata Tonkotsu --which is their regular pork broth ramen with chashu. If you want something fancier-- you can get the Dx (deluxe) which comes with braised pork belly, which is a thicker and fattier sliced pork in comparison to the simmered pork. You can choose how spicy you want your ramen and they also come in these abalone shells looking bowls, which doesn't look like a lot but it's a deep bowl. The broth was flavorful and comes with generous portions of everything. 

Overall, I would come back and recommend this place to my friends. Great fast service and probably the best ramen joint in San Francisco.
author: Jenny N.

description:
It's very convenient if you use yelp waitlist 
You don't have to wait in line for 1.5 hour to get seated.  
I really love their ramen taste, it's a little similar to santoka. 
However, the grilled chicken thigh is a bit over brunt.  I told her we would like another one, but she just removed the burnt skin and gave the same chicken thigh back to me.
author: Es L.

description:
Lovely ramen, worth the price and wait.
Chicken Dx is a must try. Each serve is a little too much for one person though.
author: Sunny B.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday at 5:45 PM and missed the initial seating so had to wait around 45 minutes for the 2nd round. Luckily it's within the mall so my friend and I browsed some of the cool japanese book stores. It's a really small shop that seats probably 50 people at most so definitely get there early if you have a large party! 

Friend and I ordered:
1. fried squid legs - the best thing here, perfectly fried and juicy, would definitely recommend
2. shishito peppers - it was alright
3. tonkatsu ramen (medium) - add corn, really good portion size, I was really full by the end of it - the egg was cooked really well too
4. tonkatsu ramen (DX) - really big in size and double the meats
5. large sake - pretty good portion for the price point
6. special beer that they had - priced at 11.5 which was pretty steep in my opinion and tasted pretty similar to a blue moon, but friend liked it a lot so go figure

Overally, I enjoyed this spot as it's one of the cheaper ramen places in SF, but I wouldn't say that the broth or meats stand out. Next time, I might try the chicken deluxe ramen as it comes with a whole chicken leg and only has 15 servings per night! Pro tip: go here early and put your name down and they will text you when you have 5 mins left
author: Anh Thu P.

description:
Coming from Japan should mean something positive in ramen industry. At least it had been in the Bay Area. 

This place was a disappointment. I'll be brief here. The service was great. The taste of ramen? Not so much. The wait time? Horrendous. 

As many people who dined here, we took some significant time like 45 minutes for the wait total. And was ramen that good? Definitely no.  I wouldn't even wait two minutes for this ramen. 

Paitan ramen is a total disappointment. Nojo in SF has way better Paitan ramen than this place. Hinodeya's paitan is also much better. Marufuku's paitan tasted diluted like they added too much water to their broth. And chicken breast? Chicken breast is the cheapest parts of chicken in Japan because nobody wants to eat it there. 

Tonkotsu was OK. I'd give four stars but still places like Yamada has it better.  Chashu was quite good and meaty I admit. But nothing special besides the Chashu. Many tonkotsu ramen shops don't put the Beni Shoga (that red ginger thing) so it won't destroy the flavor of the ramen. Of course this place has it in the ramen. 

Their eggs are almost hard boiled. Again that's below average considering many places in the bay now are serving the melty half-boiled eggs. 

Unfortunately the length of queue for a ramen restaurant like this shows that still many people don't know what's good ramen.  A native of Japan who has been to Hakata to eat their real ramen, was quite disappointed.
author: Taka T.

description:
Food 5/5. Service 4/5. Ambiance 5/5. Bang for your buck 4/5.

The South Bay has some pretty good ramen growing up, so my expectations were pretty high. There is usually long waits for ramen places so I didn't mind the hour wait. The restaurant is located in a Japanese plaza filled with other stores so it's easy to kill time. 

The ramen didn't disappoint. Nor did the appetizer we decided to try. We decided to get two orders of chicken Karage which was delicious but also vaguely tasted like a fancier version of popcorn chicken that you can grab at a boba place. A appetizer was a great idea at the time since we were hungry, but in the end we were so stuffed that we probably shouldn't of ordered it. Especially because there is so many dessert places around' 

When the ramen came out it was beautiful. From afar the ramen bowl looks pretty small but the bowl is so cavernous and deep that it never seem to end. I decided to get the Hataka DX spicy which came with an extra piece of braised pork, corn, and seaweed. I thought the extra four dollars was well worth it. The best part was probably the broth as it had great depths of flavor and wasn't too salty. The noodles were thinner than usual but I actually wasn't too mad about it. The meat was tender and flavorful and the ramen also came with a whole soft boiled egg! Remember to eat or break this egg early or it'll over cook!

One of the best ramens I ever had and definitely worth the trek out to Japantown. 

P.S. The waiter said the spice level is relatively not that spicy and I agree so get the very spicy for an extra kick.
author: Brian N.

description: Good ramen here! The soup was rightfully rich and the noodles are firm. The wait isn't too bad if you check in online ahead of time. Docked one star because it isn't a very memorable bowl of ramen and I can get something similar in LA.
author: Rose S.

description:
Duuuude if you're looking for some good ramen, you've gotta come to Marufuku. The star rating for this place is not just hype. This is the best ramen we've had so far in the Bay Area. Pretty damn good!

My family and I came here on a Saturday afternoon and the line was out the door! We placed our name on the waiting list and waited 25 minutes to be seated. But you know what? It was so worth it! 

We ordered the Geso Fry (fried squid legs) as an appetizer - so good! We wanted to order more but didn't want to fill up too much before our main course. Super simple, but fresh, perfectly seasoned and delicious! 

For ramen we ordered the Chicken Paitan and Hakata Tonkotsu (pork). The broth was to die for! The noodles were super fresh! And as if the ramen wasn't already out of this world, they added a soft boiled egg in the ramen that is mouth-watering. 

The place is small but not cramped. The decor is sleek and clean. But I'll be honest, when you're in there eating that ramen you're zeroed in on the food so much you don't even notice the beautiful decor until you're done, stuffed, and elated haha! 

Moral of the story: Come out and try Marufuku - it'll change your ramen life
author: Sonnia P.

description:
Yes the food is awesome! Ramen with the broth is different from other general Ramen place.

What they need to fix:
1) More servers, a little understaffed even though their service is great.
2) A bigger place, we had to wait for 2 hours in line for our Ramen, not a pop in on a Friday night kind of place.

Using Yelp line up system is a good touch though, gives me plenty of time to explore Japan Town.
author: Kevin H.

description: Came here on ~1PM on a Friday. The ramen was good but not sure if it was good enough for the wait time here which was well over an hour for us. A bit salty for my preference (though that was probably what made the smaller portions more filling). Otherwise, service was good and the staff was very friendly.
author: Diana C.

description:
Finally came here for dinner after going to Grace Cathedral. Arrived at around 545 pm and there were already 20 tables ahead of us. We placed our name and walked around the mall. Came back to 30 mins later and we were already called. They put an asterisk next to our name so we just walked in and said that they have called us already, so they sat us immediately. 
The lovey and I were starving so we ordered the following:
1) large salad with plum dressing
2) chicken karaage
3) buta kukani
4) fried tako
5) medium spicy ramen with pork belly

Everything  was delish! Lovey was only disappointed with the thin white noodles  instead of using the yellow thick noodles just like in Japan. 
All dishes were nicely flavored. Restaurant has modern design and nice lighting and service was fast and prompt.  If you want to come and try his joint, be prepared to wait for an hour or so. 
We were lucky to wait for only 30 mins because a lot of people couldn't wait.
author: Claudine V.

description:
I'm not even kidding when I say this is the best ramen I've ever had. I usually can't eat ramen at most places because I don't eat pork and most ramen broth is made with that, but Marufuku has a chicken alternative, which is awesome and also tastes AMAZING! 

I ordered the chicken paitan, which is chicken ramen with rich white paitan broth, chicken chashu, soft boiled egg, green onions, kikurage mushrooms & bean sprouts, and I added some sweet corn to it for $1. You can also adjust the spice level of the ramen to suit your tolerance, and spicy was perfect for me! The ramen was packed with flavor, the portion was decently generous (I couldn't finish it all and I went in hungry), and the price was extremely affordable! With my sweet corn add on, the ramen came out to $12.99. 

Marufuku is known to always have a long line outside but we went on a Friday at noon and only waited about 5 minutes. 

I would've given Marufuku 5 stars had it not been for the service, which could've been better. The restaurant was almost full when we went but service was lacking. It took 10 minutes to get water after we sat down, and the waiters weren't organized in terms of who's waiting which tables. After someone finally came by and asked if we wanted something to drink, another came and asked the same thing not too long after. The ramen came out decently quickly after we ordered it, but no one stopped by to ask if we needed anything else, etc. It's somewhat understandable because it always seems to be busy in there but it still would've rounded out the whole experience if they attended to us more.

I will definitely be back next time I'm in SF, though, and if you're on the fence about this place, JUST GO! Enjoy some yummy ramen that won't break the bank... you'll thank me later!
author: Nikki R.

description:
Tucked away upstairs at Japantown's City Center, Marafuku Ramen is warm, inviting, and absolutely delicious.

The ambiance is perfect, IMO, for a Ramen joint... small intimate tables with just enough lighting in the room.

Staff was quick to serve, cheerful, and direct.

I ordered the Chicken Paitan DX, which is a well balanced and lovely seasoned Ramen bowl, accompanied with a miso-garlic grilled chicken leg served on a cast iron platter.

The flavor and spice sizzling off of this dish is sure to turn heads. And for those that like to EAT food more than they do talk about it, it's a perfect partner to the most presumably pleasant Paitan.

Enjoy!!
author: Jesse E.

description:
Came here for dinner with friends on a Wednesday night (6:45 pm) with an estimated wait time of 45-60 minutes. We got seated a little over an hour later.  After reading all the reviews, we all ended up getting the Hakata DX vs the other Hakata ramen because it had braised pork belly (rather than simmered) and corn for $4 more. 

It started out really good. The bowl was a good size, the noodles were great, they gave a good amount of braised pork belly... but it all just started to taste really salty in the end - esp the braised pork belly. 

Because of the long wait time and the extreme
saltbae-ness of the ramen, I'm still sticking to Ramen Parlor as my go to spot in NorCal.
author: Jessica B.

description: We checked-in on Yelp to avoid waiting in the long lines t the door.  We ordered the Marufuku bites, Chicken Karrage, Hakata Deluxe, the Chicken Deluxe.  It was all very tasty and served promptly.  The food came out piping hot and the broth had tons of flavor.  I look forward to the next time we can return!
author: Shaun W.

description:
Wait -  30-45 minute @ 13:00 Saturday 

Value - $12 / dish.

Dish Size: Medium

Mentaiko - The sole reason I would come back to Marafuku Ramen is for the Mentaiko. It's a deceivingly simple dish with lots of flavors. The cod roe is a bit spicy, salty, crunchy from the sesame seeds, and bursting with cod roe goodness. All together, the bowl is extremely light and refreshing. 

Hakata Tonkotsu - Not a huge fan. The flavor of the broth is not very strong/deep - it tastes a bit watered down. You're only given two/three thin slices of pork and the pork is not very tender or flavorful. I feel the addition of the bean sprouts and mushrooms did not compliment the ramen very well. However, the thin noodles were cooked well and probably the best part of the dish. 


Having never tried a Hakata style ramen, I was eager to give Marafuku Ramen a try. Tucked away in the corner of the Japantown mall, it's easy to spot Marafuku Ramen as there is usually a large crowd of people hovering around the entrance. The wait is about 30-45 minutes, however,  it's not so bad as there is a lot of shops around to kill the time.

Marafuku Ramen is a sleek and stylish ramen joint. The space is definitely hip with a grey scale tone which accents the interesting uses of darks woods. There is an interesting O shaped communal bench seating in the center of the restaurant, with back lit glass as the seats. There's a lot of elements going on in such a small place but it's never too distracting. 

Hakata style is not my preference when it comes ramen. It's hard to justify the long wait when the ramen just isn't that good. However, I would come back to Marafuku Ramen just for the Mentaiko.
author: Julian L.

description:
This has become my favorite Ramen restaurant in San Francisco.
Came here on a weekday, put our names down, and waited a solid 45 minutes to get our table.
I opted for the deluxe chicken paitan ramen (because after 45 min I was starving) and holy hell this thing is ginormous.
Not only do you get a massive bowl of ramen, you also get a side of chicken thigh/drumstick (because why not).
The ramen was perfectly chewy and the broth was flavorful! We opted for the takoyaki and chicken karaage as well, and both were solid starters.
Will be back!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Waited for 45 minutes on a Tuesday night around 6:30 pm. You put your name down on an iPad and they text you when your table is about to be ready, which gave us the opportunity to explore other shops nearby. 

The turnover was really quick as the food arrived within 5 minutes of ordering.

The iced water was flavored with cucumbers and lemons. Service was great - they came around to refill several times and brought us the check immediately after asking if we were done. 

Got the hakata tonkatsu no spicy. This broth was sooo flavorful (got a little too salty at the end) and the noodles were perfectly cooked - a bit more firm at first, but became softer as it sat in the broth. The cayenne pepper in the shaker is underrated. It smelled so good and gave the perfect extra kick I needed. The egg was still a little more done than soft boiled, but still tasty overall. Compared to other places where they only give half an egg, they give an entire egg here. The meat was also super flavorful.

Would 10/10 come back again!!
author: Maggie C.

description:
The wait for this restaurant was around an hour on Friday night, which is expected of a popular ramen place. Luckily there are a lot of little shops next to the restaurant so you can stroll through while waiting. I ordered the hakata ramen and my friend ordered the hakata dx, which included more meat and corn for $4 more (he thought it was worth it). I loved the flavor of the ramen and it wasn't too salty. The best part was that the spicy level I ordered was actually spicy, something I rarely come across when  getting ramen. 

The only reason why this place doesn't have a 5 star rating was because they mixed up mine and my friend's order (she was dying from the spicy level in the first bite).

Overall, it was totally worth it!
author: Elaine T.

description:
There is a loooong queue. Come 2 hours before and put your name to the list and then go explore Japantown and Goodwill on the corner if you like :) We went in Early September, nights get a little chilly when you're out! 
I really like the experience, my husband doesn't like ramen or noodles but he really liked it. I have ordered rice on the side. I thought it would be real "fried rice" nope it wasn't. We were lucky enough to be seated in the middle section. It is more like traditional seating. A bit hard though to sit if you wear skirts :) 
My problem was with service. The lady who helpwd us with ordering, never "smiled" or were not kind enough to say "you're welcome" to "Thank You" that I said couple of times. 
We couldn't find the place at first by the way, looked around and around (was first time in Japantown) and then found it. It is in the kind of a mall and second floor.
author: Angela K.

description:
Stopped in here while walking around Japantown area, and it definitely did not disappoint! This place had a huge wait to be seated, but we figured it's probably worth waiting for considering how many people were willing to wait (despite the fact there were other restaurants nearby).

Luckily we weren't too hungry to begin with, so waiting the hour to be seated wasn't bad at all! Once we were seated, we were served SO FAST. Such great service! 

My boyfriend and I both ordered the Hakata Deluxe, medium spicy, and it was PERFECT. We also ordered some takoyaki to share. YUM. Everything came out quickly and hot, just how it should be. Takoyaki pieces were large and plump, and paired well with the savoryness of the ramen broth. The medium spice intimidated me at first, but it was the perfect amount of spice! It brought a lot of depth in flavor to the ramen dish, and complimented the unique ramen noodles. Also, there's a hidden soft boiled egg at the bottom! Talk about hidden treasure. Plus this dish includes 3 thick cut pieces of tender meat, which leaves you feeling full and satisfied with your meal.  

Definitely worth the wait!! stop by if you get the chance :3
author: Tina T.

description:
Came here on a Friday at around 6ish and the wait was about 45 minutes to an hour. They have you put your name down on an iPad, then text & call you when you're table is ready so you can roam around Japantown while you wait.

I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu in mild & it was amazing! The pork was so flavorful and very tender & the soft boiled egg that came with the ramen was delicious! It honestly didn't look like a lot when you first get the bowl, trust me there's a lot, the bowl is pretty deep. The service was fast, my friend & I got our food in 5-10 minutes.

Overall I had a great time & would come back again!
author: Stacie I.

description:
This place is fairly new. It's the nicest restaurant in the "mall" in Japantown seeing as its new and decor is more modern w an authentic twist. My boyfriend told me about this place and we love ramen so I was down.

We tried eating here on a Saturday night and we already knew it was gonna be at least an hour wait but we didn't want to risk it bc we had to make it to a movie in a few. So we decided to come back the next day on a Sunday morning/early noon. There was a street festival going on right outside so Japantown was abnormally busy. 

Again we already knew we'd be waiting for at least an hour so we killed time by checking out the festival and eventually coming back and getting a table!

I kinda wish we sat in the middle it was so cool lol. Anyway once they sat us, their service is very prompt and efficient. So quick as we sat they asked if we were ready to order we needed a few mins but it never felt they were trying to rush us out. 

I opted for the Hakata DX which I wish I just got the tonkatsu bc the braised beef made my broth a little too sweet and I'm not a fan of that. Nonetheless it was so yummy!!! I have to say well worth the wait but I probably wouldn't frequent this so often seeing as the wait is constant but I'd definitely come back!!
author: Samantha L.

description: Worth the 2hr wait. Seriously. This was the best ramen I've ever had. The broth is so rich and creamy. And the portions are pretty large. Yes, there was a wait, but once seated the staff is so friendly and food arrives quickly. I would give Marufuku 6 stars if I could
author: W D.

description:
I think I have just found my favorite ramen place in the Bay Area. Because we all know the best ramen places are down in SoCal! My boyfriend and I go to the Cherry Blossom Festival every year (this is our 4th year in a row!) and every time we go, we're always looking for new places to grab lunch at while we're walking around the festival. I think him and I both agree that we will be back here the next time we go to the Cherry Blossom Festival again next year!  


FOOD IS BOMB. I ordered a kakuni rice bowl, the one with the braised pork, and my boyfriend ordered the the karaage rice bowl which is the one with the chicken. I have to say I liked my rice bowl better because the meat was so tender and full of flavor! Although, his karaage rice bowl was still very good as well. We both ordered the Hakata DX ramen bowls, he got his medium spicy and I got mine mild. I tried his though, and I would say it's more vinegar-y than it is spicy hot. But my mild ramen was very delicious. The noodles had great texture, the meat was tender in the broth as well. I was able to finish all the toppings but I was too full to finish the broth. I have to say, the broth is a little salty just trying to finish the rest of it by itself with no more noodles. 

The waitresses are very attentive, and the restaraunt is pretty small in a cozy sense, which is why there's always a long line/wait list. I would definitely say its worth the wait to try it out. 

I can't wait to be back!
author: Mae-Elisa S.

description:
While I've definitely sworn off going back to certain restaurants, I've never wished for a place to close.  However, I'd be lying if I said I shed a tear when I learned about Sapporo-Ya's closure.  And now that Marufuku Ramen has opened in their place, I can't help but revel in the irony that my least favorite spot for ramen in SF has now been replaced by one of my new favorite spots for ramen in the city!

Completely renovated and modernized (the space used to look really outdated), Marufuku is so much more than just one of the trendier ramen spots in SF.  The menu is narrow (just five types of ramen to choose from, with five different spice levels), but it's super legit.  At least, based on the two I've tried.  As for the rest of the menu, it's pretty solid, offering a decent selection of starters, as well as small rice bowls with toppings like kakuni, chashu, mentaiko, and karaage.

-- CHICKEN KARAAGE - Japanese-style Fried Chicken...$5.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marufuku-ramen-san-francisco?select=DHBVBY7Gwly8iEgsIBvthw)
It was a little dark the first time we had this (old oil, perhaps?), but it looked much better every time since then.  Regardless, this was delicious each time we've had it.  The batter has just the right crispiness, the portion is pretty generous (six or so large pieces), I loved how moist and juicy each piece is (hooray for dark meat!).

--  GESO FRY - Fried Squid Legs...$6.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marufuku-ramen-san-francisco?select=3fwyYwTQDHQjRKeLYiPRXA)
Much like with the Chicken Karaage, the squid were cooked really well!  The pieces were very crispy, but the tentacles weren't burnt or overcooked at all.  What's more, you could actually taste the squid, which isn't always the case at other places where it can tastes more like oil.

-- HAKATA DX - Hakata-style Ramen with Rich Pork Broth, Braised Pork Belly, Soft Boiled Egg, Corn, Green Onions, Kikurage Mushrooms, and Bean Sprouts...$14.99
Ramen: (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marufuku-ramen-san-francisco?select=5EuJ_vLqCGgqcZqeqN1gVw)
Egg (it deserved its own shot!): (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marufuku-ramen-san-francisco?select=qch_GdD86QSiGCQYrNTIYA)
DELICIOUS!  The bowl looked a bit modest, but the portion is actually deceptively large.  The pork belly was great (flavorful, not overly fatty), and I liked how chewy the noodles were (despite their thinness), but the egg really stood out (cooked PERFECTLY).  As for the broth, it was terrific - rich and creamy, but not very heavy.

-- CHICKEN PAITAN DX - Chicken Ramen with Rich White "Paitan" Broth, Chicken Chashu, Soft Boiled Egg, Corn, Green Onions, Kikurage Mushrooms, Bean Sprouts, and Grilled Chicken on the side...$14.99
Ramen: (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marufuku-ramen-san-francisco?select=zYr6980y6RHiI2A5l6ss_g)
Chicken: (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marufuku-ramen-san-francisco?select=7J8J-PZj8SULQGPjkjOR_Q)
Although the Hakata DX was definitely better, this wasn't too shabby at all!  The noodles and egg were just as good, the chicken "chashu" was decently tender, and, while not quite as rich in comparison, the broth was still milky and tasty.  As for the grilled chicken, it was larger than I expected and tasted great, but I'm not sure it's a must get for the $3 upgrade.

NOTE: Whether it's been the Hakata DX or the Chicken Paitan DX, the "medium" level of spice for their broth has been the best for me.  It's not super intense, but it adds just the right amount of kick.  However, if you like some heat to your broth, my friend (who LOVES spicy food) goes with their spiciest level and says it hits the spot, for what it's worth.

Although there can definitely be an extended wait for a table on weekends, the line isn't crazy on weeknights (the times I've been, we've waited about 20-30 mins?).  Even then, it's still a lot shorter than Mensho and only slightly longer than nearby Hinodeya (the third hyped up ramen joint to open).  Yet, compared to both, Marufuku is better than both.

Maybe not a clear cut five, but definitely close enough for me!
author: Mike L.

description:
Hands down, the best tonkotsu ramen you'll get in the Bay Area. I've searched for quite a while, and haven't found one as good as the bowl here AND at the Oakland location.

The wait kinda blows, but that's San Francisco for you. Expect to show up and put your name down before they open, or put yourself on the waitlist on the Yelp App if you're within 2 miles ;).

I absolutely love how quickly the food comes out from the moment you order. This is absolutely key, especially if you've waited in line for forever! I'd say we probably waited only about 5 minutes before our bowl of noodles came out from the moment we ordered, and this was on a pretty packed lunch day.

Tender chashu, well-balanced (and of course, deliciously porky) broth, and fun bowls all make for a great meal. Get comfy with your neighbors, though. It can be a tight squeeze, but then again, that's San Francisco for you.
author: Patrick K.

description:
Best chicken ramen I've ever had, hands down. I snuck a few spoonfuls of the pork based ramen, and I honestly think the chicken ramen may have been better-- definitely at least as good. At other ramen places I've been to, their chicken ramen broths have tasted somewhat watered down and not as meat-y, but Marafuku has it right. Umami say whaaat? I would definitely recommend the chicken ramen WITH the sizzling chicken. Not because the chicken ramen by itself isn't enough food, but the sizzling chicken was just that good. My recommendation would be to share it with someone else. 

Unfortunately, if you do want to come here, be prepared to wait. The yelp wait list helps some, but don't bother getting to the restaurant before Yelp tells you to because even after that time, you'll have to wait. Even coming right when the restaurant opened on a Sunday for lunch, there was already a line of people waiting, so you might as well just wait in the comfort of your home.
author: Kelly D.

description:
We arrived 15 minutes before opening and stood in the line. We didn't get into the restaurant in the first round, but we were the second group on the wait list. The group in front of us had 5 and we were only 2. We were called back in about 20 minutes.

We ordered the following:

Chicken Karrage - This fried chicken was delicious and an excellent appetizer.

Hakata Tonkotsu - This was a solid dish...about what I've come to expect from trendy ramen places.

Chicken Paitan DX - This one is limited to 15 servings but we were able to order one, even though we weren't among the first seated. The grilled chicken on the side is worth the entire thing. It's so delicious that I can't describe it. But I will anyway: It's soft and full of flavor.

I was quite happy with the food. They refilled the water when they had a second and when you appear to be almost done, the check comes. It's fine because a lot of people are waiting and they want to move you through.
author: Lauren F.

description:
2 hour wait and worth it!!!
This is ramen heaven, they know what they are doing. Best ramen I have had in the states.
author: Alex M.

description:
Came to SF to watch a Giants game. After the game we were hungry and headed towards the wharf for some seafood. But the traffic was horrendous so we ended up in Japanese town. Found this place on yelp not knowing what it would be like. We came right at 530pm and there was already a small line. We were seated right away when the doors opened. We ordered the chicken ramen, Chic ramen deluxe, octopus balls and fried chicken over rice. The ramen was awesome full of flavor and the soup was on point. The chicken ramen deluxe came with a quarter chicken on a sizzling plate. The chicken was tender and juicy and had a smokey bbq taste to it. The octopus balls were also good tender and flavorful inside.  As for the ramen, you can add extra toppings if you want. I uusually get extra green onions but i didnt need them. The soft boiled egg that came with the ramen was perfectly soft inside.

The place is on the smaller side and decorated nicely. We sat in the middle where the seats were built in and had a hard time climbing over to sit down. Especially after eating, trying to climb back out of it was hard. Anyways i would definitely come back to this place whenever im visiting SF. Its a must try if you are a ramen fan. Last but not least, the service was also great. plenty of servers around so help you if you needed anything. Good job guys..keep up the good work and great food.
author: Steve L.

description: Great ramen place! I always come here when I visit SF! The broth is good and the pork is tender :) love the ramen, it's very chewy.
author: Carrie T.

description:
FOOD: ordered the tonkatsu deluxe (deluxe basically meaning a lot more toppings). the ramen is definitely one of the better ramens i've had. broth is very savory and was perfect on this cold day! also their chicken karaage is a must!!! 

SERVICE: very good! attended to us quickly and food came out faster than expected. 

AMBIANCE: music and decor was nice! but it was a lot smaller than i expected. people at other tables next to us were so close together that you kind of lost the intimacy at your own table. 

OVERALL: food was great, but not sure it was worth the two hour wait... came on a sunday and signed in at the yelp waitlist at 6:30pm and didn't get seated until 8:45pm! :( luckily there are a lot stores nearby to kill time (we even grabbed a small snack downstairs while we were waiting because we were so hungry lol). hopefully we'll be back on a weekday or sometime when it's not as busy!
author: Mirabella M.

description: This place lives to the hype. It really is that good. Everything is so flavorful and the pork so tender! I enjoyed every bite. I would recommend 100%. (I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu)
author: Leticia R.

description:
TL;DR BEST RAMEN IN JAPAN TOWN

I've been waiting a long time to go to Marufuku, and am so happy that I finally got a chance to try it. The wait is usually pretty long, but on a Tuesday at 12:30, the wait was only 20 minutes. They're queue system is great because you put in your number and they text you when you're up next. There are many cute shops to browse around while you wait. 

I got the tonkostu, with medium spice, but wish I went with mild so I could taste the broth more on its own. They have extra spice at the table if you decide you want more kick. The ramen noodles are thin, topped with bean sprouts, ginger, the crunchy seaweed stuff, and some more good stuff. Marufuku is very popular for a good reason and well worth the wait in line.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Finally came to try this place. Heard about it so much from my friends and wanted to see if it was really worth the hype. Going on a Wednesday night was not bad, only waited 20 min or so. Inside is pretty small also and service was great.

My bf and I tried the Hakata DX and the Chicken Paitan. My bf really wanted the Chicken Paitan DX, but they only service 15 of them per day, BOO. Both the broth had a lot of flavor , super rich soup. Noodles were the thin kind, but they were decent. I found the pork belly overly marinated with sweet soy sauce as well as the egg. The egg was over cooked also. At first, I was like wow this is pretty good, but after a few bites, I felt the flavors were really over whelming. I usually can finish a ramen bowl, but this one I can't. The overly sweetness made me feel kinda sick in a way. We also got the friend squid as an appetizer, it was pretty delicious, can't go wrong with fried items!

Overall, I don't think I will be coming back here, but worth the try.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Personally, not worth the 1.5 hour wait. Dude, if I'm  going to wait that long for ramen, it better blow my mind. 

I ordered the Spicy Hakata Tonkotsu, which wasn't bad in my books, but I consider myself a ramen snob and I've had better. The thin noddles weren't my thing, as I prefer a thicker, chewier noddle and the Pork belly was adorned with too much fat. The broth was tasty and the spice level was ideal. Overall, their ramen is alright, but the noodles and the taste of all the Pork belly fat could be a major turn off. 

We also tried the fried squid and chicken Karaage, which were weak. The batter was boringly thin, so there was hardly any delightful crunch in either of these. Skip the apps from here. 

Again, if you're from the peninsula area, with choices like Ramen Parlor and Ramen Dojo, the ramen and appetizers from here don't warrant the long wait and drive up to the city. If you're down to drive out of the city or peninsula area for amazing ramen, go visit Orenchi.
author: Merica S.

description:
Definitely enjoy the SF location more than the Oakland location currently. 

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings.

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it.
When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews. author: Rod M.

description: Me and my girlfriend order the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen, mild spicy for her, medium spicy for me.  The broth was the best I've ever had.  The pork belly was very good as well.  The noodles were not overcooked and aldente like we perfer it.  I have no negative things to say about the food itself but the restaurant is very small and usually has long wait times.  We decided to go on a weekday around 1pm and only had to wait 15 minutes for a table.  I suggest you do the same.
author: Joshua B.

description:
This place is great! Wonderful food. Service was great. 
I'm really happy that there's somewhere close to home where I can eat delicious ramen.
author: Ignacio A.

description:
Located in Japan Center, Marufuku is currently the newest hot spot in SF for ramen, especially since there was a line formed before the restaurant opened! We put our name down for a party of 4 and were on the beginning of the second page and waited about 30 minutes. I would recommend staying in close proximity to the restaurant, since the hostess/server was somewhat soft spoken when calling out names on the list.

We ordered the edamame and takoyaki (comes in 4) to start. Both were basic (how can you mess up edamame though?!) and nothing out of the ordinary. I ordered the Hakada Tonkatsu (I chose "spicy" as my spice level). The toppings were generous and the noodles were cooked al dente, but the broth was kind of bland and didn't have an "umami" taste as advertised... I put red pepper flakes into it and it was still "meh". My husband, whose a ramen snob, ordered the Hakada DX and he was unimpressed and didn't think it was worth the wait. However, the other 2 in our party ordered the paitan (chicken broth) ramen and they thought it was delish! So maybe we both just ordered the incorrect broths... boo.

They have several appetizers to choose from (salad, fried squid legs, kara age, etc.) in addition to small rice bowls. They also serve a few Japanese beers and sakes (both hot and cold). Service was efficient and even though there was still a wait, we didn't feel rushed during our meal.
author: Annie P.

description:
Marufuku Ramen is located in the heart of Japan town. The wait time may be long here even though Marufuku Ramen opened a few months ago. The restaurant itself is very small with very limited seatings.. so if you don't want to wait, come right when they open! There's a lot of great shops to walk around while you wait. However, if it's almost your time, make sure you wait by the restaurant because they call your name out and will cross your name off if you don't respond immediately. 

I got the hakata tonkotsu with a corn. The ramen comes with a soft boiled egg, and believe me, their eggs are perfect. I would get an extra seasoned boiled eggs if you're a fan of soft boiled eggs! The pork was very tender, a little on the fattier side which slightly too fatty for me, but some people like it that way. The ramen was made perfectly and the broth was amazing. You can choose no spicy, mild, moderate, spicy and ultra spicy. I got medium spicy, and it had a nice kick to it! 

The total of my meal was $12 not including tax, which is considered very cheap for SF! The ramen was very authentic. My friend that recently went to Japan was very satisfied and said it was comparable to the ramen she had.
author: Shelly S.

description:
We arrived at Marafuku Ramen at around 7 PM on a Thursday evening. There were about 8-9 parties ahead of us, so we decided to walk around the mall. It's nice that the ramen place is located in a bustling commercial space! There was plenty to see: we walked around the bookstore, Sophie's crepes, and saw lots of people blowing "dragon's breaths" at each other from the liquid nitrogen ice cream balls. There were also a lot of people walking around with the ever-popular ice-cream in fish-shaped dessert. 

After about 30 minutes, we wandered back to Marafuku Ramen. Still about 4 parties ahead of us, so we stuck around. TIP: make sure you stand around the door when they call out names, because they don't say your names very loudly and often times they mispronounce it! (There was a group of 3 for Ketan, but the hostess said, "Katherine! Kathleen!" so the group missed it. The restaurant is, however, very accommodating if you come back and they've already called your name; they will still seat you as soon as they can.) 

While waiting, we could peer through the glass walls at what other people ordered... so when we finally got our seats an hour later (~8 PM), we knew what we wanted. 

I ended up getting the chicken deluxe with the extra chicken thigh on the side ($15.99). They only have a limited 15 servings a day, and there were 4 left when we got there, which was surprising to me. For the extra $4 (the regular is $11.99), I think it's worth it -- especially because I brought some of it home for lunch the next day. The pork deluxe doesn't seem that worth it to me for an extra $4... it seems like it just has extra corn...? 

Anyway, the chicken was all right. It was a little dry. As for the broth, I liked the subtle spiciness (I got medium). My friend got spicy, and it was just a bit spicier than mine. The soft boiled egg was delicious - very juicy and tender yolk inside! The ramen was thin and slightly chewy... pretty good overall. 

I'd like to try to the pork broth next time. I think the pork fat would make the broth more flavorful, and the pork pieces would be less dry. Would probably not get the grilled chicken again.
author: Julianna K.

description: Oh my god!!! Heaven on earth. The salad with the plum dressing- blew my mind. Pork belly rice bowl- extra blew my mind. The waiting list isn't super short but the system is organized. Upon arrival you just enter your name on an iPad and you get placed on a waiting list. The staff is pretty quiet but they were in no way unfriendly. They also do a very good job of keeping the place clean. Overall the other aspects don't really matter to me anyways because the food is so amazing. I hope they stay here forever!
author: Graesyn H.

description:
This place has AMAZING ramen. Having gone to school in LA, I've had a good chance to explore the ramen scene, and I found that Marufuku is on par with nation-wide famous ramen restaurants in LA. 

My friend and I arrived at 1pm on a Thursday and were seated immediately (I realized later that this was very lucky; when we were leaving, a line had formed outside the door). We both ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu and were so satisfied and full after. The noodles are thin with a harder texture, which I love, and the egg (hidden at the bottom) is perfectly cooked and slightly sweet. The broth is not too heavy but creamy, with bits of pork fat floating around. The chashu was so flavorful as well. 

We ordered another hakata tonkotsu to go for a friend, and they packaged the broth separately so the noodles wouldn't get soggy. Definitely worth a wait if there is one! Great addition to Japan town.
author: Justin W.

description: Long line but worth every second of waiting . I ordered the ramen with extra noodles and roasted chicken. The chicken is so tender and flavorful. The broth of noodles is thick and yummy.
author: Terry S.

description:
My friend wanted ramen after a busy day of exploring SF, and we almost went to a different restaurant because the line was so long. Good thing we didn't. The ramen here is by far the best ramen I have ever had. 

I got the Hakata Tonkatsu Ramen and I fell in love at the first bite. The broth is rich but not too heavy, and the tonkatsu just melts in your mouth. The thin noodles are cooked to perfection and the toppings complement the ramen nicely. I finished my entire bowl of ramen and even drank all of the broth because it was so delicious.

At first, we were confused with the restaurant's location but found it on the second floor of the Japan center. The wait will most likely be long, but the ramen is absolutely worth it. I highly recommend their ramen, and I can't wait to go back!
author: Lilith H.

description: Best vegetarian ramen I ever had.  It's not printed on the menu but available if you ask for it.  The wait to eat here is no joke, arrive early and get a check-in number than wonder around the shopping complex until your notified that your table is next.  This happened to us and we rushed to get back to the restaurant but in reality we were still 15 minutes to wait as 10 guests were ahead of us. That was the only upsetting part of the dining experience.
author: Kathy P.

description:
PRICE - $15 for a bowl of ramen is a bit pricey in my opinion. The deluxe you get one more slice of braised pork, but imo, not worth the extra $4. If you go with the Chicken Deluxe however, getting a chicken thigh on the side is definitely worth the price you pay. 

BROTH - incredibly flavorful! Personally prefer the Hakata over the Chicken, but both were very delicious

EGG - soft-boiled perfection, very nicely done but I had to dig for it at the bottom of my bowl

NOODZ - I'm not a fan of their ramen noodles here, it was similar to vermicelli to me, and I prefer ramen with a little more of a bite and bounce to it. 

TOPPINGS - the pork was tasty but a little dry. Didn't understand the difference between the deluxe and the regular because the extra slice of braised pork didn't make much of a difference in flavor. However, for the chicken deluxe, you get a whole chicken leg on the side.

WAIT - on a Friday afternoon at around 11:30-12:00, the wait for a table of 3 was about 30 minutes. But we got seated quickly probably because most of the people left since they couldn't wait that long.
author: Nancy L.

description:
This place is so good! The wait time for a Friday night was about an hr which wasn't too bad considering how popular and good this place is. There's places to look at and walk around while you're waiting which is a good thing to do to pass time. 

We got seated in the middle of the room which contains 3 tables for parties of 2. It was really nice and intimate. Once we settled into our seats, they were quick to serve us. The workers worked together when serving tables which is great. The customer service is fantastic. They filled our waters without having to tell them so they were on top of it. Once they took our order, we probably waited less than 10 min to get our food. It came really quick. The service was fast but not too fast where you feel rushed. 

The bowl itself looks small but it contains more food than you think. The quality is so good and it's really flavorful. Overall, this place is a must when you're in Japan town.
author: Jaleena F.

description:
Marufuku's food is AMAZING!!  Wow. Wow. Wow.

But guess what else​ is amazing? The wait to get a table. Expect to wait 2+ hours. I'm not kidding, that is what it takes to get a seat for dinner here.   But if you do not mind the wait and can plan accordingly, this ramen it will change your life for the good.

Everything is super fresh and made to order and the wait staff is​ really friendly and helpful. I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen and my wife ordered chicken and we were both very happy with our choices and days later are still talking about how the meat just melts in your mouth, it is so good.  Mmmmmm.   My hope is that they expand into a much​ larger space at some point so mitigate the excessive wait times​, but until then we remain loyal slaves to the 2 hour wait.
author: Cameran L.

description:
This is a 5 Star ramen place in most every sense, except for the actual ramen noodles which are dinky Top Ramen style thin noodles. No one at my table thought the noodles were great. However, the rest of the bowl was fantastic. The meat was the best meat I've had at a ramen place. The broth was the right amount of spice. The atmosphere is lovely and modern.

The wait, of course, is terrible. But that's not really the restaurant's fault because they have prompt service. They seem to be trying their best. I will definitely come back here and it's now my favorite ramen place in the bay overall.
author: Jared G.

description:
Now I dream of ramen.

I don't know how I will go back to other ramens after this. 
Notoriously chicken based broths have not been as yummy as the pork but Marufuku has mastered this alternative. Medium spicy may have been too much but it was oh so delicious and I regret nothing.

Do add your name to the Yelp waitlist ahead of time. 
Do go here.
Do dig around at the bottom of your bowl for the hidden egg.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Newer business but definitely my favorite ramen in the city!  

Crowds are super crazy so expect to wait unless you come right at opening.  My favorite is the hakata dx...served with braised pork belly.  The broth is definitely rich, delicious, and super flavorful.  The egg is spot on with the runny yolk.  The star of the show though?  The noodles.  Mmhmmmm...great texture and cooked perfectly.  

They also offer chicken paitan dx which is limited to 15 servings per day.  It's basically chicken ramen with grilled chicken on the side.  I haven't tried it yet but it's definitely my next venture.  

Chicken karrage is also made well here.  Super crispy.  Fried fresh.  Tender.  Sauce is perfect to go along with it.  

Service is decent.  They won't check on you so just ask your server for anything you might need.  Solid and my numero uno, for sure!!!
author: Jen W.

description:
3.5

BUT, I think if I had ordered the chicken rather than pork ramen, it would have been a solid 4 stars.

Sooooo, here's the date night run-down:

Le boyfriend (yes, it's official) asked me if I wanted ramen one day. A little confused (as the man typically doesn't like soupy things), I was hesitant, yet agreed. Not sure what got into him, but we all know ramen is one of my fave foods and I wasn't about to turn that opportunity down.

Off we went to Japantown. On a mission. For ramen.

First, I should mention there's quite the hefty line. During peak dinner hours, expect at least an hour wait, if not longer. Nevertheless, as hungry as we were, we decided to stick it out (who knows when I would be able to get the mister to try new things again???).

As mentioned before, I decided on the fancy pork option (aka Hakata DX). The main difference between the regular and DX variety is that the DX comes with a little extra meat, corn, and an egg. Boyfriend chose the Chicken Paitan DX... and I won't front like I wasn't a little envious; I was. For the same price as the Hakata DX (about $15), he got the chicken based ramen with chicken charsiu AND A WHOLE CHICKEN LEG ON THE SIDE. It was glorious. Good thing he shared with me this time, or I might've had to throw 'bows (Excision reference, if you weren't aware).

Most importantly, though, I think he likes ramen, now. Another reason for the bumpity bump on the rating. YEEEEY!!!

Final thoughts? Have I had better ramen? Yes. Was this place still good? Yes. Was the wait worth it? I'm not entirely sure, but I'd happily come back at a less busy hour. Service was just okay, though. No one really checked on us. Which always tends to bum me out a little.
author: Vi T.

description:
Came here with a group of people on a Saturday night for 6 people. We waited an hour and a half to get a table inside! Prepare for a wait, especially for a big group. Small groups are usually a bit quicker. 

I love that it's a small and simple menu with only 4 types of Ramen. The broth is a rich pork bone broth that is rich but not too salty. You can order the broth hot or mild as you want depending on your mood. It can get hot though! First and foremost, the broth is truly the star of the show!!!

In my opinion, it's worth paying the extra $5 for getting the deluxe ramen. I absolutely loved the Hakata DX, but if I came again I would prefer the Chicken Paitan DX. It comes with a side of grilled chicken that is fall of the bone goodness! 

The only thing I didn't like is that the egg wasn't cut in half but just a whole soft boiled egg in the soup. I love that it's a whole egg, but wish it were cut in half. I also thought the ramen was good and fresh but honestly have had better. But overall, this is well worth it if you don't have to wait more than 20 mins to get a table. Otherwise go outside and there are at least 5 other great ramen places around.
author: Amy W.

description:
My friend and I recently decided to meet up for some ramen and stumbled upon Marufuku while browsing through Yelp. We decided to give it a try, and was pretty shocked to show up to a significant wait. I arrived at approximately 5:40 on a Tuesday evening, and the restaurant was already filled and I was the 15th party in line. They use a handy system involving texts and Yelp, which helps to monitor my place in line. After another 40-ish minute wait, we were finally seated.

Chicken Karaage: For about $5, this comes with 5 pieces of fried chicken. The batter is excellent, and the chicken is juicy and tender. 
Hakata Tonkotsu: The soup broth is decent, not quite as rich as I usually like. The noodles are well cooked, the soft-boiled egg was done quite well and rich in flavor. The meat was mediocre, but overall the portion was fair considering the price and location in Japantown.
Chicken Paitan: The chicken broth was quite special - I had not previously enjoyed chicken broth ramen, and was quite impressed. While I personally still prefer the flavors of tonkotsu broth, there definitely is a more unique flavor in the chicken broth.

I think one of the most difficult parts of the meal was how excruciatingly hot the restaurant was. It was probably 15-20 degrees warmer in the restaurant than outside, if not more. Particularly when everyone is enjoying hot noodle soup, it made for a relatively sweaty and stuffy experience. The smoke that came from the kitchen area didn't help either. Of the SF ramen shops, this is well priced and in a decent location as well. The shop is fairly small, so it seems like you should come with a clear expectation to wait before you eat.
author: Michael L.

description:
We waited over ninety minutes to be seated. This was after arriving when the Yelp app told us to (which itself was an hour after we added ourselves to the list). I expect the estimate to be a little off, but not by this much.

By which time, I was so hangry from waiting, it's hard to be objective about the food. It tasted good, and did the job well, but most anything would have by that point.

But we got to wander into some cool stores while we waited.
author: Neil H.

description: My favorite ramen place in san francisco. The broth is so rich and flavorful. The wait can be a little bit long but worth it.
author: John X.

description:
Went here with a friend and my husband -- absolutely worth the wait! I think we waited almost 2 hours... which I would usually never do since i get super hangry, but it was actually bearable since it's in the Japantown center so you can go to the bookstore and stationery store nearby. 
I usually am never satisfied with buying ramen since I feel guilty knowing I have my Shin ramen bulk pack at home, but this is probably the first time I was okay with paying $15 for a bowl of ramen. 
The pork was delicious, the broth was even better, and the Takoyaki was perfect. I would wait another 2 hours for this.
author: Alex C.

description: Came here second time for my favorite Ramen in Town. I always had Hakata Ramen and fried jalapeño. The noodles is so nice and chewy, the broth is so savory and spicy. So bad that they too busy and I had to wait for half hour But good thing they are in the Japan town mall, I can shop around before get the table.
author: kitty s.

description:
This place serves great ramen! Everything is made fresh to order and the staff is so nice and polite. They make you feel at home and very welcomed.

Avoid the dinner crowd especially on weekends. Place gets busy and loud. The waits can be minimum 2.5 hours. If you don't mind waiting and you like creamy thick broth for your ramen noodles, this is the place for you!

By the way, their pork ramen is always a winner!
In my opinion better than Santa Ram.
author: Zhang L.

description: Ok this place is pretty damn delicious and worth the wait! It's probably the best thin ramen restaurant in the city. The dense and rich broth is pretty much pure fat but I just couldn't stop slurping away while tallying the calorie count in my head. If I starved on an island for a week, this would be best thing to devour after!
author: Betty T.

description:
I happened to be in Japan Town and saw the line for Marufuku, I was curious and also hungry lol so decided to try it.
 
I got Chicken Paitan and it was pretty good. I'd like to go again for their Tonkotsu, but not sure if I'd wait in the long line again... I guess I'd try if the wait isn't more than 20 minutes.
author: Diana C.

description:
Finally had a chance to try it after the first attempt was too long. The wait was not long for us since everyone ahead of us left to go somewhere else.
There are some other shops you could look around while waiting for your name to be called.
The ramen is one of the best I've tried, the broth is very flavorful. My chicken paitan comes with two pieces of chicken and one boiled egg with some garnishes. Maybe only this place serves hard boiled egg instead of soft boil. The noodles made in house, unlike any other ramen place, are tasty.
Their appetizers are okay, nothing too spectacular.
The service is very fast and helpful, they asked about you even though they are busy. They put effort in making delicious foods for us despite how busy it is.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Check in to the waitlist on Yelp!!! I cannot stress this enough. The wait is horrendous and after 40 minutes you run out of shops to explore. You can join the waitlist while you are elsewhere and kill time outside of the area. Also, when you are about the 8th or 9th person in line stand at the door. We were 8th and got a message that they removed us from the list since we didn't answer to their verbal call.....the waitlist updates are not real time even if you are constantly refreshing. The ramen is extremely delicious while remaining light and refreshing. The bowls look small but they pack a lot into them, we were all filled to the brim.
author: Sabrina P.

description:
4.5 stars because I enjoyed my soup and ramen so much!

Came on a busy Saturday afternoon and the wait was about 30min. Overall, I really loved the broth here!! I got the Hakata tonkotsu ramen in medium spice! Waitress told me the spice wasn't that strong ( that's why I opted for medium ;) ). I really love the broth because it was thick and hearty just how I like my ramen! ^___^ the meat was also pretty goood and the spice was just right for me as well. The noodles were thinner than typical ramen noodles (I think) but they were good!

The line was kinda long, but their service is really quick which makes the line move pretty fast. I think this place could be my favorite ramen place around SF!

The service could be a little better, but I think they just opened so I still have very high hopes!
author: Melanie T.

description:
New year and new baby calls for a new review! :)

Not sure where to start with this one, so bear with me as I ramble more than usual! First, the positives: Marufuku serves up great bowls of Hakata-style ramen - characterized by thinner, non-curly noodles and rich, creamy tonkotsu broths. I tried the tonkotsu and chicken paitan broths and both were excellent; rich and flavorful without being over-the-top fatty or salty. I generally prefer thicker noodles, but thought their noodles had a perfect bite. The service staff was excellent: despite the constant bustle and noise, they remained calm, friendly, and on top of everything! They accommodated our bulky stroller and were very sweet and careful around our baby. :)

We tried all the appetizers and thought them solid but forgettable. I also had the karaage bowl; the chicken was nicely moist and fried but like the appetizers, thought them solid but forgettable. I would rather spend the money (and stomach space) on their ramen, the clear star of this show!

While Marufuku might be one of if not the best Hakata-style ramen shops in the Bay Area, I would say it's on par with the better Hakata-style ramen-ya in SoCal (e.g., Shin-Sen-Gumi) which don't have nearly the same crazy lines! It's not a fair comparison, but just had to throw that out there. **I definitely would not wait 2+ hours for this place!

**However, unlike certain other popular, super-hyped ramen shops (Mensho, I'm looking at you!), Marufuku offers a convenient, consumer-friendly paging system so you can run other errands in the area while waiting for them to contact you!
author: Steve L.

description:
I heard about this place from a friend who said it was the best ramen restaurant in the area. My friend and I arrived at 4:40pm and there was already a small line of people waiting for the restaurant to open at 5pm! Luckily we had arrived early and were one of the first to be seated. The service is very fast; the waitress got our food out quickly. I ordered the Hakata DX. Even though the bowl appeared small, it was stuffed with meat, noodles, and toppings! Very filling.

Broth: delicious! Definitely the best ramen broth I've had. It didn't not feel too heavy or creamy and was well flavored.

Noodles: thin noodles that go well with the broth.

Toppings: corn, green onion, kikurage mushroom, bean sprouts, and nori seaweed were all good. The soft boiled egg was a little over done and was not very flavorful compared to ajitama eggs I've had in other ramen restaurants. 

Braised pork belly (buta kakuni): well flavored but could be more tender. Since pork belly is a fatty cut of meat, I had expected it to be very tender.

Simmered Pork belly (chashu): In contrast to the braised pork belly, the simmered pork belly is plain but very tender. The chashu was a bit bland compared to ones I've had at other ramen restaurants.

Props to you if you made it this far through my review, I know it was long. Overall, I think eating here was a great experience, worth the wait, and well priced!
author: Jeannette X.

description:
We have been waiting to come here for a little bit. 

First off, be prepared to wait unless you get here before they open. They have a very efficient system of you putting your name and party number with your phone number into an iPad. It tells you where in line you are via text and the Yelp app. It was very convenient although long wait so don't get here hungry. 

The experience was very nice and also very efficient. once you get the text/call you have five minutes to get back to the restaurant. They will check you in and will be seated once the table clears. 

The food came out really fast! We ordered the chicken karaage (5 pieces) which was pretty good except they can give more of the aioli. The ramen broth was very flavorful, fresh, and overall didn't feel super fatty. It didn't taste like they used a lot of msg. The noodles were the thin kind. It soaked up the flavors of the broth well and was the right chewiness. The egg was cooked well long with the pork. All four of us really LOVED the ramen and would want to come back. They also had a Chinese New Year deal (free extra noodles). You have to show that you finished your ramen first before they offer extra noodles. 

Tips: Will definitely take transportation here as parking in the garage is expensive. Come early with the expectation of having to wait. Would not be a place for a large party.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I'm really grateful to have friends that don't play games when it comes to food. We made it a mission to eat at Marufuku weeks in advance and I was so happy when the day finally came. We were so serious that we made sure to line up around 4:30 for their 5pm dinner round. 

Because we were one of the earlier tables, my friend got to try the Chicken Paitan DX (limited to 15 servings). It came with an entire chicken leg on a sizzling grill. So if you are a chicken fan, I suggest you get that. 

At first, I was having an internal debate as to whether to have the Hakata DX or not, but that extra $4 is totally worth it.  

Some highlights:

-I was really impressed with the braised pork belly. It was so tender and full of flavor that I wished there was more. Although not every cut is the same- my friend's cut was a bit tough. 

-At one point, I forgot I had a soft boiled egg at the bottom of my bowl and wow- so good and infused with a slight sweetness. 

-The best part of my ramen was the broth- so rich and deep with flavor, my friend described it as "profound" LOL

One thing to point out is that they use thin noodles here. While I generally preferred chewier and thicker noodles, I still enjoyed my ramen. 

I was really close to giving them 5 stars, until I found myself hella thirsty post meal. Still a solid ramen place to check out if you are in Japantown though.
author: Eva L.

description:
These are the noodles I have been searching for!

I have been looking for a great broth (not fish or miso) with fresh made on site ramen noodles. I had the chicken broth and fellow yelper had the pork broth with pork belly. Reportedly the pork belly was excellent and melted in your mouth. The broth which I tried was savory and creamy style, it too was great. The chicken broth that I ordered was creamy style with the option to be spicy. It was satisfying especially on this chilly foggy perfect for soup day. They do mean if you want extra noodles wait till you have consumed the original issue and then a plate of ready to dunk ramen will be served upon request, for a couple of dollars more.

This has been officially tagged as a "be back" and may be as a regular every Thursday routine -- just saying.
author: Ed V.

description:
3.5 stars. Better than most ramen in San Francisco, with a beautiful interior, but not the best tasting. Not worth waiting over half an hour tbh.

I came here with my bf for the first time last week and waited about 20-25 minutes, which wasn't too bad. 

We ordered:
-chicken karaage 
-takoyaki
-hakata deluxe ($15)

Overall, the food was good, but I wouldn't come out of my way to come here.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Prices: $11.99 Hakata Tonkatsu ramen
$15.99 Hakata Deluxe Tonkatsu ramen

This place opens at 5:30. I rolled up at 5:36pm and became the 8th party on the waitlist. The restaurant is inside the mall and isn't visible from the street. This place is popular, and it looks like there's no good way to avoid the wait. Fortunately, they'll take your number and send you a text when your table is ready so you're not stuck just milling around in front of the restaurant. Japantown is also full of interesting stores to check out to pass the time. We ended up getting a table for two about 30 minutes later. The waitlist was 24 parties deep when we came back for our table around 6pm.

The restaurant itself looks quite sleek and classy for a casual dining type of place. I got the Hakata Tonkatsu and my husband got the deluxe version. The only difference we could see between the two is that his came with braised marinated pork, corn, and nori. The bowl isn't too big, but they really pack it with food. Both of our bowls came topped with mushroom, bean sprouts, green onion, simmered pork, a soft boiled egg, and ginger. I knew we were in for something good because I could see the fat floating in my broth before I dug in. I judge my ramen by the the broth, and this one is solid. It was rich and fatty, and had the creamy white color that a proper tonkatsu ought to have. Flavor wise, this is a pretty good bowl of ramen. I personally prefer the thicker style of noodle over the super thin ones they have here, but that's just a personal preference. The soup was a tad salty, but packed some strong flavor. It's a good bowl of ramen. I probably won't be making regular treks up to Japantown for it, but worth trying if you're in the area and don't mind a wait. Also, the waitlist was at 40 parties by the time we left at 7pm on a Friday night.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday, 11:45, still waited for 35 minutes. Good thing there was a bookstore nearby to kill some time. The line does move quick though because the food come out pretty fast. 

As busy as this place, good thing they don't compromise customer service. The waiters are patient and courteous. The bowl of ramen looks small, but it was deep so it will fill you up! Strangely, they used thin kind of ramen, but it was still good. Broth was flavorful, no surprise there. I ordered the chicken and it was very tender and juicy. Mr. Piggy ordered Tonkatsu, and it was

It's on the pricey side, not to mention the parking meters in that area out there robbing you blind, but it was worth the wait and the price.
author: Em T.

description:
My friends & I knew the line here is always crazy so we arrived 30 minutes before they opened. People started lining up around 5:15. From what we saw, they turnover tables pretty quick which is great.

We started off with the Chicken Karaage & Takoyaki. The karaage was very tender & not overcooked. I don't believe their takoyaki is fresh (tasted frozen), but still good quality.
I ordered the Chicken Paitan & it was delicious! The broth is very flavorful! The bowls look small but their portions are actually very big. The egg was a bit overcooked but still enjoyable of course. 
It is hard to get "real good" Japanese ramen here in the states, especially when you've had the most amazing ramen in Japan. But I was actually very pleased with Marufuku & will be back!
author: Nari M.

description:
Be aware there is usually a wait with this restaurant being relatively new. I waited about 30 minutes on a Wednesday night. 
There is a waitlist on the door of the restaurant where the customers are expected to go and sign up themselves. It was hard to notice at first due to the crowd of people swarming in front of the restaurant waiting for their name to be called. You kinda just have to wiggle your way to the front, sign up, and then you're free to wander off for a little. 
 
Once seated, their menu selection is succinct in the best way possible. I had the Hakata Tonkotsu ($11). Though packed, their service is quick and ramen quicker. The broth was so savory and the pork belly just melts in your mouth. Not too crazy over the thin, straight noodles but personal preference.
author: Sheila H.

description:
This is a new ramen spot that opened up in the Japan Center Mall and it seems to have quite a bit of hype. We came on a Sunday night and had to wait about an hour for an available table, talk about popular! The restaurant is a small space in the corner of the mall. The interior is modern, a clear difference from the mall's older look. Japanese inspired designs decorate the small space.  

We got the Takoyaki ($6.50) and it was nicely made. The batter was consistent and the diced octopus inside the five balls was fresh. I ordered the Chicken Paitan Ramen ($10.99) with medium spicy level. Don't be afraid of going for higher spice levels, this ramen restaurant isn't as hot as others. My friend got the ultra spicy and it was perfectly bearable. The ramen was delicious and generously portioned. The broth was flavorful and soupy. There is also a soft-boiled egg hidden inside the bowl, I didn't know about until halfway through my ramen! 

Overall, a pretty good spot if you're looking for ramen in San Francisco. They are currently quite popular, so expect the wait to range from twenty minutes to an hour. Since it's located inside the mall, the waiting area is spacious and there are many seats available for sitting throughout the mall level.
author: Vincent P.

description:
This is a weak 3 star rating since Yelp doesn't allow half stars. If they did I would give this place probably a 2 1/5 star. 

I don't really know what the craze is about for this ramen place. Sometimes I feel like people just flock to restaurants because there's a long line. It's like a placebo effect where the longer you wait the better the food will be. But TBH the food probably tastes good because you get so hungry from the wait. 

Service: 
I give them kudos for having a texting system for letting their customers know where they are in line. Given that it's located in Japantown, there are definitely places you can roam while you wait. 

BUT it is a flawed system. We decided to go sit in another restaurant for some drinks  because they said the wait would be an hour. Mid-way through we got a call saying our table is ready. So naturally we panicked, downed our alcohol and rushed the waiter to give us the check. We walked knees to chest to the restaurant to find out our table wasn't ready and it'll be another 15-20 mins wait. We waited for 20 mins while some of us got a head rush from drinking our alcohol so quickly. 

Our waiter was really nice though and took our orders and brought out or food pretty fast. 

Hakata Tonkotsu - This ramen was too salty for my liking. But it had a nice rich pork flavor and the noodles were cooked perfectly. I like that they give you a whole entire egg since you don't get that often. I just wished my insides didn't feel like they were getting preserved with the salts. 

Overall: I don't think waiting 1+ hour is ever worth it for food unless it's like the only ramen place in the city. There are definitely some other places that are comparable to Marufuku in the city. I probably won't come back again.
author: Annie V.

description:
Good but not amazing. Verdict - a bit over hyped. We had the meal during their peak hour. Coming in on a Friday at 7pm, we finally got seated at ~8:30pm. We ate for about 20 min and was done! Pro tip there is a book store nearby for you to kill time while you wait.

By the time we got there, they had no more chicken paitan XD. T.T Alas pictures of the grilled chicken leg on line looked soooo good. In any case we ended up ordering the tokotsu XD ramen instead. 

The broth was good, not too rich or oily. I love the noodles. It's surprisingly thin and delightful. But the pork slices were over cooked. Both of them! I usually don't like corn in my ramen broth because I think it detracts from the flavor of the broth. There was corn in this one, so I didn't like it hat much.Both my bf and I also think the broth was a bit salty.

Final conclusion, it's good but not enough to wait 1.5 hours! I've definitely had better ramen in the Bay Area.
author: Sherica L.

description:
I was kind of disappointed by this place. My friend and I came here for lunch around 12:30. There was a line but it's really nice that you put your name on the ipad and they send you a text when it's your turn. We waited maybe 5-10 minutes and were seated pretty quickly.

We shared the octopus balls and both had the Hakata DX ramen, mine with added bamboo shoots. Our food came pretty quickly. The octopus balls had a good amount of chopped up octopus and it was yummy. We polished that off quickly and our ramen came a few minutes later. I really liked that they gave me a heaping little platter of bamboo so they're definitely not cheap on the toppings.

The ramen itself was thin and doesn't have much chew. I like the wavy, thicker noodles that has more texture. These noodles just isn't springy enough. The broth was flavorful but oh so salty. I have been other other ramen places where the broth is salty but coupled with the thin noodles with no chew, the saltiness was too overwhelming. My friend thought the same thing.

If you're into chewy noodles, I would probably skip this joint.
author: Alice W.

description:
Update:
Man they make a delicious bowl of ramen.  Like for real.  The fried chicken was good but honestly I don't that I'll ever order anything but the classic ramen bowl from them.  It's delicious.  
We showed up 40 minutes before open and were 5th in line.  We got a table.  No suspicious wait list.  No issue.  
And I saw small parties sat at larger tables.  I didn't ask questions and I've never spoken to anyone about the second time (they have no way of communicating with them other than to walk in and they are so busy it'd be rude to interrupt them to complain about the past.)

Did I mention the ramen was sublime? My wife and I both left very content.  Exceptionally content.  Quite exceptionally happy.  

TL:DR - food good but they have some serious kinks they need to work out.  If these issues are remedied I'd love to give it 4 or even 5 stars but for now I'm very upset.  That is if I can bring myself to go back. 

I came here before and know he line is long and the wait is long.  I showed up before and was a solo party. I was sat and then told they will be seating another person with me.  I'm fine with that.  The guy was cool and we had great meals and went about our days. 

I loved the place and I convinced my wife and mother in law the food was so good it was worth the wait.  We were going to a movie next door so we could go there and eat while waiting for the movie to start at 6:30. 

We showed up today at 4:45 and waited for the list to open. Fine.  At 5 the tables are sat and we are 5th on the wait list.  Many people left and walked around but we waited at the door and watched people leave. We watched people sat.  I watched the list update.  Yay! Business as usual.  Fourth on the list.  

Then it goes bad. A large table got up and a table was sat.  But lo! Behold! The list didn't update.  My wife said "they showed up after us." She was right.  I remember because they had a dog.  They showed up after everyone was signed up and didn't wait at all to put their name on the list.  So no wait to get in list and then 15 minutes later their table is ready.  

I approached the young lady who sat them and complained.  She said "we only sit 4 or more on the table.  The list is all two and three."  I recommended moving the list faster and seeing if anyone wanted to sit together.  She said "we sit seat people together." Well I know that's not true....I've sat with people before.  "Sorry we don't seat people together."

We waited another 20 minutes and decided to leave.  The more we stood there the more upsetting it was.  At 6 we had waited an hour and 15 minutes and they walked up and were sat in under 30 minutes because they are a party of 5?!

My wife and mother in law said they never want to go back.  I'm torn. I love the food and want to go back but not if that's how they conduct business. I complained to another person and she seemed a bit more receptive and kept asking what she could do? I don't know...go back in time and not screw over people waiting an hour bec
author: Thomas W.
