description:
There was already a crowd at the door a wait at 5:15pm. My friend and I put our name down and walked around the mall. We even had time to go grab dessert before dinner, since the wait was so long. 

We waited for about 1.5 hours before we were seated. We both ordered the regular tonkatsu ramen. The consistency of the thin noodles was perfect. The flavorful soup was oily, but it wasn't too thick or thin. It wasn't overly salty either, which was good. Also, don't be fooled by the small bowl. There was more than I thought there'd be: a serving of noodles, bean sprouts, black fungus, pork, and green onions. I ended up bringing the rest to-go. 

The service wasn't very attentive. I told the waitress my seat was missing a pair of chopsticks, but she didn't bring it to me until I asked her twice. 

Marufuku definitely satisfied my ramen cravings, but it's not worth the very long wait.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Wow, so glad I only had to wait 45 minutes for this because the ramen really isn't that good. I much prefer Mensho Tokyo.

Id been trying to come to this place for months because it came highly recommended and had such good reviews on yelp. Each time I tried visiting, the wait was estimated to be about 2hrs so I'd always decide to just go somewhere else. Finally I got here early enough where the wait was bearable. 

I got the Hakata DX and the noodle was quite thin and didnt have much of a bite to it. The pork belly wasn't really melt in your mouth and the broth was... standard? Like Im honestly having a hard time describing it because it was so forgettable. Other folks in my party got the Hakata Tonkotsu who also shared the same opinion.

Overall, the ramen was just okay, but certainly not worth the hype.
author: Danielle C.

description:
What an experience. 

My wife and I got to the sign-in iPad 1 hour before it opened, walked around the Japantown mall, then waited another hour before seating (approx. 50 open seats). But ,my GOD it was worth it. 

I opted for the Chicken Paitan DX (deluxe) and the chicken alone is amazing. Pair it with the best chicken ramen you'll have and your mind explodes. My wife had the traditional tonkotsu and it was still superb. 

The bowls are deceptively large, so don't think you can eat both here and a sushi place as we were planning to. Definitely meets the hype, and makes my "go-back" list.
author: Karmelo N.

description:
Best ramen I have ever ever had. I went here fairly early in the morning, approx. 15 minutes after they opened. The wait was about an hour but they put your name on a list and text you when your table is ready, which is amazing because I wouldn't wanna wait there for an hour. 

The place is hard to find. It took me & my friend some asking around to find it. It's located at the corner on the second floor of the West side japan center? I don't remember. Just know that you go straight and you keep going straight when you enter the door of the japan center, then you'll hit it eventually. 

The ramen itself was freakin amazing. I got the most popular one based of reviews (don't remember what it's called) and the spicy was a medium and it was perfecttttt. The egg was my favorite part, it was cooked to perfection. The karaage was amazing as well. 

The place itself was pretty small but the service was really fast. Ugh, I just love this place. 

When I go home, I am most definitely going to hit this place every single time. Best ramen place in the Bay Area, no doubt about it. Highly highly recommend!
author: Jamielyn G.

description:
Amazing ramen! Perfect density and enough for hungry person. I felt like i was back in japan.
The wait can be long, sign up on yelp site.
I will be back!!
author: Alison W.

description:
I have to say that Marafuku has reached the top of the list for San Francisco ramen places to me. The ramen was delicious and full of flavor. I loved the hakata dx, and would recommend it to anyone.

Now for appetizers the marufuku bits had a nice sweet but tangy cha-shu in a warm rice bun, and the takoyaki were very good.

The only big downsider is the wait. We ended up waiting over 1.5 hours. You can however put yourself on the list beforehand, and just follow it on your phone, so do that!
author: Nikita K.

description:
I've been to this location twice now within the past few months, and I have to say the Hakata deluxe one of my favorite bowls of ramen! Delicious broth, delicious pork, and I especially love the corn. 
Like everyone else, I do wish the line were shorter-- however, I have never had any problem putting my name down in the Yelp waitlist. Come prepared to kill some time and explore the mall, and the wait passes quite quickly! It's also helpful that they provide a link so you can check where you are in line. All in all, definitely worth it!
author: Elina Y.

description:
Having lived in Japan for a number of years, Ramen has and always will be my comfort food. 

This broth is the window to my soul! Just one sip and I was in love. It's rich, creamy, and just the right amount of salty. It's worth drinking all by itself.

I've come here a handful of times since it's opened and each time there is a long wait. I've waited anywhere from 10/15 mins to 30/45 mins. It really depends on the night.  Weeknights have way shorter waits. Make sure you add your name to the list on the table by the door.

For a starter, we tried the Geso Fry ($6.50). The Geso Fry (fried squid legs) were crunchy and not too chewy. It came with some mayo, but it was seasoned well enough that you didn't need it. 

For mains, I ordered the Hakata DX. The soup. It's all about the soup. Can you tell that I like it?! The pork belly and noodles were bomb too, but I could swim in the soup. It rich and has that creamy, oily goodness that reminds me of winter in Japan. Pork belly was flavorful and generous and the noodles were perfect, chewy and not overcooked.

Only complaint about this place is the temperature and smell. I'm not if they're related but a few times I've come in, it has been scorching hot and smelly! Even with the fan on, it was an uncomfortable experience. I'm not sure how to describe the smell. Some days it's fine, but some days, it smells like vomit. I'm not sure if it being hot correlates with that.
author: Junella T.

description:
This place gets 5 stars for one reason, and one reason only:

The CHICKEN PAITAN DX

This monstrosity of an epic meal isn't only big, but it's Quality. 
100%, Unadulterated QUALITY!

The ramen broth is spectacular. Lots of flavor that will punch you in your belly. And you can choose the spicy level. The sliced chicken is excellent, as is the corn, sprouts, and other toppings. The noodles are superb. I've had better, but these are still very well prepared.

And the side of chicken. What else can I say except, SUPERFLUOUS! 
The sweet sauce us what makes it extra special. Cooked perfectly on a sizzling iron skillet, this takes the whole meal to another level.

MUST GO NOW!
author: Ron Z.

description:
I think I just found my new favorite tonkatsu broth in SF! The soup was REALLY pork-y and umami-rich without feeling too oily. The serving was also quite substantial bc the bowls are really deep. The noodles are really thin as prescribed by the Hakata style. I personally prefer thicker chewier noodles, but these were good too. 

FYI, I assumed "spicy" at a Japanese restaurant would mean "barely spicy," but it was actually pretty potent and kind of distracted from the pork flavor. I think in the future I'll stick to just the medium spicy level. 

I'm giving this place 4 stars bc their use of tables drove me bonkers. Most of the tables are 4-top, and if you are a party of 1 or 2, they still give you the whole table bc there aren't enough smaller table (I saw one person sitting entirely by himself at a table for 4 bc they don't ask ppl to share tables). There are tons of seats that aren't occupied at any given moment.. this would be fine at a less-busy restaurant but we had a wait of 1+ hours ON A THURSDAY NIGHT AT 8:30! I would really recommend that the place replace most of their 4 tops with 2 tops that can be moved together or apart as needed.
author: Jean L.

description:
I was quite honestly hoping to have ramen more than I did when I was visiting San Francisco, but I am glad to have had one bowl of it here at Marufuku Ramen in the Japan Center.  With so many places in San Francisco claiming to have the best ramen, it is difficult to try say which is the best.  I am no professional food critic, but the ramen here at Marufuku Ramen was very, very good that it could be a contender for best ramen in SF.  

The ramen here has a pure, naturalistic quality in that Marufuku isn't trying to be overly creative by adding items that shouldn't be added to ramen.  So many restaurants have to be inventive with their food, but I prefer for ramen to be somewhat simplistic, not to say that it can't have it's own kick.  Marufuku Ramen definitely balances creativity with tradition in serving it's ramen, and the end result?  Perfection.

I ordered the Hakata DX Ramen, and it was nothing short of delicious.  The broth was perfect, the noodles were again perfect...and there were a lot of them!  The ingredients?  You guessed it, perfect.  The one bowl of ramen was monstrous and therefore was great for splitting between myself and my fiance.  Had we had more of an appetite we also would have gotten some of that karage chicken which smelled wonderful, but that's something to yearn for in our next visit to SF.

I'd gladly come back to Marufuku Ramen as it seemed to be have a very authentic feel.  It was small and some of the seating somewhat resembled traditional seating in Japan - all this made for a comfortable experience.  Beware, because this restaurant is smaller, there tends to be a wait.  If you find this to be true, simply write your name on the waitlist and it'll be called out once your table is ready.  They do get patrons in and out at a fair speed, but I assure you, the service does not make you feel rushed.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Oh My Gosh! The ramen here is hands down the best ramen I've had in the States! My boyfriend and I decided to give this spot a try after seeing the long line outside. We figured, hey if there's a line, the food must be amazing. Boy, we were not disappointed at all. The wait was about 30 minutes, which was definitely worth it! Now for the food:

Hakata DX- The soup broth was excellent. It comes with a generous portion of pork and the braised pork belly is heavenly! I especially like having corn in my ramen.
Chicken Paitan- The chicken leg was first off HUGE! And secondly, it was delicious! I prefer the soup brown of the Hakata DX to the Paitain broth, but both were yummy.
Marufuku Salad- The soy sauce dressing was delicious as were the vegetables.

My experience here was great! I would definitely suggest giving this spot a try. I would even go as far to say that you should make a special trip just for the ramen. There are a lot of Japanese shops around the area like Daiso and Kinokuniya, so you'll have plenty to explore before or after your meal.

The only con is, there is a list by the door where you put your name. I noticed that some customers (including my party) made the mistake of not putting their name down because there is no sign indicating that such a list exists and the crowd waiting in front blocks the doorway. The restaurant should probably put a sign by the door letting everyone know to put their names down on the wait list prior to waiting.
author: Qi G.

description: Best service! Besides the 1 hour wait time the food was delivered quickly! Soooo good
author: Frances P.

description: Solid bowl of ramen. The broth had great flavor - I could taste some sweetness in it. If that makes sense? Noodles were good, but personally I prefer thicker noodles.
author: Michelle P.

description: Wow. If you are willing to brave the daily line... keep reading. If you're able, show up about an hour before they open. Yes. Here's why. They offer the deluxe chicken paitan ramen dish to only the first 15 people. That's right. 15 a day. You need to be in the first seating to order it. We did and it was the best drumstick I've had since I visited Lisbon, Portugal. I have no idea how this chicken leg is so incredibly delicious, but trust me, it's out of this world. I paired it with the chicken ramen bowl; epic. Boyfriend got the pork ramen; we preferred the broth in the chicken option though. Note, it's a different style ramen than the Tokyo style. Good luck- may the line forces be with you. It won't disappoint.
author: Meredith R.

description:
After 90 minutes of epic wait, we finally got it.

A bowl of steamy delicious ramen. 

Just like the one I've seen in Naruto. Just as good.

I would say the broth is not as thick as Mensho Tokyo and the noodles are quite thin as well. However, the broth is just the right amount of greasy and comfort, and the noodle is also just the right amount of thickness.
It is sort of difficult to describe how good this bowl of ramen tastes with a glass of Asahi beer. Oh mama.

That said, there is a kiosk you can check into and get a text message when it is your turn so that you can roam around the Japan Center and do other things. If possible, would recommend scheduling this ramen trip outside weekend prime time

Would highly recommend if you are looking for ramen in San Francisco
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I went on a ramen rampage, trying every single ramen place in and around Japantown. To be frank, ramen is a very subjective affair; and for me, Marufuku was my favorite.

The broth has a very unique quality to it, it has depth without being overly rich and it shows a particular tone of sweetness which I absolutely adore. It's different than any other ramen place. It's very well balanced as far as salt and fat.

The pork was truly delicious (though the texture could improve). The corn is a nice touch, too.

Beware of the level of spiciness. Like Ichiran in Tokyo, even "half" might be too spicy for some. Err on the lower side and up it as you get more familiar with the spicy scale.

Five stars. ありがとうございます。
author: George A.

description: Omfg! The absolute best ramen ever! We found this place in the Japan center in Japan town. A line starts forming at about 5pm, half an hour before the place opens. So somebody knows something! They have an chicken paitan broth...bam! That's where it's at. So we ate all the chicken things and we've been back numerous times. Highly recommended, good service and fast eats. Live this place.
author: Sanaa H.

description:
This place is good. I stumbled upon this place while walking and shopping around Japantown. I saw a line, and, you know, lines are usually a good sign. When a restaurant has a line before it even opens, it's probably pretty good. 

As you may have read in other reviews, there's a physical line and a Yelp waitlist. I believe they let everyone physically in line into the restaurant, and if you don't make the cut then you get placed into the waitlist first. Then they open up the waitlist to the public (aka within a 3 mile radius or so other reviews say). I got here around 10:45am on a Sunday and got in on the first wave.

Service is super quick. They seat you quickly, take your order promptly, and bring the food out pretty fast. They also top your water which is a nice touch.

I got the Hakata Deluxe. The broth has excellent flavor and isn't too salty. It's probably the best part of this dish. The noodles are cooked well, definitely not over cooked. I also thought the Chashu was super tender and delicious. That's three main components that they nailed, but they did fall short in some aspects. I was pretty disappointed in the Buta Kukini (braised pork belly). It was a little tough, you'd expect it to be melt in your mouth tender. Maybe I had a bad piece in a bad batch, but I probably wouldn't get it again. Nor was the egg anything to write home about. It was cooked to a perfect doneness, but it was pretty flavorless. I'm used to marinated ramen eggs, but this one tasted pretty bland. 

Overall, I thought this place was pretty solid. You can't really expect every single component to be perfect. As a reference point, this place could definitely compete with ramen joints in LA (Sawtelle/Little Tokyo). Next time, I'd definitely want to try their Chicken Paitan Deluxe.
author: Brandon L.

description:
hella slow line.  The ramen was really good, but I can get this level of ramen elsewhere without a 2 hour wait.  If you want good ramen, this is a good choice.  Just make sure that you have the time.

Ended up going over to grab some mochi while we were waiting, and shopping around in the stores.  There is a lot else to see.  

Then sat down to eat ramen for 15 minutes after a 2 hour wait.  

Because ramen is supposed to be eaten quickly, before the noodles get soggy and stretch out.
author: Benjamin H.

description:
We came here on a Sunday but unfortunately was not able to add our name to waitlist via yelp app.  We had to go to the front of the restaurant and input our information on the ipad and then you could track your wait position via yelp app.  We were #53 and had to wait about 2 hrs to get seated.  They will call you once it's almost time to get seated so you could roam around in the meantime.  The yelp app suggests a time for you to return to check in but that time is completely inaccurate and the server also mentioned that it is inaccurate as well.

The difference between hakata tonkotsu and hakata dx is the hakata dx includes a thick piece of braised pork belly and it also includes corn and a piece of nori seaweed. If you don't care for the piece of seaweed and corn then you could save 50 cents by ordering the regular hakata tonkotsu and adding a side of braised pork belly.  The braised pork belly was about 50% fat so i wouldn't order the DX the next time I visit.  Plus the meat was really salty, not sure if it was because we didn't get seated until 8pm.  Overall the ramen broth and noodles were great so i would return here.  I had ordered medium spice but it wasn't spicy at all.  The prices have increased by $1 so the hakata tonkotsu is now $12.99 and the hakata DX is $16.99.
author: Judy P.

description:
Maybe I came on an off-day, but my friend and I came to Marufuku last Sunday morning before it opened. We came about 20 minutes before the restaurant opened, and there were already about 8 parties ahead of us! After reading the Yelp reviews and seeing its popularity, we thought we were in for a great ramen experience. We didn't have to wait at all to get a table, but we did have to share a long table with a family which was no problem at all.

We both ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen (medium spicy). I thought the medium spicy would make the broth orange/red, but the broth stayed the same color of clear with fatty droplets. There were a lot of noodles, which were the thin kind (not the thicker ones that I'm used to). The broth also had a sweet taste, which caught me off guard since I was hoping for a more hearty, creamy taste. 

The egg was perfectly poached and delicious, but there wasn't enough pork belly for my taste. Overall, the broth was mediocre to me and portions were very noodle-heavy. The service was great and food came out quickly. I'd like to give Marufuku another try in the future, since Japantown is one of my favorite spots and I always hear rave reviews about Marufuku.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Fried chicken and squid apps were done well but don't believe they were done to order because it came out super fast and wasn't piping hot

Hakata Tonkotsu was what I decided to get while my family got the Deluxe version. While yes you get more toppings included + both pork proteins I personally was satisfied with the basic and adding extra noodles (they come on the side)

Broth was balanced well, not too salty, the right amount of umami (if you get medium spice, the heat is there and lingers but doesn't hurt). Downside was that the broth lacked the right level of viscosity that usually is found in broths that are stewed for a long period of time 

Proteins were solid, preferred the pork belly over the sliced pork

Ramen - I prefer the chewier kind, the ones they use are too soft for my liking

Wasabi Beer felt like a miss, nowhere as assertive as I thought it should have been and not worth the price point

Wait time can be tough for larger parties but they seem to rotate fine for the smaller groups

Overall Thoughts

While the ramen is solid, Mensho Toyoko is still my #1 go-to choice but I would like to come back one day to try the Chicken Paitan Deluxe!
author: Eddie W.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning at 11:15 with a party of 5  and made it into the first seating. We finished in about an hour. 

I ordered the chicken paitan dx because I wanted to try the chicken leg. It was very soft and juicy and has a savory sweet taste to it. The ramen has thin noodles and came with three pieces of chicken. The pieces of chicken were pretty forgettable and ramen would have been better without the chicken. Mild broth was pretty light and easy to drink. 

I also had a chance to try the braised pork which was absolutely delicious. 

Overall, I was very satisfied with this place. Minimal wait if you come before opening and the price is cheaper than Mensho or Iza. Best bang for the buck ramen in the city.
author: Edward W.

description: A delicious well-crafted broth - either the pork or chicken base! We compared the spicy pork broth versus the spicy chicken broth and the pork was noticeably spicier. Go figure. Still delicious! The Takoyaki is your average fare that you can get just about at any ramen shop.
author: Jason H.

description:
Best Ramen place ever! Have been to both it's locations- SF and Oakland and both are great. The line is always long so better not show up super hungry. Have had to wait 45 mins at least every time I visit but it's worth it. 

I believe a menu is the first indication of how good the restaurant's food is - they've limited options and are confident and skilled at nailing those every single time. I've tried Hakata Tonkotsu and Hakata Deluxe, both are amazing! Good portion size too!
author: Vasu S.

description:
I arrived around 7:15 PM and got seated around 7:40 PM. I think the wait wasn't too horrible, but the biggest flaw I noticed about their system was that they were seating two-person parties in big tables that could fit 4 or 5. I think they should either replace some of the bigger tables with smaller tables so that more parties can fit in the restaurant and prevent such a long wait time. However, there are some stores in the same plaza that you can look through to help pass the time. 

There are only 4 different options for ramen, with two variations of two main types of meat/broth. The food came out very quickly, which was nice. I normally don't tend to enjoy Japanese ramen that much, but I would say Marufuku's ramen is one that I often crave and would definitely want to eat again! 

I have tried both the pork and chicken ramens, and they're both really good! I enjoy them with medium spice, and my friend who got mild ended up asking for extra spice, so I would say medium might be the average level of spice for most people? We also tried the wasabi beer which had a very strange aftertaste. I don't think I'll ever be getting that again! 

Overall, positive experience and left feeling satisfied!
author: Hanna K.

description:
I ordered the Chicken Paitan ($11.99) and it was very filling!

The Chicken Paitan came with chicken, soft boiled egg, kikurage mushrooms, green onions, and bean sprouts. I was only given about two thin pieces of chicken and I could easily bite into them. On the other hand, I was given plenty of noodles! The noodles tasted homemade and I have never had this type of noodle before. I liked how the dish was not very salty. I also liked how you can choose the level of spiciness. 

This place isn't great for those who are vegetarian. There were only four types of ramen dishes I could choose from and all of them contained meat. 

I will probably come back in the future. Although it took over 30 minutes to be seated at a table, we received our food in about 5 minutes.
author: Kristina M.

description:
I never knew why there weren't better ramen joints in Japantown in SF. You'd think it'd be so easy to draw crowds with the cold foggy weather. Even as we're nearing June, it was pretty cold and windy this weekend. I made plans to meet a friend for lunch and we planned to get here around opening time. I arrived at 11:28 and there was already a wait before the store opened!

We didn't make the first cut but luckily we also didn't mind and were able to sit outside and catch up! After maybe a 30-40 min wait for the first round to eat and clear out (we were about 5th on the waiting list), we got seated. It's definitely not the smallest ramen joint I've seen and the decor is quite clean and contemporary with Einstein bulbs for lighting and a center island-like dining table that made seating for 3 actually quite convenient. However we noticed they weren't always efficient in seating people in this area since parties of one would sometimes occupy a setting for 3.

We started with takoyaki ($6.5) and a chicken karage bowl ($3.50) since we were going to get the Chicken Paitan DX, which came with a grilled half chicken. The takoyaki was actually pretty good.  I'm pretty picky about good takoyaki since Japan has forever ruined me. It has to be crispy on the outside but soft on the inside. This takoyaki certainly had a crispy shell but almost slightly too thin (like a crepe brûlée sugar layer on top the cracks open). Nonetheless I think many places don't execute the crispness at all and so I give them props! Chicken karage was decent but not the most spectacular I've had. It was a little on the dry side. 

I chose to order the Hakata Tonkatsu ($10.99) since it was classic and simple and I like my chasu simmered. It came with bamboo shoots, bean sprouts, green onions, and a full soft boiled egg. I also thought there was quite a decent amount of ramen. The DX version is about $4 more and has corn and braised pork belly but I just ordered extra corn on the side and I didn't exactly care to have braised pork belly. For the price of the bowl, I was quite impressed because this would have been probably more expensive elsewhere for the portion size, the full soft boiled egg, etc. And the broth was delicious!

My friend had the chicken paitan DX ($15.99) and I have to say I don't think I've had chicken ramen before. I am now a fan. The broth was very soothing and delicious..less fatty than the tonkatsu broth and I would get it next time. I could taste the chicken flavors and it was cleaner than my broth with a different complexity. The grilled Half chicken came on the side and was quite delicious! We split this and we're SUPER full by the time we finished. Only 15 orders of this a day so snag it early if you want it!

Staff was super friendly and nice. Food didn't take too long to come. The only downside would probably be the wait if you don't come early enough. All in all, I would give it 4.5 stars but I'm rounding up for good service, cleanliness, and ambiance!
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Definitely in my top 3 of best ramen I've had. 

I went on a Sunday and got there around 4:30 (30 minutes before they opened), and there was a pretty long line already. We weren't able to sign in electronically until they opened, but some reviews seem to say otherwise. By the time they filled up the tables with people in line, my boyfriend and I were the first party that had to wait T_T It worked out though because at 5pm, I wasn't super hungry. We were able to walk around after signing in and received a text saying a table was ready within 20 minutes. 

We ordered the Chicken Paitan DX and the Hakata Tonkotsu with a side of kakuni (braised pork belly), which I think came out to be a little cheaper than ordering the Hakata DX. I believe it came with 2 big pieces of pork belly. 

Tonkotsu ramen is my favorite, and the Hakata Tonkotsu here is A+. The bowl of ramen is seriously beautiful, with a bit of oil glistening on top. The broth is rich and creamy without being overly fatty or salty (I'd actually recommend getting the kakuni on the side or not getting it at all, as it kind of overpowered the broth in the end). We took home leftovers, and the broth didn't solidify at all, which is crazy! 

I like the idea of chicken ramen but have been disappointed a number of times. Marufuku really delivers here, though. My boyfriend (who isn't the biggest fan of Tonkotsu ramen) said that the Chicken Paitan ramen was the best ramen he's ever had. I had a personal preference for the Tonkotsu but would have been completely happy just eating the Paitan ramen as well. The chicken leg that comes with the deluxe option is tender and delicious.  

Also first time visitors should note that the spiciness levels aren't very spicy at all. I read a tip from another review and found it good to know. We ordered the Tonkotsu ramen with medium spiciness and the Paitan with mild, and the spice was just barely noticeable in the Tonkotsu. I didn't mind though - the ramens have plenty of flavor without any spice.
author: Allison Y.

description:
So good and totally worth the wait! They use the waitlist function through yelp so you can go shopping in Japantown while you wait. The wait also went really fast, they know how to get people in and out so fast! Fast service, hardly any waiting for your food and the check. 

I got the Chicken Paitan mildly spicy and it was barely spicy at all. I'll get it spicy next time :)
author: Rachel I.

description: First time trying this place in SF and I was not disappointed. The reviews are true that this place has a long wait time BUT the wait is so worth it. I ordered the Hakata DX. The order came out so quick I was surprised. The broth was so creamy but not too thick and not too watery. It was a perfect mixture. The pork was very tender and easy to eat. The staff are sweet and very accommodating! I like how you can type your name on their iPad and you can view all the guests ahead of you. They text you to notify you that you'll be seated shortly. Very hi-tech! I definitely recommend this place if you're ever visiting SF! 5/5 overall!
author: Mena A.

description:
I've been to a good amount of ramen places in sf and San mateo and I really think marufuku is amazing. The broth was my favorite part. I like my broth creamy and fatty. I got it spicy, but it really wasn't spicy so I'd recommend just getting the ultra spicy. I like that this place uses a more neutral spice oil rather than the spicy miso paste other ramen places give you, which only makes your broth saltier.

Noodles were good. Meat was moist and well cooked. I also really liked the pork slices because they almost had a smokey, apple flavor to it.

The karage was also so so good. It had so much chicken in it and the perfect amount of breading. 

There is a wait tho, so be prepared to put your name down and wait at least 40 minutes.
author: Stephanie K.

description: OMG take me back to Marufuku please!!! Spent LDW in San Francisco and was able to try this place. Apparently this place is very hard to get into because it's so damn good. The ramen is the BEST I've ever had. I got the medium spice chicken ramen and it had the perfect kick, the broth is delicious, absolutely mouthwatering. I will be going back to this restaurant every time I'm in SFO. You must try!!!
author: Adriana S.

description:
Was it a good bowl of ramen?  Yes.
Would I wait an hour and a half minutes for it again?  No. 

When we got there at 6:30pm on Sunday night, we were no. 49 in line.  We were seated around 7:45pm, and when we left at 8:45pm, there was still a mob outside the door, even though they close at 9:00pm...

Got the DX, which was a bit over priced (they charge a premium for the actual pork belly that I feel is standard at most other ramen shops).  My friend also noted that the broth was a bit on the sweeter side (which I definitely noticed once he pointed it out). 

Perhaps I'll go back again once the hype has died down a bit...
author: Alison L.

description:
If you want a seat with minimal waiting time, I suggest getting there 10-15 min prior to opening on a weekday. I was seated immediately after they opened. 

I knocked off a star because of the 4 tonkatsu ramen a we ordered, they got all of them wrong whether is was the level of spice and/or the additions in toppings. We don't know how that happened because each person ordered for themselves. I initially wanted the mild broth, but got the non-spicy. I found the non-spicy a bit too creamy, however the noodles were cooked perfectly. Another person in our party does not recommend getting the extra noodles (about 1/3 of what's in your bowl even if it's $2) since they put it on a separate plate and serve that to you well before your initial bowl of ramen comes out. Anyways, our chicken karagge and geso fries didn't come out till we were about done with our meal after we asked about the order. Sounds like we got real off service this afternoon. Overall, the thin noodles are delicious and the broth was just alright considering I got the wrong level of spice. I wouldn't recommend coming out of the way for this ramen shop.
author: Jess W.

description: Been to a lot of ramen places up and down California and all over the East Coast, this place has the best Pork Chashu, Broth, and soft boiled egg I've ever had in ramen. So good the morning after I had it for the first time I was part of the lunch opening line.
author: Leo C.

description:
Delicious ramen with very generous portions. Five of us ordered similar bowls and only one cleaned his completely.

The medium spice is hot, but not overwhelming. The spicy was hotter, but the heat didn't linger, so if you like spicy food you'll probably enjoy both.

This is a very popular place, so get your name on the list early. You can see your place in the queue via Yelp and they will call you when you're close to being seated, which allows you to browse Japan Center. I was worried that we wouldn't get a table, but they close the list before it gets too long and we were guaranteed a spot. The service was top notch as well. We will be returning.
author: Kevin H.

description:
I can't believe this ramen place is able to garner such high reviews.

This place is NOT worth it for the amount of wait (about an hour for a party of 2). You have to realize, this is coming from a guy who waited 2.5 hrs to eat at Totto ramen in NYC.

My friend and I both got the hakata dx.

Another low star review mentioned this but everything is SO SWEET here. The noodles have a slightly sweet taste which would normally be fine but combined with the sickeningly sweet taste of the braised pork belly, I couldn't even finish everything. Neither could my friend. The pork belly tasted about as sweet as those chinese sweet pork buns (or maybe even sweeter). I could not understand how we were supposed to eat this ramen. Perhaps it's just catered towards the average American's taste buds?? I got the medium spicy and it didn't do much in counter-balancing the sweetness...

Overall, would not recommend at all. If you've tasted any sort of decent ramen, you probably would not enjoy this place.
author: David K.

description: Very good ramen, served promptly. Use Open Table to secure a place in the long line they often have before you arrive!
author: Pat B.

description:
Great ramen place for a bite with friends! Went for a lunch on a busy Sunday and waited about 15-20 minutes for a table for 4. There is a fairly quick turnover for tables but the shop is on the smaller side so a little wait wasn't too surprising. Normally my friends and I would be restless while waiting to be seated, but luckily for us there was a purikura place a few doors down to entertain us while we waited! Great location for a busy ramen shop.

Now back to the food-- I was very pleased with quality of their ramen. At first I was a little apprehensive at the simplicity of their menu. Seriously it only seemed as if there were pork or chicken available plus a slightly fancier variation of each. However, do not be fooled! Think quality over quantity. Their meat is tender and roasted to perfection-- none of that tough stuff you find in instant ramen packs! A full-bodied broth envelops an admirable portion of chewy noodles and tender vegetables. To finish it all off, at the bottom of every bowl there is a soft-boiled egg that is sort of like a hidden treasure for the unsuspecting meal-goer. Ugh. Even though eggs and ramen are such a traditional pair, it feels like such a miracle when you take that first bite of gooey goodness! 

All in all, very pleased with our experience. A would-visit-again kind of place!
author: Kasey N.

description:
Long-ass line so here's the tip: put your name down as soon as you can, then head to the hidden sake bar around the corner to throw back a couple sake or calpico bombs while you wait. Send someone back to check on your place in line and call you if you're next. Proceed to order the chicken karragge @ Hakkata Deluxe & gorge yourself while happily tipsy, maybe with another bottle of sake.

5 star ramen & chicken & sake booooo
author: Grace C.

description: Great food fast service! Very much so worth the wait! We enjoyed the octopus balls and ramen. So full after I needed a nap :)
author: William G.

description:
First off, you're probably here because this is the number one ramen place on Yelp in the Japantown area, or you saw the crazy line. If it's the former, and you don't know about the lines yet... let me tell you: you need to show up here 30 minutes before opening and stand in line, otherwise you'll surely be waiting much much longer than the 30 minutes you waited for it to open. Folks line up and it gets unbelievably long, to the point where it seems like a grand opening (but it's actually a normal day). If you don't make it before the line gets crazy, you'll end up putting your name into an iPad, which means you can walk around and explore Japantown while you wait. 

Now, the ramen. They have regular option and deluxe option. Basically the deluxe option adds a higher quality chunk of meat to your "regular" meat that's included in the regular option. I opted for the deluxe with pork to see what all the hype was about, and it was definitely worth it. The meat was so tender and flavorful, and definitely beat out the regular pork. It also made the portion significantly larger since they basically just increase the meat level from the regular dish. The broth was incredibly flavorful, on both the pork and the chicken options. 

One thing that was odd was my entire family agreed that we had a terrible taste in our mouths (literally, not figuratively) after eating there, even including those of us who got different broth types. We did get a pork bun type of appetizer as well (which I wasn't a fan of), so we can't exactly pinpoint what it was that caused the unpleasant aftertaste...but it lasted for like a whole 24 hours later. 

Overall I might go there again just to show someone that there's this ramen place that is so popular that the line gets that long, and it's actually very good, but I think I would be just as satisfied with any ol' ramen place that had less of a wait and hopefully doesn't leave a bad taste in my mouth. Additionally, the level of constant business that they have seems to make the wait staff less attentive and friendly, which isn't a good excuse when you're waiting that long for what should be a superb experience. 4 stars sustained because the food is very good.
author: Elena S.

description: This place by far has been my favorite ramen place in sf. The broth has tons of flavor the pork belly is nice and thick and price is very better than ramen places nearby. The only bad thing about it is the wait time this place is always full but worth wait
author: Ivan C.

description:
I got here a little before they opened for dinner at 5pm on a Sunday. There was already a line but I was able to get seated pretty quickly once they opened. I was sat at the bench seating area in the middle of the restaurant which was so spacious (I was able to put my backpack next to me) but a little hard to get in and out of especially in a dress. The waitress came right away to get my order. The wait for food was also short. I ordered a spicy HAKATA TONKOTSU.  When my ramen arrived, it was a glorious sight to behold. The pork bone stock that they say has been cooking for over 20 hours glistened and called out to me. I took a spoonful of the broth and let the richness of the soup sweep over my tongue. It was delicious but really spicy! I was a little startled at how spicy it was. I probably should've gotten medium or mild. My spice tolerance has been ever dwindling since I left home. 

The pork was a little bit firm but not too hard to chew. The fresh and crisp bean sprouts and chewy, thin noodles went so well together and delivered textural bliss. I had forgotten about the stewed soft-boiled egg so it came as a pleasant surprise once uncovered. The yolk was perfectly runny and so yummy. I usually don't care for whole eggs but this beauty was such a wonder for the senses with its soft, liquid-y center and flavorful caramel exterior. The waiters were quite attentive. My cup of water was constantly being filled. When the waiter came with the check, he made sure to tell me to please take my time as I was finishing my last bites and sips. I'm glad he saved me the trouble of flagging someone down. I'm definitely coming back here to try the Hakata DX! When I left around 6:30pm, there was a crowd of people waiting outside. Better to come early next time too!
author: Lauren H.

description:
A popular new ramen joint located on the second floor of the Kinokuniya building in Japantown, Marufuku offers good-value ramen as well as rice bowls and a variety of appetizers like gyoza, chicken karaage, and takoyaki.

Although there isn't a lot of seating inside, the wait was pretty quick when I came on a recent weekday night, and the food was served very fast. To start, the chicken karaage was slightly dry and overfried, but still quite tasty, especially when dipped in what appeared to be an aioli-like sauce on the side.

The real star, though, was the hakata DX ramen bowl, which is the same thing as the hakata tonkotsu, just with more of everything. Indeed, given the price of the DX bowl, I'd say you're getting good value for your money - a generous helping of pork belly and other ingredients like corn, bean sprouts, and mushrooms, with the added bonus of a soft boiled egg sitting underneath. The broth wasn't too rich but wasn't bland either - just the right level in between.

A dependable venue for ramen in Japantown. Thanks to all you Yelpers out there for this nice find!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Line can be Long...35mins on weekday....

Kept passing this Ramen Place for quite sometime now...Intrigue by People waiting...

Tried it on the 17th of May...6'sh 35mins to be exact...

They have a small Menu choice..but...Id say they can Justify the Small Menu Choice..

Got the Squid and Chicken Karage for Appetizer . Its very good...Try it with BEER ..

Got the Tonkatsu Ramen...I can tell now why people come here...The Brought on the Ramen was good...Good Quality Ramen...

Service was faster than waiting in line to be seated...Once your inside...the rest was fast...Good Service..(My first in a Ramen House were Server comes back and ask how the dining experience) Bravo for this..

Good Quality Ramen...This is a good Try...
author: Donovan L.

description:
I'm confused why this place is so highly rated. I got the hakata dx and thought this place was terrible. The chicken karaage made up for it though because the chicken was dark meat and fried well. 

Back to the ramen. The portions were huge but the broth wasn't flavorful, the braised pork wasn't soft and too sweet. The simmered chatsu pork was rubbery and hard. I didn't even want to finish the slices given. The noodles were thin and resembled hk egg noodles and didnt have the alkaline you usually get in ramen like the thin noodles at Santouka and Ajisen. 

Overall, I think there's better ramen in the city for $15 a bowl.
author: Joanna S.

description: I waited about an hour to eat here. I had a Hakata Tonkatsu and takoyaki. Ramen was good, I enjoyed the broth a lot. The takoyaki was also pretty good. Although I liked the food here, I'm not sure I would wait an hour to eat here. Luckily, I was able to kill time and walk around the mall. If you are used to waiting to eat at restaurants, then this place would be a good choice.
author: Shirley P.

description:
I had been trying to go to this place for months, but each time it has 2 hour long waitlists that made it impossible. I finally was able to try it and it was SO WORTH IT. 

The restaurant opens at 11am and I got there around noon, but there was already a long waitlist! I had to wait about 45 minutes to get seated (23 parties before me). It was slightly pricier compared to other ramen places in the city, but the quality of their food beats out most other ramen places. My friend and I thought it was somewhat small at first, especially for the price, until we realized how jam packed the bowl actually was. Long story short, we both left happy and satisfied! 

On another note, it was kind of funny that they were so busy, they gave us the check even though we were barely halfway through our meals!
author: Sally H.

description:
I guess my expectation was just too high...?

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
Saw other Yelpers' reviews saying how popular this place is, and being newly opened I expected a long line, so I went 30 mins before it opened hoping to get ahead of the crowd. The doors were open when I got to the place already, and there was a sign-in sheet at the table, so I put my name down (there were 4 people on top of my name already) and started walking around the mall. Then when I went back 20 mins later, there was a line formed, I was thinking if there's a sign-in sheet why would people line-up? It turned out the sign-in sheet didn't really mean anything, I guess it's for later use but at its opening it would be a first-come-first-serve. THEN WHY WOULD YOU PUT A SIGN-IN SHEET THERE AT THE FIRST PLACE?? I was kind of mad, but oh well I was there already, and I had to eat, so I just started lining up...

Luckily I made it to the first round. I was actually the last person for the 1st round and there was only a table for 4 left (I was party of one). Luckily the waiter was still willing to let me take up the whole table (and I knew I had to finish as quick as possible as the table was close to the entrance and many people started peeking in).

* * * FOOD * * *
Karaage: B+
Not that it's not good, but just nothing special. The breading was quite thin and not too crispy which I liked, but I felt like it's just the same as any other ramen places I have tried.

Hakata DX: B+
It was not bad, but I have had ramen at a lot other restaurants in the bay area that are better. I guess it was just not unique enough. The pork broth was kind of thick, but not rich, it's not too salty yet nothing really stood out. Soft boiled egg was good. I was pretty disappointed at the pork belly - it wasn't tender at all, the meat was a bit tough. I did add menma, kikurage mushroom and bean sprouts to it, they came on the side which was nice, it wouldn't stuff the whole bowl of ramen.

I really want to give this place a 4-star at least, since the service was okay and the interior and everything was above average, but the ramen really did not impress me.
author: Simon C.

description:
I should have known I could have put my name on the waitlist in advance via Yelp... but alas, I did not. My friend and I triumphantly walked up to the front door thinking "it's 2pm, how busy could they be?" and proceeded to find out there were 60 parties ahead of us. SIXTY! But we were there and hungry and had hunted it down after a snafu with google maps, so we were committed. They let you enter your name on an iPad via NoWait and then text you when your table is ready, and you can also see real time updates via Yelp! 

After shopping around JapanCenter for about an hour we came back for our table and got a 4 top to ourselves which was nice, as it was slowing down since they were getting ready to close soon before reopening at 5 for dinner. I geek out over Japanese pottery, and theirs is gorgeous and irregular and perfect. We split a Shensho spicy beer, shishito peppers, chashu pork buns, and I got the tonkatsu dx ramen and she got the chicken paitan. They had a chicken paitan dx but only make 15 servings a day! So obviously that was not in the cards for us given the wait. 

Everything was delicious, perfectly spicy, flavored, textured, and hot but not scalding. My braised pork was chewy but not fatty, and the broth was thick but not gelatinous. All I can say is it was worth the wait and a great bang for your buck! $55 for everything
author: Lauren M.

description:
This was my first time at Marufuku. Came here for lunch with a friend to celebrate the end of finals (woo!). 

I got their Hakata Tonkatsu ramen, mild spicy, with sweet corn. The soup base is amazing, it's super savory and smooth. Mild is perfect for if you want a little bit of a kick but not a lot. At mild the spicy is the kind where it builds the more the eat, which I prefer over the spicy where it just punches you in the face when you take your first bite. 

I would totally come here again. Just a tip, their menu is on the smaller side so there may not be as many options as some people might be looking for or expecting.
author: Megan M.

description: I have tried many ramen places and this one is one of my favorite places now, the quantity is good and the quality also, Id definitely recommend it to fellow ramen fans.
author: Jay G.

description: Soooo Yummy! We got there before the store opened and there was already a line, but I think it's well worth the wait. With a very generous portion, affordable pricing and delicious noodles and soup, this is one of my favorite ramen places. The soup was just so good!! I got the Hakata Tonkotsu and I couldn't stop drinking it even after I was super full. It is very filling even though the bowl doesn't appear to be that big. They also serve the food super fast which was another plus for my hungry tummy
author: Lulu T.

description:
We started lining 40 minutes before opening (5:30 pm), and barely got in. After we got seated our orders were taken almost right away, good thing we had so much time in line to think about what we were going to have. My friend and I decided on a Hakata Tonkotsu - Medium spicy and Karaage Bowl. 

The Karaage Bowl came first, it was a small portion of rice with 3 pieces of fried chicken. I was hoping for more chicken, as the rice to chicken portion was very off. I ended up adding some of the ramen broth into my rice to add flavor. The chicken was juicy and tender, but did not have a crispy outer layer. I was slightly disappointed with this dish. 

The Hakata Tonkotsu however, was well worth our wait. The broth was creamy, but on the saltier side. It seemed they added a lot of ginger, as it wasn't too spicy but had a kick in the end. What made the dish come together was the thin chewy noodles, I loved them. The kikurage mushrooms were a nice addition as well, the texture blended well with the noodles. 

Although the food was memorable, the service was not. It was very rushed, and the moment my friend put his chopsticks down, staff came over to ask if he was finished and took his bowl away. But, this practice is common in Japan. 

Their ramen really stands out, and the long line of customers can prove it. It's weird to think that the time spent lining was longer than that of us enjoying our food, but it is what it is. I would still recommend to friends, but be ready for a wait!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
3.5 stars. Okay. I really hate waiting in lines for food these days. It's become a joke at times...usually it's a long line for mediocre food.  This place is pretty good actually. Except for the rushed service.  

Hakata Tonkotsu (added roasted seaweed) = good.  Milky broth, not too salty, and plenty of layers of flavor.  You can tell that they've spent time on this broth.  If you're expecting thick egg noodles, then be prepared for an almost white noodle.  It's quite different than anything I've ever had. $11.99 (plus $1.00 for the extra seaweed topping.)

Chicken Paitan = good. I want to say this is almost better than the tonkotsu.  $11.99

Kakuni bowl = good. I wanted to try the kakuni and it was awesome.  I'd get this one again. $4.50

Karaage bowl = good.  I liked it but nothing I'd go out of my way to order. $4.00

Wasabi beer = okay.  I did not taste much wasabi in it.  I loved the label though. $9.50.

Coke = $2.50.

Service = friendly enough.  Efficient.  I felt like they were trying to hustle people in and out though.  That's the one thing I didn't like about this place.  Most of us waited in a long line to get in, and they're trying to rush us out?  

Prices = reasonable.  With taxes and SF Mandate, dinner for two with a bit of leftovers came out to $50.81.
author: Fannie S.

description: You know when a ramen shop is good based on their egg. It should be a little yolky inside. Besides that, the noodles were chewy, pork was nicely flavored and SOFT (the fat melts in your mouth), but the broth was what made this meal so special. It is creamy and salty and savory and so so good. Honestly think this ramen shop is better than Ramen Yamadaya across the street. The wait time around 6pm was 40 mins. BUT the service was really really fast. You sit, order, and the food comes out immediately.
author: Ashley K.

description: The wait was long but the food is worth the wait. Once you're inside, the service is quick and your food arrives before you know it. Delicious tonkotsu ramen.
author: Leo H.

description:
I was getting Japan withdrawals after my recent trip to Tokyo and decided to get ramen last Sunday. One of my friends recommended Marufuku, so we decided to make our way here last Sunday at 11AM (they open at 11:30). We were one of the first 4 parties in line. 

At first, it looked like there were only a few people in front of us. However, by the time 11:30 rolled around, there were literally 20 people in front of us, because someone was saving a spot for their family of 8 (WAT?!) So yea, that happens. Get here early, if you don't want to wait 1-2 hours to eat lunch.

Once we sat down and ordered, the food came quickly. We ordered chicken karaage, mentaiko bowl (yummm), and shishito peppers to start.

My bf & our friend both ordered the tonkatsu ramen. I got the tori paitan dx, which comes with a side of chicken served on a sizzling plate.

Not as good as the tori paitan I had at Kagari in Tokyo, but it satisfied my cravings for tori paitan. I left feeling high and buzzy and took a 3-hour nap from the food coma. Now, that's what you call a lazy Sunday.

I would seriously come get the mentaiko bowl all the time if I lived closer. Good thing I don't live that close to Japan town.
author: Grace C.

description: We were in town and happened to come across Marufuku.  Loved the whole experience!  First, we checked into line with Yelp and watched as our icon got closer to the "front of the line."  Loved this because we could shop and come back when it was closer to our turn!  It quoted us a certain time, so we walked around the Japan Center.  We ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen (noodles were skinny and chewy) and Karaage Chicken (crisp and juicy).  An added bonus was how flavorful their chashu was in the ramen.  I am extremely picky when it comes to Ramen, but Marufuku was one of the best that I have had.  Next time we are in town, this will be our first stop!
author: Kelli C.

description: Marufuku ramen was awesome. There is always a long line for a good reason. If you come here, put your name down and walk around for 20 minutes or so. Once you are in, the food comes really fast. This ramen has broth that is so rich and creamy, the only broth I have found in the city that is comparable is at Mensho Ramen, in the tenderloine. This is a great place to come, with efficient and good service, and has some of the best ramen in the city to boot. The karaage and takoyaki were also phenomenal!
author: Ross S.

description:
Wow wow wow! The first place in the city, where I've liked ramen and it doesn't have black garlic! Whaaaaaaaaaat?

I absolutely love this place! It's the only food place that's good in the Japan center mall. I highly suggest eating here. Even more than Benihana! The place is nicely decorated and super fancy.

I came during the cherry blossom festival and the wait was ridiculously long. You write down your name on the list and wait till your name is called. We waited about an hour and a half.

The weird thing about it was that even though the people who were on the list were called, and weren't there, every single time a table opened up, they would go back to the top of the list and call again.

Seriously, WTF! THAT WAS REALLY IRRITATING AND ANNOYING. I know this is a new place but sorry, if your name is called and your not there, you gotta wait again. I know they just opened, but they need to set standards.

They only had ramen bowls,no sides no apps. And the ramen was to dieeeee for. I got the medium spicy and my bf got spicy. The spicy was pretty spicy. I liked the medium best. I also ordered the 14$ ramen with pork and I l0ved it.

I wanted to try the chicken, but I'll definitely do it on my next visit. Can't wait to return!
author: Lynn C.

description: This is my second time here and I love marufuku's ramen! The first time was the hakata tonkatsu and this time I got the deluxe. Enjoyable and would come back a third time!
author: Justin L.

description:
Great ramen, might even be the best in SF. I would just like to bring  attention to a minor issue I had when I went for lunch.

I went by myself and had signed the waitlist ahead of lady X, who signed up for 2 people.

When I was coming up next on the queue (5 people ahead of me being let in), I was already at the door. When the server had called lady X (and her friend) for a booth table that could accommodate 6 people, I was left  confused. I had to wait an extra 7-10 mins, then I got seated in the middle section that could accommodate 3 people (big enough for lady X and friend). The situation would've only made sense if atleast 4 people were seated at the booth. 

Anyway, it was fine, everyone got their ramen. I'd still come back, but by the way things went, I would recommend paying attention to the line, who came before and after you in qeueu especially during dinner when wait times can go up to 2 hours. The seating was just questionable.
author: V B.

description:
Next to the authentic ramen place I visited in Waikiki, Hawaii and another in Tokyo. This place is the next best! Love that they have a chicken option. Most ramen places are pork pork and more pork! 

Came here on a week night. Two tables ahead of use at 7pm and waited 15min or so. We ordered the pork and the chicken. Didn't get any appetisers though they looked reallly good! Next time!

Ramen came quite fast and their noodles are pretty thin for ramen but tasted sooo good(of course also had to do w the broth) the chicken broth seemed to have tasted better than the pork. I don't usually finish a whole bowl of ramen with the broth but I did here!!! It was THAT good. Oh did I mention the egg...something about it is also different and very yummy~ both my friend and I agreed.

Definitely will return to try their appetisers. Much variety.
author: Carmen L.

description:
One of my two favorite ramen places in SF, and that's saying something given how many there are! The ramen is flavorful, the noodles have perfect texture, and the toppings are wonderful complements.

Came here for lunch on a weekday and the line started about 20 minutes before opening. Luckily, was seated and served quickly. I ordered the Tonkotsu Deluxe, spicy and was delighted by everything in it.

The noodles are definitely thinner than the usual ramen place, but they're cooked perfectly and have perfect texture. The pork is neither too fatty nor cut too thick. The toppings, from the seaweed to mushrooms, were all great. The server mentioned that the deluxe has more toppings than the regular, but I wasn't quite clear on which and by how many. The ramen is served in a deeper, not as wide bowl.

Highly recommend, have also heard good things about the chicken paitan. Definitely will be back to try.
author: Tim X.

description:
Ambience: new, nice decor, wood blocks, floor to ceiling glass panels, quiet.

Takoyaki: delicious but only comes with 5 instead of the usual 6

Tonkotsu ramen: soup broth is homemade and cooked for 16 hours! And you can taste it too, one of the best broths in the city. The soft boiled egg was cooked to perfection and was slightly sweetened. Overall very good.
author: Tom P.

description:
My favorite ramen place. I think it's every-so-slightly better than Yamadaya and Tanpopo, which were my favorites for years until this place opened up. 

The seating is not as great as the ramen. Much of it is community tables (boo!) or benches (no back support! double-boo!). The *standard* seating goes first, so if you're older like me, you have to wait for a seat with standard chairs to open up. If this place didn't have the best damn ramen, I'd never come here.
author: Tim W.

description: This place is wonderful! Good ambience, fast service, great food. Not much else needs to be said.
author: Ayslin R.

description:
I consider myself a Ramen conoscere and I have to say that this place is hands down the best Ramen shop I have had in my experiences. From the very first sip of the broth, I literally said out loud "wow". Everything I prefer in ramen noodles, they did by the standard. The broth was rich and oily, noodles were thin and firm, paired with sweet but smoky thick cut chasu. The chasu was definitely the best that I've ever had! 

I must admit, we waited for about an hour to be seated but it was well worth the wait. I don't blame them, considering the fact that they are brand new. Service was very friendly, the first thing our server did was apologize for the wait. He was very helpful towards the members of our party that were unsure of what to order. Would highly recommend this ramen shop!
author: Jermaine C.

description:
Yooo, this is my spot! I swear to god I was the first once here before my spot got blown up. Please stop going here people because its getting harder for me to eat here myself. On the real tho, #1 ramen spot for me in the city when it comes to Tonkotsu ramen. I have been eating ramen religiously in SF for the past 6 months now and this place is one of the best in the city. Reasonably priced and great quality. The broth is very creamy, packed with a ton of flavor and pairs nicely with a thin noodle. 
I had the Hakata Tonkotsu Dx ramen and licked the bowl clean, then inhaled the rest of my girlfriends broth.

Making reservations is can be done easily through the yelp app, which is nice since you can plan accordingly and not waste your time standing in line. Over all great experience every time, I still have to try their Chicken Paitan DX which has a limited amount of servings per day. 

I'm definitely going back, but people seriously.. please stop blowing up my spot and eat somewhere else. Thanks ;)
author: Chase R.

description:
People had told me really good things about this place and it definitely did live up to the hype! We waited for about 45 minutes before we were finally seated. This place also utilizes the Yelp wait list. The interior was small but seating felt spacious. I loved the dark, wooden furniture with modern lighting. The waiters were very diligent in serving water.

[ Tonkatsu ] I got it mildly spicy but it wasn't spicy at all. I loved the thickness of the broth and the firmness of the noodles. The pork belly had the perfect balance of fatty meat and tender meat. The bowls they served the ramen in were extremely beautiful. 

Definitely coming back for more!
author: Annie Z.

description:
I was really looking forward to my visit at Marufuku based on the reviews.  Luckily, I happened to be in Japantown right around the time it opened during a weekday, and there was no wait (though shortly after I entered, the restaurant started filling up with the lunchtime crowd).  I ended up ordering the hakata tonkotsu (which came with pork belly, egg, mushrooms, bean sprouts, and green onions) and the karaage rice bowl.  Service was attentive, though it took longer than expected to get the rice bowl.

Unfortunately, given the high expectations I had based on what I read bout the restaurant, I was disappointed by my meal.  I think I'm realizing that I'm not a big fan of the hakata ramen style with it's thin, straight noodles, and my ramen noodles came in unwieldy clumps that made it difficult to enjoy.  I appreciated the spiciness of the broth but felt that it was relatively one-note in terms of depth.  The karaage bowl was sizable, though I thought the chicken was under-seasoned.  This was not a bad meal by any means, but I just did not get the hype.
author: Keith H.

description: Nom nom!! Even the side rice dishes were so tasty my kids ate all of it. Would love to go again when we are in the are! Food came out fast too.
author: Karen H.

description:
New item available now.!! 
Marufuku bites 2 pieces .!! And shishito chilli
I really like new item.
author: Pavitra J.

description:
The chicken deluxe ramen - spicy - is the single best ramen I've ever had in the U.S. The broth is not too thick/thin or salty/unseasoned. The fresh straight noodles were just right, and the accompanying chicken quarter, it was tender glazed mahogany that tasted like smoke.

We got to the place at opening and joined a line of about 45 people. A bunch of folks when in, and the rest signed up on the waitlist at their iPad sign. I walked around the 2nd floor of that side of the mall until I got a text and was seated about 30 mins after sign in. Good system.
author: Dennis W.

description:
This is an OK place for ramen. Given the wait that always seems to be present I wouldn't recommend.

The hakata tonkotsu broth is great. Rich flavor and the right amount of spiciness. The noodles were a little undercooked. I tried both kinds of pork and both were a little tough.

Service was good, frequent water refills and were quick to help. The one odd thing is we were asked to sit in a booth with another couple. So...who sits on the inside?? Awkward. Fortunately the waitress quickly picked up on this and asked the other couple if they would like to wait for their own table, and then told us she wouldn't seat anyone with us. They should get rid of the booths and put in chairs.
author: Charlie B.

description: Delicious ramen noodles. Right up there with ippudo in NYC. Really cool that it is in the Japan Center.
author: Christina S.

description: It was probably a bad idea to decide to try Marufuku during the cherry blossom festival but we were in the area and there were a lot of things to make the wait time pass by quickly. We probably waited at least an hour but it's nice that they have a texting system to let you know when your table is almost ready. I ordered the hakata Tonkotsu and my fiance ordered the hakata DX (deluxe). The difference was that he had a braised pork belly piece, corn, and nori. Worth the extra $4? For me, no but he liked the braised pork belly. I thought it was too flossy. The simmered pork belly that comes in both bowls was delicious. It was melt-in-your-mouth soft and very flavorful. I ordered medium and my fiance ordered spicy. Medium was already pretty spicy. The noodles here are very thin, which I didn't mind. The bowls look small but they don't skimp on the amount of noodles. You get three slices of simmered pork belly and some sprouts, ginger, and scallions. You also get a whole egg. Mine was almost half not soft boiled but my fiance's was all soft boiled. The soup was a bit too rich for me (I like to drink my ramen soup). All in all, they serve a satisfying bowl of ramen.
author: Christine L.

description: Tasty but very salty. We didn't have to wait. The portion is small. We will return...just need to order more side dishes to fill up.
author: Souris L.

description:
My personal Ramen-holic opinion:

Pros:
- The Chicken DX - best chicken based broth in the east bay, almost up there with some of the notable spots in Tokyo and Kyoto
- The Tokantsu broth - also good, with a very rich meaty flavor (but I find myself ordering the chicken here more often)
- Serving sizes - I have a pretty big appetite and think their portions are spot on, not so big that you feel defeated, but not skimpy by any means
- easy check-in with yelp - do yourself a favor and plan ahead a little and do the yelp checkin thing, there's some fun shops in the area you can bounce around while you wait.
- friendly staff - been there a few times and they have been consistently helpful and full of smiles, kudos to the management for fostering a good service etiquette
- perfectly cooked soft-boiled eggs (easy to get wrong, but they consistently get it right)

Mehs:
- The braised pork that comes with the DX is underwhelming.  It's a giant piece but has a dry, overcooked texture.  If you're set on getting the tonkatsu I would suggest just getting the regular.
- it does get busy so if you don't plan ahead there can be a significant wait, especially with groups

Summary:  one of the solid 3 legit Ramen places on my east-bay list (with Ippudo in Berkeley and Yuzu in Emeryville), notable for their Chicken broth.  But plan ahead to avoid the wait!
author: Bridge M.

description:
Overall: I thoroughly enjoyed Marufuku's "Hakata" style ramen, and I will definitely be coming back.

Highlights:
I ordered tonkotsu ramen with medium spice. Marufuku's ramen isn't your typical "basic" ramen. A few things set Marufuku apart from the rest of the pack. 1) Unlike other ramen places, Marufuku uses a skinny noodle - I suppose that's part of the "Hakata style". 2) The broth was thicker than most other places and it had a good garlic-y pork flavor. 3) Supposedly everything was hand made (the noodles?).

Lowlights:
The only lowlight here is there's normally a very long wait because it's a small space. It took about 1 hour to get seated for 2 people on Friday around 6PM. HYPE. Fortunately, you can walk around Japan town to kill time.

Service: 4/5
Food: 5/5
Value: 5/5
author: Sean W.

description: First time here..... long l line to eat good ramen.... best ramen house so far. It's worth the wait.
author: Prima D.

description: Not the best ramen i've ever had. The noodles were not traditional ramen noodles and the broth was mediocore at best. Also long wait times!
author: Jane T.

description:
After the SF Fleet Week was officially over on 10/8/2017, I was heading back to Japantown for a good Ramen dinner fix, so I came upon for this fantastic place called, "Marufuku Ramen." Marufuku (located inside Japantown Shopping Center) serves the customers of all ages to taste their delicious, eatable Ramen noodle soups, rice bowls and refreshing drinks every day and night! The atmosphere is very laid back and active as I welcomed there. The concept is much similar to Shoki Ramen House in Sacramento (i.e. 21st Street location) with soft amber smooth jazz music, modern Japanese decors and dimmed lights across the whole compact room.

The employees from hosts, servers and cookers are doing an awesome job for accommodating the customers like me a spectacular service despite the busiest environment on both lunch and dinner peak times. No cons at all!

Now onto the experience! I ordered both items on the menu: the Hakata Tonkotsu in mild spiciness and Karaage (aka Japanese style fried chicken). As I ate these two, it tasted marvelous and delicious after my orders did arrived in less than 5 minutes! The Hakata ramen cooked perfectly and eatable to bite which I did feel the fresh authentic Ramen noodles in ease! The Tonkotsu broth also tasted wonderful and spell-binding which I did feel the pork flavors of that broth thanks to the combination of simmered pork belly, soft-boiled egg, green onions, kikurage mushrooms and bean sprouts. On the other hand, the Chicken Karaage is da bomb goodness! I can feel the batter flavors of that fried chicken as well as the seasonings of wedge lemon and a special fresh mustard with powdered paprika combined. Delish dinner meal after waited 30 minutes on the waitlist clipboard after it opened its business hours at 5 pm. Not bad!

Parking at Marufuku Ramen can be quite challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street nor the parking garage if it's available. You can also alternatively ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmick.

In the end, Marufuku Ramen is the most unbelievable local Japanese Ramen restaurant that I've ever visited for the first time! Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering. A well received visit! My rating: 5 solid stars
author: William L.

description: I was trying ramen for the first time, and this place was just perfect. The chicken ramen was delicious, I had the iced green matcha with it, and it was a perfect combination. This place has a long waitlist, so I would recommend putting your name in and coming back after 45 mins to an hour
author: Amar P.

description:
Writing this review after a return visit and eating different things both times. 1st visit was pork ramen, and the ramen last night was the limited chicken one, which is chicken ramen (not limited) but w a side of chicken - leg and thigh on a hot stone (limited) for like not even that much more. 

The future Mrs. stuck w the same routine ordering the pork w corn, which costs more. We were supposed to trade half way through our own bowls.

There's no denying how good the ramen is when it's pointed out that I was more than 3/4 done and forgot to trade!

The experience the 2nd time around bc they use an app for their sign up list. We opted for a text notification telling us to come back to the restaurant.
author: Norman H.

description: Decent Hakata style ramen if you're near japantown! Came by for the 5pm reopening and had been put on a waiting list. It was very clear what to do once we got our text notification and we were told to wait again outside until the table was ready. Service was incredibly fast and the menu was simple between pork ramen, a limited chicken ramen (which I wish I could have tried), and others. Boyfriend had ordered a spicy tonkotsu and I had a tonkotsu dx. The broth for the spicy wasn't overwhelming at all, and the dx was alright. It's rich, but not too salty, but my main concern was that the braised pork made it a little too sweet for my liking. Our bowls came within 5 minutes of ordering, pretty quick. Price point is average. Give it a shot!
author: Krysta M.

description: Pretty much as good as ramen gets. The deluxe is the way to go, rich and perfectly seasoned broth, meat and veggies are cooked perfectly. Get on the wait list and wander around the mini mall because it's torture waiting to get seated while watching/smelling what you are missing. Happy slurping!
author: Al B.

description:
So good... But the wait is too damn long! I came here when it first opened and there was no wait. Nowadays, they quote at least 45 minutes waiting time (on a weekday no less!) 

The tonkotsu and paitan broth are both really good. Their egg is also always cooked to perfection. Would come here to try at least once but honestly the line makes this place a bit too overhyped now for me to come often.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Yet, another new ramen shop in JT! Located in the same Plaza as PikaPika, Sophie's crepe and the bookstore. 

RAMEN:
They offer 5 different ramen, tapas and small rice bowls. Their ramen are made with thin "egg noddle" style which I'm not the biggest fan of, but the broth and flavors almost makes up for it! 
+ Chicken Paitan DX $15: PROTEIN! I've only been to one other ramen shop that offers this on their menu. Typical ramen shops lacks protein, but this one comes with the gigantic chicken thigh+legs so it was a must get for me :D (being the salubrious protein lover I am). In addition to the chicken, there was also meat AND a whole egg in ramen. Flavor wise, brother was a tad too oily for my liking, but flavors were delicious nonetheless. 
+ HAKATA DX $15: main bae of this shop. Broth was very flavorful, pork was pretty tender and egg was nicely soft boiled but could have been flavored more. 
 
Tea is offered for free which is a bonus!

SERVICE: 
Friendly, mostly attentive and quick considering its full house w/ a waiting list. 

AMBIANCE: 
Absolutely love it! It stands out in the best way possible. Very classy, zen and high-class atmosphere. With its black textures walls and orange-gold accents and lit walls and (some) seats. It can almost pass for semi-formal attire only restaurant. The have about 3 booth seats that can sit up to 6-8 people in addition to regular tables. 

Verdict: A must try if you like more protein with your ramen without it being overly pricey. Even for someone who prefers thicker noodles, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here! Will be back to try their other ramen - that's if another ramen shop doesn't pop up in JT.
author: Samantha F.

description:
Came here for Saturday dinner. 30 more parties in the waiting queue before us, and we waited for about 30min to get seated.

We ordered:

Takoyaki 4/5
Fries squid leg 5/5 
Hakata dx 5/5
Chicken paitan 3/5
author: Yu S.

description:
My favorite ramen! The broth is very rich and creamy, the noodles are great. This is what i use as the standard for how ramen should taste. 

The only downside is that the bowls seem small, but maybe that is because I love their ramen so much I always want more! Sometimes I leave the restaurant with an extra order to take home for lunch the next day. 

I have only visited for lunch and their line can get long, but the turnover is pretty quick. I imagine that dinner starts out with a long line as well. 

Since the restaurant doesn't have their own bathrooms, patrons are directed to use the general restrooms in the mall, which are not great. But the restaurant itself probably doesn't have control over this aspect.
author: Tom K.

description: The Chicken ramen is incredible. I have to say this is my favorite ramen in bay area now!! The broth is creamy but not too greasy. Btw, their Karayagi is very goo too!! You'll enjoy in these food.
author: Yu-ya H.

description:
Love here!!
Great and yummy yummy food. 
Not expensive.
Small bowl  
Very nice stuffs 
Location is confusing because it's upstair and not on the map downstair.
author: Tirintorn C.

description:
SF Japantown gets (and earns) its rep for generally unimpressive food, but this unassuming ramen spot might deliver one of my favorite bowls of noodles in the city. 

I got to try both the Hakata DX and the Chicken Paitan DX, and both were seriously awesome. Both bowls had generous portions, delicious and flavorful broths (neither too thick nor too light), yummy toppings, and tender meats.
