Dinner was somehow my first meal of the day, but as I neared the end of my bowl, I was totally stuffed. I liked my Hakata DX just a little bit better (perhaps because I've had a chicken paitan ramen I prefer over Marufuku's in the city), but I'd actually probably get the normal hakata bowl next time as I didn't feel I needed the extra braised pork belly. 

One small blip was that my soft-boiled egg was somehow stuck at the bottom of my bowl, and by the time I got to it, it was totally hard-boiled. :( Nonetheless, I loved my ramen and would be super excited to come back.
author: Kelly R.

description: Fantastic ramen, some of the best I've had in SF. Wait can be long (upwards over an hour) and you have to reserve in person on their Yelp waiting list. We both ordered the Hakata DX and it was delicious. Flavorful broth and lots of meat. Noodles here on the slightly thinner side. Prices are reasonable, service is fast, and the interior is nice. Worth a visit!
author: Mikey J.

description:
There is a long line at 11:15am -- 15 minutes before they open. We're able to get seated first round. Phew! 

Ordered the following:
Takoyaki - yummy!! The best I've had in the US. 
Chicken karage - excellent... very tender and the dipping sauce, some kind of mayo, is right on. 
We had 3 ramen bowls - chicken Paitan and Hakata tonkatsu and Hakata DX. All have excellent flavors. The ramen are thin, which is not what I'm used to, but it's still very good. 

Saw some appetizer orders and they all look so yummy. I have to go back again to try them all.
author: mei c.

description:
I've only eaten hakata style ramen in Japan and at one of my favorite ramen places in San Diego, so I was excited to see it on a menu in SF! My friend and I both ordered the Hakata Tonkatsu as we prefer tonkatsu broth over chicken, and made one bowl spicy - Japanese spicy is honestly very mild though, and I actually enjoyed the original more because the pork flavor was so fragrant. The thin noodles were a nice chewy consistency, there were THREE pieces of tender pork belly, and the soft boiled egg was cooked perfectly and had so much flavor. I wish there had been slightly more toppings (bean sprouts and wood ear mushroom slices) but other than that it was a delicious bowl of ramen. 

When I first saw my friend's pictures of Marufuku, I was wary of the portion size because the bowl looked so small, but I guess you can fit more thin noodles into a bowl than regular noodles LOL. I was also impressed by how light and flavorful the broth was, though I think it could've been a little hotter when it was brought out. For $11 though, this is probably one of the best deals you can find in Japantown. 

Our server was very attentive, regularly checking up on us and refilling our waters as needed. It was pretty empty when we arrived for lunch at 1130, and though it filled up after us, customers didn't seem to wait very long for a table. I'm happy that I no longer have to travel to Richmond/Sunset for ramen, but even happier that I can finally satisfy my hakata style ramen cravings!
author: KC W.

description:
I've had a fair share of ramen from all over the bay and LA so I'm pretty biased and picky when it comes to ramen. Marafuku was good!! BUT it wasn't too memorable. No complaints, but it was good. I liked it. They are known for hakata style ramen, which is pork soup, not as fatty soup with thinner noodles. 

I got the Hakata and my boyfriend got the chicken special cause they only server 15 a day, but honestly go for the any other bowls. The chicken one is basically a skillet of a honey soy sauce chicken thigh and drumstick. Also, got the takoyaki. Warning, I got a medium and it was spicier than I expected cause you can't see the spice!

Good and quick service!! I came here 20 minutes before opening so I didn't not need to wait, but boy did the line get long. personally wouldn't wait a long time for this.

My heart still goes out to to Shin-sen-gumi in LA for Hakata Style Ramen. #1
author: Micaela I.

description: The broth and soft boiled egg. Oh, so creamy and delicious. Everything about the Hakata Tonkatsu was tasty but those two things make it for me at this ramen joint. I am pretty picky when it comes to ramen but this has to be in my top picks for ramen spots in SF. I have to say, I still prefer Iza Ramen but this is definitely a top contender and definitely recommend!
author: Christina C.

description:
Overall, a 3.5.

First, let me explain though, the ramen and broth is GOOD. Maybe even a 5, though I usually reserve that for Ippudo. 

Service is a 4. My first server was lovely: nice big smile, friendly, thoughtful, and explained the menu. My second server was not bad but didn't smile as much or box my meal- hence the 4 instead of 5. 

But what honestly killed it for me was the heat. No, not the spiciness of the ramen, but the fact that Marufuku's AC was broken (granted it's in the middle of winter here). So eating here is like eating in Dante's Inferno. Or for short, like hell. 

And you know what? Each time I passed this place and attempted to put my name down on the waitlist before, it was always too warm. So I don't think they'll be fixing their heat problem anytime soon if they haven't already for months.

But I did see 2 very smart girls who got ramen togo and ate right inside the mall on a bench - away from the inferno inside the restaurant, which kills your appetite and ability to enjoy the food since your eating ramen in like 90 degrees.

So I would say if you want a nice sit down ramen place, pass on Marafuku and go to Hinodeya across the block (unless it's Tuesday, which in that case Hinodeya is closed). 

Plus Hinodeya doesn't try to gyp you when it comes to how they calculate tips. It's perhaps a small thing for others, but I find it somewhat questionable of Marafuku to pre-calculate tip off of both the subtotal, tax, and SF health mandate. I've got no problem paying the tax and health mandate since I like our city to be funded and employees with health insurance. I'm all for it. But tip is given based quality of the food and service you received. Given food and customer service were things I received but I wasn't given health insurance from Marufuku, I find it unsettling that they inflate their pre-calculated tip amounts on the receipt with the heath mandate. Again Hinodeya - the reputable ramen place next door - doesn't do that, and the room temperature is fine there.

But if you're cool with togo ramen and to avoid getting gypped with inflated tipping, order togo here. For context, I've been to Hokkaido's ramen shop - the one graced by Anthony Bourdain's presence (+ photograph and autos graph), the first shop in Sapporo's Ramen Alley, and I will say the chicken/tori paitan broth here is indeed GOOD. So I wouldn't write off Marafuku's craftsman ship - just how they run their business.

P.S. just read my former classmate's review (who is a die hard foodie not to mention consecutive yelp elite for the past 4 Years) and I want to post an addendum: the soft boiled egg here is. Indeed. FABULOUS. Daresay perhaps the best I ever had with ramen. The consistency, softness , temperature is just right. (Problem is its so HOT in the restaurant, it's really hard to focus and enjoy the food when it's done right because you're burning up. O and I saw a couple of other patrons sitting by the door fanning themselves. So yes, I am upset - upset that I couldn't properly enjoy their fabulous ramen coz they couldn't fix their AC.)
author: Elena C.

description:
Outrageous wait. Use yelp to put your name in the wait list and avoid the physical line (you'll probably still have to wait though).

Ramen is tasty, price is decent. Their fried chicken (karaage?) was delicious. Certainly one of the best ramen places in the bay area. But not worth the hassle. Although it's on par with the bay area meta.
author: Kevin G.

description:
The food is yummy but do note that they only have either chicken or pork for ramen. There might've been a vegetarian but I don't remember. The flavor was pretty good, but I wouldn't say AMAZING. 

The service was decent. The only problem I have with the place is the wait. But luckily there's a cool Yelp thing where you can see where you are on the waitlist. But do give yourself plenty of time to eat there due to the wait.
author: L. C.

description: Yum yum yum. Definitely worth waiting in line 30 minutes before they open. We all had ramen, different spicy levels and the fried squid to start.
author: Heather L.

description: Like everyone else said, expect like a 1-2 hour wait. It is totally, totally worth it. Plus you can shop around the Japan Center while you wait. Best ramen I've had, hands down! Flavorful, worth the price. Costs about the same as other ramen places, and not that many options but that's fine. I got the Hakata Tonkotsu, their most popular one, medium spicy. It was the perfect balance of spice, not too much and not too bland or mild. I definitely recommend it if you've got some downtime! Tip: waitlist on Yelp first an hour before arrival so you don't have to wait once you're there -- your table will hopefully be ready for you by the time you get there.
author: YL L.

description: This place is pretty packed. Better come here 30 min before it open up at 5 pm. The line is pretty long. The price is pretty decent, we ordered the chicken Paitan dx, it came with a huge chicken leg and a bowl of ramen with chicken on top. We also ordered Hakata dx. The chicken paitan is good but the hakata is just okay. I will still go to the santouka ramen in terms of the broth and the pork.
author: L D.

description: Hands down one of the best ramen places I've had in the Bay. Because of the yelp reviews, my friends and I came to line up 45 minutes before they opened. It was worth it! Only 10 minutes after we got there, the line stretched all the way across the plaza and turned the corner. We were among the first wave that got seated having waited 45 mins. The ramen broth was so incredibly flavorful yet light. The pork belly was amazing and the soft boiled egg was cooked to perfection. Absolutely would recommend!
author: Jaime N.

description:
Very pleased! We came here on a Sunday night with quite a long line in front of us, but it went by fairly quickly. It's a small place, but people are in and out once they're done. 

We ordered:
- Hakata DX ($14.99) I loved the soup base! I ordered it in mild, and the flavor was perfectly blended with the spice. It's also a large portion - you get tons of noodles and toppings. The pork belly was also so tasty and tender!
- Hakata Tonkatsu ($10.99) It tasted similar to the DX, but definitely not as flavorful. 

Service was quick and attentive. 

Despite the price, I'd still recommend the DX over the Tonkatsu because it was more filled and rich in flavor.
author: Miranda T.

description: Favorite ramen spot in the bat area. Wait is ridiculous but worth it. Good that you can put your name in and check your spot in line through yelp
author: Eric T.

description:
What to eat for lunch on a chilly day? Ramen seemed like the perfect choice. A bunch of new ramen places have been popping up in the City and Marufuku recently got on my radar.

We had both of the deluxe ramen options - hakata (pork) and chicken paitan. I didn't read the menu closely and I just thought DX sounded good. The chicken paitan DX is enough for 2 people by itself - it came with a bowl of noodles and a quarter dark meat chicken. When I compared the broths, the pork version was much more flavorful than the chicken option. Unless you really love chicken, just choose the pork version.

The pork ramen was very good and the portion size was also relatively big. The noodles had a nice chewiness to them despite their thin shape. The egg was great, which is important to me. You can specify the level of spiciness you want with your noodles. I got "spicy" and like most Japanese places, that was equivalent to at most "mild" at a Thai restaurant.

I liked Marufuku but I think I might like Hinodeya a tad more.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Love this place. Closest to the noodle shop in Japan. Both pork and chicken broth were good. Don't care for the sizzling chicken drumstick, too salty. Save your stomach for the noodle and broth. 

The chicken karaage was pretty good too.
author: anita s.

description:
I've eaten here several times with my family.

One of the best ramens I've ever had.

I usually get the tonkatsu ramen. I once got the deluxe version but found that there wasn't really any difference (maybe the soup base was a little better). The ramen soup base itself is very rich and isn't too salty. I would recommend not getting any spiciness in it. I feel like it gets in the way of the rich broth. The pork belly is very tender and soft which makes it a delight to bite into. It has the perfect balance of sweetness and richness. Also, there are other things like corn, seedweed, etc. which give another great aspect of flavor 

Also, you should definitely order the extra noodles for $2.5 (used to be $2) which is a really good deal in my book. Since there is plenty of the soup base left, might as well spend a couple of bucks to consume basically another meal with rich flavor.

I've also gotten the chicken karaage and the fried octopus which was really good. I think they raised the price by a couple of dollars but definitely worth a try. It's a pretty simplistic batter but the quality of the chicken and octopus really shines in it's flavor. Also, they provide Japanese Mayo on the side which has the perfect unami/saltiness combo.

Overall, inside the restaurant, the environment is very beautiful. In the middle, there are two light up benches which are really pretty. On the outskirts, there are booths and tables. Regardless of where you sit, you'll enjoy the ample space and comfort.

In terms of service, I found the waiters and waitresses to be really busy most of the time which is understandable. So, you do have to make an extra effort to get more water, etc.

Overall, the price is very fair and comparable to other ramen places. But, the quality of the food, enviornmemt, and service puts Marafuku miles ahead of other ramen places.
author: Ethan C.

description:
This place is located upstairs, in the corner of the Japanese mini mall. Their turn around time for tables is pretty decent, even after the fact that they have mostly 4-6 top tables & only a few 2 tops.

Their menu is limited, which is nice because to me that means they specialize in these particular dishes. 

I came in during the Sakura Festival unknowingly & that was not the greatest idea due to minimal parking. But since I was already craving this place, I had to give it a go.

Orenchi & Ramen Dojo still conquer the ramen game in the Bay. So far I haven't found anything that tops it, but this is pretty good & decently priced.

I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu & added bamboo shoots. The noodles were a little thinner than what I'm used to, but that's okay. The broth was delicious, not too salty, not too oily. I loved that they sprinkled sesame seeds on the ramen & it was topped with shredded ginger. The soft boiled egg was on point too & that's always important for good ramen. The ramen was priced decently for the amount of food they gave you.

I'd come back again.
author: Janelli B.

description: I came here at 8:30 PM and I was surprised to find that there was still a decent line to get into the restaurant. We waited for about 25 minutes, and our server was attentive and served us quickly. Although the portions appeared small at first, the ramen was actually quite filling. I had the tonkatsu ramen and I was impressed. The noodles and the broth paired very well together and the broth was not too salty. I felt that the mild spicy level was not mild at all (I felt like they did add any spice to it), but that was easily corrected by me adding the chili to it that they provided tableside. I will be coming back again!
author: Lynn T.

description:
Don't understand the hype. Still nothing compared to Santouka in San Jose. Noodles weren't bouncy and the broth was spicy but not flavorful. You can get a richer broth and not wait forever at Ramen Yamada also in jtown.

Coolest part was how you enter your name in and can check your position in line with yelp. Some super dumb chick was holding up the line just standing there on her phone and then got indigent when asked if she could step to the side. 

TL;DR Definitely not worth the wait, better ramen to be had close by. Noodles were stiff with no bounce in a broth that was one note
author: Zaviera R.

description:
At 4.5 stars average it was an easy choice to stop in at Marufuku Ramen. We came towards the end of their lunch hours hoping to catch a break on the wait time but still had about a 20 minute sit. 
Service was good and friendly and the place looked nice inside.
Food was really tasty but I thought overpriced for what it was. Noodles were fresh and they give you a good sized portion. However a common complaint was there was too much ginger. Also the amount of meat whether it be chashu or the kukuni was sadly sparse. I've been to other places where you get much more at a few dollars less with just as much taste. I was shocked that I got a whole egg unlike the half egg slice I run into usually. Bravo. I ordered the medium spicy level broth and while I sweated up a storm it was tasty but I did need to flag the waitress down several times. She finally left a pitcher. 
I wished I had tried the Paitan chicken and secretly hoped my wife would get it but didn't. From what I can tell it would be worth it to come back to try that. A keeper.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Fairly new ramen spot in Japan town. I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen and Chicken Paitan DX. 

The Hakata Tonkotsu ramen was great. Broth was flavorful yet not too overpowering. Noodles were good too, though they stuck together a bit too strongly. Only wish the red ginger was served on the side instead of with the ramen. 

The Chicken Paitan DX was similarly as good and comes with a giant grilled chicken on the side. The chicken was superb, flavorful and juicy. I'd order this again just for the chicken alone. 

Overall, still not as delicious as Mensho or Ramen Dojo in San Mateo, but those incumbents are hard to beat. All in all, I'd come here again.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
This is VERY authentic Tokotsu ramen. I'm a Japanese, originated from Fukuoka, and just had a ramen in Hakata just two weeks ago. Marufuku Ramen is more than that! 

福岡出身。このラーメンは福岡で出てきても遜色なし。
author: M J.

description:
This place is 2 legit!!!

I had the chicken paitan (spicy), and it was delicious!   The noodles very perfectly cooked, the egg was boiled perfectly, the broth was delicious and the chicken was tender.

With so many amazing ramen spots in SF, this place is definitely somewhere at the top of the list.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: The best ramen I've ever had. I highly recommend getting here early because it fills up super fast. They were accommodating of my baby, too, which was really nice. The chicken DX ramen comes with a braised chicken leg on the side, and is well worth the extra few dollars. The pork DX has braised pork instead of simmered pork - also worth the extra 3 bucks!
author: Lauren B.

description:
When I went here, the first thing that stood out to me was the service. The waitresses are so attentive and friendly. If you want to eat here, you definitely would need to get here at least 30 minutes earlier before they open. The restaurant is kind of small which explains why the wait for it is pretty long if you don't get here early. But the place has such an earthy, Japanese traditional feel to it, which I thought was a pretty good accent. 

The Hakata DX Ramen I had was pretty stellar. But man what can I say? The broth had such a impactful burst of flavor, and the braised pork belly itself had SO SO much flavorful umami. Their Hakata DX Ramen bowls are $15.99 but it's definitely worth the price. The meat was so tender and flavorful that it worked in harmony if you ate it together with the soup. The richness of the broth really enhances the flavors of every component in the ramen, and the portion size is actually good enough to fill you up, despite how small the bowl may look!

I also ordered their chicken karaage and it was pretty good! The skin was lightly crispy, and the chicken was actually pretty big! Normally chicken karaage would be small bite sizes, but the chicken was a lot bigger than that! But I wouldn't say that it particularly stood out, but their yuzu mayo dip really complemented the karaage and it made it taste so much better. 

I would most definitely recommend this place because it is bomb.com! This is almost on par with Izakaya Sozai (another really good ramen place in SF) in my opinion.
author: Ricky K.

description:
Overall, I had a great experience here! I came in with a group of 6 people on Christmas Eve and the wait was about 45 min. 

Food:
Hakata style ramen- a type of a ramen that originates from the Hakata district of Fukuoka. The most distinguishing characteristics about this type of ramen is the thin, straight noodle and creamier broth. 

I chose the Tonkatsu DX - flavorful, creamy broth. The noodles were cooked with the perfect amount of bite to them. The star of the show was the braised pork, which they gave a generously thick portion of- it was so tender and full of umami! I found it funny that halfway through my meal, I noticed the half-boiled egg at the bottom of the bowl. Mary Poppins bowl of ramen!! Would definitely recommend!
 
My friends got the Chicken Paitan DX (apparently only 15 servings per day, they had 12 servings left around 1245p). It came with a sizzling plate of a chicken quarter on the side. The chicken skin and meat accompanied with the noodles and broth were to die for!

The takoyaki balls deserve an honorable mention as they were not too doughy or mushy. Super fun to eat and very tasty.

Having been to Fukuoka and being able to enjoy numerous bowls of Hakata style ramen, I'd say that this place is definitely a more elevated experience. I'd come back in a heartbeat!
author: Janet P.

description:
This is the best ramen I've ever had. EVER! I go here at least 2-3 times a month now. I get the Hakata DX (medium spice). The broth has a great flavor and the noodles are light and springy. The pork slices are also really juicy and delicious. 

Expect to wait a couple hours if there's around 50 parties ahead of you. Get there early and just peruse around Japantown till ur table is ready because it's definitely worth the wait. 

Once you're seated, 2 minutes later you are drowning yourself in a heavenly bowl of noodles. Super fast service. 
Food for the soul. Forever in love.
author: Paige R.

description:
This place is now good because you can get in the line via yelp. This means you can check in and take a shower and then stroll in for lunch instead of a brutal 1.5 hours wait.

Both the chicken and pork ramen was good. Also we really like the chicken karrage.
author: Clara Y.

description:
On a Friday night this place gets super busy! Arrived around 6:20PM and by the time I put my name on the waiting list I was 33rd in line. The wait took about an hour to receive a text notifying our party that we were almost ready to be seated and we sat down around 7:40PM. It's really convenient that their waiting list sends out text messages because even if the wait for a table is long you can pass time by going somewhere else instead of sitting/standing in front.

Once seated, we ordered 2 Hakata Tonkotsu ($11.99 each), the Karaage Bowl ($4.00), and a Calpico ($3.00). The ramen is so flavorful and filling; it comes with braised pork and the meat is so tender it melts in your mouth! And we ended up ordering the Karaage Bowl simply because of how cheap it was. It was tasty and comes in a small bowl with more rice than meat, but it's a nice side dish to order with your ramen if you're really hungry. Overall, definitely worth the long wait!
author: Nicole C.

description: Best Ramen in the Bay Area .But  be prepared to wait I waited about an hour.It was better than the other ramen I had in Japan.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Have been wanting to try this one out but never get a chance because the waiting line is ALWAYS CRAZY. Eventually I came with a group of 5 at a Saturday noon. The waiting line was still bad but we got in! Every of us order different things from the menu (both tonkatsu and chicken paitan) and all of them taste so good 

Pro:
- RAMEN WAS AWESOME!!!!!!! I swear every option of the ramen was very good
- nice environment/vibe
- service was good
- the bowls for ramen are so cute

Con:
- LONG WAIT (the only reason for taking off one star)


Want to come back again if the line is not that busy (but it never happens lol)
author: Sunny L.

description:
This restaurant is doing everything right. 

Get there early because it's a big hit! I got there 20 minutes before opening and the line was already across the hall ('twas Sunday at 4:40). We didn't make it in but only waited like 30 minutes. Once seated, we ordered super quick. The servers are all sweet hearts. Once we ordered, the food came within 3 minutes. The chicken karaage was at the table in two minutes and the ramen like one minute after! I got "spicy" spicy level and it was the perfect amount of spicy where my nose began to run after 3/4 of the meal and it left my lips tingling! I will say the mild and spicy difference is intense in color but don't be intimidated! I got the $11.99 tonkotsu. The chashu is sweeter than most but it's delicious! The noodles are skinny, but the perfect softness. The soup isn't super thick and creamy like Mensho downtown, but I like this better and it's cheaper! This ramen joint is in my top two favorite ramen places in SF!
author: Caitlyn S.

description: One of the best bowls of Ramen I've ever had in my life. The noodles were perfect firmness, the broth was incredible, full of flavor and just the right spice! The egg was choooo oishi ! and the meat, oh man, super tender, enough that it held all the flavors and every bite was like a little bit of heaven ! The service was great, the background music was relaxing, and the design of the restaurant was modern and very Japanese and I loved ever second. You WANT to eat here. I'm a picky hard to please person and I loved it. 5 stars for this place and they should actually get 10 stars if it were possible! Itadakimasu !
author: Scrapp H.

description: I was craving for a good ramen and so a friend recommended this place. She said to try out their Chicken Paitan and that's what I did. Honestly, I didn't have much expectations so I didn't take any photos before indulging which I regretted (now I have an excuse to come back here :D) as the dish is so tasty. I understand now why people doesn't mind the long queues just to eat at this place.
author: Kelly J.

description: Good stuff.  Deceiving deep bowl.  Long lines, go early.  Broth so exquisite, waitress asked if I wanted a to go container to take with me!!  On the fatty side, so maybe eat light during the day.
author: Padme J.

description:
The place is located in the corner where Sapporo-Ya used to be across from Kinokuniya bookstore. We stalked the place 30 minutes before opening. Nobody in sight. T minus 15 minutes and people started hovering around.  A line formed 3 minutes before opening. If you arrive 10 minutes before on a weekday, you should be golden. The restaurant filled to capacity within a few minutes.  When we left, there was a line.

Ordered the chicken karrage. The chicken arrived hot and crispy. The meat was tender and juicy. Pretty good.

I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu DX. My companion ordered the Chicken Paitan DX. Each ramen bowl includes green onions, kikurage mushroom and bean sprouts. 

The Hakata Tonkotsu DX upgrade gives you braised pork belly and corn.  The Hakata style noodles are thinner and were not optimal for me but were not deal breakers either. They are freshly made. The pork broth was rich and delicious. The braised pork had a sweet flavor. The meat was not tofu soft but was tender enough. Had the right amount of fat. I enjoyed it. The soft boiled egg was nicely done and submerged in the broth. You could miss it. The bowl is not wide but it is deep. Some of your toppings will sink.

The Chicken Paitan DX upgrade provides you with corn and grilled chicken on the side. The chicken arrived sizzling and was delicious and tender.  Chicken broth was lighter than the pork. Slightly saltier. You will get more protein for your dollar with the Chicken Paitan DX but there's only a 15 servings limit for this dish.  Augment with chicken karrage. 

If you want the leanest meal, then the chicken ramen is your ticket.  But if you are not worried about a little fat for more flavor enjoyment; pork is the way to go. They have a scale for how much spice you want in your ramen. Mild spice is the lowest on the hotness scale and it is barely noticeable.  Medium spicy is probably the way to go for some heat without decimating your tongue. If you like drinking molten lava, then go ultra spicy. 

The remodeled Japanese interior is hip and modern. Nice space to eat and be seen.

Service was friendly and very efficient. They need to maximize their margins by increasing table turnover with the waiting horde outside.

This place is very convenient to go to being in Japantown. Prices have gone up to $15.99 for the DX bowls. I just chalk it up to everything costs more in SF.  There are no godly ramen places in SF and a lot of mediocre ones. Is the high rent cost prohibitive? No idea. This one is approaching godhood. Call it demigod.

If you are in SF, this is a must try. Wintertime should enhance the experience.
author: Jaqen H.

description:
Food is pretty good. I like the variety of dishes like the salad and sides of slow cooked pork. The grilled chicken leg is good. Everything is GOOD. 

But not worth the wait time for GOOD food. 

If they seat you in the center, you'll have to climb over a fixed bench that surrounds the tables in the area. Neat decor, but not comfortable to get in or sit in. 

Don't want to give it a bad review as the food and service is pretty good. The long wait and seating conditions ruin the experience though.

Worth a try ONCE if ramen is your thing.
author: Johnny D.

description:
Ramen is getting so real in SF. You can't get away with soft-boiled eggs, pork belly, and tonkotsu--it'd better be tori paitan or *top-notch* tonkotsu, boast a unique signature ramen style, and arrive presented in a beautiful ceramic bowl that looks like it could have been in a museum collection. Oh, and there must be at least a 15-minute wait and, of course, no less than 4 stars on Yelp.

Despite these skyrocketing standards, Marufuku exceeded my expectations. I actually like it more than Hinodeya, another newly opened bouge ramen shop nearby specializing in dashi broth; however, Hinodeya seems a tad bit more pretentious, the prices are higher, and the quantities are smaller. 

Marufuku has a rather basic menu with starters, small rice bowls, and two main types of ramen: the tonkotsu and the paitan, both available regular for $15 or DX for $11. While the tonkotsu DX comes with braised pork belly (vs simmered for the regular), the paitan DX features a whopping plate of grilled chicken on the side. The bowls are whimsically asymmetrical and although it looks a bit small, it is filled with a decent portion of noodles and makes satisfying meal. 

The CHICKEN PAITAN was outstanding. If you squint,, you can almost detect what tastes like ginseng. It seems to combine the techniques of Chinese chicken soup with tori paitan for a grainy texture, robust chicken flavors, and an aromatic complex finish. The chicken chashu was unique as well, tender like pork chashu but with a umami, brined taste.

The HAKATA TONKOTSU was excellent as well, with a tonkotsu broth on point and not too salty. The simmered pork belly was melty and delicious, a bit roasty and with its share of fat almost reminiscent of porchetta :3 

As indicated by the hakata style labeling, the noodles are the thin white kind, rather than the springy curly yellow ones. The plain noodles do accentuate the rich broths but al dente die-hards may not be fans of the different ramen style.

Complimentary toppings were standard, though as several reviewers have pointed out the egg is serious business. It's on the runnier side that is more liquid than semi-solid soft-boiled eggs, so be sure to eat it off the spoon.

The interior is bright, i.e. good lighting to take pictures of your photogenic ramen!) The decor is a mix of traditional Japanese (with tatamis) and modern (the edison bulbs are like a subliminal sign of hipster subculture).

Tips:
*You can choose no spicy, mild, spicy, and ultra spicy. I chose spicy and it turned out moderately spicy. (The paitan is already a bit spicy from the ginger)
*There's a sign-in list and usually a group of people waiting outside, but the 
*One order of the regular ramen per person is good if you want to save space for dessert in Japantown afterwards P:
author: Edna C.

description:
So far my absolute favorite favorite favorite... can you keep saying favorite? ramen places ever!  The bowls are such a cute size which doesn't leave me overstuff like other ramen places.

The restaurant is small with minimal seating so the wait can be pretty long.  The service was very good. They were very attentive and our orders came in with the right timing.

My favorite is the flavoring of the broth.  I'm more a chicken fan so I did get chicken and it was so incredibly rich with flavor.  The ramen noodle had a good bite.
author: Michelle T.

description:
It was an amazing ramen. 
I was with my family and we all enjoyed. 
The only bad thing is the waiting list, but with the new Yelp app, you can know exactly you position in the waiting list. While you wait, you can walk around the beautiful Japanese mall.
We ordered 3 different ramen, our favorite was the hataka tonkotsu DX spicy!!! Looks at the pic!! The size is perfect
author: Maria Alejandra B.

description:
Friday night, we waited an hour to get in. It was totally worth it.
This is, hands down, the best ramen broth I've ever had, and the soft-boiled egg and the chashu pork were just perfect.
Any time we're in town we'll have to come back.
author: Alberto L.

description:
This place is hands down my favorite and now go to spot for ramen in san francisco. Its in the japantown center mall and relatively small in size but the ramen they make is worth it. Word to the wise, like most popular places in the city, if you come during busy times like the weekend or dinner time expect a wait. The best time to come is during the week around the afternoon. FYI if there is a wait up front, go to the door and put your name on their seating list, it can be hidden if there is a big crowd of people in front but if there is a line just go right to the door and put your name down. They are pretty good at turning over tables so long as people don't linger. Understand that traditionally when you go to a ramen shop, you order, eat, pay and leave, thats it. Save the talking for after your meal else where, This is something I think a lot of folks in the states don't understand which adds to stupid long wait times. 
On my visit got the takoyaki and chicken karrage. The takoyaki was average nothing special. The chicken on the other hand was well cooked, crispy on the outside and tender and juicy on the inside. For my ramen I got the Hakata DX ramen, pretty much this is their pork/tonkotsu ramen with everything in it and man it is sooo damn good. First off the broth is so rich and fatty and flavorful, you can taste the pork in it instead of just salt like some places. The condiments were all pretty standard corn, mushrooms, green onion, bean sprouts, and a piece of nori. The soft boiled egg here was excellent, actually cooked perfectly with the yolk still runny, I know its not much to most people but I've found that a lot of other ramen places can't get this right and its the attention to detail which makes me like this place even more. The ramen I got came with the braised and simmered pork and wow was it amazing. The pork just falls apart and has a rich meaty flavor. Not over seasoned or dry it really elevates the ramen with the broth. I got the ramen in the mild flavor and you do have the option of adding spice/heat to you ramen when you order, my friend got their ramen with added heat and thought it was good. 
This is now my go to spot for tonkotsu/pork ramen in the city and I definitely think its worth a try if you like ramen as much as I do.
author: Peter P.

description:
I'm always excited when a new ramen place opens up, I like seeing how new ones compare to the ones I like. This one was ok, nothing special but not terrible.

I got the chicken paitan ramen, the broth didn't have much depth or flavor compared to hinodeya. The chicken chasu was overcooked and dry. The bowl is deceivingly deep, it holds quite a lot of noodles, which is good if you have a big appetite. I did like the soft boiled egg, it was perfectly runny for mine but for my bf bowl it was cooked solid. So there are inconsistencies but that's going to happen with any new place. 

This place is ok and it did fill up pretty quickly after opening. If hinodeya is closed, I would come here but I still prefer hinodeya to this place.
author: Stella J.

description:
Absolutely Lit Ramen! Also Loved using the Digital waitlist feature on yelp as we showed up 10 minutes before we were supposed to and sat down right in our quoted window! 

Ramen itself was amazing as seems to be the consensus on here, and my personal highlight was that they gave me a whole egg. Most of the ramen places I go to only give you half of an egg. It was awesome! 

If you like amazing Ramen, plus some fun window shopping, hit up Marufuku!!!
author: Luke A.

description:
The bowl is full. This tonkatsu ramen has really great flavor, the broth is creamy, the pork is fatty and the egg is runny.  The service is really fast and all the workers are nice.
When I first got the bowl I was a little shaken, it didn't look like much and I thought I was on my way to disappointment. Fortunately this place is on top of things. The ramen was not soft, actually it was perfectly chewy and continued to soften and take on flavor as the bowl sat. The egg was perfectly flavored and had the right viscosity. 
I had to wait 20 minutes for a table and it was totally worth it. 
I can't wait to go back.
author: Ben M.

description:
Popular ramen joint in the Japantown mall in a spot that I swear was a different ramen joint in the past.  Pretty limited menu, but you come here for ramen, so what else do you need?  Not the best tonkotsu ramen I ever had, but pretty solid compared to its San Francisco peers.

Hakata Tonkotsu DX (Ultra Spicy): My benchmark for tonkotsu is the dreamy white broth at Ippudo NY.  I've yet to find anything comparable in San Francisco, but their tonkotsu was still tasty.  Cloudy and fatty and rich, it was definitely a nice pairing to that draft beer.  I really liked the thick braised pork belly.  It was packed with marinated flavor and had super tender meat.  The egg was pretty cool too, a whole egg that's soft boiled and oozing with yolk when you bite into it.  Noodles were decent, chewy and fresh.  The ultra spicy wasn't that spicy; I feel like Nongshim is spicier.
author: Adam B.

description:
We got there at about 11:20am (they open at 11:30am), and they had stanchions set up in front of their small place. Before we knew it, there was a massive line behind us, and there IS a reason why! 

We ordered a couple small rice bowls to try and their Chicken Paitan DX which is their Chicken Paitan Ramen served with a side of grilled chicken. And hello... that ramen was just the best thing I've eaten in a while. The paitan broth flavor was just sooooo effing good that I can't even articulate the deliciousness! I also want to mention that along with the ramen noodles, it had ALL my fave toppings: lots of green onion, corn, and a boiled egg. The grilled chicken was served on a sizzling platter and had this sweet tangy delectable glaze that made me want to keep stuffing my face (we were getting pretty full sharing the ramen and  2 small rice bowls which we ended up taking to go). The prices are super reasonable for the quality of the food and attentive service - we'll definitely be making our way back soon!
author: Joanne F.

description:
Came 15 minutes early to be the first party in line. Soon, many started filing behind us - either because they heard about Marufuku and came intentionally and/or they saw this forming line and figured they should just line up (no joke).

Once they opened the doors they promptly seated us first. They proceeded to fill up the entire restaurant to capacity. There was still a small line remaining outside the door. Then i watched as the tables next to us received water, their appetizers and ramen before us. We flagged them down majority of the time, twice having to ask where our order was. They were very apologetic. Our food came staggered still. The Chicken Kaarage went room temperature while we waited for plates and more water.

The ramen was very good though. I was happy to have some hakata style ramen. The deluxe is worth the extra money. The Chicken Paitan broth here was delicious and my favorite over Mensho and Hinodeya. The Deluxe included a sizzling side of chicken leg in a sweet teriyaki like sauce. Egg was wonderfully soft boiled. The bowls looked deceivingly small. I could not eat another bite at the end!

They're new and they have service kinks to work through. Their quick shot to fame as a hot new ramen spot in SF has forced them to deal with customers like myself. I left unhappy with the experience but did enjoy the ramen.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Was really feeling this spot. Similar style broth to Orenchi in San Jose which is my favorite. I'd suggest getig at least a little spice Even if you're not a fan of spicy as it balances out the broth which is a little sweet on its own. The egg was bomb! See pics. 

The wait can be long (like a lot of ramens spots these days) but don't worry there are Lots of spots near by to grab a beer/drink while you wait for your table. 

Maybe the only negative thing to say is skip the karage and just grab a beer. 

Then hit the karaoke bar after for more beers and saki
author: Justin M.

description: Great ramen. Extremely affordable. Book on Yelp before even showing up to skip the (very) long line in front.
author: Clémentine C.

description: Loved the fact I could reserve a table through yelp! The ramen was good I ordered the mild miso ramen but it was extremely spicy but still delicious
author: Christen Y.

description: This ramen place was so hard to find; it says it's located in the Japan town mall but me and my friends spent almost 40 minutes walking around looking for it. It's located across a bookstore for those who encounter the same problem. In addition, the wait time was super long and it was already past rush hour for lunch. I think we ended up waiting about 1.5 hours. Despite this, once we got our table, the food came out really fast and we were satisfied within seconds. The bowl may appear small at first but it's actually really deep so it ends up being A LOT. The flavor of the broth is really amazing too, not like those bland ones. Anyway, I wouldn't say this place is worth that long to wait but I would come back if the wait time was shorter and I was near by! I also had enough to take home which was nice too. Service is good too.
author: Katherine C.

description:
If you like thin noodles, then you should come try Marufuku. 

I came for dinner because I absolutely LOVE japanese and checking out new spots. I actually had Hinodeya (also a new ramen place in Japantown) a few weeks ago, and prefer Hinodeya to Marufuku. But everyone who loves ramen should go to both and decide. They're unique in their own ways (Hinodeya is thick noodles w/ dashi (clear) broth, and Marafuku is thin noodles with rich, creamy broth). 

The menu was small, which I appreciated. However, we didn't really get to choose the ramen because there were only two types of ramen options left for the evening - chicken (Paitan) and pork (Hakata) - we ordered both. What I loved about the ramen was not the noodles or soup base, rather the corn, mushrooms, soft boiled egg, nori, green onions, and bean sprouts. You also personalize how spicey you'd want your soup. I picked medium spicey and that wasn't spicey at all. 

Paitan (chicken) DX came with a HUGE piece of grilled chicken leg on the side. It was super sized and flavorful (tho too sweet for my taste). The ramen itself came with thin noodles that were overly cooked (they were soft, and usually I like my ramen noodles hard so they can finish cooking in the broth as I eat). The broth was rich, but too rich for me, and a bit too salty. I did enjoy the first few bites, but soon enough the noodles were too soft and soup was too salty so I couldn't finish. 

Hakata DX  came with a fat piece and three slices of pork belly, which was fat, sweet and tender. The ramen noodles were also too soft for me, and soup base was rich & salty. I guess the upside to a salty soup base = more water for me. 

Overall, I enjoyed the first few bites to everything we ordered, but found myself wanting to eat less and less with each bite because it was too rich (soup base), too salty (soup base), or too fatty (pork). Price is fair (~$11 for a regular bowl of ramen, $15 for a deluxe bowl of ramen), there is also the SF health mandate tax.
author: Dana Z.

description:
The boyfriend and I ate here this past weekend, on a Sunday, for dinner. It wasn't too crowded and we were seated almost immediately.

We were given the menu, which seems to be a temporary one. The menu is currently limited. 

We tried ordering some takoyaki as an appetizer, but was informed that they had run out along with other appetizers. Shouldn't they be ready for the dinner crowd? 

We ordered our ramen. We both got the tonkatsu ramen. My bf ordered chashu on the side because it doesn't already come with the ramen. We both got mild, and honestly, there's not much spice in it all. Just a hint. 

It would've been nice if the waitress explained the menu at all seeing that they're a new ramen place. I wasn't aware that it was hakata style until I read the reviews later...I guess that's sort of my fault too. But I shouldn't have to depend on yelp to get me through the menu. They need to clearly state somewhere that you can customize your ramen just as Shinsengumi does. 

Overall, the ramen was great. Loved the broth and the thinner, harder noodle. Definitely worth a try.
author: Trina V.

description: Went on a Saturday around 1pm. Waited about 45-55 mins for 2 people. I like how you put your name on an iPad and they keep you updated through Yelp on how many people are ahead of you, very convenient. We started with the Marufuku bits, tasty meat on a steamed bun. Also had the Tonkotsu ramen and the Deluxe version. The difference is the DX has: seaweed, corn, and braised pork instead of simmered pork. I personally like the taste of the simmered pork better. The broth was tasty, we asked for spicy but it wasn't really spicy. If you like it hotter I'd recommend the ultra spicy. I'd give this place a B+ for atmosphere and B+ for tastiness of food.
author: Nelson M.

description: I used to go there for lunch a few times a week. Then the line got out of control. I stopped going because I couldn't justify waiting over 30 minutes for ramem.
author: Ken Y.

description: GREAT little lunch spot -- bustling atmosphere...really good broth!
author: Emily P.

description: The ramen here was pretty good. I should have gotten a spicier level but it was creamy and delicious. Decent amount of ramen, pork was fatty and melted in your mouth. Wait was at least an hour so if you're starving, probably go somewhere else. It was overall a good experience
author: Sam L.

description:
All I have to say is.

What a Marafukin great Ramen spot. Holy moly this place is good, makes me feel like the real Hatori Hanzo of all Japanese ramens
author: Jillian M.

description:
Long wait. Limited menu. Delicious ramen. Worth it. The staff kind of rush you, but it's understandable considering how many people are waiting and how small the place is. 

The Yelp app to keep your place in line works well. You can wander around the mall and shop and anticipate when you need to mosey back.
author: James L.

description: Best ramen in SF, hands down. The problem is that the wait is way too long because they do not accept reservation. Technically speaking, you could put your name on the waitlist through Yelp, but often the waitlist is full.
author: Tom L.

description:
It's been a while since I've had such good ramen.  So good I came back a week later.

They offer two types of ramen, Hakata tonkotsu and Chicken paitan.  For an additional $4 you can order a deluxe size that comes with a few extra ingredients.  I've tried both styles, and I prefer the paitan broth more.  While the tonkotsu broth was rich and flavorful, the paitan broth was a bit sweeter and lighter.  The noodles and meat were perfect, and just the right amount to be filling.
author: Karen L.

description: This place was hard to find! It's in the upper level of the mall (the one with no Daiso and majority of the food courts) and across a bookstore. It's a small place so be prepared to wait cause there will be a line. Other than that, super quick service and the food comes out fast. The broth was so rich and fatty and even though it doesn't look like a lot of ramen it will definitely fill you up. I got the HAKATA DX
author: Katherine D.

description: Best Ramen in San Fran! This is the Chicken Paitain (not sure if I spelled that correctly). The broth is tasty and slightly creamy. I added a topping of sweet corn. The ramen noodles are delicious! Be prepared to wait or use the Yelp check in to the wait list which works fabulously! Located in the Japan Center tucked away in a corner, just look for the line!  If you want to experience the REAL thing take the time to visit this restaurant!
author: Sherri B.

description: The ramen here changed our lives. Not only is their 20+ hour broth one of the best culinary creations on this side of the planet, the pork belly literally melted in my mouth. That's how tender it was. If there was ever a food from the gods that have been granted to us humans, it's this ramen. The concept of getting it is brilliant too - put your name on a checklist and wait til they call you. If the lines outside and people dwelling until their name gets called is any indication of how good this ramen is, you're in for a treat.
author: RJ S.

description:
Hakuna matata the hakata tonkotsu hype is reaI.

I don't know my ramens but I know what I like and I like good broth (not too creamy or strong). Here at Marufuku you get a flavorful pork broth (tastes like actual pork and isn't extra creamy) with thin noodles whose hardness you can control. You can also control the spiciness level and add on toppings for a few extra bucks (no substitutes though). 

My OG hakata tonkotsu came with few small slices of chashu (the pork wasn't dry or tough for once), bean sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds, green onions, and mushroom. Everything tasted incredibly fresh so I really enjoyed it. 

The best part was forgetting that the ramen came with an egg and discovering it halfway through the meal and then biting into the egg to discover that its insides were still runny--a true ajitama. Surprises on surprises.

I finished everything (to the last sip) and I usually don't because these broths can get too heavy but this one was so good and so pork. 

My only complaint would be that the service was hella slow (we went at 8 pm and the place was only ~80% full) and a group of 3 who came after us got their food and almost finished by the time our group of 4 received our dishes ( I guess they try to serve everyone's food at the same time).
author: Lydia Z.

description:
This is the best ramen place I've been to, hands down. The online waitlist is also super convenient since you can put your name down ahead of time. We did have to wait about 20 minutes after the time it said to arrive by though. The place is usually pretty busy for dinner, but the ramen is definitely worth the wait. 

I got the tonkotsu deluxe ramen, and it was perfect. The broth is so flavorful and rich, and since I got medium spiciness it was the perfect level of heat for me. The noodles are thin but firm, and they have a great texture. I also loved how the egg was perfectly soft boiled, and the yolk was still runny. The braised meat that came with the deluxe was tasty, but honestly I preferred the meat that comes with the regular tonkotsu. Both meats are very tender, and the fat just melts in your mouth.

If you're in the area, make sure you try this place for some seriously high quality ramen!
author: Arman A.

description:
The first time I tried coming here was at dinner time on a Saturday. Huge mistake. The line was ridiculous and didn't want to wait that long. Decided to come here on a weekday right when they opened. Even then the there people lined up but thankfully I was able to get in the first seating! 

So the menu is limited to a few dishes which I like. Don't over complicate things and keep it simple. I ordered the Hakata DX ramen. The flavors come pretty close to some of the better ramen shops I've been to in Sapporo and Osaka. It's also by far better than anything g around SF at the moment. Yes better than Ipuddo. Btw Ipuddo is overrated. 

The broth has excellent flavors that are complex and rich but soothing to the palette. The braised pork melts in your mouth and and the noodles had great texture. I highly recommend to order extra pork if you're into that. You won't be disappointed. 

Service is good and quick but they don't pressure you to leave when you're done which is cool. Cant wait to come back and try their other ramen offerings.
author: Andrew S.

description: They make you sit with randos when you're solo. Waited an hour and a half assuming there was bar seating or some sort of non-awkward communal seating :( Went to Iza instead.
author: Nathan B.

description: Came from Sacramento to try this place. Did not disappoint. Best ramen I've had on the West Coast
author: Raleigh C.

description:
Marufuku Ramen is a spiffy new ramen joint that opened at Sapporo-Ya's former space.  I've actually never been to Sapporo-Ya, but it looks like they've totally remodeled the space for the better.  The decor is bright and cozy much similar to Hinodeya across the street.

The menu that they had when I went there said 'temporary' (http://bit.ly/2mj2FbJ), so I'm going to assume they're still in soft opening mode and that it might be tweaked here and there after it's initial phase.  I'm glad to see that they specialize in Hakata style ramen which I haven't had since Kagura in San Mateo had closed down.

Although I had a hard time deciding between their Hakata or Paitan ramen, ultimately I was in the mood for their Hakata ramen with their braised pork belly.  And also I ordered their gyoza to start.

Hakata DX -- http://bit.ly/2miZjoZ
Hakata style ramen, pork broth, braised pork belly, kikurage mushrooms, soft boiled egg, corn, green onion, nori, bean sprouts
I wouldn't say it's better than Kagura's Hakata style ramen, but it's pretty good nonetheless.  The noodles were thin, the broth was rich, and the soft boiled egg was nice and runny.  What got my attention the most though was their pork belly.  It was a huge tender brick of pork goodness!  I would definitely order this again.

Gyoza -- http://bit.ly/2mj0JzZ
Standard gyoza here.  I would've liked it to have been a little more fried up to give it a crispy texture, but it was still good.

While the food was good, service needs some work.  The place wasn't too busy when I was there and when I arrived, the customers that were there were already eating.  So I knew that my order would arrive right away.  My gyoza arrived first with no issues.  

Another customer came in and sat at the table next to me and then placed his order.  Then as I could see my Hakata DX bowl coming out from the kitchen, the server gave it to customer sitting beside me.  From what I overheard, he ordered a Hakata regular bowl spicy.  So when he was eating it, he asked the server if his ramen was spicy and then server looked confused.  I told him that I think they served him my Hakata DX bowl.  Then he went back to the kitchen and served me the Hakata regular bowl spicy that the other customer had ordered.  Huh?! So another server came by and told him he mixed up our orders.  

I'll give him a pass because they just opened, but it does scratch my head how the server would mess that up.  So they gave customer next to me his bowl that was served to me while I had to wait a little bit longer for another Hakata DX bowl, which came out pretty quickly, so kudos to them for the comeback.  What did bother me a little bit was how the customer next to me was apologized to and was checked on a lot.  While for me it seemed like I was being ignored since they gave me my correct bowl.  Not once did any server come back to check on me.  So that rubbed off on me the wrong way.

Overall, the ramen at Marufuku was good enough for me to warrant another visit.  I do want to try their Paitan ramen and other appetizers.  I just hope that service has been improved by then.
author: Rodney H.

description: Came here for my birthday dinner and it was soooooooo good. Made the mistake of over ordering so just keep in mind that the portions are great for sharing! Be sure to order any of the ramens
author: Livè S.

description:
This place is the bomb diggity and I wouldn't have ramen anywhere else besides Japan itself.

Which I did.

But this is the best in the Bay Area. Don't listen to anyone else, period. Not even my brother. Thanks bro!
author: Kevin F.

description: San Francisco has terrible ramen, this is just a fact. Growing up the ramen was terrible and only recently had the ramen been passable. This is not true of Marufuku ramen... this place is amazing! The broth is so rich and think... you can see little pockets of fat... which sounds gross but is so amazing. The noodle are different than what must people may be used to but great nevertheless. The meat is always soft and the egg is perfect. There is usually a long line but it moves very quickly. I would definitely recommend ramen here! Service is great also!
author: Jocelyn K.

description: By far the tastiest ramen in SF I've tried. Like, everything is cooked so perfectly. The broth is rich and packed with flavors, just heavenly. Love that they have raw garlic and garlic press at each table. Usually super busy on weekends. Come during the week to avoid the crowd.
author: Nana L.

description:
On the top floor of Japantown Mall, there is a new ramen shop that opened relatively recently that always seem to have a line outside. One Saturday evening, when my curiosity has gotten the better of me, I placed my name on the sign-in sheet and walked around the mall for twenty minutes. I got back just in time to hear my name being called. I was promptly seated and when I look at the menu, there are five levels of spiciness for the ramen. After much deliberation between the Chicken Paitan and the Hakata Tonkotsu, I chose the Chicken Paitan, with a level of ultra-spicy to go with it naturally. 

When my dish arrived, I sampled the broth and remember that it's not really spicy, in my opinion maybe it's just a slight notch above sriracha in terms of spiciness. However, they heaped a generous helping of kikurage mushrooms and a big slab of chicken on top of my ramen. The chicken went very well with the broth, and I think they couldn't have made the broth any spicier since it might overpower the chicken's natural flavor. Overall, it was a great meal, since I finished the broth and remember feeling satisfied.  

With the ramen priced at $11, I think that this place has a strong offering for ramen enthusiasts at a very good price point since most ramen places charge anywhere from $10-15 for their ramen in SF. I left the meal wondering if I should have shelled out an extra four dollars for the Chicken Paitan DX instead (it comes with a big slab of grilled chicken leg as a side in addition to the Chicken Paitan ramen). I placed that thought aside, knowing that there's always next time.
author: Nelson X.

description:
I love this ramen shop. It was a great balance of traditional and modernity. The check-in waitlist was one of the most innovative things that I have seen at any restaurant. They would then text you and let you know when to come back. They also have integration to let you see your place in line.

Once seated, the ordering went smoothly and the food was prepared quickly. My order of Takoyaki and chicken Karaage were exquisite. My order of Hakata DX was amazing and I loved that I did not have to pay extra to make it extra spicy.

Other ramen restaurants needs to learn from Marufuku.
author: Disaster P.

description:
I would have to say that I enjoyed eating at Marufuku Ramen. I ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen (not spicy). The ramen comes in a rich pork broth with simmered pork belly, soft boiled egg, green onions, kikiurage mushrooms and bean sprouts. The only item I added was the sweet corn. I really enjoyed the broth and simmered pork belly. Both were full of flavor and very tasty. One thing that my friends and I noticed was that they give you a whole soft boiled egg, when most places only give you half. Extra points for that one! The thing that differentiates this place from others is the noodles. The style of noodles is different than your typical ramen shop. These were a lot thinner. I'm not sure if they were my favorite, but I enjoyed them. We also ordered the chicken karage rice bowl, which was just okay. Nothing too special but not bad! 

This ramen shop was very good and I would return again if I'm in Japan Town!
author: Ariana T.

description: There was already a line 30 minutes before it even opened. By the time it opened we were on the waitlist for 2 people. We waited 45 minutes after they opened. It was our first time here and it was definitely worth the wait. I like how they text you when your table is about ready so you can shop around. The food was great. Tasted very good. There are many good ramen spots in San Francisco, but this place is near the top of the charts.
author: Alexis Y.

description:
Their ramen is sooo good everything from the firmness of noodles to chasu, broth, takoyakis, everything!! The only thing on the menu I didnt like was the pork buns. The bun is soaked in sauce and the pork is like shredded pork.. very dry.. I wouldn't recommend this dish.

I'm giving them 4 stars because the host should really speak up when there is a group of loud people waiting outside the entrance! When host was calling my name for seating, I couldn't hear her the first time and she just removed me from the list until I found out I was skipped (not intentionally) and complained. I waited 2 hours for seating. The host saw my name and gave me the seat but she gave me an attitude. It was not appreciated.
author: Kathy D.

description: Bf and I braved this line. It wasnt too bad considering we came before they opened and waited about 30-45 minutes. The restaurant itself looks trendy and hip. Now the ramen? To die for!! They have this amazing braised pork belly in the hakata dx ramen. The broth was rich and flavorful without being overbearing. The only down side is that they didnt have a vegetarian option so he ended up getting a chicken broth ramen sans chicken. I ate the chicken of course. So delicious and definitely worth the wait!!
author: Linda P.

description:
Always a fan of good Ramen, but man the wait is long!

Got the Hakata Tonkotsu with extra pork! It was so filling! Broth was savory and noodles al dente.

After trying so many Ramen places around the country, this place is top 3!
author: Kassie L.

description:
GOOD costumer service.
Thank you for nice dinner. Really appreciate them for they was pack my food to go.
author: Mario G.

description: Life changing. Waiting in that GD line not so much. On a fluke we went in when there was no line but every time after that, there's a line like we are waiting to go see Betty White shoot out ping pong balls no hands!  I gave it a 4 because the line sucks and they don't take reservations. The ramen will literally make you slap yo momma. The second time we went, I was with my best friend and her mom...and you guessed it, I slapped her. Hard. It was sooo good. Like everything on the menu was amazing. You have to try this place once in your life so you can say you had Ramen. Everybody else is just "cup a soup."
author: Donnie N.

description:
I don't consider myself a ramen aficionado per se but I eat a lot of ramen. I like what I like and sometimes I like ramen that other people don't and sometimes I don't like ramen that other people really love (Mensho, for instance). 

Marufuku seems to be one of those ramen spots that everyone agrees upon. It's really effing good. 

Marufuku always has a long line no matter when you go. This would be annoying but the nice thing is you can put your name on the waitlist, track it through your phone, and go get a drink somewhere else in the neighborhood while you wait (I recommend the bar at the Hotel Kabuki). 

The Hakata Tonkotsu Spicy is my go-to and it's amazing though the spice level isn't too hot. It may be my favorite ramen in the city although I have yet to try Ippudo SF. Ippudo is my measure for greatness since the one in NYC is my favorite ramen I've had. But Marufuku is worth the wait. Go, slurp up all the ramen, and try the Sansho Japanese pepper beer. It goes surprisingly well with the meal.

5 stars (even with the wait).
author: Joe M.

description: OK Ramen. Egg was overcooked and no flavor. Broth was a bit salty for my taste. Wasn't sure why there is so much hype for this place.
author: Wayne K.

description:
Mmmm. Apparently rated the best ramen in Seattle & the Bay Area- Marufuku had some high hopes to fill- and they definitely are well worth the long wait time & hype. A definite recommend if you're looking for some bomb ramen! 

I came here with 2 of my younger siblings here and waited here for about 20-25 minutes at around 12 before we were seated. The waiters here were very kind. Extremely prompt service despite how crowded it was.

Kaarage Bowl ($4)- Very generously portioned, it came with green onions and very finely sliced seaweed bits on top of their Japanese Chicken & rice. Their Japanese chicken was cooked very nicely and was crisped nicely with flavor. I was surprised at how much the bowl really filled me up and how pleasantly surprised I was by their chicken. I'd order this again, but I think to be fair I also paired it with their really flavorful broth from my Tonkatsu.

Tonkatsu Ramen ($15)- For me while I thoroughly enjoyed it- my critique of it so far like everyone else's was-

1) The pork broth was REALLY potent in flavor. So rich and flavorful, I really enjoyed and LOVED their broth here. It wasn't too salty, and it packed a huge favor punch. Completely solid broth- I loved it so much, and pairing it with my rice from my Kaarage bowl added so much flavor back into the bottom of the bowl of rice.
2) Chasew was cooked nicely, but I think I prefer Hinodeya Ramen Bar's chasew a lot more, something about the way they cook theirs really was magical to me. Still, it was cooked very well- super soft and flavorful, and no real complaints here. Their egg is also perfectly soft boiled and delicious.
3) Their noodles, while amazing were also probably not my favorite style of them- I prefer a noodle that's a little thicker, as the noodles here are on the thinner side. However, they were soft and enjoyable to consume. My siblings had taken a few bites of my Ramen and enjoyed it so much they devoured most of my bowl.

The servers- also seeing I was accompanied by young kids also brought out really cute froggy bowls for them to eat out of- which was really sweet and then much later needed when my siblings discovered how much they loved their ramen here. Shout out to the servers for being so attentive and for also checking up often to see if we needed anything.

My review may be slightly biased, since I had taken my younger siblings here and they absolutely fell in love with Marufuku. They told me coming to Japantown that the food here was probably the best ramen they've ever eaten- and while I do love it as well- I'd have to rate them a 4.75 leaning to a 5, my only reason why it's not quite hitting a 5 is solely bc there are minor bits and pieces that don't match my own personal preferences. HOWEVER, it's definitely probably one of the best ramen places I've ever had. I highly doubt if you came here you'd be disappointed. Definite recommend especially for some bomb ramen in Japantown!
author: Allison O.

description:
Enjoyed for the first time a couple days ago and I must say it's the best broth I've had since our Family Fave of this location closed.  We enjoyed the Hakata Tonkatsu and Takoyaki appetizer. 
The only con, it's too hot in the restaurant since being renovated. We use to frequent Sapporo-ya since 1979 and it has never been that warm inside the restaurant.
author: May S.

description: Just as most everyone else's reviews states, this place is AMAZING.  Definitely quite popular and busy - the wait was about 1.5 hours for a table for one, but so worth it.  For starters, Marufuku with the help of Yelp reservations, does a good job with making sure the online reservation portion is streamlined.  It is quite simple and was not that difficult to do at all.  I was immediately seated once my table was ready, and the wait staff promptly brought me my water and utensils.  I ordered the spicy hakata tonkotsu ramen and was blown away.  It's been since May 2018 when I was last there, but I still remember EVERY taste and minute of my experience.  The spicy was not as spicy as I thought, and if I ever go back, I would try their ultra spicy since I like my ramen with a kick!  Although each ingredient contributed to my fantastic ingredient, I have to emphasize how pure the broth was.  The pork broth that was probably simmered for several hours was so thin, but also rich.  It wasn't overly salty at all and I usually never drink the whole broth in ramen, but at Marufuku, I had to.  It was just absolutely so pleasant and their time and attention to their ramen was very evident.  The pork belly was ample and very tender, and the soft boiled egg was perfect!  It wasn't too runny and just so perfect with the whole dish.  I will never forget Marufuku and unfortunately, they've ruined it for me for all the Japanese ramen places on the East coast.  My journey to attempt to find a place similar here in New York City begins now.
author: Hannah L.

description: We came here on the weekend for dinner. The waitlist is digitalized. You enter in your party number and a phone number for them to text you when your table is ready. We had 8 parties in front of us and it went pretty fast we waited about 25 minutes. We were seated right away. The menu is simple. They have a few rice bowl options and a few Ramen options. The soup is great! The noodles are ok. I wasn't expecting an egg noodle texture. I was expecting the ramen squiggly noodles. The service was great. The food was yummy. The place was clean. I loved also that I was able had order extra noodles! It wasn't filling, but it was yummy!
author: Crissy G.

description: Waited maybe 45 min on a Thur night. Went to the karaoke bar next door to have a drink so was not too bad! We got the octopus and takoyaki for appetizers, both very good. I got the hakata tonkotsu and it was pretty good. Thin noodles, flavorful and full broth. Good soft boiled egg, lots of chasu- I ate the whole bowl! Good to try, and not sure if its worth more than an hour wait, but would come back if there was no line or a short wait.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Rarely do I go against the grain on Yelp when it comes to ramen, but I simply cannot agree with the 4.5 stars that Marufuku currently has as of the time I am writing this or the claim that is the "best ramen in SF."

I got the Hakata DX with extra chashu. Solid bowl, but I really did expect better. As usual I primarily rate my ramen on three things: (1) broth, (2) pork, and (3) noodles.

1. The tonkotsu broth is excellent and about on par with the best places I've had. Very rich with flavor as a proper tonkotsu broth shoud be. Medium spicy really isn't that spicy...it provides a little kick, nothing more than that. No complaints on the broth.
2. The pork is very tender (both the chashu and thicker pork belly), but I greatly disagree with the direction they take on giving the pork a sweet flavor. It provides a serious clash of flavors that really doesn't work IMO. Honestly, the pork being sweet ruined the consistency of the bowl for me.
3. To be fair, I'm not really a huge fan of Hakata-style ramen noodles because in most situations, the noodles don't carry the flavor of the broth very well. That's what I thought here. Cooking the noodles a little bit harder made it difficult for them to absorb the broth's flavor. Definitely felt there were a few bites where the noodles felt almost flavorless.

The egg is cooked the way I prefer (soft-boiled), but it also carried some sweet tendencies as well. Again, not a fan of that.

Staff here is really friendly, I have zero complaints about the service here.

As with any popular ramen spot, you gotta come about 15-30 minutes before it opens or else you will definitely be stuck behind the first wave of people. Personally, that's probably as long as I would wait for here. Wouldn't wait longer than that.

IMO if this restaurant was in L.A., there's no way the rating is as high as it is. Just goes to show that SF is shockingly lacking in elite ramen options.
author: Alexander Y.

description: Every time we visit Japantown this place has a huge line, so naturally we thought it had to be amazing! One day we finally decided to wait in line and see what the fuss was about. The restaurant was so busy inside and we were squeezed into a table in the middle. I ordered the standard pork ramen and honestly I was not impressed. The broth was super fatty and so greasy. The meat was too fatty and just not my thing. If you like extremely rich ramen full of fat and grease this is your place. I prefer Tan Popo up the street and always leave feeling great, and not weighed down by an excess of fat.
author: Larissa S.

description: Really enjoy the food and service at Marufuku Ramen. We came with a party of 7, waited a reasonable amount of time. When you get there, there is always a line and you put your name on the list. Ordering is easy enough, decent menu, good amount of choices but not overwhelming. Really recommend the ramen, the broth is really good. I had chose medium spicy and it really felt more mild, so if you like spicier ramen, I would go one up from what you think you might like. The fried squid legs were really good, as was the takoyaki.
author: Ann S.

description:
We waited almost three hours to try their ramen! Walked around the shopping center and then sat for another hour or so as we kind of patiently waited. Come 8:45pm, we finally got seated. The mister and I both ordered their Tonkotsu ramen; I got spicy and he got non-spicy. We also ordered their octopus leg as an appetizer. Everything came together at once, which wasn't a big deal. Soup base was good, as it had a lot of flavor. Their noodles were also on point and cooked perfectly. The cha-siu was a bit too fatty for me so I came him all three of my pieces. The spice level was pretty weak for my taste, but it was a good compliment. Their soft boiled egg was also perfect. I usually judge a ramen place by their egg and the texture of their noodles. This place got both spot on. 

Worth it? Yes.... if we didn't need to wait three hours. Would we come back when in SF? Maybe... if it wasn't a three hour wait lol.
author: Nancy B.

description:
Possibly the best ramen I've ever had. 

We came for a late lunch and wrote our names down on the wait list around 2:20. We ended up being second to the last group of people the restaurant accepted prior to their closing time. Waited 40-45min and was seated around 3:15. It was nice of them to continue to serve their waitlisted customers past closing time. And we didn't mind the wait too much since there are many stores to browse nearby.

I got the Ultra Spicy Hakata Tonkatsu ramen, bf got moderate Hakata DX. As a spicy foods lover, the amount of spice in the ultra spicy version definitely got my approval as it had a good kick. The moderate version was also good and did have a little bit of spice in it -- it was perfect for the bf who isn't as big of a spicy food fan as I am. The broth was so good that we both practically licked the bowls clean. The noodles were thin and the texture was just right. At the end of the meal, we couldn't stop talking about how good their ramen was!
author: Laura K.

description: Came for dinner at 5pm when they opened and the line was really long but moved quickly.  We ordered 2 bowls of ramen and sake.  Their ramen was yummy and comforting to have on this trip.  Their sake $13 for 6 ounces was not good.  Service was really fast and nice.  Decor and atmosphere was pleasant.  Price of ramen  was around $12/bowl.  We used public transportation to avoid parking hassle.
author: Sydney T.

description: This place is coveted. Long waits for dinner. Rich Unami broth - Overall it was delicious. Not the best Ramen I've had in San Francisco but I think Ramen is like pizza or cupcakes - it's subjective. I am no expert, just my personal opinion. I actually found the broth a little bit too rich and one dimensional but again it was delicious.
author: Laura G.

description: This is probably one of the BEST ramen restaurants around. Everything on the menu is great. But there's a catch MAKE SURE TO GET THERE AN HOUR EARLIER THAN YOU PLAN TO EAT!!!!! There's always a super long line to check in and it may take up to an hour to get to your turn. Since it will notify when it's you turn by text, you should definitely plan on doing something during the wait. I would recommend the bookstore Kinokuniya, and the antique store to check out. Just make sure you stay close so your spot doesn't get taken. Again this restaurant is VERY EXCLUSIVE, so make sure to be on top of it. Because the wait is so worth it.
author: Maika S.

description:
I come here about every other month. Because nothing is better than a hot bowl of ramen on a freezing San Francisco night, and it's freezing in San Francisco quite often.
This place involves some strategic planning. Possibly playing a little hooky from work. I recommend getting there at 4:30 before they open. Just be the one that's first in line. It's worth the wait in my opinion. I've had the Hakata deluxe and the Chicken Paitan Deluxe (just share the chicken with who ever you're going with cuz it's good, but it's heavy). I like my Ramen's super thick, like gravy. So this place delivers. I like the decoration, and the service is good and fast.
