Hearing about the hype of Marufuku Ramen, I decided to stop by here for lunch with a friend during this year's Cherry Blossom Festival. As expected, there was a pretty long line, so we put our name down for a table, walked around the mall for about 30 minutes, and came back just in time for our seats.

I ordered their mild-spicy Hakata tonkatsu ramen with an add-on of extra noodles. The chashu was fantastic - very tender and full of rich, fatty flavor. The broth was also phenomenal - the savory pork bone flavors complemented the noodles and other ingredients very well. The noodles, however, were a bit of a miss - they were fresh and had the thin texture than I liked, but unfortunately quite hard and I had a struggle finishing the extra noodles that I ordered. The ramen came with a soft-boiled egg that was perfectly cooked, and a bunch of other toppings such as mushrooms and green onions.

Overall, was very pleased with the ramen and was a great experience. Definitely recommend a try if you are in the area, though try to avoid peak lunch/dinner hours as the lines can get quite long.
author: Alvin W.

description: Ordered the chicken paitan and it was so good. The wait was worth it. The flavor was amazing and service was awesome.
author: Amanda R.

description: I went to this place during my trip to San Francisco. I knew this restaurant was going to be quite busy but the wait was CRAZY!!!! We waited for more than 2 hours!!!! But once we were seated, the food that I ordered (the chicken paitan) was pretty good BUT was It worth It for the LOOOOOOOOONNNNNGGG wait? Probably not but I would honestly go again if I travel back to San Francisco.
author: Katie M.

description:
I noted this new ramen place opening up earlier this week at the location of the former Sapporo-Ya Restaurant.  Therefore, a friend and I came to try it out last night. We both ordered their basic tonkatsu ramen (I forgot the name they call it) and both of us enjoyed it very much. We both ordered the spicy soup level (there was also a very spicy option but we decided not to be that brace). The soup was very tasty and the pork slices were very good as well. The noodle is of the very thin variety and was very good too (for those familiar with Yamadaya located nearby, the noodle to similar to theirs).

We also ordered a pitcher of Sapporo beer. Unfortunately the beer was flat, don't know if we got the end of their supply or what.

Also other things of note after we got the bill:

1.  They do charge for the health tax.
2.  Beware of following their 15 percent tip suggestion amount. We noted the number came out higher than it should have been, even if you were to base it on the after-tax total (which I normally don't). Our bill after the sales and health tax was around $52.70, and usually g the calculator 15% of that should have been just under $8. The bill showed the suggested amount at 15% to be $8.50.  It wasn't good for them to show a miscalculated amount like that, especially with it coming out on the high side. Hopefully it was just an error on their part and they fix it.

Item number 2 above is the reason I can't give them five stars for now.  Otherwise this joins the ranks of favorite ramen places.
author: H K.

description:
I'm from Orange County where there's pretty awesome ramen (Shin Sen Gumi, What's Up Men) and close enough to LA (Daikokuya, Slurpin' Rmane), so I wanted to check out the options in SF. 

I had the Hakata Tonkotsu (spicy), Chasu Bowl and Karage Chicken. 

The Hakata Tonkotsu was the best thing there, or at least from what I ordered. The broth was good and actually had a kick to it, though not really "spicy." Egg was perfectly soft boiled and the extra addition of the bamboo was worth it. 

The rice in the Chasu Bowl was soggy and the Chasu itself was lackluster. The Karage was dry and the overall taste was bland. 

The service was okay. We had to flag someone down each time. The overall experience was forgettable.
author: Nancy L.

description:
My boyfriend is on a ramen binge & when we travel he insists on finding "the best ramen of all time". 

Well folks I'm here today to tell you this spot has officially moved to number 1 on our list! 

I read the reviews beforehand & was already anticipating the greatness....and how awesome it lived up to every expectation! 
Taking the first bite we looked at each other with wide eyes and just said "yes....so much yes"

I got the chicken & he got the upgraded pork. I'm pickier so I just wanted to try the simple version. I will say I significantly preferred the chicken flavor over the pork, but my boyfriend insists they are tied for greatness. 

Follow me on Instagram for more foodie adventures ~ @krrenee
author: Kristen M.

description: This place is amazing. Would highly recommend. Get the Ramen and make it spicy. It's the only way to go!!!!!
author: Rishi G.

description:
As part of my ramen 2K17 run, when Marufuku opened, and I saw the good reviews, I decided to come and see what the hype was all about. I got there around 5:15pm because I didn't want to wait in line, but I quickly learned that there was no need to arrive that early. My boyfriend and I ordered karaage, hakata, paitan, and the pork belly bowl. 

The broth was good, but the noodles....We knew they were different than what we typically think ramen noodles are, but I guess the difference didn't fit our palates. It was just so different, and not in a positive way. The karaage and pork belly was nothing special. It all tasted good, but not something I would remember 3 months from now. 

The services was good, but we will not be back. In terms of ramen in SF, our favorite is Mensho followed by Hinodeya.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Love love love! Best ramen place in Japantown, hands down. Great ambience, appetizers are pretty good. The ramen is AMAZING! Love love the soup base. It is perfectly balanced, not salty or overwhelming at all. Will for sure come back soon! 

新开的拉面店，装修简单有情调。点了炸鸡，章鱼小丸子还有拉面。小吃都很赞，但是这个拉面简直太出乎意料的好吃！汤料做的很用心，一流，完全不咸，喝完也不口干，糖心蛋火候完美，是那种咬一口蛋黄慢慢流出来的质地，很难得。除了食物好吃以外，服务超级日式贴心卡哇伊，很喜欢很喜欢，会经常来。
author: Yang C.

description: Marufuku Ramen is one of the best Ramen I had in the bay area.  The line is a bit long, but due to such good ramen, I am willing to wait.  I recommended to couple of my ramen friends.  They also loved it. Definitely a must place to try.
author: Michele H.

description: I came here from Sacramento to try this place out. From the review I thought it was worth 2 hour wait. Finally we got in and ready to eat. All 4 of us were disappointed. The broth was extremely salty. We didn't want to finish it but we were so hungry from the wait so we had no choice.
author: Trung V.

description:
I don't understand what the hype is all about. I mean, the line is long; You need to be 45 mins early to be in front. 

The food is not that fancy.
Its all above $10.
The inside is smoking. Like literally smoke everywhere.

What I enjoy though is that their costumer service is awesome! Full of people? Doesn't matter, they still have you taken care off.
author: Dan Asher D.

description:
We waited for an hour. And ramens weren't good at all. Who will want to eat salty(as ocean) tonkutsu paiton ramen. And bland chicken paiton ramen.

Don't expect a shop with long line outside to be good.
author: Parinya W.

description: Bustling place, nice flavors, good presentation. Had traditional ramen and enjoyed it, a bit too salty and roast pork belly was dry. Other than those two things - well worth the experience
author: Boris B.

description: Noodles are excellent! Their service is efficient and nice! Waiting for about 30mins on Tuesday evening so get there early or go there alone! You won't regret it.
author: Ichi Y.

description: Ordered the DX and karaage bowl. The karaage had no flavor but the chicken was very tender. For the ramen: broth itself was solid, not mouth watering but it was decent. The noodles were very thin, thinner than most but I liked it that way. The pork slices were not succulent like normal and a little on the sweeter side. Some people like the sweetness though. I love the seasoned egg in ramen and was disappointed to find out it was just a hard boiled egg. Overall, it was okay. Definitely not worth the hour and a half wait.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Amazing ramen!! Very rich tonkatsu. A long wait long but definitely worth it if you love your ramen
author: Casey C.

description: My favorite ramen place to go by far. Since I've tried so many places I'm lowkey sick of ramen but this place I would always go to. Cant wait to go there again.
author: Susanna L.

description: This place is like the speakeasy of ramen it's so hard to find. The street address doesn't help and I noticed others trying to find it the same time we were and also as we were leaving. It is located in the small shopping plaza in 1825 Post. But then you look at the shopping directory and it's not listed. So you figure it's real Address is suite 235 so it is on second floor. Then it's on the back corner and if course there's already people waiting in line right as it opens.  Don't forget to sign your name in the sheet to queue up. Congratulations you made it. Because this place is so trendy I felt bad for the people  who had the window seat as they were in a fish bowl of people staring at them. Once seated, the food is served quickly and it goes without saying that the ramen is on point. Two bowls of ramen and a coke ran $30. Not a bad deal if you can stand the wait.
author: kelly m.

description:
Visiting from LA, came here based on recommendation from a friend living in SF. We put our name down on the waitlist at around 6PM and got seated around 7:30PM on a Sunday night.

I may be biased because I grew up in Japan so I've had my fair share of ramen, but it was WAY too salty for my taste (we had both the Chicken Paitan and Tonkotsu ramen, the chicken was much saltier but the Tonkotsu was still much saltier than average). Also some of the reviews mentioned that the broth is piping hot, which may be a good thing for some. For me personally, I eat quite slow (takes me about 15-20 mins to finish a bowl of ramen) and by the 10 minute mark the remaining noodles lost all of its texture, which is so crucial to the overall ramen experience.

Verdict - forgo the line, not worth the wait.

P.S. Service is actually not bad for how busy it is, but the host seem quite overwhelmed and the lady who spoke out names out spoke so quietly everyone had to huddle around her to listen to make sure their names were called.
author: Cheri R.

description:
So, I am not a ramen expert but I know when something tastes good.

I ordered the tonkatsu.   The broth was rice and creamy and very flavorful.   I ordered mine medium spicy and it had the perfect kick.   Little bits of the occasional lemongrass really brightened up the dish as well and balanced out the umami.   The noodles were thin, but tasted fresh and had a good amount of chew to them.   The pork belly was perfectly cooked.   The egg was perfect.   I really have no complaints.

We got there right when they opened so we were seated right away.   Never saw a line of people forming, so I am guessing this is a bit of a hidden gem.   Prices are pretty good too....the basic tonkatsu was $10.95, which is pretty good by san francisco standards.

Recommended.
author: Christian C.

description:
An AMAZING find in my trip up to the city yesterday.  They've replaced an older ramen joint in the Japantown shopping center, and boy am I glad they're there.  Most places in the plaza are extremely lackluster, but not this place!

Not only does the new trendy interior draw you in, but the food and service is what makes you take a seat and stay. 

Now, to be honest, when I came here with friends, we only had the appetizers and drinks, but those appetizers were damn good. 

The Geso Fry (Squid Legs) and Chicken Karaage were nicely fried, with a enough crunch to keep me satisfied.  And that karaage was so moist on the inside.  Drool. The Buta Kakuni (Braised Pork Belly) was the real winner though.  Holy smokes, like my friend said to me, 'It's so buttery'.  Talk about amazing.  PLUS, we were able to try out the Paitan Chicken!  Which was actually the grilled chicken that they served with ramen, delicious. Washed it all down with Sapporo, Nigori and my new favorite, Sansho Ale and everything was golden.  Everyone, I truly recommend the Sansho Ale when eating here.  I truly do.  

Or if you're adventurous.  Get the WASABI Beer.  Heh.

Customer service was great.  They were all so sweet and accommodating.  And they checked in on us often to make sure everything was good.

I am definitely coming back because I need to try their Hakata Style ramen.  My favorite type of ramen!  It's so hard to find a place that serves them.  

Oh my god, the craving while writing this review is so real right now.  I wish I lived closer.
author: Michele C.

description: The broth and simmered pork belly was delicious. Staff fast and friendly. I will return again.
author: alexia h.

description: I love Ramen and almost all kinds but I found this one to be bland.... and the noodles were really thin. I didn't think the soup was tasty. The vibe of the restaurant is super cool.
author: Tina L.

description: Hands down the best ramen in the city! Such a comforting bowl. I got the ultra spicy based on other reviews of people saying that it's not that spicy. It was definitely not, but it satisfied my taste buds with a little kick to the broth. Definitely coming again!
author: Kathleen Q.

description: Best ramen in town!!! Been going here for years. Fast service and all the staff is super friendly too.
author: Alex L.

description: The wait time... is Unbelievable. 3 hours of waiting and 20 min of eating wasn't worth it. The ramen was alright though, the portions were a bit small
author: Amanda D.

description: Came here at 6pm on a Sat and there's 32 parties in line; approx. 1 hour wait. Ppl get there early since it's always a long wait. I really liked how you can enter your name/number in the Ipad and then you can walk around and they will text you once it's time to come back. I was able to explore the mall and the book store for a good hour instead of just standing in line staring at my phone. Good for 4 ppl or less, best for 2 ppl as place is small and cramp. Wait staff is very pleasant and polite similar to other authentic Japanese restaurants. Got the original ramen with extra pork medium spicy. I like the overall taste but didn't like the pork too much. Spice on table is not spicy at all. Minus  points for no free hot tea.
author: Yenn T.

description:
My friends and I came to Marufuku on a Saturday afternoon and we had to wait for about 20 minutes. The restaurant had a strange interior design. Aside from the regular tables on the sides, in the center, there is a rectangular frame with three tables inside. The frame is supposed to be the seats. We were very "lucky" and were seated at one of these three tables. It was very awkward to climb and crawl over the frame to get to our table. I was also wearing a skirt so you can imagine how ridiculous looking that was.... Also, the servers themselves had to climb over it to give you the food and clean the table, etc. Simply inconvenient for everyone.

For food, we ordered the Hakata Tonkatsu ($10.99), the Chicken Paitan ($10.99), Takoyaki ($6.50), and the Karaage Bowl ($3.50). We chose not to order the deluxe version since it is four dollars more just for braised pork belly. Instead we ordered a small rice bowl which is also around four dollars. I didn't really like the noodle for the ramen because it just reminded me of regular Chinese egg noodles that I eat at home. The soup wasn't very heavy which I liked. The most surprising thing to me was how each bowl of ramen had an entire soft-boiled egg and it was done perfectly.
author: Ida L.

description: We came on a Wednesday night at 7pm and waited slightly over an hour, but I thought it was worth the wait. We ordered the Hakata Tonkatsu and the Hakata DX, which were pretty similar. The broth is boiled for over 20 hours so it's very flavorful and creamy and pork is very tender. Hiding under all the noodles is an egg which holds a creamy delicious golden center. Noodles aren't the typical ramen. They are similar to soba noodles, narrow and white; it was alright, but I prefer the traditional ramen noodles. The dish was surprisingly filling. If your have left over broth, bring it home and boil fresh ramen with it- it taste so good! Around $15 per bowl of ramen. Restaurant is pretty clean and modern compared to all the other restaurants in Japantown. Service was good and efficient. Glad to see a quality restaurant here. It's also close to Sophie's Crepes so you can have dessert afterward if you're not too full.
author: Tes Y.

description: Living not too far from Marufuku, I tend to come in from time to time. The Hakata Tankatsu Ramen is absolutely one of my favorite ramen in all of San Francisco. The portion sizes are a little smaller than you'll find at most ramen restaurants but that's alright, theres a super yummy ice cream shop just a skip and a hop down the street from here!
author: Troy L.

description: I think this was worth the wait. We put our names down around 5:30 and waited around and hour and half for it. I love their yelp waiting app. This is one of the best inventions ever! We were # 60 or something cray like that, but it went by quickly. We did a thorough tour of Japan Town (: The Hakata-style Tonkotsu ramen was good. The broth was creamy, flavorful and addicting. I definitely had a full on umami experience (:
author: Jenna L.

description: Simply beautiful ramen. The perfect meal after a long day in the city. The wait is worth it.
author: Amandeep C.

description:
I tried this place on a Thursday night and there where at Least ten names ahead of us, but it took about ten to 15 minutes to get a table. The bookstore across the hall provides a good distraction till it's your turn!
I'm glad I didn't go downstairs to another noodle place with open tables!
The menu is rather short in options and simple, but when you serve such great food it doesn't matter!
They're super quick to bring the food considering how packed they are. The portion was generous and I could not finish! Chicken ramen came with an extra piece of chicken on the side! All that amazing food for $15.50 is a great deal for PAC heights. 
I tasted my friend's pork ramen and surprised how it could taste better than mine!
I highly recommend this place. 
Great food, great price, generous portions, quick service, clean establishment and friendly staff.
author: Nick L.

description: We waited one hour and a half and was well worth it.  We had the Pork Belly Ramen and were very pleased with the dish. The broth was rich and very smooth.  Delicious and recommend it over the chicken ramen.
author: Edwina O.

description: Reserve on yelp and get a text message notification when table is ready. Ramen was thin and delicious, will return. Wait was 35-45 min lunch time on a weekday. Can't imagine weekends!
author: Daniel W.

description: Favorite hakata ramen in SF. Would be happy to have ceramic spoons and not plastic, and a slightly odd mix of Western-style dining features paired with ramen-shop-rushed-service (if you're done being served everything you've ordered, expect your receipt long before you've finished dining).
author: Rachel W.

description: Great ramen place in Japan town. Ordered the hakata tonkutsu, Chicken karaage, geso fry and buta kakuni. The broth is great. Would have been more satisfying if the noodles are harder. It was a little over cooked.
author: William S.

description: We came here on a Saturday evening at 4:30pm since the restaurant didn't open until 5pm and we wanted to beat the line. Unfortunately, everyone else had the same idea as there was a line already (about 10-15 people ahead of us). By the time 5pm rolled around, the line was 30+ people long. However, we made the first wave and service was fast and efficient. As for the food, we got the tonkatsu ramen and tonkatsu dx ramen - both were delicious!  We will be back but next time closer to home at their Oakland location.
author: Rossi K.

description: Amazing and worth the wait. The plaza is full of ramen selling restaurants, but this was the only one with a long line. So you know it's gonna be good.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: If your in to the details all i gotta say is all that matters is noodles and broth everything else is secondary....#amen4ramen!!! #domo #salamat #worththewait #exclusive #sanfranciso
author: Darren S.

description: By far the best ramen outside of Japan! A little hard to find if you're not from the area, but well worth the effort to enjoy the amazing broth, noodles and flavor.
author: Justin L.

description: Waited waaaay too long to try this place (we put our names down at 5:30 and didn't get served until 7 ish) but it was worth it!! The tonkotsu broth was probably the best I've had outside of Japan, very flavorful without being overly oily. People who say the noodles are too skinny - that's what they're supposed to be for this type of broth!! I personally prefer this type of noodle because I think it really soaks up the flavor of the broth, definitely try it out if you love ramen!!
author: Momona Y.

description:
Good Ramen and Kara-Age. Fast friendly service..just what was expected.

I would definitely go back.
author: Brandon P.

description: What can I say? I'm addicted to this Ramen place. I'd dare say that their Hakata DX is the best Ramen I've had so far in San Francisco and I've tried a lot of Ramen places. The broth is rich and each ingredient just blends about right. The Hakata Dx has the best braised pork I've had in a Ramen. The Ramen noodles is the equivalent of "al dente" in pasta- chewy and buoyant is probably another good way of describing it (my noodle vocabulary is limited). I go to this place at least once a week. There's always a wait but you can join the wait list in Yelp (the estimated wait time given is +/- 10 minutes on weekdays) to save you time from just sitting outside while waiting.
author: Roy G.

description: Good food good place. clean . Good service ..I definitely will cam back. be crowded on weekends
author: Mario D.

description: It was a cool night and I was in the mood for a nice bowl of ramen, and Marufuku was the best choice!
author: Armando C.

description: Hands down. Best Ramen Ever. I ordered the Ramen where they make only 15 of them. I cant explain the taste. It is simply...GOOD!! Very nice staff. GREAT ATMOSPHERE. I will be back on next trip for sure.
author: James H.

description: Great food, sweet service, as there is always a long line waiting in front of the restaurant, they set up a check in machine at the entrance, after check in, you may walk away to do some shop around and you will receive a reminder when it is almost your turn.
author: Jade C.

description: An amazing thing about this place is the electronoc waiting list where you put your number in the computer for a text update on the next available table, ordered Chicken Ramen and Tonkusu Ramen, they were really good, deliciuos stuff made to your own liking that is spicing. The atmosphere at Marufuku is very condusive nice and cozy, a good place for lunch, I have since been there more and more times.
author: Brian M.

description: Had dinner here last night. The ramen was nice and the broth was tasty either, however, the waiting time was to longggg. Would recommend make a reservation through yelp before you go there. Would definitely visit again.
author: Calvin H.

description: This place was very good.  The wait was really long but there was a lot of things around to keep you occupied till you get a call back.  Worth the wait and one of the best ramen places in SF.
author: Nathan A.

description:
Lately I've been on a ramen binge and Marufuku is now one of the top places I'd recommend somebody if they came to SF for ramen. They only have two types of ramen; their Hakata Tonkotsu or their chicken paitan, both in a regular and "Dx" size which is larger and comes with a hunk of meat. I prefer their chicken paitan over the tonkotsu; something about the chicken ramen here calms the soul with a ton of flavor. I'm usually more of a tonkotsu girl but the chicken hits the spot for sure. I get the regular size portions because for 11.99, your bowl comes with green onion, kikurage mushrooms, bean sprouts and a soft boiled egg which is already a TON of food for my stomach. You also get to choose which spice level you want from none-very spicy, but I usually prefer mild as they have chili flakes on the table to use at your leisure. This restaurant is also one of the only places I know that serve the white thin noodles versus the thick, yellow style noodle that is most commonly seen at restaurants. As for appetizers, I've tried their takoyaki and it is good! Some of my friends like getting their small rice bowls to get their stomach going for the main dish.

I feel this is one of the must-try's ramen spots in SF since this place opened. Make sure to come here early as there is always a wait here; be prepared to wait close to half an hour or more especially if it's prime dinner time!
author: Kathleen S.

description: Hands down the best ramen I have ever had in my life. I wasn't even there in person my husband brought me take out and it's still the best. While I was pregnant I become somewhat of a ramen connoisseur I've tried multiple places in SF, LA and NY the broth here is like no other. You will not be disappointed
author: Lindsay A.

description: Long wait but totally worth it.  Possibly the best ramen in SF! I got the Hakata DX with medium spicy. The soup was amazing and the noodle was cooked right. Love they added corn in the bowl. The pork belly was so flavorful that I wished I order extra! My only complain would be that there's no AC in the restaurant. Eating here on a hot day feels like being a sauna room. Other than that I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Andrew J.

description: Excellent noodles with delicious broth. Side dishes were all very good too.
author: T L.

description: If you want a proper Ramen, look no further. The dumplings are also a great side dish and the entire staff is very friendly.
author: Miha L.

description: They had pretty good quality ramen, we had the Hakata DX spicy miso ramen, a chashu bowl, and takoyaki. Based on taste, I give it a 4, but if you have a big group make sure to have a reservation for dinner or you'll find yourself waiting for 1-2 hrs. They also have hours where they close in the middle of the afternoon so watch out for that when trying to call and make reservations. They have a yelp waitlist that will notify you when you're next in line, but if you're hungry and just walking in, it may take a while before you're seated. The seating for a 7 person group was a little tight, but we managed. The location is nice since it's near a lot of stores, but it also makes the place really packed at times. It's on the second floor inside the Japantown shopping plaza near Sophie's Crepes.
author: Lauren C.

description: Really like this place. The wait time is a little crazy but not terrible. Go a little spicier than you think you want! It runs a little more mild than you think. Very yummy ramen.
author: Tara K.

description: Best ramen in SF? Not sure but it is one of them that's for sure. Yelp's NoWait is super cool too!
author: Jason P.

description: I can't get enough of this place!  The spicy broth is uh-mazing.  Always get extra noodles up front when you order if you're really hungry.  Thank me later, lol.  Geso fry is also really good if you like squid legs.  Oh yeah...get there early or be prepared to wait!
author: Jesus H.

description: We tried all three kinds of ramen noodle. I think the chicken ramen's is the best. It is rich and flavorful. Veggie may like the Zen noodle.
author: Qinru L.

description: One of the top places in the city. Both the tonkatsu and chicken broth were really delicious. Better than Mensho by a small margin only because sometimes the Mensho broth is too rich. Personally I like thinner noodles here over thicker so it's similar to Ramen Yamadaya in that respect. Will keep coming to this place!
author: Young Y.

description: The braised pork is amazing! My four year old was devouring his pork rice bowl. The ramen was great. Everything was out to the table in great time. Staff was attentive and very nice. Loved the food!! You hope when the wait is an hr and a half that it'll be great. They didn't disappoint!
author: Susan P.

description: One of my favorite ramen places in the Bay Area. The broth is extremely flavorful and the noodles were perfect. I can't recommend this place enough! Aside from the delicious food, there's always a wait (at least 30 minutes). Try to arrive a few minutes before they open and jot your name down on the list.
author: Lucy Q.

description:
The ramen (noodle and broth) is very good, and the chashu bowl is also very nice. It is just $4 but the portion is well enough for people with moderate appetite.

However, the appetizers like geso fry and karaage are just ok. I mean, it is still better than a lot of other Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area, but definitely not the best I have had here. 

Wait time is longer than it is worth, but you can always sign in and then go shopping first to skip the wait...
author: Ki L.

description: Worth the hype - ramen was fantastic, and though there was a bit of a wait, the food came out really quickly!
author: Tiffany V.

description: Very good broth, but noodles are thin and really average. the soup is just really good but not worth the wait. Take the pork instead of the chicken!
author: Why-Tie Z.

description:
Best ramen I've ever had. Highly recommend for all foodies and those wanting to experience something new! 
I tried the tonkatsu ramen.


Broth: very balanced and light considering it's made from pork bones. Perfect seasoning and you are given the choice of the spice level. I chose medium and it was a nice combo of spice and broth. 

Noodles: perfect width, super fresh and the starchiness was balanced. When slurping the noodles, you taste the noodle and the broth together. Now that's what I call a perfect bowl of ramen.

Ambiance: super intimate and welcoming.
author: Sareen B.

description: I love the ramen from here, especially the broth tastes so good. I love their bamboo shoots here too.  The ramen is spicy but tasted so good, especially the pork one. I love it very much. I DON'T think I will tired of it anytime soon. This is the best ramen place for me.
author: Meichelle L.

description: Excellent food and service. Though the wait is usually hours. Recommend get into the waitlist at least 1 hour before you arrive.
author: Shengkun Y.

description: We were first in line to get into the restaurant. Fast service. The best spot for Ramen.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Overall, great spot for nicely priced and delicious ramen, but service was a bit slow!

Got there around 5:45 and we only had to wait a few minutes to get seated. But by the time we left, there was a pretty long crowd of people waiting outside the entrance. 

I ordered the hakata tonkotsu and added corn. I ordered with mild spicy and my boyfriend got the same without corn but with medium spicy, but I think they mixed ours up because mine was spicier than his. Either way though it was super tasty, delicious broth, sweet corn, nice thin noodles, perfectly soft boiled egg. 

We asked the waiter and apparently the difference between what we got and the dx version was that it had an extra type of pork and a few more toppings (corn and seaweed), but it's $4 more. 

We also got the Japanese fried chicken with rice- a bit under seasoned chicken but juicy inside with a crunchy exterior, and nice sticky rice with some seaweed strips for flavor. Definitely great for the price of 3.50!

Also, the chicken dx ramen looks like it comes with a pretty heaping plate of sizzling chicken with crispy skin, which isn't obvious from the menu since it subtly says a side of grilled chicken. We saw some folks next to us get it so will definitely try it next time! Also saw another table with people who didn't seem to comprehend the chicken came with the ramen, so they actually turned it down after two waiters tried to explain it to them! I wanted to raise my hand and offer to have the dish but my bf stopped me...

The only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars was that their service was pretty slow. When we first got seated, we got menus, then a waiter took our orders and menus away. Then 5 minutes later a different waiter came and dropped menus on our table and thanked us for waiting! And we were like, no we already ordered! They also were kinda slow on water refills, and super slow on getting us our bill and then taking our credit cards. We had to flag the waiter down when he came close by for each of these tasks, my boyfriend felt like they were making it so hard for us to pay them! And plus, there were almost always a few empty tables at a given time throughout our meal, despite a crowd waiting outside, so I think they're just a bit slow on the service/ops part. But food was great :)
author: Jennifer S.

description: So good. Their Vegan ramen bowl has the best flavor and you won't even notice it's vegan. Amazing taste and flavor. Highly recommend.
author: Jessica M.

description: This is probably the best ramen house in San Francisco . The broth is flavourful and the noodle size is just right - not too fat . It's definitely worth queuing up for .
author: Jo An Y.

description: We discovered this place inside Japan center on the west side of the mall . I was craving for some nice ramen last night n dined here . My husband ordered for Paitan chicken ramen DX bowl spicy that comes with a big chicken thigh piece and I ordered for paitan chicken bowl ultra spicy . For appetizer we ordered chicken wings. Everything tasted good . Service n ambiance both are good . A nice cozy place to enjoy a hot n spicy bowl of ramen !!! For all the ramen lovers out there I recommend this place
author: Chaitra V.

description: Absolutely the BEST Ramen I've ever had. Ordered the Hakata DX with a side of rice, seaweed with Roe & Sprouts. One of the Most delicious meal's I've had in 2017. Serving size was generous and service was quick. There is a wait after you place you name on the list but thats because this place is worth the visit. Plenty of things to see and shops to visit including beer & saki bars steps away. Cant say enough good things about the food. The Ramen has a complex taste that makes you dream of your next visit!
author: Sfo'consumer S.

description:
NOT.WORTH.THE.WAIT. We were so excited to try out this place since they have so many good reviews and there were a long line before us.
After 30 minutes waiting, we finally got in. 1st impression: TOO HOT. The ceiling is already low enough and there is no ventilation whatsoever. The place is just extremely hot.
We've got the first option of the ramen with extra spicy option. The ramen was just meh. First of all, the soup was decent but lack in the boney, savory taste you got from cooking the bone in long enough (well that's what you guys claim but it just does not taste that way). Maybe the soup is just my jurisdiction, but here's the thing, the meat portion for the price I've paid was just disappointing. Only a FEW SUPER THIN slices. I mean I can literally see through the chashu, it was that thin. I feel like they gave my the trash part of the chashu when they cut it so I couldn't "feel" it at all. Egg was perfectly done so thumbs up on that.
But the place was just TOO HOT to enjoy our food. Not only it was crowded but the lack of ventilation killed our experience here at Marafuku.
Overall, the food is not that special as well as the lack of ventilation in the restaurant will deny me from coming back in the near future.
author: Huy N.

description: Had to wait a little for lunch (waitlist on Yelp) but the ramen was so good I ate every drop! (I had the chicken). Service is also great, fast but you don't feel rushed. I wish I were in SF longer to go back, next time for sure!
author: Petra E.

description: There was a really long wait but this place has some of the best ramen you can find anywhere.
author: Tony Y.

description: Marufuku is definitely one of my fave ramen places! I go here whenever I'm in Japantown. The service is super quick, and they give a generous amount of noodles! I love all the ramen dishes they serve, and I usually order the squid appetizer. As previous reviews mentioned, there is always a line formed before dinner so I highly recommend getting there 30+ mins before opening. Also, the presentation of food is awesome, and different than most ramen places I've been to in the Bay Area. Happy eating!
author: Shan M.

description: Delicious! Menu is simple. Had the Hakata dx with a side of chashu and  an order of karaage. Wait time was long but they'll text you when your table is ready.
author: Phat L.

description:
Ramen was really good.  Had the first item on the menu (page on the right), sorry.  My span of memory is terrible. Will add in the name of the ramen later (if I can remember to do it).

Shall be back .....For the ramen.
author: K L.

description:
There's a lot I don't understand about this place.

The first comes before you even step foot inside the restaurant: there's a paper form posted on the door for you to sign in and reserve your group's place in the seating order ... but then there's also a long line of folks waiting to get in. As far as I can tell, the line is completely unnecessary. But if so, then why are there stanchions in front of the restaurant that encourage people to line up?

OK, that's a little weird. But whatever. Minor logistical quibbles do not a two-star review make.

The other main thing I don't understand is how the ramen is so mediocre. I'm afraid that accusation probably comes across as harsher than intended. I'm just ... genuinely baffled. It's clear that the folks at Marufuku care about the food they make; if the menu is to be believed, the chefs put a great deal of care and thought into their craft. Indeed, the place has all the accoutrements of a super-legit ramen place. In short, I don't think they're faking their enthusiasm or commitment. But the ramen simply does not deliver on the promise of the mass of people waiting outside.

I'm not a great ramen connoisseur. Most of the ramen I've had in my life has been in San Francisco, and I've had it at five or six places here. Of those places, there are roughly three tiers of quality; Marufuku is in the third tier.

Oh, and my lunchmate claims there was mold on one of her salad tomatoes. So that's kind of icky.
author: Greg P.

description:
Ate here because of some Japanese food cravings. A hot meal after eating some bomb ice cream seemed fitting. It was the end of the day and we did end up waiting for an hour but it was worth it.

Ordered the Hakatu Tonkotsu in medium spice levels and Karaage Bowl. Both tasted pretty amazing. The food came out in minutes and the broth they used for  the ramen was rich in flavor. They didn't waste any ingredients either so one bowl is definitely enough to fill you up.  The texture of the noodles was soft and left me wanting more. The Karaage Bowl was good too, though you could easily find other Japanese spots that offer the same quality. 

The setting was really cool. It was very much reminiscent of the higher end ramen shops I did go to in Japan. 

4/5 stars for the good food and clean, atmospheric setting. Its unfortunate because had I not been to Japan and tried the real deal, I would've easily given this place a 5/5.
author: Miguel R.

description:
Good food and service and worth the 30 minute wait.  As the name implies the main entree is ramen with different flavorings. We arrived on a Friday afternoon about 1 PM and there was a fairly long line.  We put our name on the list and were seated about 30 minutes later.  It is very clean and has limited seating.  Our servers were friendly and knew their product.  We both ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu ramen (medium spiciness) (@$11.99).  This consisted of Hakata style ramen with pork broth (simmered for hours) , simmered pork belly, soft boiled egg, green onions, kikurage mushroom and bean sprouts.  It was a bit too spicy for us and next time, we'll have the mild spice.  However, it was very flavorful and more than enough for the average person. We started off and shared a small ​Marufuku salad which had Mizuna green and assorted vegetables with a nice plum flavor dressing ($5).  Additionally we ordered the Takoyaki ($6.50) which is octopus made into a ball and battered.  It was a beautiful presentation.  I probably wouldn't order this again as it had too much doughy batter and not enough octopus.

We have plans on returning with the more of our family members.
author: Robert J.

description: Got there 30 min before it opened on Saturday for lunch and we were last or 2nd to last party for the first seating. Broth is super tasty and not too salty - the boyfriend typically gets stomachaches if the broth is too rich and he didn't have it this time around at Marufuku. :)
author: Christine H.

description:
Wow! Why have I not discovered this place sooner!?!?

First off, I don't mind waiting to be seated for ramen here. They are located in a plaza so I can easily spend an hour window shopping at the cute shops before going back and waiting for my name to be called. 

The Hakata DX is to die for. It comes with fat pieces of pork belly and has a good marinated flavor and they don't skimp out on portions. I love!

The only reason that I knocked off one star was because my egg was cooked all the way through; not runny as it should have been. But still, everything was still amazballs!
author: E C.

description: Went for dinner with friends for a business dinner. The ramen and shishito peppers were excellent. Be aware of how spicy the ramen is. My friends got the hell level and despite both liking spicy food were a little over their heads.
author: Mariah O. C.

description: This place is no joke. It takes a lot to get me to say that waiting an hour to get into a ramen place is worth it, but this place is definitely worth it. Best advice? Don't come super hungry. Come on the precipice of hunger, because it's likely to take at least an hour to get a table. Get your name on the list and keep checking your progress in Yelp. Shop Japantown and get a snack at the Japanese grocery store if you have to stave your hunger off a bit. Do yourself a favor and get some of the fried chicken along with your ramen--so good with the kewpie mayo it comes with. Love this place!
author: Rosanne D.

description: Came here during a heat wave and , to no surprise, there was a line for ramen! Why do all you people want ramen on such a hot day?? Well, I'm part of this crazy group of people so I shouldn't be talking. Anyways, heard so many good things about this place and seeing that there was a line even during this insane weather, it must be a good sign. After waiting half an hour, my boyfriend and I finally got seated. I order the hakata dx with extra Porkbelly and my boyfriend ordered the chicken paitan dx. The broth was rich in pork flavor and was very creamy. It was delicious.  The noodles were not what I expected. It was like eating noodle soup at a Chinese restaurant with the long stringy white noodles. I'm no ramen expert, but I expected long chewy curly noodles that I withhold the flavors of the soup. The meat was way too fatty but at least it was tender. Nothing I would rave too much about. My boyfriends chicken paitan dx ramen was good enough to satisfy my boyfriends craving but the chicken that came on the side was way too dry and overcooked. Wouldn't recommend the chicken paitan.
author: Ada H.

description: Really amazing ramen. We both got the hakata style, I got mine spicy and it was perfect. Portions are pretty large, so I wouldn't get the DX version unless you are seriously starving. We also got the chicken karage, which was pretty good, but I would stick to the main attraction. Would love to go back and try the chicken paitan. We got here around 11:15am before they opened at 11:30am on Saturday, and there was already a line but we made it into the first seating.
author: Shabnam E.

description: The food was great! I got the Hakata style ramen and the broth was rich and flavorful. I also ordered the Takoyaki which was crispy but had nice chunks of octopus inside. The food was good and the service was fast but I'm not sure it was necessarily better than any of the other ramen joints in the neighborhood and worth a super long wait. However, glad I got to try the place at least once.
author: Veronica S.

description: We enjoyed this very much.  We waited a little while but it was worth it and the line moves quickly.  Very flavorful, and the fried chicken appetizer might have been the best Ive ever had.  The egg was cooked perfectly, the pork belly had plenty of meat and we really liked the experience.
author: Lena L.

description:
We arrived around 1:30pm with a short line ahead of us. We waited about 10 mins and were then called into our seats. We ordered and waited about 5 mins or so before we got our food. My girlfriend and I recently came back from Japan, so we have been craving quality ramen like crazy. We both ordered the Hakata Tonkotsu at $10.99 each and also got the Kakini bowl (braised pork & rice).

Service was great, they checked on us a good amount of times. First off the broth was really good and spicy like we asked for. The pork was delicious! Very soft and really flavorful. The ramen noodles were a tad thinner than most ramen places.
author: Jeffrey L.

description: My new favorite ramen spot. My bowl was meticulously created by a perfectionist in the kitchen. The noodles were al dente and the broth was full of flavor. It's nice to have a chicken option too. The line is long but you at least can walk around the mall or in the bookstore while waiting.  They'll send you a text when your table is ready.
author: Kristine E.

description: Long waiting time but it's worth the try. Excellent food with reasonable price. The broth of the ramen is fantastic! Definitely should be on the to go list
author: Lion C.

description: A great spot to eat after your spa treatment!  The foods excellent, service is consistently top drawer, and the Chicken Paitan was incredible!  Watch the time you visit however, as the lines can be a bit long during prime time!
author: Frank S.

description: Honestly, I felt this Ramen place was too overrated. I tried the Chicken DX and the broth wasn't thick and was a bit too runny. The noodles, I felt was too soft and the taste of the broth was so ordinary. The line was also so long. It's not worth the wait. I wouldn't come back here.
author: Michael C.

description: Delicious ramen best in the city.  Beats Ippudo as my favorite spot in the city by a hair.  Get the Hakata DX pork.  Spicy is pretty spicy.
author: Jay H.

description: Okay. Maybe it's just me. The broth was a bit salty and the meat not as tender. There are better options. Like the ramen place on the lower level. I base ramen houses on the broth because I always like to finish by savoring the broth. I left most of it in the average sized bowl. To be fair, the night we went, their air conditioning wasn't functioning properly so 20 minutes in I felt as though I was in a sauna. Also, maybe I had high expectations due to the lines to get in. Not sure if I will be back. Like I said, there are better options in the mall and in the city....
author: William Y.

description:
Was easily the best ramen in Japantown, though of late, the quality seems to be slipping, which sadly seems to happen once restaurants become popular in these parts. I waffled between 4 and 3 stars, but I think 4 is still fair for here.

They don't accept reservations though I believe you can put your name in the queue online. Come anytime near peak hours and expect to wait a long, long, time - it's not uncommon to have at least 30 other parties ahead of you at peak hours. Fortunately, it's right across from the bookstore, so you can browse while you wait.

We pretty much always get the standard Hakata Tonkotsu ramen, which has pork belly, soft-boiled egg, and bean sprouts. The broth is the standout here. It's very rich and satisfying.

We also frequently get the chicken kara-age bowl (fried chicken over rice) and occasionally get the takoyaki (sautéed octopus balls) when we're hungry. Over the past few months, the kara-age quality in particular has plummeted. They're probably pre-frying and leaving the stuff under a heat lamp now. It used to be much fresher.

Still the best ramen in Japantown (for now), but "best" is a relative term. And be prepared to wait before you're seated - for a good long while.
author: A P.

description:
THE BEST RAMEN IN SF!!!! 

I have been to this ramen joint for more than my one hand can count so I feel inclined to write a review on how and why this place always has me coming back for more. 

First off, the line can be daunting to look at from afar so I advise y'all to come in at least 30 minutes before opening to avoid the line (it's so worth, trust me). Or you can wait an hour like I did on a Friday night.. Worth it though! They now have an online system so make sure you put your name down and your phone number. They will contact you as soon as your table is ready which is great b/c you don't have to physically wait in line and have a chance to check out Japantown. 

I normally get the chicken karaage as a starter. Honestly, it's nothing special, but the chicken is crunchy outside and so juicy inside and goes well with the japanese mayo. 

The ramen here is amazing! I normally go for the safe route and do a tonkatsu ramen, medium spicy (which is amazing here!), but after I tried the chicken paitan, medium spicy... I swear my life took a 180. Although they only give you two pieces of chicken, the chicken is so moist and you can def taste the chicken in the broth. Plus, you came here for ramen right? Not chicken? The spice level was perfect. Not to the point where your taste buds are compromised from the spice, but to the point where you still get that slight spice kick and maybe a few sniffles here and there. The egg is located underneath all the goodness (don't trip like I once did thinking they forgot my egg) and make sure to fish it out to the surface before the yolk completely cooks. Anyways, the ramen here is thin and the broth is hearty. I swear you'll be seeing the bottom of your bowl in no time. It's a reasonable amount to fill up your stomach, but if you have a bigger appetite, don't fret, you can purchase extra noodles! 

Pros:
- food comes out super quick!
- 10/10 on the flavor and creaminess of the broth
- noodles are cooked perfectly. Not too soft and still has that crunch factor for texture lovers like me
- ambiance was cute and intimate. Lighting was dim and perfect in noise level
- parking isn't too hard to find. You might have to circle around Japantown for a bit if you want street parking, however there is a public parking lot nearby

Con:
- the line can get and will get ridiculously long if you don't show up before opening... 
- small space which contributes to the long wait. There are only about 15 or so tables. However, this is made up by their speedy customer service once you're seated!

Overall, this ramen joint truly lives up to the hype! Try it out, it will change your life like it did mine.
author: Stephanie O.

description:
Good stuff everyone!!  Having had ramen the evening before at Katanaya Ramen on Geary in Union Square this place was more manageable, less salty and just delicious.  Though I knew it was there, i squealed with excitement when I hit the egg in my dish.
Dreaming of more soon!
author: Ryan C.

description: Three of us came to the restaurant at noon a Sunday and there was already a long line of people in front of the store. At some point, I was starring at those people from the window hoping that they would sense "hungry puppy eyes" and leave early instead of chatting forever inside. After an hour or so, we finally got a table right by the window (where the outsider can look at us eating and curse at us secretly for taking our time, jk). Menu was basic ramen store with straight ramen and tonkotsu broth. We all ordered Hakata Dx, mild (some spice but not spicy at all), medium (some what spicy), and spicy (spicy with a hint of sweetness). The broth itself is very rich from the pork bone. But what set it apart from other broth is the nice blend melted pork belly fat, sesame oil, creamy potato (?), and spicy pepper. The noodles are straight and chewy. There was wood mushrooms, corn, seaweed, and soft-boiled egg in soy sauce in the Hakata Dx. They also gave us 2 big pieces of pork belly to eat with our ramen. The meat is super tender and a little sweet with a hint of soy sauce. Overall, very high quality (and quantity) for the price you paid ($15/bowl). Would come here again in the future.
author: Vivi L.

description: Ordered the Hakata DX and the chicken karaage to start off with. The quality and services definitely outweighs the wait time so be prepared with a book to occupy your time. Oddly enough, I'd say my experience brought me back to Japan when I crunched into that piece of karaage.
author: Eddy T.

description: First time visiting Marufuku Ramen and it did not let me down. The broth, as advertised, was phenomenal and tasted as if it has been simmering for days. Only problem I had was wish ore broth came in the bowl. I would highly recommend. Pork was on point as well. Highly recommend.
author: Anthony R.

description: The ramen is so delicious! I love this place here in Japan town. This is a must to go place, if you're visiting San Francisco. I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen noddles and it was fantastic. I will definitely come back to this location. Also good service!
author: Anonymous A.

description: My favorite ramen place in SF so far! The broth is so delicious and the noodles are cooked just right. I also like that it is a decent portion size, without making you feel super tired and overly full after (at least from my experience). The wait is long, almost all the time, but you can utilize Yelp to put you on a waitlist. I wouldn't recommend going on an empty stomach since it will be a long wait, but if you have time, this place is so good!
author: Linda L.

description:
Came here during weekend with family.  One of the best ramen place I have ever been to in the States. 

Ordered:
1) CHICKEN KARRAGE - Japanese style fried chicken; the chicken nuggets are juicy, tender, in a great crispy batter.

2) HAKATA TONKOTSU - Broth: rich pork broth bit on the salty side. With great combination of ingredients, such as:  simmered pork belly, soft
boiled egg, green onions, kikurage mushroom and bean sprout. Love their pork belly, the texture and flavor makes you want more. lol. Even they only put one piece of the pork belly in their ramen, in my opinion, this is still better than having only few slice of Chasu at other Ramen places.

3) MARUFUKU BITS - Homemade cha-shu and buns. This one is different from the Chinese Cha-Shu (BBQ Pork) buns.  Good tastes and good flavor but nothing much to wow about.

Favorite is still definitely the Ramen (It's THE BOMB!!! Which is their speciality anyways)!!!  

Highly recommended this place if you are into hunting down good ramen like me.  Side note: 1) beware of the size, it's only Asian size not the American size, so it depends on your appetite, you may need more bowls. lol. 2) beware of the wait, this place the wait is really really something. Don't come down this place when you are starving. 'cause of the wait, you may end up have to go to the other restaurant instead. :-p
author: S B.

description: This is another great ramen place. I would suggest getting it with sake. It's a great combo. Will definitely come again! Would highly recommend to others
author: Deborah Y.

description: The Ramen was tasty, but not worth the wait imho (waited for about 1-1:30 hours). Iza Ramen / Ippudo Ramen are comparable, with a shorter wait time
author: Minh Tri P.

description:
There is no bar to wait for the insanely long wait list. 

It's next to a ton of other places that you could eat a lot faster and maybe have more of a selection. 

Worth every second you will wait. 

Best ramen I've had in my life.
author: Jessica D.

description: I ordered donkatsu ramen and it was perfect. I have never had such a flavorful ramen soup. It was not salty as some ramen shops make which I don't like. I noticed that Marufuku's ramen soup is just properly flavored  not to overpower the ingredients such as vegetables and seafood and meat. I have tried several other ramen dishes but donkatsu has been my favorite. If you are in a mood for a warm soup, I definitely recommend Marufuku.
author: Pat K.

description: Absolutely amazing. I highly recommend this place. The ramen had a light flavor but just enough for you to drink all of the broth because of how good it was. The noodles were perfect and soft. Man the soft boiled egg was also perfectly cooked gooey and tasty.
author: Kevin L.

description:
You know there will most likely be a wait if almost every photo has patrons lining up outside the establishment. 

I came here 15 minutes before opening on a sunny Saturday afternoon and there was already a line reaching near the stairwell of the mall. Be prepared to wait with others on the waitlist sheet or come ahead of time. 

My party and I were promptly seated when one of waitresses called us out. I ordered the Chicken Paitan ramen and it was alright. The broth wasn't too bad. Nothing too special but it was good. We actually got a whole egg for our ramen while most would just give you half. Not much to write about. One of my friends got the DX version which came with the paitan ramen in addition to a plate of roasted chicken. I had to dock a star off because the chicken karrage that we ordered wasn't made well -- it was still a bit cold inside. Place is somewhat small and street/garage parking is needed.
author: Tony C.

description: Almost perfect. Noodles clumped up. Need to figure out how to cook noodle without them stuck together. Broth, chicken, egg and other ingredients tasted fabulous. The only disappointment was the noodles (-1 star).
author: Rosalie W.

description: I arrived at 5pm tuesday this week and there were a few people already waiting on line. When it opened I was about fourth to get in. I thought waiting 15 minutes before opening is enough. Good ramen. I had donkastu ramen and compared to what I had in Tokyo and Osaka, the ramen was still amazing. I also had Takoyaki but it didnt meet my expectation. But i think its good enough.
author: Yeongyoob P.

description:
Probably the best ramen in SF so far. This place has a serious WAIT. We came on a Friday night (2 of us) at 830 and they close at 930 and there was about 40 people on the waiting list! We decided to wait it out since it seems like a lot of people put their name down and just leave so it actually went faster than I expected.

We started with the chicken karaage and it was really good with huge chunks of chicken and not as much breading as other places. I got the regular ramen and it was good. The noodles are super super thin and the broth is really fatty. The egg was okay - definitely had better. The toppings were spot on and typical of ramen. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Worth the wait! Incredibly nice owner and staff, and delicious food! The Hakata Tonkatsu is delicious as is the Chicken Karaage. 

Our wait time was about 30 minutes 15 minutes before closing on a Sunday night. Generously, they keep the sign up queue open until closing time. 

The noodles are on the thin side, but the broth is truly amazing. You can tell they worked on it for 20 hours. The decor is also really nice-- I've also taken guests from out of town, and they had a great time.
author: M L.

description:
Already a line right at the time of its opening hour.  Waited for the 2nd round for about 45 mins.  Sat down and ordered the hakata tonkotsu mild spicy and it was ready in just 5 minutes.  Guess because it's hakata noodle, thinner and quicker to cook.  The shop doesn't offer choice of firmness but the portion scale up.  Noodle was good and the soup was tasty.  Happy to see hakata noodle gains popularity in Bay Area, although I still miss the inaniwa noodle from now-closed Maki that was next door before. 

Just as usual, after ramen, felt very thirsty and drank a lot of water, tea and soda. Wish it could be less salty.
author: Ile F.

description: This is hands down one of the best Ramen that we've had. No frills, but excellent and fast service along with authentic ramen makes this a must experience spot when we are visiting SanFrancisco. It's well worth the wait - don't let the long list at the door discourage you - it moves fast.
author: mica g.

description: This place always has a crazy line . I went to the Japanese market for my first time and saw multiple ramen spots and they all had lines but Marafuku had the best reviews so I waited for an hour to see what it was about. I ordered the tonktotsu with egg , seaweed cashew pork. The soup was really really good the broth was flavorful and the cashew pork was the best I've ever had. The noodles were a little thin for my taste but the ramen was over the top. In Vegas we have just as good if not better Ramen. So due to the 1hr and a half average wait time and the thinner noodles I chose to give it 4 stars.
author: Jeff N.

description: This place is legit. Creamy thick ramen broth is hard to find. The only bad thing is the wait is insane. Don't come an hour before closing. You won't get a seat. Positive thing is you can put your name in on an iPad and they'll give you a call. It's located in a Japanese mall so plenty of interesting things to check out while you wait. Probably best ramen in SF.
author: Michael B.

description: Loved the food. The environment feels a little rushed but I guess that just comes with having a lot of customers so it's completely understandable. Definitely worth coming back to over and over again.
author: Jordan Jeremy Kalel E.

description:
jesus christ this ramen is good. It's been a week since I've had it and I'm still thinking about that pork belly. We went on a tuesday night @ 7pm and waited like 45 mins. Mind you they severed our food within just a few minutes of ordering, so hella fast turnover. 

it's seems to be a different style of ramen than mensho so I'm hesitant to say which is better but I really did enjoy this ramen. The noodles are pretty thin if that matters to you. We paid the extra dough and got the braised pork belly. $15 and totally worth it. And thank god they don't put kale in their ramen

We also got the chicken karaage for like $5.50. It was really good but a little small.

Anyway despite what other reviewers say I was *really* full after this meal. Karaage, ramen, and beer. It was definitely more than enough.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I've wanted to try Marufuku Ramen in SF since it's opening a few months ago, and finally made it today! I was excited after seeing raving reviews on Yelp. It is inside the Japan center on the second floor. After 20 mins, we were seated in a charming spot in the middle for which I had to swivel like a lady. Service was quick and polite.
We ordered Mentaiko Bowl (Cod roe over rice), Hakata DK and Chicken Paitan DK. Mentaiko Bowl was excellent. Roe was spicy and went well with the rice, sesame seeds and sea weed. Hakata DK is Hakata Ramen with all the toppings. We got that one as Spicy. Chicken Paitan came with a side of big grilled chicken leg, we got this one medium. Spicy had a good flavor, but the condiments to soup ratio was too high in both ramen. I prefer my ramen with more soup than noodles and condiments in it. Overall, it was an okay ramen experience.

Mentaiko Bowl : Spicy, good texture and flavorful : Very Good (4.5/5)
Hakata DK (Spicy): Okay flavor, too much condiments to soup ratio : Okay (3/5)
Chicken Paitan PD (Medium) : Okay flavor, too much condiments to soup ratio : Okay (3/5)
author: Kritika K.

description: This is the best ramen I've ever had. There is always an hour wait but it's totally worth it.
author: Rishav R.

description: Get there early because there will be a long line! We got there when they opened at 5:30pm and there was already a 45 min wait. You can put your name down on the list and walk around. If they call your name and you aren't present they put a Star next to your reservation and when you do come back they'll seat you. It's worth it and once you're seated the service is super fast. We ordered endamame and Takoyaki which came out within 5 minutes. The Hakata Tonkotsu was delicious. If you like your ramen spicy I suggest getting ultra spicy. I will definitely be back again.
author: Meredith E.

description:
If I hadn't read all of the hype prior to dining here, I think I would've given 5 stars had my expectations not been so high. I know for these type of ramen places you have to wait a while, which is fine since it's in the West Mall of Japantown so you can shop around while you wait. We probably waited 45 minutes around 7pm to be seated. 

We both ordered the chicken paitan dx, which to our surprise they still had available even though it said they only give it out to the first 15 orders 

The chicken on the side is amazing! Well flavored and well cooked! The ramen was decent, but I have to say it wasn't my all time favorite in the city. It was good and definitely worth a try, but for whatever reason it just wasn't what I expected.
author: Megan F.

description: Best ramen I've had, the broth is amazing. I ordered the vegetarian ramen and it was a really pleasant experience. It's hard to come by good vegetarian noodles. Really recommend, Definitely coming back :)
author: Mey P.

description: The wait was an hour and a half but it was worth it. I had the tonkatsu ramen which was okay, but the braised pork inside the broth was the best meat I've ever had. It was tender, sweet, salty, and melted in your mouth. I'd come back just for the pork.
author: Belinda Y.

description:
Pleasantly surprised!

The sign up sheet looked huge but most ppl didn't show up and we got seated in 40 mins for dinner (730 ish arrival).

Tonkotsu ramen pretty solid. Broth great. Noodles great. Fairly standard decent portion for a normal ramen price. 

Kaarage on yelp looked terrible but it's better in real life. I think ppl uploaded half eaten portions cuz it's much larger (or they increased it).

Service fast - always good for ramen cuz who wants to wait 2 hrs for noodles.
author: Edward K.

description:
I came with my brother on a busy Sunday for lunch and was met with a huge line outside waiting. We decided to have the wait since it's conveniently located in the Japan Center mall and we figured we'd just walk around. We put our names down on the waiting list and went exploring. 

When we came back around 15 minutes later, we were still pretty far back on the list so we sat down on one of the benches nearby and waited for another 15 minutes before we were sat.

However, after we ordered, the food was out in a really reasonable amount of time and it was so delicious!! We ordered the chicken karrage (Japanese fried chicken) and got both hakata tonkotsu (pork ramen) and chicken paitan (chicken ramen). It was so worth the wait!! Everything was so delicious, and the price wasn't bad either. We devoured everything and were stuffed. I'm only visiting my brother but I'm sure he'll be back for more in the near future. Highly recommend!!!
author: Vivien S.

description: This place was really good! Came here with a group of people and we all agreed that the tonkotsu broth was delicious! The chashu pork was flavorful & tender and you can customize how spicy you want your ramen. Marufuku is known for their thin noodle ramen which was certainly delicious. However, I think I will stick to my thick noodles because I like the chew as my own personal preference. I would definitely come back if I was in the area for a delicious bowl of ramen and because all the servers & waitstaff were very friendly.
author: Jennie J.

description: Best ramen in sf hands down but still not as good as santa ramen IMO. Come early of the wait will be at least 90 mins. they have an ipad waitlist system that tells you when you are about to be seated. The fried squid appetizer is also worth a mention and I would recommend it. In terms of the ramen itself, the broth was tasty, rich and not watered down. The noodles were on the thin end (i prefer thick) but otherwise yummy. I would recommend to try this place at least one but dont anticipate to be seated right away.
author: Robert Y.

description: Soup is a bit too salty, Can't really taste the pork bone booth, portion is small. Many other Ramen places are better than this. Doesn't worth the 45 minutes wait.
author: Becky C.

description:
Finally, an acceptable new ramen place opened in the Bay Area. 

I've been there when the main Japanese chef was there and also when his latino guys were doing the stint for him. Both times, I left the restaurant satisfied. They know what they're doing and doing in the right ways. 

Good ramens are sold at Nijiya under 5 dollars for 2-3 servings. If I bring myself to an eatery and pay 10+ dollars for a bowl of ramen, they should be better than grocery ramen. Marufuku is one of the very few ramen places in Northern California that are worthy to pay a visit. 

Ramens, rice bowls, side dishes are very well made by culinary professionals. I'm glad this place always has people waiting in line to be served. The customers I shared the dining time were mostly non-Japanese Asians and I can't believe the same crowd used to rush into crappy noodle houses like (names omitted). 

Servers are adults with professional attitudes. No angry fat ass with attitude like the ones you meet in (censored).
author: yota L.

description: Hakata Tonkotsu - at first I was thrown off by the sweetness of the pork and the egg yolk, but I ended up LOVING this. If you've ever eaten "Thit Kho", a vietnamese dish of caramelized pork with eggs cooked with coconut soda, marafuku's pork has a similar taste. With hefty amount of tender noodles, flavorful broth and thick cuts of pork - I left very full and happy even with the 40 minute wait
author: Kim N.

description: I love Ramen so I tried visiting this place and man, the place was so full that you literally have to wait for almost an hour to get a table. It's worth it though. Everything in their short menu is delicious. They have high-quality ingredients as I've noticed. This place is surely a place to go by ramen lovers.
author: Yena H.

description:
It's a bit heavy but it's so good and so worth it. Best ramen i've had in the city. 

I'm not giving it 5 stars because the line to get in is always nuts and service isn't the best - but I clearly think it's worth it because I've been back multiple times. Come before you're too hungry, put your name on the list, walk around Japan Town, maybe check out the karaoke bar next door and have a drink, then stuff your face at Marafuku. 

I generally order the Takoyaki to start and the ultra spicy Hakata Tonkotsu.

I'm a huge fan of spicy food and they have broth for all levels of preference which I really appreciate. Delicious.
author: Sonal K.

description: Got here 20 mins before open. The line was about 30 feet long already. Tried waiting in line 30 mins anyway. The group two or 3 ahead of us were the last ones let in since it's a small place. So we would have to wait another 45 min for a table. F that. Not worth the wait when there are so many other good places to eat in/around Japantown.
author: Kevin D.

description: Very good Hataka Tonkatsu Ramen. Tonkatsu meat was tender, moist and sweet tasting. Egg inside was delicious and broth + noodles solid. Good but not mind blowing, and super long wait was an inconvenience for 4 star food.
author: Leon H.

description: Long wait for good food! I had ramen a side of pork belly. The environment is clean. Satisfied with everything
author: Vonnie G.

description: My daughter came her with a friend's family and encouraged us to give it a try. There was of course a long wait but we were happy to give it a shot. We actually waited in line to put our name down on a list and then walked around until they sent us a text notifying us out table was ready...although it wasn't actually ready. We had to wait another 10 minutes or so after we checked in when they texted us. We loved the ramen broth, very flavorful.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Waited for more than hour, we expected ramen that will blow us away.

3 stars for the soup. I love that it's not very salty even after eating it for a while

I'm not a big fan of the noodles. 

The grilled chicken is also just okay
author: Dimples P.

description: Great ramen but the sodium level is super high (noodles and soup). It will make you drink a lot of water afterwards.
author: Martin N.

description:
Top 5 Ramen spot ever. Wait. Make that a Top 3. If you brave the 25 minute (18 people head) to 45 minute (30 people ahead) wait, Marufuku will make it worth your time. Amazin, flavorful, fun ramen. Some of the best pork and broth I've EVER had. 

Got the takoyaki starter and it didn't disappoint. While it wasn't as amazing as the ramen, it was a good try. Would get again.
author: Joshua F.

description: Best damn ramen I've had. Every time I come here, their food is always consistent. I wish I could keep the broth in my freezer!
author: Angel F.

description:
Great ramen.  Noodles were thinner than I'm used to but they were perfectly cooked and delicious.  Have been meaning to try but the lines have always been too long.  Went with some co-workers for lunch on a Friday, table for 6, and only had to wait about 20 minutes.  

The geso fry and fried squid legs were great appetizers.
author: Armando A.

description: really good japanese ramen that's worth the wait! the noodles were thinner than other ramen i've had. make sure to waitlist through yelp first though because my friend and I had to wait 2.5 hrs on a friday night
author: Jenny Y.

description: Great service! The staff is awesome! :) Thin ramen noodles that complement the dish. Portion size is good.
author: Trisha C.

description:
Really tasty broth, not too salty. The best cha shu I've had in ages too! Love a good ramen spot and this can be added to the list for sure. I went at 5:30 and there was already a 1 hour wait for a table, so I got takeout which came to me in less than 5 mins and ate outside!

Everything is very fresh and tasty! Am going again today
author: Jen S.

description: Let me start by stating that the wait is generally very long. Out of the many times I've been, the shortest I've waited is probably 40 minutes. That's being said, I believe this is the best thick broth ramen available in Japantown, and one of the best ramen places in San Francisco (I've been to a lot). Service is fast once you get seated, and the ramen is excellent. The bowl may seems small, but rest assured it's decently portioned. Despite the long wait every time, I have never regretted coming here.
author: Michael Y.

description:
I'm a lover of food whether it is authentic, fusion, or some other variation, but what I'm not a fan of is restaurants passing something off as genuine or authentic when it really isn't. 

Marafuku claims they hand make everything. Their noodles taste like the same store bought noodles my mother in law uses when making her Thai dishes. Their broth is delicious at first, but the braised pork belly's sweetness just leeches too much into the soup halfway into it. To note, the braised pork belly marinade tastes like they used some Thai spices such as star of anise, Thai sweet soy sauce, and a good amount of brown sugar. 

It's ok. $13-14 for a bowl of average ramen, is not something I'd pay for again. 

Btw a good amount of the employees are Thai, which one could say that there is some Thai influence.
author: Denise N.

description: Oh this place is sooooooo good. Absolutely love the thick bone broth. Just thinking of it make my mouth watering.
author: Jane L.

description:
Worth the wait. Get there at 4:30pm if you don't want to wait for dinner ;)
I love how they have different portion sizes and rice options. Not much for vegetarians, but then again it is ramen.
author: Kathy Z.

description: I've been here at least ten times. I want to live in the bowl. It's the bowl of ramen that keeps on giving.
author: David L.

description:
The restaurant was average with a decent price. This place is definitely hyped. 

The rating is more towards the service  portion as it was really bad. We waited a while in line before they opened at 11:30am... At this point we were all super excited to try this place  as we were standing in a line with about 40 people before opening.  If the line had this many peoplle before opening I really thought it was gong to be really great! Upon opening and ince they seated us, this was when we were disappointed as we waited a while for our waitress to take our order. It was shocking that our waitress couldn't get our order of water with ice correctly.  This is as if they were very stingy with ice... as we asked for ice multiple times and was not given ice until the third time. After waiting for our ice she finally came back with one tiny cup of ice for five of us to share. Then she took our orders and that was the last time we saw our waitress as she never came back to refill our water or give us our check. We had to ask another waitress to give us our check and another person brought our food. In terms of service, we were very disappointed. 

In terms of the food, I've had better Japanese food, especially Ramen,  but this place was decent. A little on the plain side but decent. The food didn't impress me but the decor and bowls did.  I will probably not be returning for a second time.
author: Leahla X.

description: Went last week with some friends and I got the tonkotsu ramen. The flavor was amazing and had so much depth to it. I also loved the noodles. I like ramen noodles that are more firm and thin and these were cooked perfectly. The soft-boiled egg in the ramen was also amazing as well. Perfectly seasoned and each bowl gets a full egg instead of half an egg like some places. I also saw other tables get the chicken karaage and it smelled amazing. I love me some Fried Chicken. I definitely have to go back and try some!
author: Isabel C.

description: Fabulous, delicious and wonderful!  I only wish they still served their curry at lunch time, it was a real treat!
author: T H.

description: The Hakata Tonkatsu is so, so good. Wait time can be long (especially on weekends), but well worth it.
author: Charlie B.

description:
I'm not a ramen eater. I think it's overhyped, and never really hits the spot. I don't like waiting for food, and especially not food that doesn't enthuse me.

We went for a walk around Japantown while we waited, which made the wait a bit less annoying.
